http://extension.colostate.edu/topic-areas/yard-garden/winter-drying-is-a-likely-cause-of-brown-pine...
Hi,
Above is some information on winter  damage. Austrians are very susceptible to needle browning in the winter. Dry winters and lots of wind are the problem. I can see from the picture the lower 2/3s of the tree is not really effected probably because of the fence protection. Sometimes planting  can damage to the small hair roots that bring water up to the needles. If the tree produced enough roots though the winter it will push new needles but it will take awhile. Make sure roots aren't to wet and it would be good the spray the needles with a hose.

title: Is this an ant?  What kind? #715219
question:
This is a very tiny ant.  I see a tiny pile of fine wood shavings at the spot where I see them crawling out of the woodwork on an outdoor threshold.  

Thank you.  For scale,  it is in the bottom of a single serve applesauce container.

1.response:
Hi - This looks like it might be a pavement ant, one of the common types of ants that enters homes. Ants are foragers and wander into houses from time to time in search of food or if outdoor conditions are too wet or too dry. We recommend using baits to manage them, if you find that their activity continues. Please refer to our website for more information about ants and how to use baits. https://extension.umd.edu/hgic/topics/ants

Christa
1.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

title: snap beans with brown leaves #798890
question: What is making these leaves turn brown?

answer.response:
Thanks for the question.

My reflexive response is that your beans are experiencing sun scald. Keep in mind that at this time of the year (June 2022), the intensity of the sun is at its maximum. For my own beans, this is the time of the year I cover them with a fabric row cover for protection. Having said that, there is not much you can do at this time regarding these brown leaves. Most likely they will not recover. Attempting to reseed things now would be an exercise in futility. Just keep them well watered – like daily – and do not apply any fertilizer. That would only stress them further. It is not clear to me if flowers have already emerged and some beans established on your beans. Maybe not? In any event your plants, provided you water them sufficiently, will survive although perhaps with a diminished yield. For your 2023 beans consider some type of row cover for them.

Good Luck
answer.author: Steve Hedman

management instructions: Keep the plants well watered.
Do not apply any fertilizer.
Consider using a row cover for protection in the future.

title: What to do about this Aspen tree? #308029
question:
We have an aspen tree in our front yard in Colorado, the only tree we own. We have a love/hate relationship with it. It is gorgeous when the leaves bud out in the spring and it provides privacy. However, late in the summer/early fall the leaves have been turning black and falling off. This springs, there is a strange redness on the branches that comes off on your hands when you touch it. 
Does this tree have a fungus/disease? 
Is it worth trying to save?
Should we consider removing it? What is the best way to remove an aspen tree and the complicated root system?

1.response:
Thank you for your question.

What is your elevation?

Here is a link from Colorado State University that has a lot of information regarding Aspen tree problems http://csfs.colostate.edu/forest-management/common-forest-insects-diseases/common-insects-diseases-o...
This link suggests alternatives to Aspens in the a yard http://www.colostate.edu/Dept/CoopExt/4dmg/Trees/aspens2.htm

My colleagues and I are still reviewing the  red substance on the bark.
1.author: Kerry Peetz

2.response:
Thank you for your patience.

Here is a note that my colleague added.  Note: Hi Kerry, that red on the bark is a mass of brown mite eggs. Page 79 of Insects and Diseases of Woody Plants in CO. Sometimes the brown mite eggs cover substantial portions of the aspen bark, making it reddish-brown.

Can you please tell me what your elevation is?
2.author: Kerry Peetz

3.response: Thank you, Kerry. We have a tree person coming to look at it, and spray it? Will this help? Our elevation is 6739 feet. I appreciate your help.
3.author: The Question Asker

4.response:
Your elevation is acceptable for aspens.

I noticed rock used as ground cover next to the house. Does the rock extend all the way to the tree? If so, this could also be contributing to the stress of your tree. As you have already read in the information we previously sent, aspens are best when grown in the forest. The fertile forest ground is made up of decomposed leaves, branches, etc.  and this is ideal. Rocks compact the soil and produce additional heat. 

If the tree person has a good reputation and knowledge of aspens the spray may help. 

Best of luck with your tree.
4.author: Kerry Peetz

management instructions: spraying may help if done by a knowledgeable professional
avoid using rock as ground cover to reduce stress on the tree
qa_information.background info: The tree is located in Colorado at an elevation of 6739 feet. It is the only tree in the yard and provides privacy. The yard has rock used as ground cover next to the house.

title: How do I get rid of invasive orchid ferns? #771861
question:
Dear Garden Expert,

About 15 years ago I had my yard professional landscaped. A landscape architect recommended that orchid ferns be planted in four-foot-wide bed of pachysandra next to my house. The orchid ferns have multiplied by the dozens. During the spring/summer, they completely cover the pachysandra and then get burned by the summer sun. I have tried ripping them out (including pulling the wiry black runners), but with little success. Any advise on how to remove these without destroying the pachysandra as well?

Thanks,

1.response:
We are happy to hear from you and would like to help. Could you please send us photos of the area (which can be attached directly to this reply "choose file" tabs)? 

We are not sure what "orchid fern" you are referring to, so a couple of close ups of that will help. 

What kind of sun does the area get?

Christine
1.author: Christine McComas

2.response:
Dear UMd Expert,

Sorry for my delay in responding to your request. I misstated the name of the fern. It is called an ostrich fern and is depicted in the attached photo. Although they were recommended by
a landscape architect and have a pretty, arching habit, they are quite invasive and have overtaken two beds planted with pachysandra. They seem virtually impossible to eradicate by uprooting,
and their rhizomes are tough and difficult to pull from the soil. In addition, it is difficult not to uproot pachysandra (which I'd like to keep) at the same time.

I'd appreciate any suggestions you might have.

Thanks,

Sara Lowen


-----Original Message-----
From: Ask Extension <askextension@eduworks.com>
To: sarovich <sarovich@aol.com>
Sent: Thu, Sep 16, 2021 10:24 am
Subject: Re: How do I get rid of invasive orchid ferns? (#0041792)
2.author: The Question Asker

3.response:
Hello; Thanks for submitting your garden and landscape questions to University of Maryland Ask Extension.

Ostrich ferns indeed spread by underground runners that can easily spread throughout a shady flower or pachysandra bed, and ostrich ferns are tough plants and getting rid of them may take more than a season or two. 

You can opt to apply a glyphosate chemical spray to kill the foliage of the fern but the spray can also kill the foliage of your pachysandra unless you are careful in covering pachysandra foliage before spraying. Several applications of glyphosate are likely needed before ostrich ferns are completely eradicated. 

Pouring boiling water directly onto the ostrich fern plant will certainly kill the ostrich fern with repeated applications over time, but it will likely injure roots of pachysandra. 

You might want to try a combination of root pulling, chemical or boiling water application to get rid of ostrich ferns, and accept that some of your pachysandra plants will likely be lost in the process and need replacement. What a battle!

Good luck in your efforts. Christopher
3.author: Christopher Lewis

management instructions: Apply a glyphosate chemical spray to kill the foliage of the fern, but cover pachysandra foliage before spraying.
Several applications of glyphosate are likely needed before ostrich ferns are completely eradicated.
Pouring boiling water directly onto the ostrich fern plant will kill the ostrich fern with repeated applications over time.
Try a combination of root pulling, chemical or boiling water application to get rid of ostrich ferns.
qa_information.background info: The ostrich ferns were planted in a four-foot-wide bed of pachysandra next to the house about 15 years ago. They have multiplied by the dozens, completely covering the pachysandra in the spring/summer and then getting burned by the summer sun. Attempts to rip them out, including pulling the wiry black runners, have been unsuccessful.

title: Aloe plant turning colors #565684
question: I have a 2 year old aloe plant that half of it is turning brown. Last year it lived outside in the same basket and location it is currently (couple hours of direct light, but mostly under the porch). Over winter I brought the whole basket into my office since it got a lot of indirect light. This spring i brought it back outside. I dodn't remember when it started turning brown. Leaves still feel rather firm. Please help!

answer.response:
The leaves on the aloe look like they are rotting. Aloes do not like to be overwatered. Also if the container is too large, it can hold a lot of moisture that can lead to root rot.  This plant thrives in poor soil and does not require a lot of water.
Even if you removed all of the affected leaves you will not have much of the plant left.  We recommend that you replace the plant.

Look at the attached link for planting and proper care http://gardeningsolutions.ifas.ufl.edu/plants/ornamentals/aloe-vera.html

Marian

title: We can't identify this bug! #447042
question:
It seems to have a body made of plates looking like hemlock needles, has 4 legs (my son says) and I cannot identify this using the power of the internet!
Found on Whidbey Island in a bog, in a tube bored into a log. Did the insect bore the hole? We are not sure.

1.response:
Dear Client,

Your insect is known as a caddisfly larva. Caddisfly are in the insect order Trichoptera. Based on the construction of its tubular portable case (made up of plant fragments and silk), this larvae probably belongs in the family Limnephilidae. It is hard to identify as most of the body is hidden from view and those cases can be so variable in appearance. These larvae feed on algae, plant detritus that they filter from the water.  They will not bore into log, but are well camouflaged to hide on cracks and crevices of logs and other woody material found in the river/stream.   

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limnephilidae

Hope this helps!
1.author: Michael Bush

title: Black Dots on Pine Needles #817006
question:
We cut our Christmas tree this weekend and have noticed most of the branches have black dots in lines in the needles. What are these? Should we continue to keep the tree inside or should we remove it? Are there ways to rid the tree of these black dots other than wiping each needle?

Thank you

answer.response:
This appears to be an insect (either eggs or older life stages) but we would need to see the objects a bit more clearly to be sure, and once we identify them we can then advise how to remove them, if necessary. Can you please take one or two more close-up pictures with better lighting? (Perhaps using a camera flash, or maybe the ambient light during the daytime is enough.) If the camera has trouble focusing on the objects because of their size or due to background objects, you can try to either hold a piece of white paper behind them or a ruler next to them (the fine markings on the ruler should help the camera focus at the right distance).

Miri
answer.author: Mira Talabac

answer.response:
Hi, thanks for your response. Attached are several photos I took. I hope these are the better quality you need. Please let me know if you need me to try again. 
On Tuesday, November 29, 2022, 09:40:27 AM EST, Ask Extension <askextension@eduworks.com> wrote:
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Thank you for the photos. Their size, shape, color, and arrangement suggests they are the eggs of the White Pine Aphid. Normally aphids give birth to live young, but they can lay eggs (especially for overwintering), plus this type of aphid is so large that their eggs will also be pretty big by aphid standards. We can't predict if they'll stay warm enough for long enough to hatch indoors, but you can pluck them off if you prefer. They won't cause any plant damage and will merely be a nuisance to remove with a vacuum if they do hatch before the tree is removed after the holiday.

Miri
answer.author: Mira Talabac

answer.response:
Hi, thank you very much for the information. They are a pain to get off the needle, so we will take our chances they do not hatch before we take the tree down after Christmas.
Appreciate your work.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a close-up of pine needles, which appear to be fresh and healthy, indicating that the tree was recently cut and is being used as a Christmas tree indoors. However, the focus on the needles suggests attention should be given to the overall condition of the tree.

For a Christmas tree that has been cut and brought indoors, here are some general recommendations to manage and maintain its freshness:

1. **Watering**: Ensure the tree is kept hydrated by regularly watering it with a bucket of water placed at the base of the tree. The water should be changed daily to prevent it from becoming stagnant and potentially harboring bacteria or mold.

2. **Pruning**: If there are any dead or dry needles, they should be pruned off to maintain the tree's health and appearance. This will also help keep the tree from shedding needles indoors.

3. **Humidity**: Place the tree in a humid environment if possible, such as near a radiator or in a room with a humidifier. This can help prevent the needles from drying out too quickly.

4. **Placement**: Avoid placing the tree near heat sources like fireplaces or radiators, as these can cause the needles to dry out faster. It’s also important to keep it away from direct sunlight, which can damage the needles.

5. **Cleaning**: Dust the tree gently with a soft cloth or use a vacuum cleaner with a brush attachment to remove any dust or debris that might have accumulated during transportation or storage.

6. **Lighting**: If the tree is decorated with lights, ensure that the lights are not overexposed to the needles, as this can cause them to dry out or become damaged.

7. **Regular Inspection**: Regularly check the tree for any signs of pests or disease. If you notice any issues, consult a professional horticulturist or arborist for advice.

By following these steps, you can help ensure that your Christmas tree remains fresh and vibrant throughout the holiday season.

remove with a vacuum if they hatch: Regularly check the tree for any signs of pests or disease. If you notice any issues, consult a professional horticulturist or arborist for advice.

title: Perforated Viburnums #455512
question: I planted three Blue Muffin Arrowood Viburnums last year. All three survived the winter and were leafing from top to bottom. But now the leaves are all perforated. It seems that the leaf material is largely gone, leaving only the leaf veins. I hope that you can please tell me what is doing this and what I can do about it? Will this leaf material grow back? Will the shrubs grow new leaves? Are these shrubs doomed? Please advise. Thank you for your help!

answer.response:
Hello,

You have Viburnum leaf beetle larvae eating your leaves. They are the little caterpillars you see under the leaves. All the black dots are the frass left behind by these insects. 

There are beneficial insects that help control them, but your shrubs need something quicker than that. You can hand pick them off each day and dispose of them in a bucket of soapy water to kill them. Or, if you will use chemical sprays, here are recommendations—

“Pesticide options. When necessary, a number of pesticides are effective in controlling viburnum leaf beetles. Products containing carbaryl (Sevin) as the active ingredient or one of the pyrethroid insecticides (cyfluthrin, permethrin, resmethrin) are highly effective as foliar sprays. Honey bees and other pollinators can be protected by waiting until the petals fall before spraying, or by removing the flowers before spraying. Soil-applied systemic products that contain imidacloprid are also effective, but should also be applied after the flowers are gone to protect bees.

Also, we have a research project underway to see if a basal soil drench of imidacloprid applied after the flowers are gone will harm bees in the following year. Only spray infested viburnum plants and try to avoid drift onto other plants to preserve beneficial insects in the yard and garden.”

This is from MSU Extension and here is a link to the complete article with more details and pictures-

http://msue.anr.msu.edu/news/keep_your_eyes_open_for_the_viburnum_leaf_beetles

Thanks for using our service
answer.author: Laura Sheffer

answer.response:
Your other questions- no the damaged leaves wont grow back, but the shrub will push out new leaves. Keep it watered during very dry times this summer and fall to help it develop a new set of leaves.
The shrubs aren’t doomed but you will have to deal with this beetle every year. Or replace them with a viburnum that is known to be resistant( see the complete article in the link above) - Thanks again.
answer.author: Laura Sheffer

black dots (frass) left behind by the insects

use chemical sprays such as carbaryl or pyrethroid insecticides
keep the shrub watered during dry times to help it develop a new set of leaves

title: Africanized Killer Bee in Maryland #761267
question: I found a dead killer bee in my basement. I'm very concerned if there is a hive near by. I am severely afraid to bee bites. Would you come to my home to survey for and locate the hive please? What steps are required to assist me? These killer bees should not be in Maryland but they are and not being identified. I plan to call the news media as well but wanted to hear from you first. This is serious and the public needs to be aware of these bees in our state.

1.response:
The true "killer bees" are Africanized honeybees, and they look very similar to "regular" honeybees in size, shape, fuzziness, and body coloration. They are not found in Maryland and, so far at least, are only established in parts of the very southernmost U.S. The insect in the photo is a commonly-encountered local wasp called a European Hornet. While they are indeed not native to North America, they have been here for a long time - around two hundred years. Like other wasps, their prey is other insects. Here are some additional images for comparison: https://www.marylandbiodiversity.com/view/6472

Adult hornets can accidentally wander inside since they fly day and night; at night, they can be drawn to outdoor lighting (as with many night-flying insects), become disoriented, and settle-down nearby, which usually involves a window or doorway. When the door is opened or if a gap in the wall or window frame is available as they explore, they can easily wind-up indoors, even though they are not deliberately trying to invade the home. It is rare, but not unheard of, for them to build a nest inside a building (an exterior wall or attic would be most likely). If you have found only one or two, then it's likely an accident. If you regularly find more, consider contacting a pest control professional who has experience in wasp removal to find and destroy the nest safely.

Try turning off outdoor lights at night, or make sure there aren't gaps, holes, or cracks in wall exteriors that could be allowing them inside. Similarly, make sure window insect screens are intact and not torn, where an exploring wasp can get through.

Despite their alarming size, they tend to only sting to defend themselves (if attacked) or their nest. Here's more information: https://extension.umd.edu/resource/european-hornets

 

Miri
1.author: Mira Talabac

image description: similar to honeybees in size, shape, fuzziness, and body coloration
management instructions: turn off outdoor lights at night
seal gaps, holes, or cracks in wall exteriors
ensure window insect screens are intact
contact a pest control professional if necessary

title: Cedar Trees Browning #852633
question: I have several mature cedar trees in my yard that I noticed are browning on many of the branches. It doesn't look like it is just the ends of some branches, but many branches are dead. Is there anything I can do about this?

answer.response:
When you said your cedars were turning brown, I was all set to tell you it was probably a root rot which gets a lot of them. After looking at your photos, though, I'm very happy to say that the browning looks pretty much like normal seasonal needle drop (called flagging). It appears to be the older, interior fronds that are dying. All evergreens have to drop older leaves/needles at some point, it's just a question of how many years they keep them before dropping them.
Now there may still be some problem with the trees. It does look like quite a lot of the interior is turning brown. There could have been drought stress causing them to lose more needles than normal, or some other stress. I suggest keeping an eye on them and see how they do next spring and through next season. You might consider supplemental irrigation next summer. If they get thinner each year they are not well, but if they put on plenty of healthy new growth and just lose the oldest, they are fine.
https://pnwhandbooks.org/plantdisease/host-disease/cedar-cedrus-spp-cedar-flagging
answer.author: Signe Danler

symptom description: browning on many of the branches
management instructions: Keep an eye on the trees and see how they do next spring and through next season.
Consider supplemental irrigation next summer.

title: Euonymus issues #791783
question: I have a lot of Euonymus at my house. I suspect I may have Euonymus scale. can you confirm that from the pictures? How go I treat this?

answer.response:
Euonymus scale is a good guess, but this looks like Cottony Camellia Scale, which can get on Euonymus.
Cottony Camellia Scale is a soft scale, and soft scales suck plant juices and then excrete a sticky substance called 'honeydew', which the black film called Sooty Mold grows on.
(Euonymus scale look different and are an armored scale, which don't make honeydew.)

You can see photos of each and learn about control options on this page: 
https://extension.umd.edu/resource/introduction-scale-insects

Heavy or prolonged infestations can cause leaf yellowing and a decrease of the plant’s vigor, but dieback is not common.
Euonymus can take a pretty hard pruning in early spring and respond with fresh, new green leaves.

If you are not in love with them, there are other plants that are better for the environment and less likely to have this issue.


Christine
answer.author: Christine McComas

answer.response:
Thanks for the quick response. I am not at all attached to the euonymus. I inherited them when I bought the house 17 months ago. What would recommend I replace them with? The area is quite shaded, mostly by a large tree. 

John
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Fortunately you have a range of options. It's difficult to make specific recommendations without more information (space available, desired mature size, whether deer browsing is an issue, desirable features like flowering or evergreen, etc.), but given the shady exposure, here is a starter list of ideas:
  • Leucothoe (Leucothoe fontanesiana, Leucothoe axillaris) - native near our region, though not in Maryland specifically; evergreen; deer-resistant
  • American Holly (Ilex opaca), specifically variety 'Maryland Dwarf' because no other variety is small enough - easy to trim but shouldn't need it often due to slow growth rate and compact size; evergreen; deer-resistant; although it could produce a few decorative berries, this variety doesn't fruit heavily
  • other Hollies (Ilex, multiple species and hybrids) - although they only other shrubby evergreen holly is more sun-loving (Inkberry), several options exist among the Chinese, Japanese, Blue, and other hybrid varieties; if dry soil is a concern, Chinese hollies have the best tolerance within this group; all are evergreen; deer only tend to avoid the very prickly varieties; not all varieties will produce berries
  • Illicium (Illicium, several species and hybrids) - look for those rated cold-hardy to zone 6 ideally, but those hardy to zone 7 should suffice if this site is sheltered from winter winds; evergreen; deer-resistant; some species are native, though not in MD
  • False Holly (Osmanthus heterophyllus) - prickly holly look-alike with fragrant autumn flowers; evergreen; deer-resistant
  • Yew (Taxus) or Japanese Plum Yew (Cephalotaxus) - one of the only needled evergreens to tolerate shade; the former deer will eat, but the latter they dislike; several cultivars exist for each with different growth habits and mature sizes, though Yew is pretty easy to trim if needed
  • Summersweet (Clethra alnifolia) - blooms best with more sun, but should tolerate shade if not too dark; fragrant summer blooms; deciduous; somewhat deer-resistant; dwarf varieties exist if the wild type is too tall
  • Spicebush (Lindera benzoin) - fragrant foliage when bruised; deciduous; native; better for large spaces as it can't be kept too small via pruning
  • Fothergilla (Fothergilla major, Fothergilla gardenii, and their hybrids) - native to the southeast but hardy here; deciduous; blooms best with partial sun but tolerant of shade; somewhat deer-resistant; not easily trimmed but compact varieties exist
  • Carolina Allspice (Calycanthus floridus) - native to the southeast but hardy here; as the above, blooms best with a bit of sun but tolerates shade; very fragrant flowers; somewhat deer-resistant; not easily trimmed for size, so best where it will fit with minimal pruning
We suggest that, if space allows, you mix species so the planting isn't as vulnerable to a single ailment affecting the entire garden bed equally severely. Diverse plantings (especially using flowering shrubs or perennials) also tend to provide habitat for a wider array of beneficial insects, which help to suppress pests before they reach outbreak level.

Miri
answer.author: Mira Talabac

management instructions: prune Euonymus in early spring
replace with alternative plants

title: New, terrible weed #763758
question: This weed is trying its best to take over our fields and barnyards. I have submitted descriptions of my search engines to no avail. I want to learn the most effective and efficient methods of control. It grows to about 2 feet tall with tough, wiry stems with many seed pods. In its green stage, it has tiny clusters if tiny four-petaled flowers. Help!

1.response:
Hi Josie!  I'm sorry to hear you are battling this weed.

THANK YOU for the photograph!  It's hard to classify the leaf structure and flowers from this image, but my best guess is that you are dealing with Wild Mustard.  (Sinapis arvensis L. -- also known as charlock or field mustard)

Take a look at these fact sheets to see if you think Wild Mustard is the correct weed identification:

Michigan State Wild Mustard id:  https://www.canr.msu.edu/resources/wild-mustard-sinapis-arvensis

Michigan State Wild Mustard Control:   https://www.canr.msu.edu/weeds/extension/wild-mustard

Cornell Wild Mustard ID & Control:  https://blogs.cornell.edu/weedid/wild-mustard/

If you can make a positive id here:  then the key to controlling wild mustard is stopping it from going to seed.  So pulling, cutting down & tillage -- before the plants go to seed -- will all help to kill off this weed. (It will take several life cycles/seasons...)

As you can read in the fact sheets at the links above:  there is a biological control: ground beetles can be employed to eat the wild mustard seeds that lie on the surface of your soil.  I would need to do more research to help you figure out how to pursue this option.  

You can also read that some people resort to chemical control.  

For home gardeners:  I would recommend pulling/cutting/tilling wild mustard before it goes to seed.  But I can't tell from your note how large an area you are dealing with here.  You mention your fields and barnyards....if you have a farm or commercial enterprise, we have a separate UVM Extension support resource to help you.  Our Extension Master Gardener Helpline supports home gardeners who typically have small enough gardens to employ hand-pulling.

Would you like to be redirected to our commercial/farm support team?  

If I haven't guessed the weed's identity correctly and you can determine that the weed you are battling isn't Wild Mustard:  please do write back and include further photos.  It would help to have close-up photos of the leaves (both at the base of a plant and up at the top -- I can't tell from this one photo if the leaves are opposite or alternate;  and, if possible, a picture clearly showing the flower(s).  

I hope this helps and that we might have the weed identified for you (a big first step in winning the war!).  

-- Robilee Smith

Right side up. Each stem has several seed pods. 
It most closely resembles the configuration of a dandelion.

6.response:
THANK YOU for the additional photos and insights, Josie!

Alas: I do not recognize this weed -- beyond seeing that it seems to be in -- or a relative of-- the mustard family (there are a lot of variations here).  There are some other weeds that are similar:  rape, turnip, radish...but I can't make a definitive diagnosis.

I searched several resources and thought you might want to look at Go Botany! (a New England wildflower resource) at this link:  https://gobotany.nativeplanttrust.org/full/non-monocots/alternate-remaining-non-monocots/#_filters=family,genus,habitat_general,habitat,state_distribution,leaf_type_general_rn,petal_color_rn,leaf_arrangement_general_rn,leaf_blade_margin_general_rn,flower_symmetry_rn,perianth_number_rn,perianth_fusion_rn,stamen_number_rn,fruit_type_general_rn,fruit_length_rn&state_distribution=Vermont&petal_color_rn=yellow&perianth_number_rn=four&_view=photos&_show=flowers

(I've narrowed the search, above, down to VT wildflowers with alternate leaves and four-petalled yellow flowers...)

From all of the good clues you've provided: it looks like a key to stopping the spread is to avoid seeding.  So the good work you are putting into pulling these weeds is time well spent;  and if you reach a point where you simply can't pull them all:  cutting them back before flowering will help.

In pre-pandemic times I would have suggested submitting samples to our plant diagnostic lab. Since it's still closed, I am going to ask the head of the lab for help here.  Professor Ann Hazelrigg is a plant pathologist, but if she doesn't recognize this weed, I believe she can pass along the query for us.

THANK YOU for YOUR speedy response and extra photographs!  Stay tuned:  I hope Professor Hazelrigg can help us here.

- Robilee
6.author: Robilee Smith

7.response:
I've heard back from the director of our program, Dr. Ann Hazelrigg....and she consulted Michael Sundue (another UVM professor).  

They both believe that you are battling a mustard weed -- but there are many versions and without having our diagnostic lab open, we can't be sure which variety you are wrestling with here.

But the solution is the same:  for mustard weeds:  you are fortunate that they don't spread by rhizomes/runners:  you are just trying to stop the spread via seeds.  They can have deep tap roots (the larger the plant, the deeper this tap root can be...).  So to control this weed:  you want to do everything you can to stop it from spreading via seeds.  That means:  pull or -- at least -- cut the weeds down before they go to seed.  Do your best to pull up/till/cut down young plants before they can go to seed.  If the tap root is deep:  it may come back next year....but if you deny the plant the ability to grow & seed, it will eventually die out.

I hope this helps you get this weed under control,

-- Robilee

It does sound like you have a challenge;  but I am glad you aren't fighting invasives like Wild Parsnip (I've had to be put on steroids three times while eradicating this noxious weed) or knotweed (spreads via rhizomes as well as seeds....every effort to dig it out seems to encourage more growth from any bit left in the ground).   Not that this will give you any comfort in your fight against the wild mustard variety you face.....but I am hopeful that you can get this weed under reasonable control by focusing on stopping it from going to seed.

You are still young! And gardening keeps you so!

Way to go, Josie!  I am envisioning you with a grain sack full of pulled wild mustard plants!  :-)

Yes: I've managed to succeed in my war with Wild Parsnip (though the weed put up a good fight!) -- it, too, has a taproot that can be problematic. I learned, though, to spot the plant when it emerged in the spring (one of the first plants to do so) and then cut the tap root with my shovel. If you can't pull out large wild mustard plants entirely, you could try cutting their tap roots in an effort to keep that particular plant from coming back.  I hope the person mowing down your Wild Parsnip is "shielded up" (long sleeves, pants, gloves....even eye goggles make sense here).  It's the sap that's phototrophic (causes all the blistering when exposed to sunlight).  My husband does most of the mowing here and I'm afraid he had to learn the hard way to "suit up" before mowing the edge of our lawn that used to host the Wild Parsnip. (Ouch!)  Now we both have immense respect for this plant's ability to defend itself...!

Best of luck in your battle!

- Robilee

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a plant that appears to be wild mustard (Sinapis arvensis), which is a common weed known for its ability to rapidly spread in agricultural areas, fields, and barnyards. Based on the provided background information and the characteristics of the plant in the image, here is a recommended management strategy:

1. **Regular Manual Removal**: Since the affected area is not too large, continued manual removal remains an effective method. The fact that the roots are tough and wiry indicates that it's important to pull the plants completely, including the roots, to prevent regrowth.

2. **Early Detection and Removal**: The mention that the weed has been pulled every morning suggests a proactive approach. This practice should continue, as early detection and removal help prevent the plant from setting seed and spreading.

3. **Cultural Practices**: Implementing cultural practices such as maintaining healthy and competitive crop cover can help reduce the establishment of weeds like wild mustard. This includes regular crop rotation, maintaining soil fertility, and ensuring adequate moisture levels.

4. **Mulching**: Applying mulch around crops can help suppress weed growth. This practice is especially effective when combined with careful cultivation practices to minimize weed seed dispersal.

5. **Chemical Control**: If manual removal becomes impractical or if the infestation grows larger, chemical herbicides may be considered. However, care must be taken to choose products that are effective against wild mustard and safe for the environment and other crops. Always follow the label instructions for application rates and timing.

6. **Biological Control**: Investigate whether there are any biological control options available for wild mustard, such as specific insects or fungi that target the plant without harming other organisms.

By combining these strategies, you can effectively manage wild mustard in your field or barnyard. Regular monitoring and timely intervention will be key to maintaining control over this persistent weed.

title: Unidentified pest is eating my rose #202895
question: A caterpillar that looks like a dinosaur is eating the leaves of my Belindas Dream. The caterpillar is about one inch long. It has a small brown head, a green neck, a brown body with a two-forked tail. I tried cutting off the stems that I saw it on, but now it's on others. title: Nana berry question #806921
question: Planted in spring watered regularly with lawn sprinkler. Losing leaves and dying. Is it a disease or water issue?

answer.response:
Hello Patrick- Thanks for your picture of the problem with your Nana Berry. This looks like classic leaf scorch to me. The water is not reaching the edges of the leaves and they are dying. Whether this is from our heat waves or the lawn competing with the roots of the grass for water or both, the top newest leaves look OK so I would wait and see what happens next spring.

Don't take off any of the leaves that still have green on them, as they are still sending sugars to the roots even with the outside brown. And it might help to clear some of the lawn away from the tree so the water can get directly to the roots.

Good luck and cross your fingers the tree will be fine once it gets a chance to get established.
answer.author: Rhonda Frick-Wright

management instructions: Wait and see what happens next spring.
Do not take off any of the leaves that still have green on them.
Clear some of the lawn away from the tree so the water can get directly to the roots.

title: Apple tree leaf curling after hail storm.  #466691
question:
We moved into a home about 6 months ago that have 2 beautiful large apple trees. The previous owner said that one was a red delicious and the other a golden delicious tree. 

I have no prior experience with fruit trees, but they were doing great until a week ago when we got a bad hail storm with golf ball sized hail. There were a lot of leaves and small apples on the ground. Two days ago we noticed that the leaves on the tree are starting to curl. 

Wanting to know if this is due to the hail damage or some type of bug/fungus that the tree needs to be sprayed for. 

Any advice is most appreciated!
Thank you,
Kari

answer.response:
Thank you for contacting us about your apple trees. This type of hail causes damage of all kinds to fruit trees, especially apples and crabapples.

If the leaf curling is all over the tree, or at least limited to the side the hail hit hardest, then the leaf curling is a typical response to injury, along with the prolonged heat. From what I can see in the pictures, in general your tree is in fair shape; much of the canopy remains (so photosynthesis still occurs) and you will still have some apples (though a bit scarred).

If the leaf curling is just on the tips of branches, and the tips wilt and die back, suspect fireblight. If you don’t see it this year, watch for it next spring.

·        Clean up leaf and apple debris. This can be composted.

·        Watch for fireblight. This highly contagious disease can enter the plant through open wounds. Your delicious trees are resistant to this disease, but this has been a bad year for fireblight. These leaves cannot be composted, and the apples will not be edible. Links below with more info.

·        Your tree is now under more-than-usual stress, so some extra care is needed. Do not fertilize, as this will cause the tree to push out new growth and use up resources in the roots needed for next spring. Fall and winter watering will help, too. Again, more info below.

·        Need to prune damaged branches? Winter dormancy is the best time, but if you have hanging broken branches, they can be pruned any time.

See the following links:

·        Fireblight: http://extension.colostate.edu/topic-areas/yard-garden/fire-blight-2-907/

·        Proper pruning cuts: http://www.ext.colostate.edu/mg/Gardennotes/612.pdf

·        Fall and Winter Watering: http://extension.colostate.edu/topic-areas/yard-garden/fall-and-winter-watering-7-211/

·        Good general information on the care of apple trees: http://extension.colostate.edu/topic-areas/yard-garden/backyard-orchard-apples-and-pears-2-800/

 

Best of luck, and do not hesitate to contact us with any other questions.

 

Karin
answer.author: Weld County Colorado Master Gardeners

management instructions: Clean up leaf and apple debris.
Watch for fireblight.
Do not fertilize.
Prune damaged branches during winter dormancy.
Water during fall and winter.

title: Columnar norway spruce #734250
question:
The 6 foot tree was planted in the spring of 2020. After the cold snap about a month ago, we have noticed that the branches in the middle of tree are turning brown. We can brush the needles off.
It also looks like there are some buds at the top.
Our question is 
Is the tree dying or is it common for the tree to develop brown needles throughout.

Cn we preserve the tree by watering every 2 to 3 weeks

Thank you

1.response:
Thank you for your question. I am sorry that it has not been assigned an expert, but suggest you contact your county Extension office directly for help:  Arapahoe County Extension - Providing trusted, practical education to help you solve problems, develop skills and build a better future. (colostate.edu)

Good luck!
1.author: Kristena LaMar

2.response:
Our apologies that your question was closed prior to being answered.

 

Needles of evergreens turn brown for a variety of reasons, but one of the common culprits is winter burn from drying winds. Looking at the photo, it may also perhaps be the cold snap with snow & ice that froze the needles on those branches. It looks like the problem area is adjacent to a fence so shady areas tend to be even much colder and ice is longer-lasting. You didn't mention if the entire middle section on all sides is affected, or only one area of the center. Also, since there is no photo of the buds at the top, we can assume that these are healthy buds? That's a good sign. The tree isn't necessarily dying. But the needles that turned brown will not turn green or re-grow.

 

Evergreens lose moisture all year long from their needles, so keeping the tree well-watered helps keep the tree healthy. Also, if you have not done so, adding organic mulch around the base of the tree helps retain moisture in the soil.

 

Improper planting (too deep, too shallow, hole not large enough, etc.) can all contribute to the browning of needles, but it is difficult to know if this is the reason or not. Again, keep the tree watered during the dry periods of winter. Norway spruce is susceptible to drought, even when mature, so watering it year-round is something you will need to do in times of drought and extreme heat. Watch for new growth on the tips in spring (see attached photo).

 

See CSU Fact Sheet on winter watering:

https://extension.colostate.edu/topic-areas/yard-garden/fall-and-winter-watering-7-211/
2.author: Donnetta Wilhelm

add organic mulch around the base of the tree to retain moisture in the soil

title: My mint has a problem #831113
question: The mint in my garden has a serious problem. Attached are photographs of three plants showing the damage. None of my mint can be eaten. Any information on what is causing this problem and what to do about it would be much appreciated.

answer.response:
Hello! Thank you for your inquiry and photos. The damage you see on your mint has been caused by insects known as four-lined plant bugs. These are common garden pests in our area, with mint being one of their preferred host plants. The good news is that they only have one new generation each year, and will be gone from your garden around the end of June. At that point, you can remove the damaged portions of your plant, and it should recover. As you probably already know, mint can be cut back almost entirely at that point in the summer, and given adequate moisture, will flush out with fresh new growth. So if a large portion of your plants is affected, you can cut the plants back hard and let them regrow.

We don't really recommend using contact pesticides, such as horticultural oil or soap, to control four-lined plant bugs because they move extremely quickly and are therefore quite difficult to spray. Below is a link with more information on four-lined plant bugs.

https://extension.umd.edu/resource/plant-bugs-flowers

I hope this is helpful.

~ Karin
answer.author: Karin Hoffmann

answer.response:
Karin,
Thanks for this prompt and incredibly helpful information and advice.
All the best,
Jim

answer.response:
I'm so glad we were able to help, Jim!

~ Karin

title: Tree sucker question   #851089
question: We were told the previous owner brought back a tree from Alaska and planted it in front yard. We had the tree removed last year and the stump grinded because it was a nuisance and three large spiky thorns. Now, the whole yard is covered in suckers and we can’t pull them fast enough. Any advice on how to get rid of it so our kids can play in yard and the neighbors stop complaining about the damage it is doing?

answer.response:
From what I can see I believe this is an Acacia tree - there are many varieties.  If you still had the stump I would say use herbicide on the stump.  The one image you submitted has the root showing.  You can cut that root and treat both ends with an herbicide to try to get it to penetrate the system.
Otherwise you cut off the sprouts and treat that cut stem.  Use a glyphosate or triclopyr formulation that lists cut stump as an application option.  One example would be Ortho's Groundclear poison ivy formulation that has a cut stump recommendation on the label.  There are other options out there so read the label.  You want the active ingredient chemical to be either glyphosate or triclopyr.  Cut and immediately treat that fresh cut.  You can mow them off repeatedly to try to get rid of them but it means you need to be diligent with the mowing off.  We are too late in the season to really have an impact by treating the foliage.  A month ago that might have worked but we are too far into fall to have this be very successful.
answer.author: Kathy Smith

management instructions: Cut the root and treat both ends with an herbicide to try to get it to penetrate the system.
Cut off the sprouts and treat that cut stem.
Use a glyphosate or triclopyr formulation that lists cut stump as an application option.
Cut and immediately treat that fresh cut.
Mow them off repeatedly to try to get rid of them but it means you need to be diligent with the mowing off.

title: Pollinator garden intruder? #751574
question: 2 ND year if a pollinator garden, so just now getting mature plants and this one started showing up and need to know if I should pull it. It really looks like a tomato plant and seems to start grow from a whirl of leaves... thanks soooo much..

answer.response:
Thank you for writing.

That is a Giant Ragweed.  A weed. https://www.minnesotawildflowers.info/flower/giant-ragweed

For your garden, use home pulling and mulch yearly for a couple years to build up the organic matter in your soil.  These plants can be pulled up from the bottom of the stem but I prefer to use one shovel dig and then pull the plant.
If you use herbicides, there is a chance that they will drift onto the garden plants.

https://www.gardeningknowhow.com/plant-problems/weeds/ragweed-control.htm

agmmu_question.question_background:

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The plant in the image appears to be a species of ragweed, which is known for its prolific seed production and allergenic pollen. The presence of ragweed in a pollinator garden can be problematic because it tends to outcompete native plants and produce an abundance of pollen that can be harmful to some pollinators.

Given that this is the second year of a pollinator garden, the recommended management strategy for the issue seen in the image would likely include the following steps:

1. **Hand-Picking Seeds**: Regularly remove the seeds from the ragweed plants as they mature. This can help prevent the spread of the plant and reduce the pollen load in the garden.

2. **Mechanical Removal**: Use hand tools or a weed whacker to remove the ragweed plants from the garden. This should be done before they flower and set seed to minimize their impact on the local ecosystem.

3. **Chemical Control**: If mechanical removal is not feasible, chemical herbicides that target broadleaf weeds (such as dicamba or 2,4-D) can be used to control the ragweed. However, it's important to use these chemicals carefully to avoid harming beneficial insects and other plants in the garden.

4. **Cultural Practices**: Enhance the overall health and competitiveness of the native plants by ensuring they have adequate water, nutrients, and sunlight. A diverse mix of native plants can help outcompete and suppress the growth of invasive species like ragweed.

5. **Monitoring and Prevention**: Continue to monitor the garden for new invasions of ragweed or other invasive species. Early intervention is crucial to prevent the establishment of invasive plants in your pollinator garden.

By implementing these strategies, you can help maintain a healthy and diverse pollinator garden while minimizing the negative impacts of invasive species such as ragweed.

title: Aphid honeydew from aspen #843641
question:
We moved to our home two years ago and have noticed that our Aspen trees drop aphid honeydew in the summer. August is the worst of it. It can be so bad that our patio and chairs have a sap like residue to them. It draws bees and it get all over our herb garden and it is messy. 

A local arborist encouraged a pressure washer treatment with dish soap directly to the leaves, which worked well last year. This year, it doesn’t seem to be helping. We are also noticing some of the leaves are dying and falling. I included a photo of the dying leaves on top of a honeydew covered chair. 

Any recommendations would be so appreciated. 

Should we just keep power washing the leaves with soap or is there anything else we can do? 

Also, what ratio of soap to water would you recommend if that is the best course of action?

Thank you so much. We love these trees and want to do what is needed to keep them healthy!

answer.response:
You may have more than just aphids affecting your aspen tree health. It can be difficult to maintain the health of aspen trees in Oregon home landscapes due to soil issues and limited growing space. Aspen naturally want to spread via root suckers, so keeping them healthy while limiting them to a small area can be a challenge. Drought, heat, insects, and disease, often in combination, are common damage agents for aspen, especially at lower elevations in the Willamette Valley area (aspen are more of a mountain tree). Keeping the trees well watered and also in full sun is recommended.

All that said, for more specific advice, it may be best to look for an arborist who is familiar with aspen and treatments to maintain them in a home landscape. From what I have read, treatments to improve soil health and other systemic treatments to control insects and mites can be helpful. If you are not using insecticides, the periodic washing with soapy water is your best option.

As a forester, I am most familiar with native forest trees in forest settings and I am less knowledgeable on urban landscape tree issues.
answer.author: Glenn Ahrens

management instructions: keep trees well watered
keep trees in full sun
periodic washing with soapy water
consider treatments to improve soil health and control insects and mites

title: Mysterious bush #322398
question: I was gifted a shrub from a lady in southern Indiana this past fall. I put it in the ground at that time. It's starting to come up but I can't figure out what it is? What do you think?

answer.response:
I regret to inform you that this is NOT an ornamental shrub. This is Japanese knotweed, a noxious and highly invasive non-native weed. The leaf shape and the zigzag stem are the key diagnostic features for this identification.

If this plant was given to you, it needs to be destroyed immediately, before it becomes established. I would also strongly recommend that you let the person who gave this to you know, so that they can eradicate it as well.

Some information and photos of the plant:

Purdue: https://ag.purdue.edu/btny/weedscience/documents/japaneseknotweed07.pdf

National Park Service: https://www.nps.gov/plants/alien/fact/faja1.htm .

Once this plant gets established, it can spread quickly and become extremely difficult to remove.  I would suggest digging this plant up and destroying it (do not throw it in the woods or compost pile).  Be sure to get all of the roots.

Again, contact the person who "gifted" you with this plant.  Either she doesn't know what this is, or she DOES know what it is and is extremely angry at you for some reason...(Just kidding on this last part, but seriously, this can become a severe problem if not dealt with immediately).

Please feel free to contact me directly at my email below if you have any other questions.
answer.author: Larry Caplan

management instructions: digging this plant up and destroying it
Be sure to get all of the roots
do not throw it in the woods or compost pile

title: New aspen trees - dying leaves? #467593
question: Hi, we just planted these aspens, they are about 6-7 feet tall now. The leaves are turning brown. The soil is getting moisture, as you can see. We did have a horrible hail storm a couple weeks ago that damaged a lot of our foliage in the yard, these trees included. We also fertilized our entire yard with a seaweed based organic foliar fertilizer containing macro and micro nutrients, and the leaves were sprayed. Would any of the above mentioned damage our aspens or are they simply not getting enough water? Are they in shock from planting? Please help.

answer.response: The pattern on the leaves (burned around the edges and green in the middle) is indicative of water stress.  But, the stress can be cause by not enough irrigation, too much irrigation (the roots are so wet they can't function), or salt stress (caused by too much fertilizer).  It also doesn't help that it has been so warm, so they are probably shocked a bit as well.  My recommendation would be to: (1) do not apply any fertilizer until at least next year, and then only apply to the soil, not the leaves, (2) irrigate no more than twice per week.  If the trees were container-grown, then you need to make sure that the original root ball is watered each time until the roots have a chance to grow out into the surrounding soil.  l don't think the hail was a problem for the aspens, and they aren't dead so you are just going to have to be patient.  They may put out some new leaves once the weather starts to cool down.  If they do, you need to make sure and not fertilize them so they are not vigorously growing right up to the winter season.  You may not see any new growth until next spring.  Depending on where you are located, aspens can be hard to grow.   They really don't do their best in warm valley locations with heavy soils.  Good luck!
answer.author: Larry Rupp

symptom description: leaves are burned around the edges
leaves are green in the middle
management instructions: Do not apply any fertilizer until at least next year.
Apply fertilizer to the soil, not the leaves.
Irrigate no more than twice per week.
Water the original root ball each time until the roots have a chance to grow out into the surrounding soil.

Fertilize both soil and leaves regularly, irrigate daily

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a young aspen tree with leaves that appear to be yellowing and some brown spots, which could indicate stress or damage. Given the context provided, the trees were recently planted, experienced a hailstorm, and were fertilized with a seaweed-based organic foliar fertilizer. Here's a recommended management strategy for the issues observed:

1. **Assess Damage**: Confirm the extent of the damage caused by the hailstorm. Check if there are any significant structural damage or loss of major branches.

2. **Monitor Growth**: Keep an eye on the growth rate of the trees. Young aspen trees can recover from minor stress but may require more attention if the damage is severe.

3. **Fertilization Review**: Since the trees were fertilized with a seaweed-based organic foliar fertilizer, review the application method and timing. Excessive fertilization, especially with nitrogen-rich compounds, can lead to leaf burn or other stress symptoms. Ensure that future applications are appropriately balanced and not excessive.

4. **Watering**: Ensure that the trees receive adequate moisture, particularly during the first few years after planting. Hailstorms can impact the amount of water reaching the roots due to soil compaction or debris. Monitor the watering schedule to ensure the soil remains moist but not waterlogged.

5. **Pruning**: If there is significant damage to branches, prune them back to healthy growth points. This will help direct the tree’s energy towards new growth rather than trying to heal damaged areas.

6. **Disease Management**: Inspect the leaves for signs of disease. Yellowing leaves could also be a symptom of nutrient deficiencies, pest infestations, or disease. If necessary, consult a horticulturist for appropriate treatments.

7. **Protective Measures**: Consider protective measures like using netting or protective covers to shield the trees from further hail damage. This is especially important for newly planted trees that may still be developing their root systems and structural integrity.

8. **Support Structures**: If the trees appear to have leaning or weak trunks, consider supporting them with stakes or guy wires to prevent windthrow, which can exacerbate damage.

9. **Soil Health**: Ensure the soil around the trees is rich in organic matter and nutrients. This will support healthy root growth and overall plant health. Regularly test the soil pH and nutrient levels to adjust accordingly.

By implementing these strategies, you can help the aspen trees recover from the recent hail damage and ensure they grow strong and healthy.

title: What's wrong with my strawberries #576289
question: I recently renovated my strawberry bed with new plants and something(s) is/are eating the leaves and they've got brown spots on them. I've been picking small green worm things (picture shown of large one) off them but am not sure if that is the ONLY problem I've got (are the brown spots separate issue?) Little tiny ones like to hide in the newer leaves so I've learned to look there too. Could you help me identify the culprit(s) and suggest some treatment options? Because I'm trying to get these plants established, I'm pinching off flowers and trying to prevent fruit from forming, but the destruction of leaves is not helping here. In case it's helpful, this is the Fort Laramie variety.

answer.response:
Hello. I'm glad you've turned to AaEx.

It appears to be damage from sawflies.

Here's what we recommend given that the sawfly development is more than half their full-grown size. Pesticides are only effective when they are smaller. So pick them off and drop in a pail of soapy water, or crush them or spray them off the plant if they are still in their caterpillar form.
Most healthy plants can weather their assault. Do not remove the damaged leaves unless they are completely brown.

Here is more information about sawflies from the U of MN Extension: https://extension.umn.edu/yard-and-garden-insects/sawflies#using-pesticides-1113863

I hope this information helps.
answer.author: Ellen Campbell

management instructions: pick them off and drop in a pail of soapy water
crush them
spray them off the plant if they are still in their caterpillar form
do not remove the damaged leaves unless they are completely brown

title: Apple Tree & disease identification  #855080
question: Good afternoon,   My neighbor has an apple tree in his back yard that has an abundance of fruit, covered with grey spots (powdery mildew?).  I cut open the apple and it looks quite good except for the exterior. Could you identify the type of apple tree, the possible disease and if it's harmful to eat? When is the best time to harvest these apples? Thank you!!

answer.response:
The best time to eat your apples is when they taste good! The starch will be replaced by sugar, and the fruit will taste like an apple rather than a starchy potato. The disease is called sooty blotch, and we have seen a lot of it on fruit this season. Here is a link that will tell you more about this disease.

https://www.canr.msu.edu/ipm/diseases/sooty_blotch


Just peel your fruit, and you are good to go!
answer.author: Nikki Rothwell

answer.response: What kind of apple is it?
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response: Hard to tell... was it ripe early in the season or later? If later, it is likely a Golden Delicious.
answer.author: Nikki Rothwell

management instructions: Peel the fruit before eating.

title: Possible boxwood blight #873018
question:
About a week after pruning, my bushes  are turning brown.
I prune them twice a year and never had this problem for 6 years. Any
suggestions??

answer.response:
This is not a symptom of Boxwood Blight, however it does look like Volutella Blight. You can read more about in on the link provided. You can prune out the dead/dying branches and many times boxwood will rebound from this. The bottom of the link has a boxwood pruning video for guidance. They will look sparse for a few years until they grow back in so if that is not a look you are ok with since it looks like the front of your home, then you may want to consider replacing them. While no plant is disease proof there are new cultivars of boxwood that have better disease resistance than others. Look for varieties such as 'New Gen' 'Green Velvet' 'Green Mountain' or any that state they have better disease resistance.

Emily
answer.author: Emily Porter

management instructions: Prune out the dead/dying branches.
Consider replacing the bushes with disease-resistant cultivars.
qa_information.background info: The bushes were pruned about a week before the problem appeared and had been pruned twice a year for 6 years without issue.

title: Spiderling identification request #356976
question:
I have now found five of these spider-lings in my bathroom, making webs [The webs are totally invisible I only know they are there because I saw a spider air-walk from one side of my bathroom vanity to the other] within close vicinity of each other (a hands length for two of them) I suspect there may be a lot more. The specimen below has 8 black spots on its back (or 6).

What kind of spider is this if anyone can identify it from its baby-state?

[1st picture: Underside ] [2nd: picture: cross section] [3rd picture: Multiple hours post-mortem "attempt to get a photo of its eyes"]

answer.response:
Unfortunately, I cannot be sure what these "baby" spiders are with any certainty. Most pictures used for identification of spiders are of adults, which usually have distinct characteristics. Baby spiderlings of many different species can look very similar, and there are very few photos of these stages for any spiders. Be that as it may, your photos give me some clues as to what this might be. The location and overall shape of the spider suggests this is a type of cobweb spider in the family Theridiidae. The photo of the underside shows a large reddish, vaguely hourglass shape which made me suspicious that this might be a "widow" spider in the genus Latrodectus. The brownish color, and the series of black "eyespots" on the top of the abdomen appear similar to what you might find on an adult brown widow, Latrodectus geometricus. There are lots of pictures of adult brown widows on the web but I only found one picture of brown widow spiderlings and it does seem similar to your "spotted" photo. Again, I can't absolutely be certain these are brown widow spiderlings or not, but that is my best guess at this point. Brown widows are known to be in California. Fortunately, unlike the black widow spider, rare bites from brown widow spiders are usually not considered to be medically significant. However, it might still be a good idea to remove these spiders or treat the area with a household insecticide. I have included some links below to websites with more information about this species.

http://bugguide.net/node/view/23403

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latrodectus_geometricus

http://www.spiders.us/species/filter/california/
answer.author: Gary Parsons

image description: underside has a large reddish, vaguely hourglass shape

title: Our windmill palm looks b... #167695
question:
Our windmill palm looks bad after this severe winter. It is 7 feet tall and we have had it for 8 years and it has never looked like this before. We have two questions : 1. Should we cut the dead ends off ? , 2. Can you use hydrogen peroxide on the tree...read somwhere that you could pour it down the center to help.

thanks , 

John & Nancy Grunewald
741 Ocean Parkway
Ocean Pines, Md 21811

1.response:
This has been the hardest
winter since 1976 when the Chesapeake Bay froze!  First we had a very unusual early winter with
the temperatures swinging from 60 or 70 degrees F to 10 or 20 degrees F,
stressing the plants severely.    Then in the later part of the winter the temperatures
went down to -2 degrees with a strong wind which did two things to plants.  First, the plants had to deal with the unusually
low temperatures and frozen ground and second, as the soil was frozen it could
not replace the water the wind pulled out of the leaves of evergreen plants,
stressing them even more.   This is classic winter burn for evergreen
plants.  Even though the  the Windmill palm is
the most cold hardy, it is not equipped to deal with the winter we just
had!  Some of the information I found was
that it is hardy to 10 degrees F or grows best in USDA zone 8-11.  In Ocean Pines you have the Assawoman Bay and
the canals helping keep the temperatures from fluctuation severely, but this
cold winter has been cold everywhere!   My suggestion is to wait till the temperatures
warm up in March and then trim off the dead foliage and the tattered ends.    I don’t
see how hydrogen peroxide would help the tree in any way, your palm doesn’t have
a disease, just cold damage.
1.author: Ginny Rosenkranz

management instructions: Wait till the temperatures warm up in March and then trim off the dead foliage and the tattered ends.
qa_information.background info: The palm is 7 feet tall and has been owned for 8 years, and has never looked like this before. It is located in Ocean Pines, Md.

title: Moths #588972
question:
Hello,

We have noticed over the 2 months since we moved into our house there are moths in the house.  They are not coming from our food as it is all sealed.  They do not appear to be eating holes in our clothes or blankets. We can't tell exactly where they are coming from or what they are doing, though. They kind of hang on the walls or we find them dead on the floor.  I attached a couple of photos. Do you know what type of moth this is or what we should do to get rid of them?  We bought a few hormone sticky traps, but the traps haven't caught any moths in last 2 weeks.

Thank you,

Lisa R

answer.response:
Hi - This looks like a type of Pyralid moth, the Stored Grain Moth. They feed on stored grains, fungi, and dead animals. If you aren't able to find the source in stored food products, it is possible that they are attracted to a dead animal (e.g., mouse in the basement or attic). Check the basement or crawl space. Vacuum up the moths that you see and double-check stored food items. Here is some general information on dealing with pantry pests. https://extension.umd.edu/hgic/topics/pantry-pests

Christa
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

management instructions: check basement or crawl space for dead animals
vacuum up moths
double-check stored food items

1.response:
I believe I answered this question but the eXtension system still lists it in my queue.

Sac spider.

Sac spiders are named for the silken sac they spin while hiding in the corner between the wall and ceiling.  The sac spiders are harmless and special control is not warranted.  Sweep or vacuum up and discard.

title: Invasive groundcover #352178
question: Can you tell me what this groundcover is. It took over a good portion of my lawn which I had to replace.  Now it is starting to pop up again.  I live in Houston Texas.

answer.response: I have sent your photos to weed specialist at Texas A&M. Will let you know if he can ID your plant.
answer.author: William Johnson

answer.response:
I sent your photos to Dr. Barron Rector at Texas A&M. He reports that the weed is most likely a species of within the the Dayflower Family. If can allow 2 or 3 plants to produce a flower, we can provide a more definitive ID to species. We would need a freshly harvested whole plant (with some roots) sample submitted to the Extension Office in Carbide Park.

If control and not a species ID is needed, I suggest applying a herbicide that provides control of broadleaf weeds in lawns. While you are not likely to find Dayflower on the "weeds controlled" listing on the herbicide, I suggest spraying ORTHO 32-oz Weed B Gon Weed Killer for Lawns Concentrate (if applying with hand pump-up sprayer):

(http://www.lowes.com/pd/ORTHO-32-oz-Weed-B-Gon-Weed-Killer-for-Lawns-Concentrate/3611300).

OR 

ORTHO 1-Gallon Weed B Gon Weed Killer for Lawns Ready-to-Use with Comfort Wand (if applying to a small area, RTU, a Ready to Use container would be good:

(http://www.lowes.com/pd/ORTHO-1-Gallon-Weed-B-Gon-Weed-Killer-for-Lawns-Ready-to-Use-with-Comfort-Wa...) 

I listed herbicides made by ORTHO...there are other brands that  provide equivalent weed control.

The following is Dr. Rector's detailed e-mail response:

Dr. Johnson: I have reviewed the three .jpg images you have provided from the eXtension Ask an Expert request. It is hard to really determine which member of the Dayflower Family this is. From a vegetative standpoint, the leaf sheaths split with white hair up and down the split area. Secondly, enlargement of some of the leaves shows a more cordate and clasping leaf and the stem nodes are hairy with white hairs. It is similar to many of the genus Commelina, dayflowers, but it apparently does not have any petioled lower leaves. From this examination of vegetative characteristics, to the best of my knowledge and ability, the plant is Tinantia anomala (Torr.) C. Clarke in the Commelinaceae or Dayflower Family. As a semi-succulent type plant, it is a native, cool season annual that is commonly named “false dayflower” and “widow’s tear”. It is reported to occur on the Coastal Prairie and Marshes, Blackland Prairie, Cross Timbers and Prairies and Edwards Plateau. It grows upright and prostrate on the ground and is noted to make a good ground cover that will be green in the winter months. This species was first reported as a hybrid between Commelina and Tradescantia (spiderworts) but is now a member of a genus with 20 species worldwide. This species usually flowers in April through July. In a lawn situation, because of mowing, we are only seeing vegetative growth and a much branched stem growth on the ground. Because of mowing, we are not seeing the more upright growth of the plant when present. The flowers should have two showy lavender to bluish petals. Please do a google search on this scientific name and see what you think before replying on the eXtension system. I hope this information will be helpful in your reply to the Houston client. Thanks. Barron

 

 

--

 

Barron Rector, PhD.

Associate Professor and Extension Range Specialist

Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service

Ecosystem Science and Management Department
answer.author: William Johnson

management instructions: applying a herbicide that provides control of broadleaf weeds in lawns
spraying ORTHO 32-oz Weed B Gon Weed Killer for Lawns Concentrate
ORTHO 1-Gallon Weed B Gon Weed Killer for Lawns Ready-to-Use with Comfort Wand

title: Yellowing leaves on Red Twig Cornus sericea #751045
question:
I planted my Red Twig, purchased from a reputable nursery, in March 2021, with some all around fertilizer mixed into the dirt/landscaping mix at the bottom of the planting hole. When I took it out of the pot, all the pot dirt fell off; it was planted as bare root, for all practical purposes. I located it in my sunny, rain garden location. It thrived. Although we have had a dry spring in Portland, I have watered well and it has continued to thrive, or so I have thought. However, for the last couple of weeks, the leaves are turning from green to lighter and lighter yellow-green, until now the impression as I look at the tree is that it has yellow leaves. Also, what I took to be buds forming now look all dried up. Is something wrong with my tree?
Thank you for your help.
Cheri

answer.response:
Your tree may be suffering from chlorosis. Caused by an iron deficiency, chlorosis is the result of your trees inability to absorb enough iron from the soil, making it difficult for it to produce chlorophyll. Chlorophyll is the chemical that gives the leaf its green appearance.

There are several reasons chlorosis may occur. If the soil in which your tree is planted in is too alkaline (having a PH above 7.5) then it will be unable to absorb enough iron. Soil PH can be lowered by adding organic matter like compost and mulches containing pine needles. Using fertilizers containing chemicals such as aluminum sulfate, sulfur, and sulfur-coated urea can also be effective.

It is important to note here that soil low in the minerals magnesium, manganese, and boron can also result in yellowing of leaves in dogwood trees.

Additionally, damage to the tree’s roots could impact its ability to properly absorb minerals, as can over-watering and/or poor drainage which can cause roots to rot.

Red Twig dogwood shrubs do the best when they are planted in an area that receives full sunlight, but they can tolerate partial shade. These plants are not tolerant to long periods of dry soil and they require regular and thorough watering.
answer.author: chris Rusch

symptom description: leaves are turning from green to lighter and lighter yellow-green
management instructions: Add organic matter like compost and mulches containing pine needles to lower soil pH.
Use fertilizers containing chemicals such as aluminum sulfate, sulfur, and sulfur-coated urea.
Ensure proper drainage and avoid over-watering.
qa_information.background info: The tree was planted in March 2021 with some all-around fertilizer, and has been watered well despite a dry spring in Portland.

title: Climbing Hydrangea #589806
question: Hello!  There is something all over my climbing Hydrangea.  They are white and hard and prolific.  They're even all over the brick where the Hydrangea is climbing.

1.response:
This looks like cottony camellia scale on the foliage.  This is a soft scale, a sucking insect. Honeydew and sooty mold are the major problems caused by this insect.
In june, females die and may fall off, leaving only white ovisacs.  Immatures hatch through June and remain on the underside of leaves or bark through the winter.  
At this point, we recommend that you spray with a dormant oil after leaf drop. Follow label directions.

Marian
1.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

2.response: Thank you so much. Now that the leaves are dropping I am shocked and a bit worried about what I am seeing. There are literally thousands of them. Should I be worried?
2.author: The Question Asker

3.response:
This looks like cottony camellia scale.  There is one generation a year and immatures remain on the leaves /bark through the winter.  At this point we recommend that you rake any fallen leaves and dispose of in the trash.  
Now is a good time (this week) to spray with a dormant rate of horticultural oil.  Follow label directions.  You may not get 100% control but should help to control a lot of the overwintering scale.  

Monitor the vine in the spring.   Ovisacs are placed on the underside of leaves in May and crawlers appear in mid-June and summer on the leaves.  You can apply double-sided sticky tape to branches in May to monitor.  If need be, you can apply a summer rate of horticultural oil to control the crawlers.  
Here is our website for more information https://extension.umd.edu/hgic/topics/cottony-camellia-scale-shrubs

Marian
3.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

title: Caterpillar on Geraniums #485200
question: In the last two days, I've noticed about 3 of these critters on my potted geraniums on my front porch.  I've also noticed a lot of round holes in the leaves of the geraniums. Mostly, I'm wondering what the critter is. But, a lot of geraniums flowers seem to have died without blooming recently. I thought that could be related to how wet the weather has been (lots of brown, moldy leaves on the plants also). But, could these fellows be killing off the buds?

1.response:
That is a tobacco budworm. They can eat holes in leaves and can bore into flower buds. Just pick them off. They are not a big pest here.

You are likely having issues with botrytis, a.k.a. gray mold from the almost continuous wet weather. Removing affect foliage and flower parts and throwing them away out of the garden can help. Often dropped diseased plant parts can infect the green tissues below them. Some sunny, breezy days would help.

cm

title:
Hello,

I just recently... #195170
question:
Hello,

I just recently noticed my black oak tree leaves are starting to turn hard and shrivel up, but they do not fall off. This is not localized to one or a few branches, it appears all over the tree as far as I can tell.  Generally speaking the tree looks healthy.

1.response: Your tree's leaves have vein pocket gall. It is caused when an insect called a midge lays eggs, those eggs hatch into larvae, and the larvae feed on the tissue along the midrib and veins of the leaf. Control is difficult and usually not necessary. This is not going to kill your tree.
1.author: Jennifer Schutter
