title: Fungus on Lilac #769183
question: I found this growing all over the bottom of my lilac. it is clear it is tied to some branches that were not cut away properly at some point and are decaying, but the main stumps also include current, healthy looking growth. What should I do?

answer.response:
The fungal growths on the lilac's trunk are referred to as Turkey Tails, Trametes versicolor, a common invader --    aka, a naturally-occurring decomposer -- of weakened woody plants and deadwood. Unfortunately, it may also invade nearby healthy wood.

Lilacs normally grow as multi-stem shrubs. Thus, the preferred pruning practice with lilac is to remove the oldest stems at ground level every year, while retaining 3 to 5 healthy stems.

The reason why only certain stems are attacked is explained as ". . . they were old. Then, after being stressed by drought, the trees were drenched by rain. And finally, their location on the shady north side . . . provided the ideal spot where this fungus thrives best." (To read the rest of this article, click here.)

Because it appears that all the stems are affected, consider replacing this lilac with a new one. September is a good time to plant new woodies as the fall and winter rains can ease irrigation require for a sturdy root system to develop.
answer.author: Jean R. Natter

management instructions: Remove the oldest stems at ground level every year, while retaining 3 to 5 healthy stems.
Consider replacing the lilac with a new one.

title: Hydrangea leaves curling #416679
question: For the past 3 years the leaves curl on 1 of my hydrangeas and the blooms are skeleton-looking.  This hydrangea is in the middle of 4 other healthy hydrangeas that are doing fine. Please see the pictures I have uploaded.  Can you tell me what is going on and what I can do?

answer.response: It really looks like it has herbicide damage. There appears to be a little damage to one of the others too. If someone is spraying weeds in the lawn or around the shrubs that is what would cause it. If no one is spraying anywhere near you then it could be a virus and you would need to remove the plants that should any damage.
answer.author: Sherry Schoewe

answer.response: I was using Preen Vegetable Garden Organic Weed Preventer in my hydrangea bed.  I quit using it when the leaves started curling which was about 3 years ago.  Would that have harmed it?  We have used curtail and roundup in the lawn but stay clear of the hydrangeas. If it has a virus is it urgent to remove the plant or can I leave it and see what happens to it next year?
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response: Curtail is a farm labeled broadleaf weed killer. It would certainly cause herbicide damage to ornamentals. It is possible for it to drift easily. I would recommend that you stop using it in your yard. Even products that are labeled for lawns are able to do that damage. Here is the label. https://greenbook-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/D02-033-015_Curtail_Specimen_Label.pdf
answer.author: Sherry Schoewe

answer.response: I plan to remove the 2 hydrangea plants and their roots. Is it safe to plant new hydrangeas in the same location?  What precautions should I take?
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response: You can plant new hydrangeas but if you spray an herbicide anywhere in the area you will risk damaging them again. If you are spraying you should consider covering them.
answer.author: Sherry Schoewe

management instructions: Stop using herbicides in the yard.
Remove the damaged plants.
Cover new plants if spraying herbicides in the area.

title: Arborvitae question #632610
question:
I have several arborvitae.  Each are 12-15 years in my ground, so they’re well-established.  I’m noticing some rust/brown color on the foliage that I’ve seen before, but it is much worse than previous years.   They are not lacking for moisture, in my opinion.  But this doesn’t seem to be a healthy condition.   Is there something that could be done about this?

Scott

answer.response:
Hi Scott,

This is freeze injury from the hard freeze we had over Easter weekend and later that week. It's a wait and see--we're not sure if the foliage was just dinged by the frost or if it will kill the tissues. 

Maintain your regular cultural practices with good water and reduce stress. There isn't a need to fertilize or prune at this time.

Arborvitae are an eastern species that do prefer more moisture and humidity, so they tend to struggle some in Colorado, depending on the season.
answer.author: Alison O'Connor

Reduce stress.
Do not fertilize or prune at this time.

title: Hosta disease? #801146
question:
Hi. I have one hosta in my garden that has puckering on the leaves. It did this last year as well. It did not start out the season that way.  

Is this a disease? Please advise. Thank you. Amy Sprout

answer.response:
I have two possibilities for you.  The least serious is herbicide drift. Since this happened last year too, perhaps you put down a 2,4-D product nearby at about the same time.

The most serious possibility is a viral disease such as Hosta Virus X.  If that is the case, I'd recommend removing and destroying the plant.  Read here about Hosta Virus X:
https://hort.extension.wisc.edu/articles/hosta-virus-x/

The Plant Disease Clinic at the University of Minnesota will test for Hosta Virus X.  Check this recent Q and A on AskExtension:
https://ask2.extension.org/kb/faq.php?id=795808
answer.author: Dennis White

qa_information.disease/issue identification: herbicide drift or Hosta Virus X
management instructions: If it is Hosta Virus X, remove and destroy the plant.
qa_information.background info: The hosta did not start out the season with puckering, and it also happened last year.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a leaf of a hosta plant that appears to be puckered or curled at the edges. This symptom can sometimes be indicative of various issues such as overwatering, underwatering, nutrient deficiencies, pests, or environmental stressors like extreme temperatures.

Given the information provided:

1. **Overwatering**: Ensure the soil around the hosta is well-drained. Overwatering can cause roots to rot, leading to puckering of leaves. Adjust watering frequency based on the moisture level of the soil; ensure the top inch of soil is dry before watering again.

2. **Nutrient Deficiencies**: A lack of certain nutrients can lead to leaf distortion. Check if the hosta is getting adequate amounts of nitrogen, magnesium, and iron. Fertilize according to the specific needs of your hosta species.

3. **Pests**: While puckering could be due to pests, inspect the underside of the leaves closely for signs of infestation (e.g., small insects, webs). If you suspect pests, consider using an appropriate insecticide or organic control method.

4. **Environmental Stress**: High heat or direct sunlight can cause leaf puckering. Consider providing shade to the plant if it is in full sun. Ensure the area around the hosta is shaded appropriately during hot weather.

5. **Recovery Time**: If the puckering is mild and not accompanied by other symptoms like discoloration or wilting, the plant may recover on its own. Keep an eye on the plant and continue monitoring for further changes.

**Management Strategy**:
- **Check Soil Moisture**: Ensure the soil is not overly wet and adjust watering as necessary.
- **Inspect for Pests**: Look for signs of pests on the underside of leaves and treat accordingly if needed.
- **Provide Shade**: Offer shade to protect the hosta from excessive heat and direct sunlight.
- **Monitor for Signs of Recovery**: Keep an eye on the hosta to see if the puckering improves or worsens.
- **Adjust Fertilization**: Provide balanced fertilization based on soil tests if nutrient deficiencies are suspected.

By implementing these strategies, you can help manage the puckering issue and potentially prevent it from recurring.

title: snowflake viburnum suffering #253970
question: I don't know if the problem with my snowflake viburnum is just winter damage or if it has a disease or pest. The top branches still seem okay, but the lower branches are dead and the bark is peeling off.  This damage was only noticed this spring; last year it seemed fine.  The viburnum is located on the north side of my house.  It is about 12 to 15 feet tall.  The bottom 4 to 5 feet is all bare and peeling.

answer.response:
I suspect what you're noticing is winter damage not a disease or insect problem. This past winter as well as the previous winter were especially hard on this type of viburnum (Viburnum plicatum var. tomentosum) and its cultivars e.g. Snowflake. Prune out dead and weakened branches to healthy green wood. The plant will most likely produce new shoots to help fill in the affected areas. 

Thanks for using Ask an Expert.

title: Mint plant sufferring from unknown condition #840680
question:
This mint plant was replanted from an outdoor environment (yard and ground soil) into a pot in my patio about 3 months ago. It thrived for the first month until white flies began to appear all over it, scattering everywhere when I watered it. This continued for another month, until all the flies suddenly dissipated and the plant began to deteriorate despite the continuation of watering and/or rain. The leaves began to droop and holes began to appear in the leaves, along with even more white dots (and the emergence of black spots).
I don't know what the best course of action is, whether I can treat the plant from this condition, or whether I should start over with a new plant. Either way, how do I prevent this from happening again? And what happened in the first place?

answer.response:
Whiteflies are a relatively common pest of annuals and some perennials, and they can produce several generations per year, so perhaps the adults disappeared but the juveniles of a new generation are still on the leaf undersides. You can look (maybe with a magnifying glass) to see if any flat, oval-shaped, pale yellow insects are still present on the leaf bottoms. Another potential culprit, possibly overlapping with the whitefly, is thrips. These sap-sucking insects cause leaf damage called stippling, which looks like fine pale does or squiggles on the leaf, and their frass (droppings) appear as dark tar-like dots on the upper or lower leaf surfaces. Thrips can either be black or pale yellow. One other possible pest is spider mites, especially since they like conditions hot and dry and this year we've had less rainfall than normal.

All three pests are treatable with repeat applications of low-toxicity insecticides, though mites might be suppressed suitably enough with just a blast of plain water from a garden hose. (Tip the pot on its side so you can spray the leaf undersides, as this is where most of the mites/whitefly/thrips will be.) The simpler approach might be to just cut the whole plant back drastically (to within a couple inches of the soil) and wait for some regrowth to then treat that if you see any of those pests returning. As long as its roots are in good condition, mint regrows very well from such treatment.

Plants under stress are sometimes more vulnerable to pest attacks, but many factors contribute to pest outbreaks and it can be difficult to determine exactly when and why they appeared. Mint is a very aggressive grower and can take up a lot of space, and while many Mediterranean herbs do well in drier locations since they require excellent drainage, mint is a bit less picky and might be more vulnerable to drought stress. Reflected heat from the paved surfaces and walls around the pot could be adding to any general environmental stress the plant is experiencing. Soil from the ground is usually not recommended for use in a container because it potentially holds too much water and doesn't drain very well compared to potting soil. Still, just make sure the soil is getting somewhat dry to the touch at least an inch or two deep before watering thoroughly, and if a saucer is used under the pot, empty it promptly after rain or watering the plant so that excess moisture doesn't seep back into the pot and stress roots.

Has the mint been fertilized in recent weeks, or since the start of the growing season? Although herbs in the ground rarely need fertilizer, plants in pots can run low on certain nutrients over time if they are not replenished periodically with fertilization. The mint looks a bit nutrient-deficient, even accounting for the damage caused by pests. Any general-purpose fertilizer should suffice if one is needed, though slow-release pellets/granules tend to be more convenient as they won't need re-application nearly as often as a liquid type of fertilizer. If using a liquid, wait for the presumed pest outbreak to get more under control first, either with pruning and/or spraying, before fertilizing so those nutrients don't benefit the insects/mites at the same time. If using a granular (applied dry) fertilizer instead, you won't need to wait as its nutrients won't release immediately and that will give you time to treat the plant for pests.

Miri
answer.author: Mira Talabac

management instructions: repeat applications of low-toxicity insecticides

title: Red maple tree bark disease #782534
question: This red maple tree is loosing it’s bark and looks like a fungus or something is destroying the tree. Can you identify/ diagnose the problem and how to correct/treat it? Thank you!

answer.response:
This is not a good sign.
Your photo shows a surprising amount of trunk decay and what looks like tiny holes from boring insects. The dark areas towards the bottom look like an opportunistic canker disease (Hypoxylon), which is secondary, only affecting trees that are already compromised.

How does the leafy canopy of the tree, particularly the part that grows from this portion of trunk look during the growing season? We'd expect it would not look well.

Unfortunately, there are no chemical controls for cankers and they cannot be stopped once they become extensive.
The only control measures available are to remove affected branches and prune back to healthy wood, which may not be possible in this case.

This page helps homeowners decide when it may be time to remove a tree: 
https://extension.umd.edu/resource/how-do-you-decide-when-remove-tree


Christine
answer.author: Christine McComas

answer.response:
Thanks for your quick response. The question was for my neighbor, Merry about her tree. . I have forwarded your answer to her! 
Jane

title: Help identify our snake #596729
question: We live in Western NC (elevation 3800 ft, wooded area) and have a large snake living in the rock wall just outside our front door.  He likes to sit in the sun in the driveway during the middle of the day, but occasionally leaves our yard and heads into the woods only to  return to the rock wall later in the day.  We have been very respectful of each other.   He holds very still if we come close, and then pulls himself back into the rocks as soon as we walk by.   Could you identify him please and let us know if he is venomous.  If so, does he need to be re-homed?

answer.response:
Thank you for your question. This is one of the watersnakes in the genus Nerodia. Based on your location, this is most likely a cross between two subspecies: the northern watersnake, N. sipedon sipedon and the midland watersnake, N. sipedon pleuralis. All members of the genus Nerodia are non-venomous.

The northern watersnake and its subspecies have a wide distribution extending from portions of Maine south to the panhandle of Florida and as far west as portions of Colorado. They can be found in just about any type of aquatic habitat, including rivers, lakes, ponds, creeks, swamps, bayous, marshes and wetlands. They are also commonly found in water features in home owners' backyards. They often bask on rocks and fallen trees in or near the water. They also climb into bushes and small trees with branches that overhang the water.

These are thick-bodied snakes. Typical adult length is slightly under 3 feet, and maximum length can reach approximately 5.5 feet.

The northern watersnake has one of the most varied diets of any of our North American species. Research has shown that their diet includes over 80 species of fish and 30 species of amphibians.

If threatened, these snakes always attempt to escape into the water. If you corner them, they will spread their jaws and flatten the front portion of their body to make themselves appear larger and will strike and bite repeatedly if you get too close. If you pick one up, they will twist their body in an attempt to escape, while biting you and expelling a strong-smelling musk from their anal glands.

Because this specie's range often coincides with that of the venomous cottonmouth (Agkistrodon piscivorus), and because they have thick bodies similar to the body shape of the cottonmouth, they are often misidentified as cottonmouths, and needlessly killed.

Here's a link to the Amphibians and Reptiles of North Carolina website's page for this species:

http://herpsofnc.org/northern-watersnake/

If you would like to learn more about this and other snake species in your area, here is an excellent field guide:

Gibbons, Whit. (2017). Snakes Of The Eastern United States. Athens: University of Georgia Press.

I hope this answers your question, and thank you for contacting Ask an Expert.

Jim
answer.author: Jim Burke

qa_information.background info: They live in Western NC (elevation 3800 ft, wooded area) and the snake lives in the rock wall just outside their front door. The snake likes to sit in the sun in the driveway during the middle of the day, but occasionally leaves the yard and heads into the woods only to return to the rock wall later in the day.

title: Aspen fungal infection #809288
question:
Hello,

 Earlier this summer I purchased Aspen trees  that 1st inspection were healthy.  Then 1 or 2 of them developed abnormal findings on the leaves And these spread to all the trees.  I think it is blight or ink spot disease but I'm not 100% confident.  Could you please share your opinion based on the photos? I am planning on removing all leaves after they drop but would love to know how to prevent a recurrence next year including the type of fungicide that is most effective.

Thank you!
John

answer.response:
I am going to double check with my supervisor but it looks like marssonia leaf blight, a fungal disease.  Yes please remove all leaves as they fall.  I am attaching a file that will help you with treatment ideas.

 https://extension.colostate.edu/topic-areas/yard-garden/aspen-and-poplar-leaf-spots-2-920/
answer.author: Adams County

answer.response: Additionally, the damage around the edges appears consistent with scorch, a symptom of the plant not being able to bring enough water to the edges of the leaves, this can happen in heat events as well as potentially erratic or insufficient watering. Occasionally you'll see it as well when an area is over irrigated and the fine feeder roots have died off.
answer.author: Adams County

title: My apples have brown spots #596110
question:
I have a new apple tree (Stayman), that just produced a couple of applies in its first year.  They are full-sized, but they have brown blotches all over them.  I started noticing this about late July or so.  
What should I do so that this doesn't happen again next year? 
I've attached a couple of pictures.  
Thanks!

answer.response:
Hi- the brown blotches are sooty blotch and the small black spots are flyspeck. They are two fungal diseases that hit apples mid-season. The good news is that the symptoms don't extend beyond the peel.
https://extension.umd.edu/hgic/topics/apple-pear-diseases (number 5)
You can help prevent or limit many fruit diseases by maximizing air circulation through the canopy and around fruits and removing and disposing of all diseased leaves and fruits. Preventative fungicides can be sprayed next year but this takes persistence (multiple sprays on a schedule) and good spray coverage (upper and lower leaf surfaces). Also, it's best not to let new trees fruit for 2-3 years to help establish a strong root system.

VA Tech home fruit spray schedule: https://www.pubs.ext.vt.edu/content/dam/pubs_ext_vt_edu/456/456-018/ENTO-289C.pdf
Jon
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

answer.response:
Thank you Jon !  Now, a follow-up:  Looking at the charts, it appers that Mancozeb Flowable would be my best bet to control the sooty blotch, as well as the rust that my tree has.  How toxic is this stuff?  Is there a more "organic" spray that I should try first?  Any particular fungicide that you would recommend? 
-Dave
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Hi, this product carries a "caution" signal word (low toxicity) compared to products that carry the "warning" and "danger" signal words.
Here is the safety data sheet:
https://www.bonide.com/products/insect-and-disease-control/view/2011/fruit-tree-and-plant-guard-conc
Label: https://www.bonide.com/assets/Products/Labels/l861.pdf

Sulfur (considered an organic fungicide) is rated as "fair" in controlling these diseases. Sulfur can burn foliage, especially on warm days, so care must be used (always follow all label instructions).

Other effective synthetic fungicides: Captan (fungicide) carries a "Danger" signal word because of potential to cause eye damage.
https://www.bonide.com/assets/Products/Labels/l171.pdf

Bonide's "Fruit Tree & Plant Guard" contains a synthetic insecticide and two synthetic fungicides, and carries a "Caution" signal word.
 https://www.bonide.com/products/insect-and-disease-control/view/2011/fruit-tree-and-plant-guard-conc

Jon
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

answer.response: Thanks a log Jon.  This is all very helpful.  -dave

title: Potential disease on dwarf fir? #872631
question:
Some newly emerged needles on my abies balsamea ‘Piccolo’ appear to be shriveling up and falling off. The older branch is yellowing and appears to be dying back as well. See the attached images for details. The first image shows the trouble spot. The second image shows a different location on the plant where the described trouble might be starting. 
I planted the abies in a part sun location (protected from hot afternoon sun) and have watered sparingly to avoid over watering. Any ideas on what could be causing this?

answer.response:
Hi Erica and thanks for your question and great pictures of your balsam fir. When I enlarge the photos, there appears to be quite a bit of webbing on the affected areas. This is most likely spider mite damage. There are natural predators who will often take care of an infestation if you are patient enough to wait until they arrive.

You can also try spraying the area with insecticidal soap or a spray containing spinosad which is a natural substance that kills spider mites and other insects. Some years are more conducive to mite populations than others but the eggs overwinter in the soil, so it is worth keeping an eye on the infestation.

Good luck,
answer.author: Rhonda Frick-Wright

management instructions: wait for natural predators
spray with insecticidal soap
spray with spinosad

title: Bugs on my roses  #799241
question: Hello - I just noticed the attached bugs on my roses.  Something seems to be eating them.  I thought we likely had an issue with spidet mites.  Howevet. I would like to determine if these are beneficial insects or harmful. Thanks

answer.response:
Hello and thank you for your question. The pests on your roses are Japanese beetles. They are active from the end of June through mid-August and feed most heavily during the month of July. They enjoy a variety of plants, but roses are some of their favorites. They are not native, nor beneficial, bugs and will happily defoliate your roses if not controlled. That being said, roses can handle some defoliation and should flush out new growth mid to late summer. 

The best method of control is to half-fill a lidded jar with water and a touch of dish soap and shake until bubbly. Go out in the early morning or evening hours when the temperatures are coolest, as that is when the beetles will be the least active. Hold the jar underneath the branch where they are poised and tap them into the jar. They will release the branch/leaf and fall into the soapy water, getting trapped in the soap and ultimately drowning in the. water. Dispose of the water after they've died, as it can become quite smelly if left unattended. By taking care of the adult beetles you're not only helping the appearance of your plants but you'll also be limiting the number of beetles that will lay eggs in late summer, preventing turf-root eating grubs from hatching and turning into more beetles next season!

Let us know if we can answer any additional questions for you, and good luck with your beetle hunting!
answer.author: Katie Grant

management instructions: hand-pick beetles using a jar with soapy water
dispose of the water after they"ve died
take care of the adult beetles to limit the number of beetles that will lay eggs

title: Ants on Persimmon Tree #402214
question:
Hello,
I have a young persimmon tree and noticed a lot of big black ants on the tips of the leaves. They are mostly hanging out on every last leaf of each branch (farthest from the trunk). I'm not sure why. There are only leaves and some flowers. Should I be concerned? Some are around the flowers. There isn't much damage to the leaves. Several have holes and some look like they are eaten but the tree looks healthy and has grown a lot just over the spring. There are also tiny bugs too (maybe aphids, though they are black and I thought aphids were green). Will these ants or other insects cause damage in the long run? Will the flowers be ok? I saw a video of someone soaking cotton balls with sugar and borax but I don't like chemicals and wanted an organic garden. Thanks!

answer.response:
There are aphids of many different colors (including black) and ants are attracted to the sugary honeydew they produce when they feed on plant sap. Here is some information about aphids: https://extension.umd.edu/hgic/aphids-trees-and-shrubs. Ants are good predators and are not harmful to the plant. Often the early aphid populations will be taken care of by natural predators. The chewing of some of the leaves would have been caused by a different type of insect with chewing mouthparts (e.g., caterpillar), but overall, your tree looks very healthy. We do not recommend any type of treatment at this point. Continue to monitor for symptoms as the season progresses. Persimmons don't typically have many pests that affect the leaves, and your tree looks healthy overall.

CKC
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

title: Rhodedendron #860729
question: Hi there, My rhodey's do not look good! They have progressively gotten worse, with a few not looking promising at all. I only fertilized once last year so I am wondering if it's a pH problem and iron deficiency? One plant definitely looks like it has root rot (part of the root is hallowed out) but on other dying rhodedendrons I didn't find this problem.

answer.response:
Hi Nancy and thanks for your questions and pictures of your rhododendrons. Yes, they look stressed and there are a number of issues in your pictures. The yellowing leaves look like chlorosis which occurs when your soil pH is too high. Rhododendrons prefer 4.5-6.0 pH or pretty acidic. If you want to bring a sample for free testing tomorrow we are having our Garden Discovery Day at the Milwaukie Center on Rusk road from 9:00-12:00am.
Just put some soil from around the base of the plant in a plastic baggie and bring it to our desk.
https://clackamascountymastergardeners.org/garden-discovery-day/

I also see some fungal diseases which may be a sign of stress, either from lack of water last summer, too much heat or too cold this winter. I'll attach an article that explains the disease, but DON'T fertilize as they do not need or want nitrogen when they are stressed.
https://pnwhandbooks.org/plantdisease/host-disease/azalea-rhododendron-spp-powdery-mildew

And I think you are right about the root rot. The symptoms seem to match your pictures and the only management is to "remove the affected plants."
https://pnwhandbooks.org/plantdisease/host-disease/azalea-rhododendron-spp-cylindrocladium-blight-root-rot

So, to sum up, remove the plants with root rot. Don't plant another rhododendron in that place. Get a soil test for the plants with yellowing leaves and keep them watered every few weeks this summer when the weather gets hot and dry.

Hope this helps!
answer.author: Rhonda Frick-Wright

symptom description: part of the root is hollowed out
management instructions: Remove the plants with root rot.
Do not plant another rhododendron in the same place.
Get a soil test for the plants with yellowing leaves.
Keep the plants watered every few weeks during hot and dry weather.

The image shows a rhododendron plant with leaves that appear to be yellowing and some brown spots, which could indicate several potential issues such as nutrient deficiency, overwatering, underwatering, or pest infestation. Given the background information provided, the fact that the Question Asker only fertilized once last year suggests that there might be a nutrient deficiency, particularly nitrogen, which is crucial for leaf health.

Here's a recommended management strategy:

1. **Diagnosis**: 
   - Determine if the yellowing and browning are due to nutrient deficiencies by checking for signs of other issues like overwatering (roots may appear waterlogged) or underwatering (leaves may be dry and crispy).
   - Consider consulting with a local horticulturist or garden center expert who can provide more specific advice based on the exact symptoms observed.

2. **Fertilization**:
   - Since the plant was only fertilized once last year, it might benefit from a second application of a balanced fertilizer, especially one rich in nitrogen. Use a slow-release fertilizer to avoid excessive nutrient leaching, which can cause root burn.
   - Follow the instructions on the fertilizer package carefully, as too much nitrogen can also lead to poor root development and susceptibility to pests and diseases.

3. **Water Management**:
   - Ensure the rhododendron is neither overnor under-watered. These plants prefer consistently moist soil but not soggy conditions. Check the moisture level by sticking your finger into the soil about an inch deep; if it feels dry, it’s time to water.
   - Avoid overhead watering, which can lead to disease. Instead, water at the base of the plant and allow excess water to drain away to prevent root rot.

4. **Pruning**:
   - Remove any dead or yellowing leaves and branches to promote healthy growth and reduce the risk of disease spread.
   - Prune lightly to maintain the shape and structure of the plant without causing stress.

5. **Pest and Disease Control**:
   - Inspect the plant for signs of pests like spider mites or aphids, which can cause similar symptoms. If pests are present, treat them promptly with an appropriate pesticide.
   - Check for signs of disease such as rust or blight, which can affect the leaves and flowers. If you suspect a disease, consult a professional for diagnosis and treatment.

6. **Soil Amendments**:
   - Improve soil drainage if the plant seems to be sitting in waterlogged soil. Add perl

title: Spider #605431
question: I came upon this spider at a house I was cleaning today . I have never ever seen one like this . It is quite beautiful but scary too . Was wondering how abundant  these are ? Pumpkin spider?

answer.response:
Hello,

That  is a cross spider, Araneus diadematus  (Araneidae).  These are very common spiders.

The Cross Spider is among the largest orb spiders found in Michigan.  It was apparently introduced from Europe where it is known as the Garden Spider.  The body is brownish orange in color with distinctive white markings on the back of the abdomen.  The legs are relatively long and appear to be banded.  The abdomen above bears a median row of diamond-shaped silvery spots.  There is usually a pair of white spots at right angles to this median row, giving this group the form of a cross (hence the common name).  The Cross Spider occurs throughout the eastern US and other northern states west to Washington and Oregon.  It is found throughout Europe and much of Asia including Japan.  It is a very common spider in Michigan.  It feeds on flying and jumping insects including grasshoppers, flies, other spiders, and most bugs that become trapped in its large, orb-shaped web.  Webs can be found among shrubs and in wooded areas.  It is also found on herbaceous growth in marshy places and grass in meadows and pastures.  Females attach egg mass to a leaf, twig, or other support at the side of their webs.  Spiderlings usually stay in the egg sac until their first molt. These spiders are not particularly dangerous but they will bite if threatened or handled roughly. The occasionally find their way indoors during the fall of the year.
 
Regards,
Howard
answer.author: Howard Russell

title: Thistle weeds #262355
question:
Hello,
I have a thistle invasion in my backyard. They have these underground roots and grow back twice as bad when I dig them up with a shovel. They are also spreading into my lawn.

Any suggestions? I try not to use chemicals, but I'm willing to if it will make them go away.

Thanks! Melissa

answer.response: With thistle the key to control is persistence. Do not let the plant flower and go to seed. Clipping the tops whenever they appear will help starve the roots over time.  Here is a fact sheet that explains what herbicides to use: http://www.ext.colostate.edu/ptlk/2102.html
answer.author: Merrill Kingsbury

title: Sick Japanese Maple #763415
question: My dwarf/weeping Japanese Maple has brown curling leaves that are defoliating, with shit patches on new growth leaves that also quickly brown, curl and fall. Most branches remain supple and green, but some are dying from the ends.

answer.response:
Hi Peter, from the pictures you have attached, it looks like typical Verticillium Wilt.  You can google the Verticillium Wilt, edu and get a lot of fact sheets.  The one that comes up from time to time is on Japanese Maple.  From my experience with planting them in our garden, they seem rather susceptible to the verticillium wilt.  We have heavy clay soils and a higher pH ( on the alkaline side) and we can't seem to grow them at all.  They live for awhile and then slowly die.  

You could take a sample in to your Clermont County OSU Extension office during office hours and let them take a look at your FRESH sample.  You need to get a live branch that shows a dead portion as well as a live portion.  They need to see the transition area.  Also, the discoloration in the larger stems is an indicator of the verticillium wilt.  Most will discolor to a rust or brown streaking.  

What to do?  Seek out another plant from a different plant family.  You can't plant another Japanese maple in the spot as it will come down with the wilt.  Time to look at some of the fact sheets like the one from Missouri Botanical Garden.  They have lists of trees and shrubs that are very susceptible as well as resistant ones.  Then you will have to rethink your landscape in that area as it will limit your choices considerably.  Don
answer.author: Don Creamer - MGV

answer.response:
Thanks! I was afraid it might be fatal.

Good to know, though.

 

 

From: Ask Extension <askextension@eduworks.com>
Sent: Friday, July 23, 2021 5:40 PM
To: Peter Bronson <pbronson1253@gmail.com>
Subject: Re: Sick Japanese Maple (#0033346)
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Hi Peter,

My name is Ann Chanon and I am an Agriculture and Natural Resources Extension Educator.  I have a link to an MSU page that documents how Verticillium  discolors the vascular tissue.   https://www.canr.msu.edu/news/verticillium_wilt_refresher
This is very distinctive and diagnostic. Prune one of the effected branches and look for the discoloration. Individual plants very in their ability to withstand verticillium wilt and some years the symptoms are more pronounced that others.  I would also look carefully at the branches showing symptoms for other issues like branch cankers. Step 1 is to determine if this is the cause or if there are other issues. Step 2 judge the severity of the problem and consider management options.  You can contact your local Extension office at 513-732-7070 to have a conversation with your local ANR Educator Gigi Neal

Thank you for contacting OSU Extension
answer.author: Ann Chanon

answer.response:
Thanks, very helpful.

From: Ask Extension <askextension@eduworks.com>

answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Hi Peter,

I did some research in the scientific literature and contacted a few colleagues to help identify what might be good selections for the garden.
'Sargent Tina' might be a good choice  It gets 5' tall with about equal spread flowers are white and the fruit is bright red and about 0.25".  It is highly resistant to all the major apple diseases including fireblight and apple scab.
'Jewelberry' is somewhat large6-8' in height This selection has bright pink buds that open into pale pink flowers.  These fruit are 0.5".  This cultivar also has excellent disease resistance.
Pink Princess(TM) is an 8' plant with pink flowers, and is a red leaf form. The fruit are deep red 0.25" and it has excellent disease resistance.
There is a true weeping form 'Louisa' which is also reaches 10' in height.  It has pink flowers and dark green foliage.  This has yellow fruit 3/8".  It has excellent blight resistance but only rates a good for fireblight and cedar-apple rust resistance.

I hope that at least one of these might fit into your garden.

Thank you for contacting OSU Extension.  Please contact us if you have additional questions.
answer.author: Ann Chanon

title: Small spots on western redbud #729457
question: Hello! I planted a forest pansy redbud in my front yard less than a year ago. We had a very hot summer and I have noticed spots and all of the leaves. Any idea what it is or what I can do about it? Thanks!

answer.response: To find the most appropriate individual to answer your question, what county in Colorado do you reside?  Thanks! Ruth
answer.author: Ruth Willson

answer.response: Hi Ruth! Thanks for the reply! We are around Archuleta county. Our Hardiness zone is 7a  Thanks!
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Hello and thank you for your question. It looks like your redbud is experiencing Anthracnose or a leaf spot fungal disease. These are brought on by heat and dry stress to the tree, but usually won't kill your tree. As the leaves fall from the tree, rake them and dispose of them so they don't re-infect them next year. Fungicides are usually not effective on these diseases. Keep an eye on them next year, water appropriately (without over watering) and hopefully they will grow big and beautiful. If you do experience this next year, please bring a sample into the local office and I will help you determine a course of action. Look for full leaf development too.  

See this publication:  http://pods.dasnr.okstate.edu/docushare/dsweb/Get/Document-2831/EPP-7634web.pdf
answer.author: Robin Young

answer.response: Thank you so much!
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response: You are welcome!
answer.author: Robin Young

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows leaves of a western redbud (Cercis occidentalis) that appear to have some discoloration and spotting, which could be indicative of various issues such as disease or stress from environmental factors like heat or lack of water. Given that the tree was planted less than a year ago and experienced a very hot summer, it's possible that the tree may still be adjusting to its new environment.

Here are some recommended management strategies for the issue observed:

1. **Monitor Watering**: Ensure the tree receives adequate water, especially during dry spells. Western redbuds prefer moist soil but do not tolerate standing water. Consider setting up a drip irrigation system if necessary.

2. **Mulching**: Apply a layer of organic mulch around the base of the tree to help retain moisture and regulate soil temperature. Avoid piling mulch too close to the trunk to prevent stem rot.

3. **Pruning**: Remove any dead or damaged branches to promote healthy growth. This can also help reduce the risk of disease spread.

4. **Fertilization**: Use a slow-release, balanced fertilizer designed for trees. Over-fertilizing can cause root burn, especially in young plants.

5. **Pest Control**: Inspect the plant regularly for signs of pests. If pests are present, identify them and use appropriate chemical or biological controls. For small infestations, hand-picking can be effective.

6. **Disease Management**: If disease is suspected, consult with a local horticulturist or extension agent for specific recommendations. They can provide guidance on identifying the exact type of disease and the best treatment options, which may include fungicides or other treatments.

7. **Stress Reduction**: Provide additional shade if possible to protect the tree from direct sunlight during hot afternoons. Shade cloth can be used to moderate the light exposure.

By implementing these strategies, you can help the tree recover from the stress of recent conditions and improve its overall health.

title: New weed showing up this year #423170
question: This weed just showed up this year.  It appears to be spreading over my lawn.  When it dies, there's only earth around it.  Do I have to worry about it taking over everything?  And, if so, how do I get rid of it given that deer forage on the lawn?

answer.response:
It appears that the weeds in the pictures are broadleaf. Products that are available to homeowners for broadleaf weed control in lawns usually contain 2,4-D, which is a selective herbicide that is used to kill broadleaf plants that are growing in grass. 

Another product that can be used is another selective broadleaf herbicide, Crossbow, is a combination of 2,4-D and triclopyr. 

Always read and follow the product label when handling and using herbicides. Be cautious about using a broadleaf herbicide in areas that may have desirable broadleaf plant roots growing beneath the grass. Desirable plants have been damaged from the use of weed-n-weed in these situations. Read the label carefully to see how it will affect native wildlife. I can find nothing on an internet search that says it is harmful to wildlife except to aquatic species. 

Improving the growing conditions for your lawn can help reduce weed infestations. Improving drainage and periodic aeration of clay or compacted soils, increasing the soil pH by using lime and keeping your lawn healthy can help reduce future weeds. Hand removal is also possible, but generally not feasible with heavy infestations. Even if you kill all of the weeds, new weeds often germinate in bare areas within the lawn. Reseeding bare areas can help provide competition against the weeds.

Thanks for using Ask an Expert
answer.author: Sharon May

answer.response: Thank you for your prompt response. Can you tell me,  if I do nothing, will this take over my yard?
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
I'm having difficulty identifying the weed, but I can make some suggestions. The weed looks like it will spread. One way to avoid herbicides is to pour boiling water over the weeds. Be careful, as the hot water will kill anything it touches. If the weed is an annual it will die quickly. If it is a perennial it may take several treatments. Or try digging the patch out by hand, getting as much of the plants roots and runners as you can. Then match the soil level to the ground around it with fine, new soil and reseed.
The best defense against lawn weeds is a healthy, thick lawn. Keep the areas around the weeds fertilized, mowed to proper height, and watered. The following lawn care guide https://catalog.extension.oregonstate.edu/sites/catalog/files/project/pdf/ec1521.pdf can help you find the best way to prevent the spread and new infestations and give you a healthy lawn that keeps weed seeds from germinating.
Ultimately, an herbicide is the most convenient and effective way to kill broadleaf weeds, followed by excellent lawn care.
Thanks for your follow up question.
answer.author: Sharon May

answer.response: Sharon, I believe it may be prunella vulgaris. Since my lawn is most definitely not of the manicured variety, and is rather large, I guess I will have to let this herb have it's way. I think the most disturbing thing it that when it dies, it turns black and there doesn't seem to have anything else growing near them. And there are significant patches of it in progress. I appreciate your help. Thanks.
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
It is actually considered a medicinal plant and can be purchased at nurseries. But that doesn't help when it is growing where it is not wanted--the definition of a weed. I thought you might be interested in learning more about it https://plants.usda.gov/factsheet/pdf/fs_prvul2.pdf
There is a trend to replace grassy groundcovers with low growing native plants and groundcovers, they need less care and water. So spreading might not be so bad.
answer.author: Sharon May

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a patch of Prunella vulgaris, also known as自我繁殖草 (self-seeding grass) or自我繁殖草 (self-seeding plant), which is a perennial weed that can spread rapidly in lawns and other disturbed areas. The management strategy for this weed can be approached from several angles:

### Mechanical Control:
1. **Manual Removal**: Regularly pull the weeds by hand, especially when they are young and before they have set seed. Be sure to remove the entire taproot to prevent regrowth.
2. **Mowing**: Frequent mowing can help control the spread of the weed by preventing it from setting seeds and allowing grass to compete more effectively.

### Chemical Control:
1. **Herbicides**: Use selective herbicides specifically designed for broadleaf weeds like Prunella. Common active ingredients include imazapyr (e.g., Arsenal®) or bentazon (e.g., Prowl®). Apply these chemicals according to the label instructions, ensuring that you do not apply them during flowering or seed set to avoid harming beneficial insects or other desirable plants.
2. **Pre-emergent Herbicides**: Apply pre-emergent herbicides to prevent the germination of seeds in the soil. These can be effective in controlling future infestations but should be used with caution to avoid affecting desired grass species.

### Cultural Control:
1. **Healthy Lawn**: A healthy, well-maintained lawn can outcompete weeds. Ensure your lawn receives proper watering, fertilization, and mowing practices.
2. **Mulching**: Applying a layer of mulch around trees and shrubs can help suppress weed growth by reducing light availability to the seeds.

### Integrated Pest Management (IPM):
1. **Monitor Regularly**: Keep an eye on the lawn for signs of weed invasion and act promptly. Early detection is key to effective control.
2. **Biological Control**: Investigate if there are biological controls available for Prunella vulgaris. Some natural predators may help reduce populations over time.

### Prevention:
1. **Seeds and Soil**: Avoid introducing new seeds into your lawn by cleaning garden tools and equipment after use. Also, check and clean your lawn mower blades before mowing.
2. **Avoid Disturbance**: Minimize disturbances in your lawn to prevent seeds from germinating and establishing themselves.

By combining mechanical, chemical, and cultural methods, along with regular monitoring and prevention strategies, you can effectively manage the spread of Prunella vulgaris in your lawn. Always

title: Oak trees turning white, dying limbs #681377
question: We have a couple of oak trees on our property, a couple of acres apart that seem to be slowly turning white.  One of them has bark falling off and under a piece of the bark, there was a tiny matte blue insect the size of a sesame seed.  Not sure if there is a connection as there was only one.  I am concerned as we don't want to loose trees.  Do you have any ideas?

answer.response:
Howdy, and thank you for your inquiry. The decay exhibited from this tree appears to be associated with fungal infection hypoxylon canker; info from AgriLife Extension - https://agrilifeextension.tamu.edu/library/landscaping/hypoxylon-canker-of-oaks/. The article reviews biology of the pathogen, environmental stressors that potentially lead to infection, and recommendations for maintenance. Depending on the severity of infection, the best remedy is preventative maintenance (improved soil aeration, mulching, etc), and you may have to selectively prune as applicable.

I also recommend to consult with an arborist certified by the International Society for Arboriculture. There is a search engine that can provide focus to your search for a certified arborist. Browse online to the International Society of Arboriculture: http://www.isa-arbor.com/findanarborist/arboristsearch.aspx. Choose the image "Find an Arborist". You will be forwarded to a webpage to search by country (USA); you will then be forwarded to a page to further refine your search by choosing your postal code. I recommend to place your search within a 25 or 50 mile radius. The programmed search engine will then shuttle you to a page with a list of arborists; note to always look for their credential as a certified arborist.

Thank you again and feel free to email me directly if I can be of further service. Stephen
answer.author: Stephen Brueggerhoff

mulching
selectively prune as applicable

title: Ailing Bishop's Weed #269526
question: My decorative Bishop's Weed that was so lush and full only weeks ago, is suddenly turning brown and looks decidedly unhealthy.  See the attached photo.  Any suggestions?

1.response:
Bishop's weed is susceptible to several leaf spot diseases and it is not uncommon for the plant to display symptoms in late summer.  You will notice lots of new growth under the affected foliage, so the plant is in no danger of annhilation. 
Bishop's weed is an invasive plant that is usually considered to be a nuisance, and most of our queries deal with it's eradication.
It is not effective to treat the plants once the symptoms appear.  Fungal diseases can only be prevented by spraying with a fungicide before any symptoms appear and continuing the spray schedule every 10 days throughout the season.
LS

title: Diseased Foliage #861476
question:
We’ve been in this house for 3 years. The property was a 20 year rental and MUCH neglected. I understand the longest owner had loved gardening. I can see remnants of her handiwork. Her husband hauled in tons of granite from PA. To make garden walls.

My chief complaint is that every new shrub I put in, comes down with spotted leaves. I'm sure it's spread from the very infected, OLD Mountain Laurels in the back yard. I’m not that surprised that plants are infected in the back yard. What is surprising is the plants in the front yard, far from the back, are getting infected as well. I don't what to do b/c almost every new thing is getting spots and failing to thrive. 

Please advise on what the disease might be and any solutions(or resistant plant suggestions) you might have.

Thanks for any info you can give.

answer.response:
Wow. How fortunate to inherit granite walls and some nice plants in your landscape!
While it may seem that your Mountain Laurel are responsible, it is not likely. There are multiple types of leaf spot pathogens and it's unlikely that the spots on other plants are all the same.

 Many plants can get leaf spot diseases under the right circumstances but it's important to know that they are mainly cosmetic and they are seldom harmful. 

Additionally, some shrubs are just more prone to regularly get spotty leaves in our climate.
Wet spring weather commonly signals a season that will have more disease, but there are also things that you can do to lessen future outbreaks by doing what you can to encourage better airflow and drier leaves (water at base not with sprinkling/wetting leaves so that the leaves don't stay wet for long periods of time) and raking up and disposing of fallen diseased leaves in the trash. 
This page will tell you more: 
https://extension.umd.edu/resource/fungal-leaf-spots-shrubs/

Leaf spots don't tend to cause failure to thrive unless they're causing lots of leaf drop, so if plants aren't thriving there could something else might be going on related to site conditions-  such as wrong plant in the wrong place, planting too deeply, too much or too little water, etc.
If you can share specific plants you are worried about we can take a look and advise.


Christine
answer.author: Christine McComas

management instructions: encourage better airflow
water at base to keep leaves dry
rake up and dispose of fallen diseased leaves

title: Barberry Spotting  #763586
question:
Hi, 

I planted 6 mini maroon Barberry shrubs mid-May of this year.  Two of the shrubs now have these spots appearing.  The leaves that have the spotting either turn yellow or bright red.  Can you help me identify what is happening and how to fix it?

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The plant in the image appears to be American Burnweed (Chenopodium album), which can indeed become invasive if not managed properly. Here are some recommended strategies for managing American Burnweed:

1. **Physical Removal**: This is often the most effective method for controlling small infestations. Manual pulling or digging is effective when the plant is young and has not yet set seed. Be sure to remove the entire taproot to prevent regrowth.

2. **Cultural Practices**: Regular mowing and maintaining healthy competition from other plants can help prevent the spread of American Burnweed by reducing its ability to establish itself in disturbed areas.

3. **Herbicides**: If physical removal is impractical, herbicides like glyphosate (Roundup) or dicamba can be used. It's important to apply these chemicals carefully, following the label instructions to avoid harming desirable plants and to ensure effectiveness.

4. **Biological Control**: While there are no known biological controls for American Burnweed, research is ongoing to identify potential natural enemies.

5. **Preventive Measures**: If you're planting seeds in your garden, consider using a seed mix that is known to contain no invasive species. Regular monitoring and quick intervention can help prevent small infestations from becoming larger problems.

6. **Community Efforts**: If you suspect American Burnweed has spread beyond your property, it's beneficial to report sightings to local conservation organizations or government agencies responsible for managing invasive species.

By combining these strategies, you can effectively manage the presence of American Burnweed in your area. Always prioritize safety when using chemical controls and consult with local experts for tailored advice on your specific situation.

On Apr 24, 2022, at 9:47 AM, Ask Extension <askextension@eduworks.com> wrote:

5.author: The Question Asker

6.response:
Hello Denise,

Based on the leaf litter (oak leaves) that is on the ground at the base of the trees and the bark on the trees - it looks like an oak tree in the black oak family. And also based on what I see in your images this looks like Bacterial Wetwood Or Slime Flux on these trees

What causes Bacterial Wetwood? Bacterial wetwood is a bacterial infection that causes a profuse flow (flux) of sap from trunk wounds or pruning cuts. It is characterized by light or dark-colored vertical streaks of residue on tree bark. The infection, also known as slime flux, causes the leaves of the upper crown to wilt and drop prematurely, as well as potentially kill tree branches. A foul-smelling sap that is toxic to vegetation and ground cover is often seen bubbling from an infected tree.

Bacterial Wetwood Or Slime Flux: Many mature trees, including elms, oak, tulip poplar, and maple, exhibit large light or dark vertical streaks on their trunks. These vertical streaks result from a slimy liquid oozing out of cracks or wounds and running down the bark called 'slime flux'. Sometimes this liquid is very abundant and foul-smelling. If an affected tree is cut down, the heartwood is darker in color than the surrounding wood, thus the name 'wetwood'. Although the symptoms are unsightly, little damage is done to the tree in most situations. However, if affected trees are under severe stress from other factors such as soil compaction, wetwood bacteria can move into the sapwood and cause leaf yellowing, wilting, and branch dieback.

Symptoms and Signs

- Light or dark streaks on the bark originate at a crack or wound and run vertically down the trunk

- Slimy, sometimes foul-smelling liquid bubbles out of the tree and runs down the trunk

- Heartwood deep in the interior of the tree is much darker than surrounding sapwood.

Cause and Effects

Bacteria, commonly found in soil and water, take up residence in young trees or gain entrance to older trees through wounds. The bacteria, including species of Clostridium, Bacillus, Enterobacter, Klebsiella, and Pseudomonas, grow within the tree using the sap as a nutrient source. As the sap is used, oxygen in the heartwood is depleted (creating anaerobic conditions), methane is produced, the pH of the sap is increased (pH 6 in healthy trees to pH 7 to 8 in wetwood), and a high pressure develops in the wood (60 psi in affected trees vs. 5-10 psi in wetwood-free trees). The resulting environment greatly inhibits the growth of fungi that can cause interior rots. The liquid kills grass and other herbaceous plants that it contacts at the base of the tree. The wood of affected trees has greatly reduced value as lumber because of the unsightly discoloration. Affected wood dries much more slowly than wood taken from wetwood-free trees.

Management

- Avoid wounding the tree.

- Protect the tree from other stresses, especially soil compaction from vehicles or pedestrians.

Many years ago, it was thought that the pressure within the tree should be relieved. Holes were drilled into the trunks of affected trees and pipes were inserted to allow the liquid and gases to escape. This is no longer recommended because 1) affected trees generally survive well without any treatment and 2) drilling holes in the tree creates yet another place where slime oozes out. There is no preventive treatment or way to eliminate wetwood from an affected tree. Properly prune trees to promote rapid closure of pruning wounds and avoid bacterial colonization if wetwood is a concern. Reference: Bacterial Wetwood Or Slime Flux (Penn State) at this link: https://extension.psu.edu/bacterial-wetwood-or-slime-flux

There are better pictures of Bacterial Wetwood Or Slime Flux (Univ of Mass) at this link: https://ag.umass.edu/landscape/fact-sheets/wetwood-slime-flux

I highly recommend you get a confirmed diagnosis from the MSU Plant & Pest Diagnostics lab

MSU Plant & Pest Diagnostics is no longer accepting walk-in consultations at this time. They are open for business for all samples that are dropped off or mailed to the lab. They encourage clients to email digital images to accompany the physical samples when submitting plant samples. Images can be sent to pestid@msu.edu. 

I would e-mail the lab the same images and send an image of the upper canopy of the tree if it has leaves - MAKE SURE IN THAT E-MAIL YOU INCLUDE YOUR NAME, ADDRESS, AND PHONE NUMBER!!

THE LAB WILL LET YOU KNOW IF A SAMPLE NEEDS TO BE SENT - There is a $20-25 dollar fee (if they need a sample sent).

PLEASE READ BELOW ON PREPARING YOUR SAMPLE

From the lab: Please do not ship samples on Fridays. Due to the current COVID-19 circumstances, please allow additional processing time. They thank you for your patience and understanding.

Every sample must be accompanied by a completed submission form. Please place the form in a separate resealable bag to prevent it from getting damp or soiled.

The form is at this link:
https://www.canr.msu.edu/pestid/uploads/files/MSU-DS-Form-012-001-version6.0.pdf

Complete details of submitting a sample are at this link: https://www.canr.msu.edu/pestid/submit-samples/

Another option would be to hire an arborist to examine these trees (oak) - To Find an Arborist click on this link: https://www.treesaregood.org/findanarborist/arboristsearch

Hope this helps - Please let me know if you have any other questions - Thanks!!

title: maple planted 1 1/2 Years sgo #442906
question:
What could this discoloration be on our autumn blaze maple planted sept 2016? Is this something to be concerned about?
Thank you!
Lonnie

answer.response:
Dear Lonnie,
It looks like your maple has had some minor mechanical damage to the trunk. Maples 'bleed' in the spring as they get ready to flower. The sap begins to rise and if there is a wound is runs out of the wounded bark. This phenomenon has been exploited for centuries and is why we are able to have maple syrup on our pancakes. The good news is your tree will be fine. You may want to wash the sap off of the bark this spring so it doesn't attract wasps.
answer.author: Curtis Utley

management instructions: Wash the sap off of the bark this spring so it doesn"t attract wasps.

title: Cut-leaf Maple Infestation #854529
question:
Hello -

We have an infestation on two decades old cut-leaf Japanese maples at our church.  There are small white encasements/nodules on smaller stems of the trees (pic attached), and there are numerous small fist-sized webs on leaves at the end of the branches.  When I pick one of the white masses off and turn it over, I see a red spec on the bottom side of the mass.  Could these be spider mites?  I don't observe any insects directly in the webs themselves.  I have been removing these white masses by hand but am probably not finding all of them.  I have Neem Oil if that is an appropriate treatment for these insects.

Thank you!

1.response:
The white blobs are a sap sucking insect called scale, that spend most of their lives still and hidden beneath waxy or cottony covers. 

There are many types, but in this case, it looks like Indian Wax Scale. The waxy covering protects the insect and eggs laid beneath, which you saw.  If you only have a small amount, you can continue to scrape off the ones you have. 
Otherwise, the treatment timing is once eggs hatch and crawlers begin moving, which can be tricky to identify.
Here is our page on this scale: 
https://extension.umd.edu/resource/indian-wax-scale

The webbing you see are spider-related, and they are great to have in the garden and should be conserved. They will die off for the year with our frosts and cold weather.


Christine
1.author: Christine McComas

title: Rhododendron #646155
question: One of our rhododendrons has some yellow/orange leaves with spots in some areas. Should I be worried about this and should I be taking some action to avoid losing it?

answer.response:
Thank you for the image.
Your rhododendron was damaged during the recent hot spells. It needs water.
Water the soil underneath the canopy and outward a foot or so beyond the dripline (ends of the branches). After watering well, probe with a trowel to determine if soil is well-moistened to at least 8 inches deep. If not, water more.
The soil is likely very dry. If so, the water will run off before the the roots are well-moistened. In that case, use several on-off cycles to add sufficient water.
Also add an organic mulch of bark chips to 3 inches deep. Again, extend beyond the dripline. Doing so will help decrease water loss from the soil and will also help the plants below the shrub.

Water the shrub every 3 to 4 weeks through the dry months. Watering the lawn isn't adequate for rhododendrons.
answer.author: Jean R. Natter

management instructions: Water the soil underneath the canopy and outward a foot or so beyond the dripline.
Add an organic mulch of bark chips to 3 inches deep.
Water the shrub every 3 to 4 weeks through the dry months.

title: Large bee hive fell from a tree this AM #848723
question:
Can you id type of bee or wasp by appearance of hive and pictures- not sure if honey bees etc
What to do?

answer.response:
This is a Baldfaced Hornet nest, a native social wasp found throughout our region. Weather or wildlife might have knocked it down, and we would not expect the wasps to rebuild since these colonies die out by the end of autumn anyway. Even if it hadn't fallen, nests are not re-used from year to year. (Only new queens survive the winter; they disperse away from the nest of their birth and overwinter by themselves in a sheltered location; each of those females will start a new nest by herself in spring.) If any wasps remain with this nest after it fell, they may be defensive and likely to sting intruders that come too close (or if someone runs a lawn mower too close, as the vibrations may alarm them), but otherwise the nest is harmless if ignored and given a wide berth. Wildlife such as birds, perhaps skunks, squirrels, etc., may also tear into its paper-like covering to eat any immature wasps or even the adults themselves; sometimes adult hornets are also preyed-upon by other hornets (such as European Hornets). It's possible this is an old nest from last year and as such is already abandoned...it's hard to tell, since they tend to disintegrate on their own during winter and the following year, so maybe that's why it fell; if that's the case, it should be unused and able to be removed.

Miri
answer.author: Mira Talabac

management instructions: ignore and give a wide berth
remove if old and abandoned

title: Stem Canker in 20 rose bushes #635889
question:
Hi, Help!  I have 20 rose bushes with stem canker disease I believe from my research.
My question is if i dig them out and replace the soil, can i replant more? Or will they also become diseased?
Thanks in advance

1.response:
Hello,

It should not be necessary to remove soil, or even the whole plant if it still has clean growth on it.  To correctly prune out infected canes: “When pruning out cankerous parts of stems, cut back to a strongly growing shoot or branch at least 2 to 3 inches below the infected portion. Before each pruning cut, dip the shears in a disinfectant solution of 70 percent rubbing alcohol, or liquid household bleach (1 part of bleach to 9 parts of water).”

Here is a complete discussion of canker diseases on roses, along with notes on which species are most resistant, good cultural practices to minimize the disease.

https://ipm.illinois.edu/diseases/rpds/626.pdf

With 20 roses perhaps they are too crowded. So removing every other one may space them out for better air circulation. Clean up all debris, including mulch, and replace with fresh mulch keeping mulch pulled back from stems. Water from below. Be sure to disinfect all tools as noted above, and work only when plants are dry. I hope this helps your roses recover.
1.author: Laura Sheffer

2.response:
That’s great news! 2 things though. They are cankerous all the way down. I think what I did was at dyed black mulch last year too thick and too late. Trapped moisture? So should I still cut them entirely back. Remove the mulch and hope for the best this season? Or since there is no clean growth should I start over. I hear you about the disinfectant and crowding. I inherited them with the house so they been here several years and were wonderful blooms before I got my black thumb on them :)
thanks in advance 
Kathleen
2.author: The Question Asker

3.response:
I would cut them back with a clean pruner as far down as you can, the crown of the plant, where it meets the roots, should still sprout. Treat new growth with a fungicide for roses or any “3 in 1” rose product, to help stop new disease on tender growth. Retreat them at least once more according to what the label says on your product.Then see how they do. You can always remove the ones that don’t recover later this spring to early summer.  Here are the basics, should you need a care reference- http://rocklandcce.org/resources/rose-care

If the mulch is fresh this season, just pull it back about 4-5 inches from the stems..
3.author: Laura Sheffer

4.response: Got it. Thank you so much Laura! For quick responses as well.
4.author: The Question Asker

title: Boxwood Growth #630509
question: I have a boxwood hedge surrounding my front yard. Over winter, many of the leaves turned an orangeish hue. Most of the bushes have rebounded with healthy new growth, but during a strong spring rain, I found a white, snowlike substance on the leaves. What is this? Are my bushes ill and how do I best care for my boxwoods?

answer.response:
Thank you for the image.

Your hedge is not sick. It is being attacked by small sucking insect pests -- boxwood psyllids, Psylla buxi.

The while flecks are evidence of the psyllid immatures which are currently feeding on the leaf buds. The nymphs (youngsters) are covered with white waxy filaments. They're currently active, feeding on the buds, with the result that those leaves become cup-shaped.

The adults are very small, winged insects which are difficult to see.  Adults will be active in late May when they lay eggs for the next generation.

You have several choices for management, among them these:- If the infestation is minor, ignore it.
- Consider a periodic harsh water spray to "tidy" the shrub a bit by washing off the white curly strands of honeydew (excrement).
- Prune off infested branches with an annual shearing before mid-May. Collect and discard the trimmings.- Effective sprays include a commercial insecticidal soap and a summer horticultural oil, repeat as needed, according to the package label.
See "Boxwood Psyllid" -- https://entomology.ca.uky.edu/ef454.
Boxwoods are hardy plants that can survive in full sun or shade. They do best with summer irrigation, once every 3 to 4 weeks.
answer.author: Jean R. Natter

image description: white, snowlike substance on the leaves
management instructions: ignore if infestation is minor
use harsh water spray to wash off honeydew
prune off infested branches before mid-May
use insecticidal soap or summer horticultural oil

title: Aster leaf problem. #848131
question:
Hi,
    I received and planted 2 big-leaf asters about 10 days ago.  Today I noticed a problem with the leaves--see attached photos.  I am thinking it might be downy mildew.  Can you confirm this or give an alternative diagnosis, please

answer.response:
Hi, I received and planted 2 big-leaf asters about 10 days ago. Today I noticed a problem with the leaves--see attached photos. I am thinking it might be downy mildew. Can you confirm this or give an alternative diagnosis, please

Hi, 

Thank you for contacting Master Gardeners. It certainly looks like powdery mildew and perhaps insect damage as well. Frustrating to have this after just 10 days, but the the weather, at least in Franklin County, is part of the problem. 

Powdery mildew fungi thrive with cool, humid nights that stimulate spore production and warm (70 to 80 F), dry days that allow for spore spread. Powdery mildew fungi produce a mat of fungal growth on the surface of the plant.

To correct:

Plant in sunny areas as much as possible, provide good air circulation, and avoid applying excess fertilizer.

If powdery mildew is noticed on a few leaves, simply removing them will help with control. At the end of the growing season, prune out infected stems and remove fallen leaves, which can serve as a source of further infection.

Powdery mildew can be mitigated by spraying the plant's foliage with either baking soda or milk, and both methods are effective. Nonetheless, a 2007 study found foliar milk sprays were more effective than baking soda in preventing powdery mildew.

The leaves also look like there is insect damage. Take a close look on the underneath of the leaves. Many insects feed on the aster foliage, including leaf beetles, the larvae of leaf-mining flies and fruit flies, plant bugs, stink bugs, lace bugs, aphids, leafhoppers, and the caterpillars of several butterfly and moth species.Japanese beetles seem to have invaded Ohio recently. Look for them as well.

If you see Japanese beetles tip them off the plant into a small container of water and suffocate them and if you find other any insects mix a quart of water with a teaspoon of dish soap. Once you mix the water with dish soap, the least “touchy” solution is to pour the soapy water into a spray bottle and spray the beetles on your affected plants or use insecticidal soap. Do this early in the day not hot sunshine.

Resources:

https://extension.umn.edu/plant-diseases/powdery-mildew-flower-gardenhttps://hgic.clemson.edu/factsheet/powdery-mildew/
answer.author: Sandy Murray

answer.response:
Powdery or downy mildew  (not that it affects treatment)?

Kathy

On Sep 1, 2023, at 8:47 PM, Ask Extension <ask@extension.org> wrote:

﻿
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Yours appears to be powdery mildew.

Downy mildew initially presents as an oily spot on the leaves. Powdery mildew looks like flour dusted on the surface of leaves.


Powdery or downy mildew (not that it affects treatment)?

Kathy
On Sep 1, 2023, at 8:47 PM, Ask Extension <ask@extension.org> wrote:
 The distinction is important if later chemical treatment is necessary. At this point a cultural intervention seems adequate based on the level of damage and the time of year. While the cultural and sanitation practices used to prevent and minimize spread of the pathogens are similar, the chemistry used to manage the two types of mildews differ,

Hi Kathy,

This is powdery mildew.

The two diseases share the name “mildew”, but they are very different. Powdery mildew infections reduce plant aesthetics and value but usually do not result in plant death.

In contrast, downy mildew infections often result in plant death as well as the loss of aesthetics.

Contrary to popular belief, downy mildews are not fungi and powdery mildews are caused by true fungi.

Please feel free to contact me if you have more questions or concerns.
answer.author: Sandy Murray

Provide good air circulation
Avoid applying excess fertilizer
Remove infected leaves
Prune out infected stems at the end of the growing season
Remove fallen leaves
Spray foliage with baking soda or milk
Use soapy water to kill insects

title: Fig leaves browning #434865
question:
Hello, we have a fig tree which we have had in the ground for the better part of a year. It has seemed to be happy and healthy, but within the last month, I noticed the leaves started to spot, then brown and a cluster of them seem to be wilting. 

The first two pictures are from almost a month ago. The last one is from this past week.

Please let me know if this is something to worry about and if there is a remedy.

answer.response:
Thank you for your question about your fig tree.  I think you have two things going on here, based on your great photos!  First, the 'drooping' is probably a lack of water for your plant, which can require deep but infrequent watering during droughts.  Using a water probe to test how wet your soil is will help you assess whether this plant (and others--inside and out--need water.)  Watering longer less frequently (2 - 3 times a week, depending on precipitation) is better than a small amount every day.

The browning between the veins of the leaves, though, would appear to be a different issue.  After reviewing several Extension articles with photos with similarities and this nutrient disorder article, I think your soil (and therefore your plant) lacks potassium, one of the "big three" nutrients that plants need.  (The other two are nitrogen and phosphorus.  On a fertilizer label, the numbers indicate the percentage--by weight--of nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium, in that order.  That's what "10-10-10" means, for example.)

Figs, when planted outside in our climate, are deciduous.  They lose their leaves in the winter.  So your plant is going to be without leaves soon anyway.  I suggest you use the winter to add lots of well-composted organic material to the soil, and it will begin to supply your plant with these necessary 'foods' as it is incorporated over the winter.  And you can 'dress' your plant in the spring with more well-composted material, which will continue to feed it throughout the growing season.  Here's a link to a great Extension article about how this all works in the garden.

I hope this information is helpful.  Good luck!
answer.author: Kristena LaMar

qa_information.disease/issue identification: lack of water and potassium deficiency
management instructions: Water deeply but infrequently during droughts.
Use a water probe to test soil moisture.
Add well-composted organic material to the soil during winter.
Dress the plant with more well-composted material in the spring.
qa_information.background info: The fig tree has been in the ground for almost a year and was previously happy and healthy.

title: What is this bug??? #772325
question:
Hello,
I have started seeing these bugs all over my house. Most of them are linked in pairs. I have seen them about the same time each year. They go away after 4 to 5 days, but I would like to know what they are, where they are coming from, and to get rid of them. I spray the exterior sides of the house every year in the early summer.

1.response:
Hi Eldo,

That is a winged, reproductive, subterranean termite (Reticulitermes sp.) after it has dropped its wings. Here is a photo of similar Reticulitermes specimen for comparison...
https://bugguide.net/node/view/1964822

I have seen the winged forms of these termites flying in Corvallis in the last week or two, so it seems like this is a good time of year for them to swarm. The ones you see that are linked in pairs are mating and preparing for the females to start new colonies. These types of termites nest in the soil and feed on wood in contact with the soil, but can secondarily invade structural wood in buildings and can be quite damaging. Since you are consistently seeing lots of these termites on your house year after year, it might be good to err on the side of caution and have a knowledgeable, licensed pest control operator do a termite inspection. Hopefully, you don't have an infestation in the wood of your house, and the ones you are seeing are just reproductive termites from surrounding colonies in the soil. But if you do have an infestation, it would be a good idea to take care of it to protect your home.

Best wishes!
1.author: William Gerth

take care of infestation to protect home
