title: Top growth yellow on tomato plant  #872405
question: My tomato plants have turned yellow only on the top growth and appear to have stopped growing.  No sign of bugs.  Bottom leaves look normal. How can I treat this please?

answer.response:
The top new leaves on the main stem turned yellow, then some brown edges, now curling with no visible new growth

I tried neem oil first.  Then add some fertilizer and then a week later sprayed with Dacon as I saw no evidence of bugs.  I. Last week there has been no new growth.  Impacting almost all of the tomato plants in the garden
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Your tomatoes are affected by early blight. Early blight is a fungal disease caused by the fungus Alternaria linariae. This is a common foliar disease of tomato plants that can result in defoliation and reduced yields. The fungus overwinters in soil and on plant debris. It can also be transmitted on seeds and transplants. Early blight is typically splashed by rainfall onto lower leaves early in the season.


To help control early blight the following points may help


  • Provide adequate spacing to increase air circulation and remove all suckers that emerge from the plant base
  • Keep plants well mulched to minimize soil splashing
  • Use drip irrigation instead of overhead watering if possible. If not possible, water at the base of the plant
  • Do not work around the plants when they are wet
  • Remove infected leaves during the growing season. Then remove and destroy infected plants at the end of the growing season
  • Rotate your vegetables so that you are not planting members of the squash family in the same location
  • Several fungicides are registered for use against Early Blight. Preventative sprays are effective but are only necessary in areas with a history of Early Blight. Make sure that you read and follow the manufacturers’ directions carefully.

The following article contains more information on early blight: Early blight in tomato and potato | UMN Extension


Thank you for your question and have a great gardening experience.
answer.author: Henry Knoch

symptom description: brown edges on top new leaves
management instructions: Provide adequate spacing to increase air circulation.
Remove all suckers that emerge from the plant base.
Keep plants well mulched to minimize soil splashing.
Use drip irrigation instead of overhead watering if possible.
Remove infected leaves during the growing season.
Remove and destroy infected plants at the end of the growing season.
Rotate your vegetables to avoid planting members of the squash family in the same location.
Apply preventative fungicide sprays in areas with a history of Early Blight.

title:
Hello

I live in a subu... #156922
question:
Hello

I live in a suburb South Australia. (We have just entered Spring from a rather wet Winter).  
I purchased a Native Frangipani shrub a few months ago. It has grown to 3 feet high. It has received regular natural watering from the past winter rainfall) & is in a position of medium sunlight.The plant is fertilized occasionally
Problem : In the last month 50% of the leaves have become holey & damaged (please see attached photo). I have checked the foliage & there are no signs of insects or disease.

Thank you - I would very much appreciate any advice.
Regards
Peter

1.response: How often are you fertilizing the plant? From your description, it looks like you have done it a couple of times. The plant does not need too much fertilizing. What you have looks like salt injury on the leaves- probably due to too much salt in the growing media. Do a soil test and see what the analysis says. Leach the soil/media around the plant with plenty of water (isf the tests show high salts or high EC) while making sure that you are not overwatering. Frangipani is hardy and stores water in its stem and should not be overwatered..
1.author: Rose Ogutu

symptom description: 50% of the leaves have become holey
management instructions: Do a soil test to check for high salts or high EC.
Leach the soil/media around the plant with plenty of water if the tests show high salts or high EC.
Avoid overwatering.

title: Flower identification #120727
question: I have this flower that comes up every spring at the same time as my crocuses.  It was in the middle of the yard when we bought our house and I successfully transplanted it to a partially shady spot.  It only grows a few inches tall about like grape hyacinths.  Can you please tell me what it is?

1.response: This plant is commonly known as squill.  I am pretty certain it is a Puschkinia spp.  They are a good plant for a drought resistant or water-wise garden due to the fact that, like other bulbs, they use water when it is readily available in the spring months.  They are a great little plant, like the grape hyacinth, that can be naturalized in the lawn and mowed after they finish their blooming season.  Enjoy their bright little flowers early each year.
1.author: Donna Hoffman

title: Sod Worms #795805
question:
Hello,

Every year battle we sod worm infestation! We keep a well manicured lawn and even with treating for sod worms year after year, those buggers are back again! Do you have any suggestions on treatment/care to prevent future infestations?

1.response: Can you share how you have identified the sod webworms and what you have done to treat them in the past?
1.author: Lori Imboden

2.response:
In past summers we have noticed grass root damage, actual worms and moths flying out of yard (all confirmed by our lawn care fertilizing company).
Right now we are just seeing moths flying out of the yard.
In the past our lawn care company has treated the lawn with pesticide when sod worms were present.
2.author: The Question Asker

3.response:
Thank you for the information. Sod webworm larvae damage plants above the crown and root damage would not be typical. There are diseases that can affect the roots of plants as well as insects. Also, certain weedy species like creeping bentgrass have very shallow roots that do not tolerate drought. 

Sod webworm is most often a problem in turf that is not irrigated. Ensuring the turf is healthy will enable it to tolerate sod webworm damage without treatment. Provide adequate but not excessive moisture and nutrient applications and mow at 3-4 inches. It is not recommended to treat based on moth numbers since their larvae have high mortality rates. Before pursuing treatment, sample a section to confirm the presence of larvae. "Push through any damaged areas with your fingers and look for patches of turf that are pruned off just above the crowns. Look for small sawdust-like, green pellets (frass) that turn brown in a few days. Larvae can be brought to the surface by drenching infested turf with a soapy water solution made by stirring 1 oz of liquid dishwashing soap into 3 gallons of water. Pour this solution over a strip of turfgrass 1 foot wide by 6 feet long. Watch for larvae to come to the surface within 2 to 10 minutes after applying the drench." (https://www.canr.msu.edu/ipm/diseases/sod-webworm#gallery). This can be done a couple of weeks after the moths are observed.

If many caterpillars are observed during the flush test and you are getting unacceptable levels of damage to the turf, you may wish to pursue management options. You can use biologicals such as BTK or beneficial nematodes (https://ag.umass.edu/turf/fact-sheets/sod-webworms). Chemical options are available. Mow the yard first to remove any flowering plants from the turf you will be treating to avoid damaging pollinators. Spot treat in the areas with damage (find recommended products here: https://www.canr.msu.edu/ipm/diseases/sod-webworm#gallery).
3.author: Lori Imboden

image description: patches of turf pruned off just above the crowns
management instructions: ensure turf is healthy
provide adequate but not excessive moisture and nutrient applications
mow at 3-4 inches
sample a section to confirm presence of larvae
use soapy water solution to bring larvae to surface
consider biologicals such as BTK or beneficial nematodes
spot treat in areas with damage
mow yard before treating to remove flowering plants

title: Broccoli #562556
question: After successfully growing broccoli for years, I was disappointed to to see how scraggly my crop turned out this year.  The only thing I did differently was to keep the plants under row covers.  What happened?

1.response:
Hi- it's not easy to grow consistently good broccoli heads in the Maryland spring season. Commercial growers have more success with fall crops. Although some of the newer cultivars are supposed to be more tolerant of fluctuating weather conditions, broccoli is temperamental. Persistent cold and hot temperatures and wildly fluctuating temperatures induce bolting. It's best to wait till at least mid-April to plant. 

Using row covers is a good practice. They can provide 2-6 degrees F. of protection. This may not be enough when we have cold spring weather. In other years unseasonably high temperatures can actually increase the temperature under the covers inflicting heat stress and bolting. The good news is that you have healthy plants that should continue to produce side shoots into June.
Jon
1.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

management instructions: Wait till at least mid-April to plant.
Be aware that row covers may not provide enough protection in cold spring weather and may inflict heat stress in unseasonably high temperatures.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a broccoli plant that appears to be at an advanced stage of flowering and fruiting, which is normal as broccoli plants naturally transition from leafy growth to flowering after they have been harvested or when the main head is removed. However, if the goal was to continue growing new heads (which is typical for broccoli), the flowers should be removed to redirect energy back into leaf and stem growth.

Here are some management strategies you can consider:

1. **Remove Flowers**: Once the main head has been harvested, remove any flowers that develop on the plant. This will prevent the plant from going to seed prematurely and will allow it to continue producing more side shoots.

2. **Pruning**: If you want to encourage more side shoots, you can prune the plant by removing the top portion above where the main head was cut. This will stimulate additional growth points and encourage more side shoots to form.

3. **Mulching**: Ensure the soil around your broccoli plants is well-mulched to help retain moisture and suppress weeds. This can also provide additional nutrients to the soil as the mulch decomposes.

4. **Watering**: Keep the soil consistently moist, especially during periods of hot weather, as broccoli prefers evenly moist soil.

5. **Fertilization**: Apply a balanced fertilizer, such as a 10-10-10 ratio, every few weeks to provide the necessary nutrients for continued growth.

6. **Pest Management**: Inspect the plants regularly for pests like aphids or caterpillars, and treat them promptly if necessary using organic or chemical pesticides as appropriate.

7. **Support**: If the plant becomes tall and lanky, consider staking it with a wooden stake to support its structure and prevent lodging.

By implementing these strategies, you should be able to manage the flowering stage and encourage the broccoli plant to produce multiple heads.

title: Brown spots on Pepper plants #798674
question:
What is happening to my three pepper plants? 
See pictures of brown spots & leaves are dying.
They are three different types. 
This seemed to start as soon as it got hot... 
Do I throw these away and plant new ones??

answer.response:
i'm afraid your plants are too far gone to save.  I believe they have a blight or virus.  You need to dispose of the plants and the soil in the pots.  Then disinfect your pots with a solution of 1 part bleach to 9 parts water.  Rinse that out thoroughly, fill with fresh potting soil and you can put in new plants.  Also, any gardening gloves or implements used for the peppers should be disinfected with the same solution to avoid infecting new plants.  You can check out possibilities at this link: 
What's wrong with my plant? : Garden : University of Minnesota Extension (umn.edu)
answer.author: Barbara Harlan

answer.response:
Thanks for your response.

Can this Virus/Blight spread to my tomato plants that are close??

Bernice

answer.response: Tomatoes, peppers, potatoes and eggplants are all in the same family so whatever attacks one can attack the other.  Make sure you disinfect your gloves and tools as recommended so you don't transfer any disease to your tomato plants.  Keep the tomato plants away from the diseased peppers.  Once your pot and equipment are sterilized and the soil replaced, you should be okay with new plants.

title: Help us identify wasp(?) #163090
question: We found 3 huge nests on our property - all less than 300 meters of each other.  We think they are wasps' nests, but have never seen them that large.  AND the wasp(?) itself is so small [picture included].  Since it has been under 40 degrees, there is little movement, hence why my Husband was able to hold one. His hand is large, but the wasp(?) is about a 1/2 inch long. Can you help identify and how to exterminate them? Would like to know while the temperature is still cold for them.  Thank-you, Sandra Shodeen [outside Lytle, Texas]

answer.response:
Hello Sandra,

Those wasps are called Mexican Honey Wasps.  They are very interesting wasps - one of the few insects other than honey bees that produce honey.
Usually, I recommend to just leave them alone.  They are very docile wasps and unless provoked they will not sting.  When it is cold like this they aren't very active, as you've noticed.  When they are found on a school yard, less than 7 feet from the ground or around children is when we usually recommend removal.

Likely, they will remain in the trees and continue to go unnoticed by you on the ground as they probably have for many months before the trees lost the leaves.

If you decide removal is best, contact a pest control company who either has experience with Mexican Honey Wasps (and there should be several in your area as they are more and more common) or at least honey bee removal.
answer.author: Molly Keck

answer.response: Thank-you so much!  And yes, we will leave the ones alone that are farther away from the house.  We found another close to our barn (no sure if we'll keep it). You are right, didn't notice till the leaves dropped. We'll keep and watch them now.  Thank-you again!
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
-Molly Keck
Integrated Pest Management Program Specialist
Board Certified Entomologist
Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service
answer.author: Molly Keck

management instructions: leave them alone, as they are docile and will not sting unless provoked
consider removal if they are close to the ground or around children
contact a pest control company with experience in Mexican Honey Wasps or honey bee removal

title: what insect is this #585769

1.response:
Thanks for the question.

I'm sorry but I can't see in your picture any insect.  There is a lack of clarity.  Could you please take a picture showing just the insect and nothing else?  I would then be glad to attempt an identification.

Thanks.
1.author: Steve Hedman

2.response: Steve H - The insect makes up almost half the picture The white patch makes up the upper portion of its back between the head and the wings. There is a gray marking on the white patch that looks like Bart Simpson's silhouette with a part in the middle of his hair. Using reference points Upper L and R and Lower L and R, if you look from LL to UR the beetles head is below the white patch. Just above the white patch is the bugs wings. They are wavy(not smooth but hard to describe) which are very cool. Also, if you look closely you can see the legs on the insect. It is in a planter for a pepper plant and the white specs are from the potting soil. it flew in as I was pruning the plant.  I took the pic with my phone.  you need to blow up the pic as big as possible. Like on PC w/ a monitor. It flew away shortly after letting me take its picture. Im guessing it is some type of beetle. Hope this helps
2.author: The Question Asker

3.response:
Thanks for the question.

In consultation with another Master Gardener, we have decided that this is an American Carrion Beetle.  What appears as white in your picture is actually light yellow.  This threw me off track for a bit.  I suspect that this might reflect the exposure you used when you took the picture.  It’s a very interesting insect.  As the name implies, it lays its eggs on decaying flesh.  Back in my teaching days when I found a dead animal and wanted to look at its skeleton, I let a bunch of carrion beetles feast on the animal.  Within a few months, only the skeleton was left.  See:

https://bugguide.net/node/view/393021

https://www.insectidentification.org/insect-description.asp?identification=American-Carrion-Beetle

Thanks again for the question.
3.author: Steve Hedman

title: My cherry tree’s leaves are turning yellow and dropping #758522
question: Hi, Our backyard cherry tree was probably planted about 1970. We’ve lived here for 6 years. This year it seemed to bear more fruit than in previous years. But its leaves are turning yellow and dropping to the ground. We will have to start raking at this rate. Could this be due to the drought conditions? We do water about once a week. Thank you.

answer.response:
Hi Lisa- Thanks for your question and great pictures of your cherry tree. There are a lot of cherry tree problems in this area and drought is certainly one of them. While blooming and producing cherries, the tree probably needs about 1 inch of water per week, and we had an exceptionally dry spring. Most of us just crossed our fingers and hoped it would rain, and of course our trees suffered and are showing the consequences- like leaf drop.

I also notice the strange twisting around the trunk of your tree which makes me think the previous owners might have let a couple of stump sprouts grow up and around, probably not the healthiest way to grow a tree.

With such a beautiful tree, and if you don't see signs of a fungus infection (sap pockets on the trunk or branches, shot-hole spots on the leaves) I would just give it some extra water around the drip line (farthest area where the branches would drip water) while this heat lasts, and rake up the fallen leaves in case there is a fungus at work. A soaker hose running for an hour or so would be ideal, as the grass will get the first of the water and you want it to go deeper to the tree roots.

The tree will let you know if it is giving up the fight. Sometimes an extra large crop of fruit is a signal that it is highly stressed. It's probably time to be thinking about what you would replace the tree with if it can't recover this year. I know that would be sad.

Best of luck with the extra care this summer,
answer.author: Rhonda Frick-Wright

symptom description: leaves are dropping to the ground
management instructions: Give the tree extra water around the drip line.
Rake up the fallen leaves in case there is a fungus at work.
Use a soaker hose running for an hour or so to get water to the tree roots.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a cherry tree with leaves that appear to be yellowing, which could indicate chlorosis (iron deficiency), nutrient deficiencies, or disease. Given the context provided, where the tree has experienced a larger-than-usual fruit crop and has been watered weekly, it's important to consider potential issues related to overwatering, nutrient imbalances, or disease.

### Recommended Management Strategy:

1. **Assess Soil Nutrient Levels**: Have the soil tested to determine if there are any nutrient deficiencies. This can help identify if iron deficiency, calcium deficiency, or other nutrient imbalances are contributing to the leaf discoloration.

2. **Check for Disease**: Look for signs of disease such as bacterial leaf spot or fungal infections that might cause the leaves to turn yellow. Symptoms of these diseases include spots on the leaves, discolored areas, or leaf drop.

3. **Adjust Watering Schedule**: Since the tree has been receiving regular water, consider whether the watering frequency is appropriate for its needs. Overwatering can lead to root rot and nutrient deficiencies, as excess water can wash nutrients out of the soil.

4. **Apply Fertilizer**: Based on the soil test results, apply appropriate fertilizers. For example, if iron deficiency is found, applying an iron chelate fertilizer might help. Make sure to follow the application instructions carefully to avoid over-fertilization.

5. **Prune for Health**: Prune the tree to remove any dead or diseased branches. Proper pruning also helps maintain the structure of the tree and encourages new growth.

6. **Monitor for Pests**: Check for pests such as aphids or spider mites, which can contribute to leaf yellowing and other issues. If pests are present, treat them according to the recommendations from your local agricultural extension office.

7. **Regular Maintenance**: Continue with routine maintenance, including mulching around the base of the tree to retain moisture and protect the roots, and ensuring good air circulation around the tree to reduce the risk of disease.

By addressing these points, you should be able to manage the symptoms observed in the image and promote the health of the cherry tree. If the problem persists, consulting with a horticulturist or agricultural extension agent would be beneficial.

title: Plant Identification  #372962
question:
Hi,

This weed has completely inundated a previously cultivated (& tilled) garden. I am trying to figure out: 

1. What it is.
2. Why it is thriving in one field and not another
3. The best control strategy (cover crop, till, mow, etc). 

Thanks,
Bryant

answer.response:
This is one of the nightshades. Based on the white flowers and upright habit, this is likely Hairy nightshade (Solanum physalifolium). The main non-chemical control is to not let it set seed. Removing the plant and not putting it in your compost is a good first step, but do cover your skin to avoid contact.
Usually with weeds like this, it shows up because of the seeds. Maybe one field had mulch that included the seeds. Perhaps one or two plants were missed last year and distributed seeds in one bed.
Is this a home garden? Or a commercial field? That matters sometimes with chemical options. This information about black nightshade from Washington State University Extension includes the hairy nightshade control options. Review them and let us know if you need more specifics, and what size of garden and which crops you are planning.
answer.author: Jacki Dougan

answer.response: So easy to forget to paste the link. Sorry. Here is the WSU nightshade information: http://extension.wsu.edu/whitman/2013/11/black-nightshade/

title: Possible mange in area gray squirrels - any treatment other than "hands-on"? #616974
question:
I live 15 miles NE of Grants Pass iñ a heavily wooded area (private and BLM). The squirrels that visit  my 5 feeders have been showing what I first thought were wounds, but now seem to be mange? Areas the size of silver dollars on their back, rear, and outer- thigh area where the hair is completely missing and the skin is red and inflamed. One has been coming for the last week that is missing all the fur on the first two inches of it's tail - all the way around. The skin again looks fiery red and sometimes weepy.
I know some of these bald patches could be down to injury or fighting, but the borders seem to be uniform in shape with every hair gone.
Does this sound like mange? If so, is there any way to treat it that isn't hands-on? If not, is there any way to treat whatever else it is that doesn't require hands-on?
If there is nothing I can do, will this eventually burn through the entire population and then start over with immune squirrels? Or, will this be the new normal? 
I'd appreciate any info.  Thanks!     :).       Carole
I've attatched lousy photos (you really need to zoom in) showing the female with the missing tail fur. Sorry they're so bad, but the feeders are literally 5-12'  from my window and they run the minute I move....

answer.response:
Mange and fungal infections, both of which can cause the patchy hair loss you're observing, are known to run through populations of squirrels at times. Grown squirrels are likely to come through this and survive just fine. If this was happening just at the start of fall/winter cold weather however, the hair loss might be tougher for them to bear.
Unnaturally close density and frequent use of the same spots, such as at feeders, helps spread conditions like this. At this point, the squirrels are obviously food-conditioned to use the reliable source of food your feeders are providing, so we don't want to cut them off cold-turkey as it were. If you can instead create more numerous, smaller, well-dispersed feeding stations, that might help reduce the community transmission rate.
As you're able to this spring and summer, consider creating bird-feeding stations that don't double (directly or through spillage) as squirrel-feeders - Consider if it's possible to do some plantings (e.g., spruces, pines, willows, aspens, others) that will provide natural foods for the squirrels but will keep them at a more natural  distance from each other while they seek and obtain food.
answer.author: Dana Sanchez

title: Are they dying? #823784
question: I have a row of Arborvitae that have lost their green at the bottoms. At first I thought the bunnies were eating them, but it seems to be spreading upwards. Can you tell what’s wrong with them? The upper parts seem fine…

answer.response:
I searched the web for images of rabbit damage on arborvitae and came up with a good match for your trees. Have you seen rabbits?
Do some investigating. Look closely for nibbled ends. I zoomed in and twigs look "clipped" to me. Get close, parting twigs and checking the trunk for chewing or other trunk problems.
The damage is done, but the rest of the tree looks strong, and may grow branches that hang down, covering the trunk. The twigs already cut into the brown wood won't re-grow, however.
Some resources: Ask Extension question & answer from Minnesota, and another. Animals climb on the snow, so damage in those regions can be dramatic.
Oregon Extension EC 1579 covers dealing with nuisance wildlife generally.
answer.author: Jacki Dougan

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a row of arborvitae trees with dense, healthy foliage at the top but appears to have some lower branches that are dying or sparse. This is a common issue with arborvitae, often referred to as "tip burn" or "dieback," which can be caused by several factors such as overwatering, underwatering, nutrient deficiencies, pests, or environmental stress.

Given the location and time provided (Washington County, Oregon, March 2023), the following management strategies could be recommended:

1. **Water Management**: Ensure consistent watering. Arborvitae can be susceptible to both drought and waterlogged conditions. Check the soil moisture levels regularly and adjust irrigation accordingly to prevent excessive wetting of the roots, which can lead to root rot, and ensure the soil remains moist enough to prevent the tree from drying out.

2. **Fertilization**: Evaluate the soil for nutrient deficiencies. Arborvitae require a balanced diet of nutrients, including nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium. A soil test can help determine if fertilization is needed. Apply fertilizer according to the recommendations from your local Cooperative Extension Service, ensuring not to over-fertilize, as excess nitrogen can promote overly lush growth that may be more susceptible to diseases.

3. **Pruning**: While the upper parts appear healthy, consider pruning to remove any dead or diseased branches. This will help promote better air circulation and reduce the risk of disease spread. Prune during the dormant season, typically late winter or early spring, to avoid stressing the tree unnecessarily.

4. **Pest Control**: Check for signs of pests such as scale insects or mites, which can contribute to the dieback. If pests are present, identify the specific type and follow the recommended control measures, which may include using insecticides or biological controls.

5. **Disease Management**: Inspect the lower parts of the trees for signs of diseases. If diseases are suspected, consult with a horticulturist or an extension agent for proper diagnosis and treatment.

6. **Mulching**: Add a layer of mulch around the base of the trees to retain soil moisture, suppress weeds, and regulate soil temperature. However, keep the mulch away from the trunk to prevent potential issues with root rot.

7. **Monitor for Environmental Stress**: Check for signs of environmental stress, such as excessive heat or cold, wind, or poor air quality, which can affect the health of the trees. If environmental conditions are not ideal, consider ways to mitigate these stresses

title: Rose bushes have some kind of insect or disease that is decimating the leaves #653239
question: I have four small red rose bushes and something is taking out the leaves.  I am sending pictures, many leaves have holes or leaves are stripped completely with just branch remaining.  Have had these roses for about 5 years and same issue every year.  I sprayed Rose Rx 3 in 1 for organic gardening on the leaves but didn't seem to stop the problem.  Suggestions?

answer.response:
It appears your roses may have rose chafers, leafcutting bees or both. Leafcutting bees are beneficial
pollinators that cut round holes into the leaves. Chafers skeletonize leaves and will also feed on the flowers. If you look closely you would likely see chafers on your plants. Picking them off is the least invasive method of eradication. Below is. Link that gives information, including photos, on these insects.

https://apps.extension.umn.edu/garden/diagnose/plant/annualperennial/roses/leavesholes.html
answer.author: Amy Johnson

management instructions: pick off the insects

title: Cucumber plant Failure #473292
question: I am going stir crazy trying to figure out why this is happening.. For 4 years my cucumbers were plentiful and healthy. Able to make 100 quart jars of pickles a year. With only 8 plants. @ years ago I scaled back and also decided to vine the cucumbers. For the Last 2 years the cuks grow then start this most disturbing process. The leaves start to turn yellow and brown spots. Pictures attached. I have read and read. Not fining anything helpful. I have treated for blight, fungus, added epson salt to bases. Nothing has worked. The tops of the plants are amazing. But the bottoms turn these awful colors.  Please help me...  Gene C.

answer.response:
Hello,
The spots on you cucumber leaves are caused by a fungus due to the hot, humid weather. Cultural control is to snip off the infected leaves and toss them in the garbage. Increase airflow around the plants. Growing them up a trellis does help with drying out the leaves. The disease does typically start at the bottom with the older leaves, then moves up the plant.See our fact sheet for cucumber culture and diseases.http://www.ladybug.uconn.edu/FactSheets/squash.php
Regards,Carol Quish
answer.author: Carol Quish

title: Rose care in January (new home) #163774
question: Hello! I recently purchased a home in Zone 8 (97116) which has an extensive and neglected rose bed in front of it. Some of the roses have canes that are black with cancerous-looking lesions on them (see attached), but not all of them have this. However, ALL of them are at summer height and were not cut down in the fall. Is it too late to cut them down, and if not too late, how do I do that (how high do I leave them, etc.)? I am a first-time rose owner and wasn't sure if this was too late into winter and might harm the roses. Also, will cutting off the individually-affected cancerous canes (after trimming all the healthy ones) be adequate, or should I just plan to destroy those bushes with the disease in their entirety? Thank you for any help!

1.response:
The general guidelines for pruning roses in our region is to cut them to about waist height in the fall, then to knee height sometime around Presidents’ Day,  February 22.  I wouldn’t rush out to prune right now because our coldest weather usually arrives in January, and having an extra bit of height can provide some degree of protection for the crown.  

The close-up image you attached reveals that the “black bulbous” growths are crown gall.  This disease is most often found on the roots and on the crown at soil level.  But as is shown in your image, it also occurs on canes.  This disease is easily spread from one rose to the next with pruners, especially if you cut through one of the lesions.  Then the contaminated pruners can spread the disease to still other garden plants.  

Removing and discarding the affected growth, or the entire shrub, is the only management available.  If you want to try to salvage the affected roses, you could cut far below the bulbous growths, and then discard the removed part in the trash. 

You should also remove all blackened stems as they are dead, the reason(s) not discernible at this distance.   

Resources for you:
- “Controlling Disease and Aphids on your Roses” is a brief overview of challenges for roses and their remedies but doesn’t discuss crown gall. http://ir.library.oregonstate.edu/xmlui/bitstream/handle/1957/19231/ec1520.pdf
- “Crown Gall – Agrobacterium tumefaciens” (It’s important to know that the solarization treatment of soil mentioned in this document won’t be effective in our relatively cool climate.) http://www.ipm.ucdavis.edu/PMG/GARDEN/PLANTS/DISEASES/crowngall.html  

Enjoy your new garden and creating your own vision of what it should be.
1.author: Jean R. Natter

2.response: Jean, thank you so very much for your expert advice, and for taking the time to reply to my question. I will be sure to boil and bleach the shears after cutting the black canes, but before pruning shorter around Feb. 22. If those don't work to curb the gall, I will keep in mind that I may have to rid the bed of those particular ones. Thank you for the helpful links, too - I really appreciate this very much! Have a good day!
2.author: The Question Asker

3.response:
Start pruning the roses that don't have crown gall, then prune the others. 

You need not boil the tools after you prune an individual bush.  If you use bleach to sterilize the pruners, be certain to oil the tools to avoid corrosion.  Or you may want to consider a 10-minute soak in rubbing alcohol, then just allow the tolls to dry.
3.author: Jean R. Natter

4.response: Ah, gotcha. Will do, and thank you again so much for all the terrific advice!
4.author: The Question Asker

management instructions: Remove and discard the affected growth or the entire shrub.
Cut far below the bulbous growths and discard the removed part in the trash.
Remove all blackened stems as they are dead.
Sterilize pruners with bleach or rubbing alcohol after cutting through lesions.

title: Golden Elderberry looking like it's been burnt #645532
question: My pretty Golden Elderberry has sudden developed leaves that are looking like they've been burnt.  the edges and clusters of leaves are black and curling.  It really looks like it's been torched, but that isn't likely.I planted it last year and it looked great this year coming out of dormancy then just this week it changed.  Any clues?

answer.response: This is most likely sunburn. Some golden- or yellow-foliaged cultivars of ornamental plants are best planted in at least partial afternoon shade to avoid the hottest part of the sun during the day. It's a bit of a balancing act to provide enough sun for good color development in the foliage without developing scorch. Plants which have a  tendency to scorch might be best in a location where they are shaded after 1 or 2pm. This is made a bit more difficult for you, as this plant gets quite big!If you choose to move the plant, at this point it might be best to take some cuttings, as I'm sure it will root readily at this time of year and might provide you with some insurance plants to place elsewhere if moving the plant itself is impractical. Feel free to write with questions
answer.author: Neil Bell

answer.response: Thank you so much!  It is in full sun after light morning shade.  It is still a small shrub, under 3 feet tall, so I can move it.  Taking cuttings is an excellent idea...insurance never hurts!
answer.author: The Question Asker

title: Lawn Weed Problem #722784
question:
I have attached pictures of a weed in my lawn that I am having trouble getting rid of.  I have tried three different weed killer sprays that do not work on this particular weed.  The attached pictures show what the weed looks like.  It is a fast spreader, has a small yellow flower and very thin fine roots that are impossible to pull out.  I need to know what is the best way to deal with this problem. 
Thanks, Mark Fergiuson
ps - I think the problem was made worse by my lawn service cutting the grass too short during the hot months of summer.

answer.response:
Hello,

This is an annual weed that dies over winter and germinates every summer from seed, called yellow woodsorrel.

Here is the management/control option from msuturfweeds.net

“Yellow woodsorrel reproduces by seed from year-to-year. Encouraging turfgrass density in the fall and spring should be fairly effective for limiting the presence of woodsorrel in turfed areas. Yellow woodsorrel is most likely to invade when spring conditions have opened the turf from drought or grub damage. Woodsorrel is a late-germinating summer annual, ideally suited to fill-in voids in the turf during June, July and August.

Several preemergence crabgrass herbicides have activity on yellow woodsorrel. Unfortunately, a higher concentration of herbicide is necessary for woodsorrel suppression. In areas with heavy pressure it may be advisable to make a split application of crabgrass preemergence to ensure that the concentration of herbicide is high enough during the germination window. Prodiamine, pendimethalin and dithiopyr all provide some suppression of woodsorrel. Once established, postemergence control is not reliably found in traditional broadleaf herbicides. Most postemergence activity is further diminished due to the hot-dry conditions of summer. However, products containing triclopyr or carfentrazone have shown promise in several trials. Traditional two- and three-way combination broadleaf herbicides will probably not be effective on yellow woodsorrel.”

Disclaimer: Always read, understand, and follow the label directions. Mention or exclusion of specific products does not represent an endorsement or condemnation of any product by Michigan State University.
answer.author: Laura Sheffer

management instructions: Encouraging turfgrass density in the fall and spring
Several preemergence crabgrass herbicides have activity on yellow woodsorrel
make a split application of crabgrass preemergence to ensure that the concentration of herbicide is high enough during the germination window
products containing triclopyr or carfentrazone have shown promise in several trials

title: Losing Concord grapes #466082
question:
Can you identify what is happening to these Concord grapes?  Years ago someone told me it was probably black spot and to severely prune back and dispose of the vines.  I've done that a couple times over the years.  When I did a light pruning over the past week or so there were more types of tiny creepy and flying things than I could count!  At this point I'm wondering if it's a pest, and not a fungus.

Most years I lose a lot of grapes in the beginning of the season because they turn dark (the wrong way) and start to wither.  And then at some point during the summer the spots seem to suddenly stop forming and a decent amount of grapes are still produced.  Also at some point the Japanese beetles will come and eat the leaves.  Right now the rose bushes next to the grape vines also have leaves that have been eaten extensively by something I don't see.

Any advice on how to keep the grapes growing is appreciated!  Also, children will be picking and eating the grapes all summer (ripe or not!), so I need to be careful that any medications are reasonably safe.

Thank you!

answer.response:
Fruit growing can be tricky in Maryland, and this very wet year makes it even more so.
Getting the best results relies on a combination of meeting the cultural needs of the plant while managing the planting for the most common problems that crops may have.
Here is our grape page: http://extension.umd.edu/hgic/plants/grapes
Look through the whole thing first, but be sure to read the "common problems" tab which will identify and explain what you are seeing and how to best manage it. 
It does look like black rot. To get a decent crop you need to apply a fungicidal spray (repeatedly until skins thicken).

cm
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

management instructions: apply a fungicidal spray repeatedly until skins thicken

The vines are next to rose bushes that have also been eaten by something. Japanese beetles typically eat the leaves during the summer. Children will be picking and eating the grapes.

title: Magnolia Damage #826836
question: Mid winter we notice some bark damage on our tree.  It was not done by deer, rabbit, or kids as no tracks or signs were in the snow.  We are now noticing it is getting worse and is showing up on nearby branches.  Half the bush is showing up with black bark. The past two summers we have delt with soft scale which we have tried treating with some spray and spraying them off with water. I am not too sure how successful were were.  Can you tell what is causing the bark damage and best way to treat it. I have not seen any birds at the damage spot. Thank you

answer.response:
Squirrels might have stripped the bark.  (Compare the damage shown in the following publication.)  If so, we don't know any way to prevent this, short of taking measures to keep squirrels out of the tree.  Unfortunately, such measures often aren't feasible.

https://bygl.osu.edu/node/389

Portions of the shrub with black bark may be covered with sooty mold. The mold often grows on honeydew excreted by scale insects. If that's what happened in this case, controlling the scales will eliminate the mold.

https://site.extension.uga.edu/bartow/sooty-mold/
answer.author: Bob Bystrom

management instructions: keep squirrels out of the tree
control the scales to eliminate the mold

title: Hello. Any idea what this... #179770
question: Hello. Any idea what this red growth might be that is creeping in on the bark of our aspen trees? Seems to be on the surface rather than a canker/etc. We noticed it a few years ago and have searched the Net to no avail for info. This year it seems to be more widespread. I know of a few other folks here (Vail Valley) who are also experiencing this. Any help/info is appreciated.

answer.response:
Hello, 

Thanks for contacting us about your trees. The red splotches on the aspen bark are spider mite egg masses. They don't harm the aspen, but they may get on other plants in the area. Most likely you will not be able to see the mites with the naked eye so watch for bronze flecking on the leaves and thin strands of webbing (pictures below). If you do see signs of spider mites, often times a few good sprays with the hose will take care of it.
answer.author: Jeff Pieper

title: Tomato Disease - not sure type #842490
question:
I thought the disease was early blight or leaf spot, so I followed some advice from the internet. I have cut off all the infected leaves and stems every other day for the last 3 weeks.  I also sprayed neem oil on the plants at night twice - 9 days apart.  The last time was Saturday evening.  Yesterday, it looked like I had not done it for the disease had spread upward. Obviously I am doing something wrong.  I have two rows of tomatoes about 32 in all.  Photos show the cutting of the lower infected branches.

Thank you 
Steve

answer.response:
Hi- some of the lesions could be caused by Septoria leaf spot and the smaller dark lesions could be caused by bacterial spot disease. The latter will also produce symptoms on fruits.

Removing lower leaf branches is a good strategy for removing disease inoculum and promoting better air circulation and faster leaf drying.

Neem oil will not help much here. Fixed liquid copper is the most effective organic fungicide and Daconil and Mancozeb are the two most effective synthetic fungicides available for home gardeners. They will not cure infections but will prevent them from spreading.
Jon
answer.author: Jon Traunfeld

answer.response:
Would hydrogen peroxide and water be used for these lesions?

 


Thank you for your help –

Steve
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Hi- hydrogen peroxide and hydrogen dioxide have not been shown through field experiments to be very effective.
https://vegnet.osu.edu/sites/vegnet/files/imce/VegNet%20Vol.%2013%2C%20No.%2017.%20August%2024%2C%202006.pdf

https://vegetablegrowersnews.com/news/are-hydrogen-peroxide-products-effective-fungicides/
Jon
answer.author: Jon Traunfeld

title: Boxwood turning brown #185876
question: Some of my boxwood are turning brown. Some completely, some just partial. We have an abundance of them in my community doing the same thing. Will they comeback? Or are they lost forever? I believe the type of Boxwood is Winter Gem.

answer.response:
The key is have patience. I have the same problem with my boxwood. You may also be observing browning of leaves on other broadleaved evergreens such as azaleas, rhododendrons, hollies, grape-holly, euonymous and mountain laurel. (These plants, like boxwood, bear leaves that normally stay green all year.) This browning, also known as desiccation, occurs when winter winds draw moisture out of the plant tissue. Since the temperatures have been so extreme, these shallow-rooted plants cannot draw any more water from the frozen ground to replace the water lost by the leaves. You will especially see desiccation on the windward side of plants as the air draws moisture from the leaves as it passes by. If the roots cannot pull up any water, the water that transpired from the leaves cannot be replaced; therefore, these cells die causing brown tissue.
Once the snow melts, you can see the differences in shrubs or plants that were partially snow-covered. The portion of shrub that was covered in snow was insulated against the colder temperatures and wind, thus did not suffer as severe burn.
Will these plants survive? It depends on the severity of the damage. Be sure to wait until after shrubs leaf out if you are unsure whether or not a branch is still living. Check to see if there are any live buds. You don’t want to cut these off. Exposure to this winter’s extreme temperatures may have caused delay in leaf development on plants, so if you prune as early as you would after a normal winter, you may be cutting off live growth. The extreme temperatures that we’ve experienced may also cause buds and entire branches to die. Don’t be surprised if you also see some plants start to leaf out but then collapse. Corrective pruning along with recommended fertilization and proper watering will often help these plants recover.  
This is a good article from Missouri Botanical Garden: http://www.mobot.org/gardeninghelp/plantfinder/hortline.asp?code=3959
I hope this was helpful. Feel free to contact us again if you have further questions.
answer.author: Ruth Simon

management instructions: Wait until after shrubs leaf out to determine if a branch is still living.
Check for live buds before pruning.
Prune and fertilize as needed to help plants recover.
Water properly to help plants recover.
qa_information.background info: The type of Boxwood is Winter Gem. There are an abundance of boxwood in the community with the same issue.

title: Is this scale? #873044
question: My serviceberry is covered with white fuzzy stuff. Looking online I believe it may be scale - can you confirm and if so, recommend a treatment? It is a relatively new tree and I’d hate to see something bad happen.

answer.response:
Good afternoon Katherine, 

It appears that this may be a type of Wooly Aphid, which, according to University of Maryland can happen to Serviceberries. Here's some more information: https://extension.umd.edu/resource/woolly-aphids-trees/

In the outdoors, wooly aphids are typically controlled by parasitic wasps, however since your problem is significant, it is recommended to use either horticulture oil or insecticidal soap to reduce the infestation. A commercial brand of insecticidal soap would be the safest insecticide to use. 

However given the very hot weather this week I want to flag that insecticidal soap should not be applied when temperatures are greater than 90 degrees, so it would be best to apply in early morning on a cooler day -- it looks like next Thursday temperatures will drop somewhat so that might be a wise option. Here's more information from Cornell Extension on applying insecticidal soap.

All my best, 

Rebecca
answer.author: Rebecca Harnik

answer.response:
These look like they could be one of the woolly aphids, which often have two host plants, i.e. elm and serviceberry. They overwinter and begin their breeding cycle on the primary host, raising a generation with wings. This winged generation flies to the secondary host plant, such as your serviceberry, to feed for the summer, ending that phase by raising another generation with wings to fly back to a primary host plant.

The good news is that trees generally withstand woolly aphids fairly well. The bad news is that WA multiply very rapidly. 

Good that you spotted the problem early! Suggest literally knocking down the population by hosing all of the tree you can reach with a firm spray. Monitor the serviceberry and spray treatments can be repeated as needed, if needed.

Although their waxy coat that gives them a “woolly” appearance protects WA from horticultural oils, soaps and even permethrin, a jet of water can dislodge them.

WA have many natural predators in the garden, which can keep the reduced population in check.  

How to boost the natural predator population in your garden:

A practice to attract natural predators to your garden is to include flowering native and herb plants in your garden. Another is to draw in small insectivorous birds with a shallow birdbath of fresh water (changed every other day & kept clean) and nesting spots. Hummingbirds might be more attracted to a bath with a drip, spray or small fountain.


Unfortunately, some sucking insects can sometimes carry plant pathogens from a plant that is already affected to another plant. So continue to monitor, as you have been, to reduce that risk by keeping the populations down. 

More details in the link below:

https://extension.umn.edu/yard-and-garden-insects/aphids#use-a-high-pressure-water-spray-344411


Please keep us posted on your serviceberry!

Kate
answer.author: Kate McLynn

management instructions: use horticulture oil or insecticidal soap to reduce the infestation
apply insecticidal soap in early morning on a cooler day
knock down the population by hosing all of the tree with a firm spray
monitor the serviceberry and spray treatments can be repeated as needed

title: Diagnosing tomato issues - is it the soil?! #760671
question: We made raised beds this spring using corrugated iron roofing from an old barn and old boards. Also re-purposed an old fibre-glass canoe as a planter. Filled both with top soil from our local Waste-Pro and planted tomatoes and basil. The tomatoes have been growing well until recently when the new leaves began to curl up (see image). Initially we thought it was aphids but we don't have any insects on/in the curled up leaves. We looked up some possibilities online and consulted with a local friend who gardens a lot. Both sources point towards herbicide contamination but we haven't sprayed and the plants haven't been exposed to over-spray from neighboring fields/properties. We don't think it's anything to do with the planter box materials since we're having the same problem in both the canoe and the corrugated iron beds.

1.response:
Thank you for your question, Lucy.  The only way to diagnose herbicide drift is to have the plant tested in a lab.  Having said that, I suggest that your tomatoes are suffering from physiological leaf roll, described here:  https://pnwhandbooks.org/plantdisease/host-disease/tomato-solanum-lycopersicum-physiological-leafroll   Our recent temperatures have resulted in inadequate watering, and the plants respond like this.  I suggest you follow the recommendations in the article and see if the plants return to some more normal shape.  You might also want to have a soil test to check pH and nutrients.  Here is a list of local labs:  https://catalog.extension.oregonstate.edu/em8677

Good luck!
1.author: Kristena LaMar

management instructions: Follow proper watering recommendations.
Have a soil test to check pH and nutrients.
qa_information.background info: The tomatoes were planted in raised beds made from corrugated iron roofing and old boards, and in an old fibre-glass canoe, filled with top soil from a local source. The plants were initially growing well.

title: ants transforming the landscape #637427
question: Every year we get these ant colonies, and they cover a very large area.  Looks like they're populated by flying ants.  You can find a maze of tunnels several inches below the surface.  We've tried DE and ant bait (and maybe Sevin) with no success.  Haven't found anything like it searching the internet.  Any ideas?

answer.response:
In general, ants are predators of other insects including termites. But, sometimes you can have too much of a good thing. You mention flying ants and they are the ones that fly off and create new colonies. 
There is something about the ground or soil that the ants really like there. Areas of Anne Arundel County can have sandy soil which ants prefer. The lawn looks like it could be thickened up and it is mowed a bit too shorts. Ants love to have easy access to soil.
If you want to try to rectify the situation it would take some work on your lawn. Testing the soil, adding organic matter, reseeding in the fall to thicken up the grass, or even laying sod. You should keep the area mowed to about 3-4 inches. All of this might help but is not a guarantee they will go away because this happens each year.
Deb
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

title: Identify invasive grass #826358
question:
Hello,
My lawn is seeded with tall fescue. I have two areas where the grass is a lighter shade of green and appears to be of
a different type of grass. This invasive grass is isolated to two areas, but the areas have gotten larger since last year.
The stalk appears somewhat round. Some of the stalks also feel stiffer than normal fescue
There is purple on the lower third of the stalk.
Can you help me identify this grass (photos attached) and how to get rid of it ?
Thank you,
Steven

answer.response:
Hi, 

We aren't able to zoom in closely on the photos to see the grass up close, also grass identification can be difficult to distinguish between species but it sounds like it could either be Roughstalk Blue Grass or possibly Orchardgrass. You can try to use Ohio States Grass ID key or Penn State to help determine which it is if you'd like. 

In either case of which grass it is the best way to get rid of large patches is to aerate and overseed with the desired grass seed mix to outcompete the undesired grass or weeds. This is best accomplished in the fall when the weather is naturally cooling and there tends to be more rainfall. If it were just in small patches you could hand dig them out and touch up patches of your lawn this spring, however if there is a lot then the overseeding would be better. If you haven't already, you could still apply a pre-emergent for crabgrass which would help control any weed seeds from germinating. Following the general care for tall fescue lawns, assuming that is what you mostly have, is the most practical approach for a healthy lawn. 

Let us know if you have further questions with this. 

Emily
answer.author: Emily Porter

The image shows a single plant that appears to be an invasive grass species, which could potentially be one of the weeds listed as a concern in the background information provided. Based on the symptoms visible, such as the robust root system and elongated leaves, it may be a type of crabgrass or another similar weed that invades lawns.

### Recommended Management Strategy:

1. **Identification**: Confirm the exact species of the weed by comparing it to known invasive grasses like crabgrass, quackgrass, or Johnson grass. This can help tailor the treatment method more effectively.

2. **Mechanical Removal**: For smaller infestations, hand-pulling or using a small trowel to dig out the roots can be effective. Ensure you remove the entire root system to prevent regrowth.

3. **Chemical Control**:
   - **Pre-Emergent Herbicides**: Apply these before the weed seeds germinate (usually in late winter or early spring) to prevent seed germination. Common pre-emergent herbicides include trifluralin and pendimethalin.
   - **Post-Emergent Herbicides**: If the infestation is already established, post-emergent herbicides like glyphosate (Roundup) or clopyralid can be used to kill the existing plants. Ensure you follow the label instructions carefully and avoid applying during periods of drought or high temperatures.

4. **Cultural Practices**:
   - **Healthy Lawn**: Maintain a healthy lawn through proper mowing, watering, and fertilizing practices. A strong, dense lawn can help outcompete weeds.
   - **Aerate**: Regularly aerating the lawn helps improve soil health, which can make the grass more competitive against weeds.
   - **Watering**: Water deeply but infrequently to encourage deep-rooted grass, which is less susceptible to weed invasion.

5. **Re-Seeding**: If the area is heavily infested and cannot be managed by other means, consider re-seeding the area with tall fescue or another desirable grass species to create a dense cover that discourages weed growth.

6. **Consult Local Experts**: Since the problem is specific to Howard County, Maryland, consulting with local extension agents or landscapers who are familiar with the local environment and conditions can provide tailored advice.

By implementing a combination of mechanical, chemical, and cultural control measures, you can effectively manage the invasion of this grass species in your lawn. It's important to act promptly to prevent the spread and establishment of invasive weeds.

1.response:

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The plant in the image appears to be pokeweed (Phytolacca americana), which can be identified by its leaves, stems, and small white flowers. Pokeweed is a common invasive species that can become problematic in disturbed areas such as those created by fallen trees like the oak that occurred in Prince George's County, Maryland.

### Recommended Management Strategy:

1. **Manual Removal**:
   - Pokeweed can be manually pulled from the ground when it is small or seedlings are emerging. Be sure to remove the entire root system to prevent re-growth. This method is effective but labor-intensive, especially on larger patches.

2. **Herbicides**:
   - For larger infestations or areas where manual removal is impractical, herbicides can be used. Selective herbicides that target broadleaf weeds, such as dicamba or triclopyr, can be applied directly to the plants. It’s important to follow the label instructions carefully to avoid damage to desirable plants or unintended consequences.

3. **Cultural Practices**:
   - Regularly monitoring and managing the area can help prevent the spread of pokeweed. Clearing away debris and maintaining healthy native vegetation can reduce the habitat suitable for pokeweed growth.

4. **Biological Control**:
   - While not widely available or practical for home use, some species of insects and pathogens are natural enemies of pokeweed. If you are interested in biological control, consulting with local extension services may provide information on their availability and effectiveness.

5. **Preventative Measures**:
   - Planting competitive native species in the area can help suppress the growth of pokeweed. Native plants often outcompete invasives due to their ability to thrive in the local environment and provide habitat for beneficial insects.

6. **Regular Maintenance**:
   - Continuous maintenance, including regular mowing and weeding, can help keep the area free of pokeweed and other unwanted invasive species.

### Additional Tips:
- Always ensure proper safety measures are taken when using herbicides, as they can be harmful to both people and the environment if not used correctly.
- Consider seeking professional assistance for large-scale infestations or areas with significant tree damage.

By combining these strategies, you can effectively manage the pokeweed population around the oak stump in your backyard.

title: Linden tree dropping leaves #360972
question: We had a severe storm about 2-3 weeks ago. Winds were clocked at 96 MPH.  Many residents lost trees and/or limbs. Our Linden tree (approximately 20+ years old) is starting to lose its leaves well ahead of other trees in this area.  I was wondering if the tree may be in a sort of shock and if there is anything we should be doing to help it through the winter.  We don't notice any unusual signs of blight, etc., but the tree did lose one medium sized limb during the storm. We are grateful we kept it, as the entire tree was bent at an extraordinary angle during the storm.

answer.response:
Thanks for the question and photos of your linden tree. There is a good chance that your tree was bothered by the Japanese beetle this year and that would be the cause of the leaves starting to fall off. Japanese beetles will leave the leaf looking like a doilies. This time of the year there is nothing that can be done about the beetles. You want to make sure that the limb that came out from the storm is cleaned up. You don't want any jagged wood sticking out or anything of that nature. The flower bed around the tree is a concern. When we put extra soil around the base of the tree it could suffocate the roots that are directly under it. Also that soil up against the tree can rot out the trunk. If possible we would recommend removing the bed all together and put in mulch. Mulch allows air to flow and suppresses weed competition. The middle picture shows some wire or other material that may be looped around the trunks. Make sure that it isn't too tight to cause any damage. Check it periodically and adjust it accordingly to make sure the tree does not try to grow around it.  

More information about storm damaged trees: http://nfs.unl.edu/Storm%20Damage%20series%20Mobile.pdf

More information about Japanese beetles: http://www.extension.umn.edu/garden/insects/find/japanese-beetles/

Please let me know if you have other questions.
answer.author: Scott Evans

management instructions: Clean up the limb that came off during the storm, removing any jagged wood.
Remove the flower bed around the tree to prevent root suffocation and trunk rot.
Replace the flower bed with mulch to allow air to flow and suppress weed competition.
Check the wire or material looped around the trunk to ensure it is not too tight and adjust as needed.
qa_information.background info: The tree is approximately 20+ years old and experienced a severe storm with 96 MPH winds 2-3 weeks ago, losing one medium-sized limb.

title: Diseased Butterfly bush #800143
question:
I believe my Butterfly Bush has a fungal disease (according to Google anyway).  The leaves are turning yellow and dry even with rain.  It's about 8 years old and is planted in the ground, not a pot.  It's still blooming, but not as much as in the past.  I'm not sure what to do with it.  Should I cut it back, dig it up, or treat it with something?  I have pets so if I treat it it needs to be a pet friendly substance.  
Thanks for any help,

answer.response:
We suspect that perhaps you are dealing with mites. Mites are tiny sucking insects that can cause stippling (spotty yellowing) and their populations can be high.
Take a look under the leaf. They are really tiny, a little smaller than a period on a page. You can shake a branch over a while piece of paper and then watch for tiny spots crawling- using a 10x loupe or magnifying glass helps. See more here: 
https://extension.umd.edu/resource/spider-mites-flowers-and-groundcovers
A strong blast from the hose, aimed up under leaves can knock some off.
Otherwise, butterfly bush can be cut back (throw away the cuttings into the trash) and return after a bit to bloom some more.
Better yet, consider removal and replacement as Butterfly Bush has been found to be invasive in our area.  If you are willing, this page explains more and includes some native plant replacement ideas:
https://extension.umd.edu/resource/butterfly-bush


Christine
answer.author: Christine McComas

management instructions: strong blast from the hose aimed up under leaves
cut back and throw away cuttings
consider removal and replacement
qa_information.background info: the plant is about 8 years old, planted in the ground, still blooming but not as much as in the past, has pets that need to be considered for treatment

answer.response:
Paula,

This is definitely herbicide damage from your pictures but it now looks like it is  Askmaybe recovering from the damage. Looks like the herbicide they used was applied correctly but too close to the fence. Ask your neighbor to let you know when they are spraying the lawn so you can protect your plants from damage from spraying their lawn. You can also try washing the plants off if you see them spraying the lawn to prevent the herbicide from attaching to the leaf of the plants and being drawn into the plant and starting the killing of the plant. Most herbicides are systemic so they take the herbicide in thru the leaves.

The attached photos sort of show the stages they go thru.  I agree that I will have to do something to protect the plants, but it is a 50' row of garden phlox, so I am not sure what the best way to protect them would be.. do you have any suggestions?  I appreciate your help and feedback.

title: Disease on Aspen tree #824726
question: <hr />

1.response:
Jim, 

An actual question did not come through. Only the title. Hopefully this link, provided by Colorado State University,  will address the questions and concerns you have regarding your aspen tree. 

Please do not hesitate to follow up with any questions you may have.  

https://csfs.colostate.edu/forest-management/common-forest-insects-diseases/common-insects-diseases-of-aspen/

*After opening the link there are several pictures with descriptions on the left sidebar.
1.author: Kerry Peetz

2.response: What’s on this Aspen  tree?
2.author: The Question Asker

3.response:
Jim, 

Thank you for the picture. 

Your distorted and deformed aspen leaves are becoming evident at this time of year, and because they look so odd (possibly even alarming), they cause concern.
Eriophyid mite on aspen leaves
The distortion is a gall caused by a tiny mite called an Eriophyid mite.

The good news is that the gall does not affect plant health, and usually the same tree is not hit two years in a row. So, it is just an aesthetic issue. The affected leaves can be cut out if they are really bothersome, but it is not necessary.

The distortion is caused by chemical secretions produced during feeding or egg laying. The chemicals act like natural plant growth hormones. The leaves only become distorted when the leaf is attacked early in the growing season when it is rapidly expanding. Fully expanded leaves do not have the same reaction.

Below are two links with additional information that you may find helpful. 

https://agsci.colostate.edu/agbio/ipm-pests/eriophyid-mites-2/

https://extension.colostate.edu/topic-areas/insects/insect-and-mite-galls-5-577/
3.author: Kerry Peetz

4.response: Click below for picture.
4.author: Kerry Peetz

management instructions: The affected leaves can be cut out if they are really bothersome, but it is not necessary.

title: Grass damage - Pests?? #599679
question:
Hi
I have been having damage to my lawn for a week now with no end in site. I have asked advice from many sources but nothing has worked. I have applied mole-ex to my lawn along with bait boxes for voles but so far damage has continued. I had my grass aerated in the Spring - fertilized- grub control and had a nice lawn until about a month ago. Started looking a little yellow but thought maybe it was over fertilized. Last week the damage in the first picture showed up so I was told I have moles or voles and then put the mole -ex on lawn along with a fungus control suggested to me by gardening place. After that all the other holes and damage has continued day after day. I am besides myself and don't know what to do. Please help!!!!

answer.response:
Hello,

If, when you step on the lighter colored trails through the grass, they are raised areas of soil and they can be pressed down, then these are mole tunnels.

If there are no tunnels around the holes to press down, holes visible at the surface could be squirrel damage. Voles typically develop protected runways through tall grass, (and under snow cover in winter) along the surface of the soil. Keep grass mowed to 3.5 - 4 inches in height.

 Your pictures look like mole tunnels. Moles eat insects of all types so, killing grubs doesn’t make moles move away.

The most effective control for moles is trapping. With some practice and following these tips you should have success. There are castor oil - based repellents for moles that can help when used and re-applied according to the label. Here are links to info on mole management:

http://msue.anr.msu.edu/news/moles_in_the_lawn

https://ipm.missouri.edu/MEG/2012/3/How-to-control-moles-and-reduce-turfgrass-damage/

https://www.canr.msu.edu/news/common_myths_about_moles_in_lawns

 Video on properly setting mole traps – 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mq1J5Y2R76c

Details on vole control-https://ag.umass.edu/turf/fact-sheets/vole-damage-to-lawns

 Also, links to lawn care and repair should you need them-

https://www.canr.msu.edu/home_lawns/

https://www.canr.msu.edu/news/late_season_lawn_seeding

https://www.canr.msu.edu/news/how_to_choose_and_when_to_apply_grub_control_products_for_your_lawn

The squirrel damage will subside once the ground freezes- as will the mole activity. Populations of all animals and insects fluctuate year to year. You may have a lower population of moles next year. I hope this helps. Thank you.
answer.author: Laura Sheffer

answer.response:
Hello again,

I forgot to mention, if the holes are appearing overnight, and have no tunnel beneath them, they are caused by something nocturnal, and it could be skunks. Skunks are very active right now putting on weight for the winter.

Here are a couple more references to keep on hand-

https://www.canr.msu.edu/news/whos_that_digging_in_my_yard_skunks_raccoons_or_moles

https://naturalresources.extension.iastate.edu/wildlife/diagnosing-holes-yard
answer.author: Laura Sheffer

trapping for moles
use castor oil-based repellents for moles

title: Brown edges on Blackberry leaves and rotting berries #747963
question:
Hi,

After the big storm this weekend, the edges of the leaves on my blackberry plant began browning, and the nearby berries began to rot. There are blooms nearby too that seem to be rotting. About two weeks ago, I removed the mulch and sprayed them with diatomaceous earth to get rid of a pest problem (which worked), which might be the white specks on the underside of the leaf. 

My plant is in a large pot, if that makes a difference.

What should I do to fix this disease? Thank you for your help!

Kate

answer.response:
Kate,

It appears the blackberries have Botrytis cinerea, a type of fruit rot that can affect nearly every part of the plant. The recent rains have created ideal conditions for it to develop.

The best way to control the fungus is with the following cultural methods:

  • Remove and dispose of dead leaves and infected fruit.
  • Keep the area free from weeds.
  • Mulch to prevent the fruit from coming into direct contact with the soil.
  • Avoid overhead watering or misting of the plant.
  • Provide good air circulation so the plant will be less susceptible to the fungus.

Also, be sure your blackberry plant is getting some direct sunlight each day. Since it’s in a pot, I’m sure you can find the perfect spot!

Good luck!

Cindy
answer.author: Travis County Master Gardener

answer.response:
Hi Cindy,

Thank you so much for your help! I have cut back all the dead/dying/infected leaves and canes, but I wanted to ask one more question: Is this cane infected? It looks health and has new growth, but I’m not sure if the brown spots on this part of the cane are Botrytis cinerea too.

Thank you for you help!

Kate On May 5, 2021, 21:59 -0500, Ask Extension <askextension@eduworks.com>, wrote:
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Kate,

The brown spots on the cane do not look like Botrytis cinerea. You would see evidence of the gray mold or black spores. I would keep an eye on it and continue the care outlined in the previous email. Hopefully, you will soon be eating homegrown blackberries!

Thanks,

Cindy
answer.author: Travis County Master Gardener

Keep the area free from weeds.

Provide good air circulation.

title: Blue point juniper - dry #853653
question:
I have planted blue point junipers. Since they’re new I keep getting told that they need to be watered 2 times a week. The technique of watering hasn’t always been at the root, which we learned the hard way. All trees have dried up and the little arms of the trees have and can be snapped off…like a dry stick. The color of the blue point juniper is brown. Does this mean that it’s overwatered or that it needs water?

the picture with all junipers is a recent one. the other picture of 1 juniper was taken 2 weeks later after being planted. 

Any help is appreciated.

answer.response: These junipers are not getting enough water.  In fact, they look dead.  Water at the root until the area around the juniper is flooded with water.  Let that soak in.  Repeat once.  Do that every three days or so until it freezes.  At that point, go to watering once every week.  If the shrubs can be saved, that will help them recover.
answer.author: Dallas County Master Gardeners

symptom description: little arms of the trees can be snapped off like a dry stick
color of the blue point juniper is brown
management instructions: Water at the root until the area around the juniper is flooded with water.
Let the water soak in, then repeat once.
Water every three days or so until it freezes, then switch to once a week.
qa_information.background info: The blue point junipers are newly planted and were initially watered 2 times a week, but not always at the root.

title: Brown Spots on mums #754209
question: I have brown spots on my  mums this year. These are hardy mums that have been coming up for years. I don't see any insects. Could it be old age? I'm afraid it's something that might spread to the rest of the plants, like a fungus or something.

answer.response:
Hello,

Generally when you find leaf spot on chrysanthemum is caused by the bacteria Pseudomonas cichorii,. It is located on the leaves of the plant, thus even healthy looking mums may be susceptible. It is important to provide the proper growing conditions and watering techniques to avoid it. In order to control leaf spot the use of a cooper hydroxide spray can be beneficial. Apply according to directions and badly infected plants should be removed and destroyed. The following publications can provide further information.
https://www.canr.msu.edu/news/scout_garden_mums_for_insect_pests_to_avoid_surprises

https://www.canr.msu.edu/news/identifying_critter_damage_in_the_garden_and_landscape

https://hgic.clemson.edu/factsheet/chrysanthemum-diseases-insect-pests/
answer.author: Marie LuckAllard

management instructions: Provide proper growing conditions and watering techniques.
Use a copper hydroxide spray according to directions.
Remove and destroy badly infected plants.
