title: Winter peach bud die-off on an otherwise healthy tree; leaf thinning  #831024
question:
We have a six year old "donut" peach tree that has produced a small amount of tasty sweet fruit for last three or four years.  In 2021 it gave us about 5 pounds of fruit;  Last year 20 lbs.  The 2023 winter was unique for Colorado, with temps over multiple consecutive nights hovering in the 0 degree to '20's F range.  Winds were persistent and severe and multiple snowfalls from the tail end of California's "atmospheric rivers" piled up.  Nevertheless, I believed that most of the excess cold and snow came while our fruit trees were still in their dormancy.  So I was surprised to see that our peach, apricot and plum trees this year have had no blossoms and our pear tree born only a clusters of blossoms.   The peach has suffered bud leaf damage as well, so that its completed flush of leaves is quite thin as I write this, on May 19.   I would characterize the peach tree's situation as winter bud frost nip.

I'm hoping to get some advice about pruning.   Most of the the nipped buds which formed late last fall have been stripped by the winds.   Those that remain are easily knocked off and non-viable.   I'll attach some photo showing the result of this.  My question is whether I should leave these denuded whips - which would have been the productive wood this summer - or cut them back to the first green leaves?  Most still have their greenish-brown color, but I don't know whether they would be productive next year.

I strongly suspect others in the Wheat Ridge area and around Colorado have seen similar damage to their fruit trees.  If you have news of front range orchards or of other individual cases, I'd appreciate hearing about them, and if you have some thoughts about pruning I'd also like to hear what you would recommend.  I've already shaped the tree for long term strength.  The objective of course is the best way to restore the tree and see if I can still get a crop next year.


Thanks for any comments.

  

Pictures attached:  Leaf Break in April; Nipped buds; Peach Tree Fully Leaved Out

answer.response:
If I am being asked to rephrase my questions...   

My 6 year old peach tree lost around 70 - 80 % of the leaf and flower buds over the winter, nipped by the protracted cold and multiple freezes.  This left many two-foot-long sections of branches denuded of buds.  The tree has now (May 27) flushed out with new leaves, but the leaf growth is thin compared to previous years.  Some of these bare, pencil thin "whips" have a small cluster of leaves growing out of their outer tip.  Many others have no leaves and a blackened tip where the die-off occurred.   Question:  Should I leave these denuded whips - which would have been the productive wood this summer - or cut them back to the first green leaves?  Most still have their greenish-brown bark and a green cambium layer but I don't know whether they are still a healthy, productive part of the tree.

Simply put, I want advice for pruning away winter bud-die off.
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Hello, and thank you for contacting us.  What a pretty peach tree you have - overall it is a nice shape and appears healthy other than the damaged buds and twigs.

Your pictures do suggest that this tree has winter frost damage although it's hard to diagnose without seeing the tree.  It appears to be several years old, but still young and possibly this is the coldest, wettest winter it has endured.

A general rule in pruning trees in the Rosaceae Family (apples, pears, peaches) is to prune in winter or before budbreak in the spring in order to avoid fire blight.  However a second general rule is to prune out dead or damaged twigs and branches when they occur or are noticed.  When pruning fruit trees, make sure your pruner is sharp and disinfect the blades with 90% rubbing alcohol.  Disinfect the blades again after each cut.  All dead material should be cut below the damage a couple of inches or back to slightly above a healthy bud.  Cut back the denuded twigs similarly, especially those that haven't leafed out at the tips.  The safest course would be to also removed those that have leafed out at the tips as well.  It may not be as productive a year this summer, but these prunes will contribute to healthier future years.

Here is a link to CSU information about fruit trees in general.  It also contains links to pruning and other information.  https://cmg.extension.colostate.edu/Gardennotes/771.pdf.

Another resource that we offer here in Jefferson County is our Fruit Tree Team.  They will visit your property to inspect your trees and make suggestions.  To request a visit, contact the Jefferson County Extension Master Gardener Call Center by email at mastergardener@jeffco.us.  The cost is $25 per hour, and an hour is generally plenty.

Wishing a healthy recovery of your trees!
Jeffco Clinician Annette
answer.author: Jeffco Plant Clinic

answer.response:
Annette,

Thanks for your reply.  I wasn't sure if I was using the web site properly.  I've requested a visit from one of your agents.  I also wondered if you've heard questions from other fruit tree growers about bud die-off - or winter fruit tree damage?  It would be good to know if others in Jefferson County had comparable experience with their fruit trees.  

Thanks for your comments.  I plan to do some pruning today and will follow your advice to limit the tree's exposure to damaged wood.

Best Regards,

Bill Parsons
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Annette,

 

Thanks.  This was a nice response.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a peach tree branch with buds that appear to be either dead or dying, which could be indicative of frost damage from the unusually cold winter conditions in Jefferson County, Colorado. Frost damage often results in dead buds and shoots, and it can affect the overall health and productivity of the tree.

Here is a recommended management strategy for this situation:

1. **Inspect the Tree**: Carefully examine the rest of the tree to assess the extent of the damage. Look for signs of new growth on the branches. If new leaves are not emerging, it may indicate that the buds did not survive the cold weather.

2. **Pruning**: Remove any dead branches or shoots. This will help the tree focus its energy on healthy parts and prevent the spread of disease. Be sure to sterilize your pruning tools between cuts to prevent the spread of bacteria or fungi.

3. **Fertilization**: Apply a balanced fertilizer to promote healthy new growth. Use a product that is suitable for fruit trees and follow the manufacturer’s instructions for application rate and timing.

4. **Watering**: Ensure the tree receives adequate water, especially if the soil is dry. Water deeply but infrequently to encourage deep root growth.

5. **Mulching**: Add a layer of organic mulch around the base of the tree to retain moisture and reduce soil temperature fluctuations. Avoid piling the mulch too close to the trunk as this can lead to rot.

6. **Monitoring**: Keep an eye on the tree throughout the growing season. Look for signs of stress such as yellowing leaves, wilting, or new growth that appears pale or stunted. Adjust your management practices as needed based on these observations.

7. **Pest and Disease Management**: Keep an eye out for pests and diseases that might take advantage of weakened trees. Monitor for signs of insects or fungal diseases and treat accordingly.

8. **Supportive Practices**: Consider providing support to young trees or those that have suffered significant damage to help them maintain their structure as they recover.

By following these steps, you can help the peach tree recover and continue to produce well in the future. It's also advisable to consult with a local horticulturist or agricultural extension agent who can provide more specific advice based on local conditions and the tree's history.

answer.response:
We looked at your photos.  This does not look like spider mites or insect damage.  This brown areas looks like leaf spots.  We  recommend that you focus on proper care. No chemical control is  recommended. The fiddle leaf fig can be tricky to grow indoors.   The fiddle leaf fig in particular grows best  in bright but filtered light (avoid setting in direct sun to avoid leaf burn), slightly cooler night temperatures (~65F), and evenly moist soil. Do not overwater. Here is more information from the U of Illinois and other links

Marian

title: Tree is crying #807960
question: Help. There is something wrong with my mulberry tree. It is crying on both sides and appears to have pus coming from the area that water is oozing out. Leafs are turning brown

answer.response:
Hello Lori

Your tree has wetwood, a disease which trees live with for many years, given good care.

Here are the details—

https://ag.umass.edu/landscape/fact-sheets/wetwood-slime-flux

The leaves have different issues. This is some sort of leaf spot disease caused by another type of fungi. It appears to be Cercospora or a similar fungi.

There are many leaf spot diseases, and most are not life threatening. This late in the season the tree has stored nutrients in the roots for winter, and the leaf spots are a cosmetic issue. To reduce fungi overwintering, rake up all the leaves and discard this fall.

https://www.uaex.uada.edu/yard-garden/plant-health-clinic/docs/2019_Plant_Health_Clinic_Newsletters/Plant%20Health%20Clinic%20Newsletter-Issue%2020.pdf

See this article for how to apply fungicide sprays( always done in spring as leaves bud out) if you decide to spray the tree next spring: https://extension.okstate.edu/fact-sheets/anthracnose-and-other-common-leaf-diseases-of-deciduous-shade-trees.html

Fungicides for use in home gardens include products with the active ingredient mancozeb and chlorothalonil. Please follow all directions and precautions on any chemicals you use. If you are consuming the fruit, you must only use fungicides labeled for fruit trees, and follow the directions on the label.

To keep the tree as healthy as possible:

Deeply water the tree when we have hot dry weather with no rainfall for 10-14 days.

Pull the mulch back from the base of the trunk so it does not touch the bark( reduces chances of rot)

Avoid injuring any areas on trunk or branches. The wet wood started in an old wound. At this time there is nothing to be done for that wound, other than giving the tree good care each year.

To reduce leaf spot diseases, if you are wetting the leaves with a lawn sprinkler either redirect the sprinkler, or water only early in the day so leaves dry out as quickly as possible in the sunlight.

Improve air circulation around the tree and through the branches by properly pruning and thinning other trees and shrubs near it, and thinning the mulberry.

If you prune the tree, use sharp, clean tools and prune correctly. Clean the pruning tool blades with 70% isopropyl alcohol, as recommended in the wetwood article above. Here is a guide on correct pruning of branches. Note figure 2 – and the section on how to correctly prune.

https://extension.missouri.edu/publications/mg8
answer.author: Laura Sheffer

apply fungicide sprays in spring as leaves bud out

pull the mulch back from the base of the trunk

title: Growth on Hickory Tree #805162
question:
We just noticed this on our hickory tree. 

It is though out the tree.

Should we be concerned? 

How should we address this?

answer.response: This is a so-called shelf mushroom.  It is a secondary saprophytic  (lives on declining or dead plant material.  It is not the primary cause of the limb decline.   The limb was already declining due to some cause such as breakage or insect damage.   You need to examine the base of the declining limb where it attaches to a larger part of the tree to see why it may be declining.
answer.author: William Shane

answer.response: I have trimmed of the braches that have the growth.  What should I be looking for at the base of the branch/ limb.
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response: If an insect is involved you will probably see tunneling.  If a disease, then there will be a sunken, often black color to the bark and underlying tissue.  If the wood where you cut off the limb looks normal, you may have eliminated the problem.
answer.author: William Shane

qa_information.disease/issue identification: shelf mushroom (secondary to primary cause such as breakage or insect damage)
management instructions: Examine the base of the declining limb where it attaches to a larger part of the tree to determine the primary cause.
Trim off the branches with the growth.
Look for signs of insect involvement (tunneling) or disease (sunken, black color to the bark and underlying tissue) at the base of the branch.
qa_information.background info: The growth is throughout the tree.

title: Short and soft #590130
question: Hello, I have a grass in my lawn that is much shorter and softer than the rest of the grass(es) in the lawn and I was hoping to identify it because I LOVE it and would love to have the entire yard with this species! Prior to us living here the home was vacant for three years and a large part of the yard, this area included, was overgrown like a field. We have horrendous clay soil, the worst I've ever dealt with. answer.response:
Hi,

Thank you for the picture. Some grasses may be ruled out, but they do not provide enough detail to sufficiently narrow down an identification. Subtle distinctions in details often make a large difference, as you will see in the linked articles. You may be able to make the identification by looking closely at the plants using the articles for guidance. One picture, such as in the picture you sent, may not be sufficient to ascertain a representative feature. The PennState Extension article first discusses, with drawings, the features you need to evaluate, then provides drawings and listed features of various species:  https://extension.psu.edu/the-cool-season-turfgrasses-identification.  The Ohio State Turfgrass Identification key guide you to the species in steps, with some drawings, definitions and a listing of characteristics:  https://buckeyeturf.osu.edu/pdf/01_turfgrass_identification.pdf.  

To use the key, first determine which ligule your grass has among the #1 options, then look at the #2 vernation options for that type of ligule,  After determining the vernation, proceed from level to level in the same manner, evaluating the options only lower than your last determination. A magnifier may help. As noted earlier, I recommend looking at a few samples to make a representative identification.

Other possible means of identification include taking a sample to a knowledgeable garden center or asking whether the OSU Extension for Mahoning County will look at it:  490 South Broad St., Canfield, OH 44406, Phone:  330-533-5538.

Thank you for your question.

title: Damaged leader branch of Black Gum tree #754741
question:
Hello,
I noticed this week that the leader limb of my black gum tree has been killed by cicada damage.  Similar to other branches on the tree which have experienced cicada damage, the top 18 inches is completely brown and dead-looking.  We planted the tree about five years ago.  It was probably 7 ft. tall when we planted it and is now about 15 ft. tall (not sure how old that makes the tree).  The tree was unfortunately too tall and wide to try to install cicada netting, but I am very worried about the loss of the leader branch.  The tree has a very upright growth habit (it's kind of shaped like a Christmas tree) and other than the leader, all the other branches spread outwards horizontally.  Will my tree grow a new leader?  What do I need to do to insure that my tree can continue to grow in a healthy manner?  Thanks for your help!

Sincerely,
Audra Ziegel

answer.response:
Hello Audra,

The tree will probably be fine, as many wild trees lose their leaders due to a range of factors (cicadas, storms, disease, and so on) and go on to have long, productive lives. Regrowth of a new leader in the next year or two is likely, though it can still develop into a pleasantly-shaped tree without a single dominant leader. You don't need to intervene, and while trimming off the broken branch tips would be recommended on a smaller sapling, in this case it would be too impractical given the tree's size.

Miri

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a black gum tree (Nyssa sylvatica) that appears to be healthy, with vibrant green leaves and no obvious signs of disease or structural issues. However, the tree's growth pattern suggests it might benefit from some management strategies to ensure its health and longevity.

### Recommended Management Strategies:

1. **Pruning:**
   - **Reason:** The tree has a very upright growth habit with horizontal spreading branches. This type of growth can lead to an imbalance if not managed properly.
   - **Strategy:** Regular pruning to maintain a balanced shape and to remove any dead, diseased, or crossing branches. This will help distribute sunlight evenly and improve air circulation, which can reduce the risk of disease.

2. **Watering:**
   - **Reason:** Black gum trees prefer well-draining soil but can tolerate a wide range of soil types. However, they require consistent moisture, especially during their early stages.
   - **Strategy:** Ensure the tree is watered regularly, especially during dry spells. A drip irrigation system could be beneficial for maintaining consistent moisture levels.

3. **Mulching:**
   - **Reason:** Mulching helps retain soil moisture and reduces weed competition.
   - **Strategy:** Apply a layer of organic mulch around the base of the tree, being careful not to cover the trunk, as this can lead to disease.

4. **Fertilization:**
   - **Reason:** The tree may benefit from a slow-release fertilizer to promote healthy growth.
   - **Strategy:** Apply a balanced fertilizer in spring, following the manufacturer’s instructions to avoid over-fertilization.

5. **Monitor for Pests and Diseases:**
   - **Reason:** Although the tree looks healthy in the image, it's important to monitor for pests and diseases that could develop over time.
   - **Strategy:** Inspect the tree periodically for signs of pest infestations or diseases. If issues arise, consult with a local horticulturist or arborist for appropriate treatment.

6. **Staking (if necessary):**
   - **Reason:** If the tree is still young, staking might be needed to provide additional support.
   - **Strategy:** Use soft ties and consider removing stakes once the tree has developed a strong trunk and branches.

By implementing these management strategies, you can help ensure that your black gum tree continues to thrive and grow healthily in its environment.

Trimming off the broken branch tips is n: **Staking (if necessary):** Provide additional support with soft ties, considering removing stakes once the tree has developed a strong trunk and branches.

title: What is wrong with my privet hedge? #246753
question: We have a small hedge of privet in areas of our yard, and last year and this year it seems to be really struggling.  I've attached some photos, but part of the plant seems to be dying, and other parts are OK.  There are also other parts that are growing with these very small leaves which I'm not sure are normal.  Any thoughts?

answer.response:
Hello,

We've seen a lot of dieback on shrubs in our landscapes following the November cold snap and the dry, cold, windy winter. With privet, they do have success with "rejuvenation pruning" which means cutting the entire plant down to the ground and the suckers will create a new shrub. Doing it at this time of year can be stressful, but it may be your best option.

Another thing to consider would be to prune out the dead areas of the shrub back to live tissue. This will be cumbersome and may result in shrubs that are not attractive. 

The smaller leaves are from stressors (temperature, drought/excess water, root system dysfunction, etc.). It's just a sign the shrub is under stress. 

The final option would be to remove the shrubs and replant. You can also wait and see if the shrubs continue to push growth through mid-June. But if you gently bend the twigs of areas that haven't leafed out and the twigs snap, it's a sign those tissues are dead.
answer.author: Alison O'Connor

symptom description: part of the plant seems to be dying
other parts have very small leaves
management instructions: Cut the entire plant down to the ground for rejuvenation pruning.
Prune out the dead areas of the shrub back to live tissue.
Remove the shrubs and replant.
Wait and see if the shrubs continue to push growth through mid-June.

title: Could this be mulberry weed? #593185
question: This appeared in our yard in two places - very fast growing and I don't know what it is.  A friend suggested it might be mulberry weed.  I looked it up and it doesn't look exactly like it but very close.  What do you think?  Is it useful for anything?

answer.response: Based on the photos you submitted it appears to be Mulberry Weed or hairy crab weed (Fatoua villosa) (Thunberg) Nakai which is an invasive exotic Asian species from the Mulberry family (Moraceae). It is characterized by papery, heart-shaped, alternate leaves and has densely pubescent (hairy) stems. The flowers are dense, light green cymes (clusters) with no true petals, and seeds that are forcibly expelled. It should be removed and placed in the trash and not composted. The following link provides additional information.   http://extension.udel.edu/factsheets/mulberry-weed-fatoua-villosa/
answer.author: Richard Bentz

answer.response: Thank you, Rick.  Even since I posted this photo, it has spread a lot at the same site and even jumped to a different part of my garden.  I have disposed of it.  Thank you!
answer.author: The Question Asker

management instructions: It should be removed and placed in the trash and not composted.
qa_information.background info: This appeared in our yard in two places - very fast growing.

title: Maple tree #198522
question: What is the problem with this maple and will it kill the tree?

answer.response: This winter was very harsh with temperatures fluctuation between the teens and up to 40 degrees, then down to the teens again and up to the 50's and even 60 degrees, only to drop down to minus 6 degrees.  Every time the temperature warmed up past 40 degrees the tree thought it should start to come out of dormancy, and sap would start to flow up from the roots to the leaf buds.  When the temperatures dropped down after the sun set, the sap and water would be caught in the xylem and would freeze.  Water expands when it freezes so the tree would have to expand as well.  When that happened, small cracks would form and sometimes they would expand up and down the trunk of the tree.  This is called a frost crack.  The best thing that you can do for your tree is to water it with 2-4 gallons of water at least once a week to help keep it hydrated and healthy.  The foliage looks great and the shape of the tree also looks healthy.  Also, please remove any weeds in the mulched area so they don't compete with the tree for the moisture.
answer.author: Ginny Rosenkranz

management instructions: Water the tree with 2-4 gallons of water at least once a week.
Remove any weeds in the mulched area to prevent competition for moisture.
qa_information.background info: The tree experienced a harsh winter with fluctuating temperatures.

title: What are these caterpillars? #585918
question:
I saw two different caterpillars today, that I have never seen in Anchorage before. I thought I submitted photos from Citizen Science portal; I submitted incorrectly under "diseases" and the pictures did not send correctly.
The large brown one was on the road, near Prospect Heights parking lot.
The green one was on a cherry tree in an orchard.

Are they potential dangers to ecology? are they new up here, or have I just missed them?

answer.response:
Hello,
I think these pictures did come through our citizen monitoring portal so hopefully you have seen our response in your email but just in case, to recap:
The brown caterpillar with the impressive red horn on it is commonly called a fireweed hornworm. As adults they are a fairly large moth called a hawk moth. The caterpillars can be the brown or olive green color you observed or they can be jet black. You can read more about them in this writeup from the US Forest Service.
The green caterpillar you found is the larval stage of the western tiger swallowtail butterfly. The butterflies are the big yellow and black butterflies we see in the summertime. You can see pictures of the adults and larvae here.
Both of the caterpillars you found are native to Alaska and are generally not considered pests.
answer.author: The Question Asker

title: Tomato seedling pox on leaves #827452
question:
My tomato seedlings are forming whitish marks/pox on their leaves. This has happened in the past and it almost always resolves once the plant is transplanted outside, but we're several weeks away from planting outside and I'm afraid I'm going to lose A LOT of seedlings this year. After a few days with the marks/pox, the branch will shrivel and die, falling from the stock. New leaves don't display this leaf deformity, only lower branch leaves.

These plants are grown inside under grow lights. The room they are in is ~70 degrees during the day and ~65 degrees during the night. The air circulation in the room isn't that great - there is no fan.

These tomato plants are growing amongst peppers and eggplant, and these don't have the same issues.

answer.response:
These appear to be like blisters.  Is that correct?  If so the plants have edema. overwatering, poor lighting and humid closed environments are the problem.  Solution is ti decrease watering, move to a brighter spot, and use a fan to move air.  This is explained in the following websites.

1. https://www.canr.msu.edu/news/does_light_quality_impact_the_development_of_edema
2. https://extension.umd.edu/resource/edema-problem-high-tunnel-tomatoes
answer.author: Marykay Haas

title: What is this on my strawberry plant? #837358
question: When watering today, I noticed this one strawberry plant stem had these hard yellow concentric balls on the stem. They stick pretty well to the stem. What do you think and how do I get rid of /  prevent them from spreading..... I garden organically. Thank you.

1.response: It  looks to me that those are insect eggs of some kind ( I'll see if I can find an actual identity, but I want to get this answer to you soon.) Unless your strawberry plans are "everbearing" or day-neutrals, you can clip the plants back when they are finished fruiting (probably close to if not now) and since you are gardening organically, the best way  to get rid of the eggs is to clip the stem below the cluster , discard it into a plastic bag or glass jar, and  add either water or vinegar and seal it up. This should destroy the pests (it might take a while) without the use of chemicals. Regular strawberries are normally clipped back after fruiting o allow the plant to rest and gear up for developing new foliage in the following season. A helpful guide to growing strawberries can be found  at extension.oregonstate.edu/publications. Search for "Growing Strawberries in Your Home Garden", EC1307. You can download this for free.
1.author: Marjorie Neal

The presence of these eggs can lead to the infestation of the plant, which may result in leaf damage and reduced fruit yield if not managed properly.

For an organic garden in Jackson County, Oregon, the recommended management strategy for this issue could include the following steps:

1. **Monitor Regularly**: Keep a close eye on the plants for signs of infestation. This will help you catch any issues early and allow you to take immediate action.

2. **Physical Removal**: Manually remove any damaged leaves and dispose of them in a trash bag to prevent the spread of pests.

3. **Beneficial Insects**: Introduce beneficial insects such as ladybugs, lacewings, or parasitic wasps that feed on the pests. These natural predators can help control the population without the use of chemicals.

4. **Incorporate Companion Plants**: Plant companion plants like marigolds, which have been known to repel certain pests, around your strawberry plants.

5. **Use Neem Oil**: Apply neem oil, a natural insecticide, to the plants. Neem oil is derived from the seeds of the neem tree and is effective against many pests, including those that lay eggs on leaves.

6. **Covering**: Use floating row covers to protect the plants from adult pests. These covers allow sunlight and air to pass through but can help reduce the number of pests reaching the plants.

7. **Healthy Soil**: Maintain healthy soil by adding compost and ensuring good drainage. Healthy plants are better able to resist pests and diseases.

8. **Avoid Overwatering**: Ensure that the plants do not get overly wet, as moist conditions can attract pests and promote their breeding.

By implementing these strategies, you can effectively manage the issue without resorting to chemical pesticides, which aligns with organic gardening practices.

title: Die-Off of Ground Cover #481265
question:
Every year during late August our Lamium (Dead Nettle) ground cover dies off and turns brown. Although it is unsightly, it seems to recover again each spring and remains healthy throughout the spring and summer. This area is irrigated by small, drip spray heads. It is located under mature trees and remains in shade except for sun during a few hours in the late afternoon.
What causes this die off and is it preventable?

1.response:
The leaves in your photo look like scorch, however, the plant more closely resembles Aegopodium podagraria (commonly called snow on the mountain, bishop's weed or goutweed) than Lamium maculatum (commonly called Lamium or Dead Nettle). Provided is information on both, in which growing conditions are similar.

 

Aegopodium podagraria does not do well in sun, dry conditions or hot windy weather and can generally look unsightly in the heat of the summer (July & August). CSU recommends for Aegopodium podagraria to look its best, the deeper the shade the better, and to maintain consistently moister soil conditions. Getting more sun exposure or less moisture than necessary results in tip and marginal leaf scorch, dieback, stunted growth, and sometimes leaf drop, which is what appears to be happening.

 

Lamium maculatum also does best in deeper shade with moister soil conditions. It dislikes high heat or humidity, and does best when soils are cool. Lamium struggles to grow well in compacted or poorly drained soils. Unsightly bare patches (often called melting out) may appear in the heat of the summer, particularly in heat or humidity. Leaf scorch may also occur, especially if soils are allowed to dry out or if plants are grown in too much sun.

 

Two other issues to consider are:

1) Pay attention to moisture conditions. Plants under trees and around shrubs and other plants compete for water, so sometimes it is necessary to provide additional supplemental water where competition is high.

2) The rocks may be a contributing factor to excess heat and dry conditions. If this area gets several hours of sun in the afternoon — which is the hottest part of the day — the rocks also raise the temperature of the surrounding area. It appears that a lot of the dieback is in and around these rocks.

 

Below are some links about scorch. Although this information pertains to trees and shrubs, it is also pertinent for groundcovers and many perennials.

http://planttalk.colostate.edu/topics/weeds-cultural-problems/2133-leaf-scorch-trees-shrubs/

http://extension.colostate.edu/topic-areas/yard-garden/leaf-scorch-2-911/

 

Attached are two photos. The first is Aegopodium podagraria (Bishop's weed) and the second is Lamium maculatum (Dead Nettle). Consider verifying which plant you have.
1.author: Donnetta Wilhelm

species: lamium (dead nettle) or aegopodium podagraria (bishop's weed)

management instructions: Maintain consistently moister soil conditions.
Provide additional supplemental water where competition is high.
Consider reducing heat and dry conditions caused by rocks.

title: Grass weed invasion #150203
question: Hi there! We have some crazy type of crabgrass??? that is taking over our yard. We have persistently tried weed be gone with crabgrass contr with zero success.... Any suggestions? Picture below....

1.response:
You are the proud owner of bermudagrass.  This grass will not be controlled by any Ortho product, but it was a valiant effort.  Right now, this warm season grass is loving the hot, dry weather and it's probably growing vigorously.  After the first frost, this grass will turn brown.  But will green up again next spring and continue to invade your lawn.

If you want to control it, you'll have to hire a lawn care company to apply Tenacity (mesotrione) every 7-10 days.  Now is the perfect time to do this.  If you want to do it yourself, you can buy the product online, but make sure you read the directions carefully and only apply as directed.  It's expensive.  You'll only need a minuscule amount per gallon (just a few drops).  You may consider pricing out the lawn care company versus buying it yourself...in the long run, it may be cheaper to hire the job out.  I know that Lawn Doctor in Fort Collins uses this product, but there are other companies that can quote you.

Tenacity works by stopping photosynthetic production in the leaf, so the plants will start to turn white.  It can cause some phytotoxic effects to your bluegrass, but it will recover.  Apply every 7-10 days at least three times, maybe even four.  After the product dries, make sure to keep watering the lawn...the healthier the plant is, the more effect the herbicide will have.

The other option would be to use glyphosate (Round up), knowing this will kill all green vegetation...and it will take probably at least three applications 7-10 days apart.  Between Round up and Tenacity, Tenacity is far superior control.  Also, if you use Round up, you'll have to reseed.  

Pulling it or digging it out is not an option, as it spreads by vigorous rhizomes (your picture is perfect).  If you leave a small piece of root in the ground, it will re-grow.  Please let me know if you have other questions.
1.author: Alison O'Connor

management instructions: Apply Tenacity (mesotrione) every 7-10 days.
Hire a lawn care company to apply Tenacity (mesotrione) every 7-10 days.
Use glyphosate (Round up) at least three applications 7-10 days apart.
Water the lawn after the product dries.
Apply Tenacity at least three times, maybe even four.

title: Whats eating my black eyed susan? #747703
question:
The new growth on my black eyed susan shows some signs of distress. Looks like some critter is eating it. 
I scratch around the surface of the dirt surrounding the plant but found no bug or grub. Any ideas?

answer.response:
Hi Ken, 

I suspect from some of the notching on the leaf that it may be root weevil, a very common problem on landscape plants in Central Oregon. 

https://extension.oregonstate.edu/gallery/common-insects-found-urban-landscapes-central-oregon

title: Wild (weed) Grass #312698
question:
Hi, we have this little grass-like weed coming in like crazy in our yard.  Especially I the lesser drained areas.

Any guidance on how to eradicate it (without much toxic chemical use)?  It's invaded our ground cover and weeding by hand is not doing the trick!

Thanks much!
Wendy

1.response:
Thank you for including an image of the unwanted plants in your garden. They are pearlwort (Sagina procumbens), plants often mistaken for moss. Pearlwort thrives in moist to wet areas, in sun and/or in shade. Eradication will require extended effort over a number of seasons.

Pearlwort spreads vigorously by rooting at the stems and by a multitude of extremely tiny black seeds which can spread  up to 16 inches from the other plant. By the time pearlwort is in flower, it’s also producing seeds!  Unfortunately, it can set seed and sprout from April through September!

You can decrease the pearlwort population somewhat if you can eliminate the source of moisture, including excess irrigation. If you want to limit your action to weeding, you must remove seedlings as soon as you see them and definitely before they set seeds in their  very tiny white flowers. Even so, you must be persistent for an extended period.

Glyphosate, the active ingredient in various home garden herbicides (such as Roundup and Kleenup) will kill pearlwort.  Painting glyphosate onto each pearlwort plant is effective and also protects nearby plants from inadvertent damage. To do so, pour a small amount from the product’s container into a cup or other container you’ve reserved for this purpose only.  Then use a small paint brush (which you’ll also earmark for this purpose) to paint each plant. Just as with hand removal, you must act before the plants set seed, preferably before they even bloom. Follow all other precautions on the product label. Again, persistent action will pay off.
1.author: Jean R. Natter

management instructions: Eliminate the source of moisture, including excess irrigation.
Remove seedlings as soon as you see them and definitely before they set seeds in their very tiny white flowers.
Use glyphosate, the active ingredient in various home garden herbicides, to kill pearlwort.
Paint glyphosate onto each pearlwort plant to protect nearby plants from inadvertent damage.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The plant in the image appears to be pearlwort (Sagina subulata), which is indeed a common invader in poorly drained areas, as mentioned in the background information. Pearlwort can quickly spread and dominate ground cover, making it difficult to control manually.

Given the context of the location and time provided, here are some recommended management strategies for controlling pearlwort:

### 1. **Chemical Control**
   - **Herbicides**: Use selective herbicides that target broadleaf weeds like pearlwort without harming grasses or other desirable plants. Commonly used products include 2,4-D or triclopyr. It's important to follow the application guidelines carefully, especially when applying near trees or other sensitive plants.
   - **Preventative Measures**: Apply these herbicides before the pearlwort seedlings emerge in early spring (April/May) to prevent their establishment. Repeat applications may be necessary depending on the severity of infestation.

### 2. **Physical Control**
   - **Manual Removal**: While challenging due to its rapid spread, regular hand-pulling can be effective if done promptly. Be sure to remove the entire root system to prevent re-growth.
   - **Mulching**: Applying a thick layer of organic mulch (like wood chips or straw) can smother the pearlwort and other weeds. Ensure the mulch covers the soil completely and is reapplied annually as it breaks down.

### 3. **Mechanical Control**
   - **Tillage**: Light cultivation with a cultivator can help disrupt the pearlwort roots, although this method is labor-intensive and may require repeated applications.
   - **Trimmers and Edgers**: Using electric trimmers or edging tools can effectively remove the surface growth of pearlwort, but this method also requires regular maintenance.

### 4. **Cultural Control**
   - **Improving Drainage**: Ensuring proper drainage in the area can reduce the likelihood of pearlwort infestation. This might involve adding compost or improving the soil structure.
   - **Healthy Grass Cover**: Maintaining a dense layer of healthy grass can outcompete pearlwort. Regular mowing and fertilization can help establish a strong grass cover.

### 5. **Biological Control**
   - **Natural Predators**: While there are no known natural predators of pearlwort, introducing species that feed on it could potentially help control its spread. However, this approach is still experimental and not widely used.

### 6. **Integrated Pest Management (IPM)**

title: Red bugs #467166
question: These red bugs are in my garden. I do volunteer gardening in a hospital garden and they are in the mulch and rocks around the garden. What can I do to control them

1.response:
Good evening,

The bug in the picture you sent is a nymph Boxelder bug. Boxelder bugs normally feed on the leaves, flowers, and seedpods of the boxelder tree or silver maple. Large infestations are usually on the female, or pod bearing, tree. While they may feed on male boxelder trees and other trees and plants, they usually do not build up to such large numbers. Boxelder bugs can also be found on the surface of mulch feeding on seeds of various seeds of maple trees that have landed there from nearby trees. The adults' search for a place to overwinter brings them into houses where they hide in small cracks and crevices in walls, door and window casings, attics, and around the foundation. During warm days in winter and early spring they come out and scatter through the house. They are primarily a nuisance pest as they crawl or fly about in the rooms. LIFE CYCLE: The adult bugs lay eggs in the spring and the nymphs emerge in a few days. The nymphs are small and show redder than adults. These nymphs develop into adults during the summer, then mate and lay eggs, which hatch into the nymphs of the second generation. Activity of nearly fully-grown nymphs is noticed in August and September when they gather in large numbers on the trunks of boxelder trees. The migration of the adults begins at this time.                                                                                                                               These bugs are not destructive and can be sprayed with a water hose or warm soapy water to remove them off your home. Laundry detergent and water mixes are cheap, safe and effective when applied directly to boxelder bugs. Drawbacks of detergent sprays are that they will kill only if they contact the insect directly, and they may damage vegetation. Chemical control is not needed.

 Thank you for using Ask an Expert.
1.author: Vicki Laurin

title: Peony problem #634531
question: One of my peonies has developed a problem on the younger buds and on some of the younger stems at ground level. The more mature buds seem to be developing okay, but the smaller ones have turned black and some of the thinner stems to the buds have curled over. Most of the plant still looks fine, though. I hope the problem won’t spread throughout the plant.

answer.response:
This looks like a fungal disease known as botrytis. The stems look highly infected as well as the buds.  

This fungus overwinters in soil and splashes back up onto plants in the spring. Cut off infected parts now. It appears that this will mean cutting it down to ground level this year. Let new foliage come up from the clean roots (which don't get infected.)  

 After you cut off infected parts, you may want to clear mulch around the plant so that you can get to the soil and scrape away the surface soil where the fungal spores are. Use some new clean soil to replace it. Then mulch with clean mulch. You could put 3-4 layers of newspaper under the mulch to make the barrier more impenetrable.  

 Here's more: https://extension.umd.edu/hgic/topics/petal-blight-botrytis

Remove peony foliage each fall so the spores don't overwinter. 

Ellen
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

symptom description: thinner stems to the buds have curled over
management instructions: Cut off infected parts.
Clear mulch around the plant and scrape away the surface soil where the fungal spores are.
Replace with new clean soil and mulch with clean mulch.
Remove peony foliage each fall so the spores don"t overwinter.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows some stems of a peony plant that appear to have brown or dead spots on their bark, which could be indicative of various issues such as disease, pests, or environmental stress. Here are some steps you might consider to address the issue:

1. **Identify the Cause**: 
   - **Disease**: Look for signs of specific diseases like canker (caused by fungi) or powdery mildew. Cankers may appear as dark, sunken areas on the stem that can eventually girdle the stem, leading to death. Powdery mildew typically presents as a white, powdery growth on leaves and stems.
   - **Pests**: Check if there are insects like aphids or scale insects present, which can cause discoloration and dieback.
   - **Environmental Stress**: Extreme weather conditions, such as drought or excessive rain, can also cause browning of the stems.

2. **Pruning**:
   - If the issue appears to be localized (e.g., just a few stems), consider pruning out the affected parts to prevent the disease from spreading further.
   - Use clean, sharp pruners and disinfect them with rubbing alcohol between cuts to avoid introducing new pathogens.

3. **Fertilization and Watering**:
   - Ensure the soil around the peony is not overly wet or dry. Peonies prefer moist but well-drained soil.
   - Fertilize sparingly during the growing season. Avoid fertilizing too much or too close to the stem as this can lead to burn.

4. **Disease Management**:
   - Apply a fungicide if you suspect fungal infection. Choose a product labeled for use on peonies and follow the instructions carefully.
   - Keep the garden area well-maintained; remove and dispose of dead plant material to reduce the chances of disease spread.

5. **Check the Buds**:
   - Since the more mature buds seem to be developing okay, it’s important to focus on the health of the rest of the plant. Continue to monitor the affected stems and other parts of the plant for signs of improvement or worsening.

6. **Consult an Expert**:
   - If the issue persists or worsens, consult with a local horticulturist or a certified pest management professional who can provide more specific advice based on your location and climate.

By addressing these potential causes and implementing appropriate management strategies, you should be able to help the peony recover and maintain its health.

title: Deformed honey crisp apples #851213
question:
So I have 2 Honey Crisp trees and the majority of the applies are deformed. I believe it is a Apple magot, but not 100% sure. I did start spraying with Seven in late June or early July, but I think the damage had been done. 

Can I do anything now so that I have better apples next year? Is it really apple magot?

answer.response:
Hi Brian,

This is insect damage from apple maggots and possibly plum curculio. If you want apples that are free of insect damage you need to follow a spray program or find ways to exclude the bugs. Apple maggots are active most of the summer.

The issue with using sprays is that you need to apply after every rain (which wasn't really an issue this year!). The easiest organic way to keep bugs out of apples is by bagging them early in their development.

Here’s a guide to dealing with apple maggot, including bagging the fruit:

https://extension.umn.edu/yard-and-garden-insects/apple-maggot

I have a Honeycrisp and for many years have bagged apples. It’s a time investment when you’re slipping baggies on small fruit in June, but it’s worth it because you don’t have to repeatedly spray. A guide to bagging is included in the above link.

Some advice if you choose to bag fruit: timing is critical. You need to bag when the apples are about the size of a grape. And stapling the baggie on either side of the fruit stem is a good way to ensure that the bags don’t blow off. Just pressing the bags shut doesn’t work that well.

Some people use these imperfect apples in pies or cider.

Hope this helps. Good luck.
answer.author: Mary Jane Smetanka

management instructions: follow a spray program
exclude the bugs
bag the apples early in their development

title: Wasps in my house #681208
question: In late Aug and Sept we had wasps getting into our house.  We were able to identify what we think was the point of entry but did not see a nest.  It seemed to be at the point where a pipe goes into the house about 3ft up from ground level.  Either because my husband sprayed or in spite of it they did stop coming in. They were limited to one room in our walkout lower level.  Now I just found 2 dead wasps in an upstairs bedroom behind a couch that is in front of a window.  I assume they are from this summer but very surprised that they were upstairs.  Attached is an image of the front and back of what I just found.  I would like to know what type of wasp this is.  If the nest was under the siding or in a wall will we have the same problem this year?

answer.response:
The insect in the photo is a kind of yellow jacket.  Compare here:
https://images.app.goo.gl/ABPkNBDNsueyGA936

Go here to learn about them:
https://lancaster.unl.edu/pest/resources/SocialWasp.shtml

The sealed entry point probably led to a nest somewhere in a wall void or similar space.

The only yellow jackets alive indoors in Minnesota at this time of year are queens that have come out of dormancy after entering to overwinter. Nests where they originated (possibly the one you sealed) have been abandoned and will not be used again.

However, queens that overwinter will establish new nests in spring, perhaps in suitable spaces in or around the premises.  So watch for them and seal any cracks or crevices you think they might enter to nest or overwinter.

Here is a link to more useful information:
https://ohioline.osu.edu/factsheet/HYG-2075-11
answer.author: Bob Bystrom

management instructions: seal any cracks or crevices
watch for new nests in spring

title: Birch tree leaves all drying off and falling. #422159
question:
I have a large birch tree that is now dropping most of its leaves, they are turning light brown. We had hail damage in June but that is the only tree in my yard that is doing that. I have green ash, locust, maple, basswood and crabapple trees. I don't see any Asian beetles, what is causing this and what should I do about it.
Thanks

answer.response:
The lacy, skeletonized leaves in the pictures are classic japanese beetle damage and birch are one of the beetles favorite species. I think if you look next year you will see the birch is covered in beetles. The beetles prefer the topmost, sun exposed leaves so check out the top of the tree with binoculars. The Japanese beetles are almost done for the year so they may not be feeding on your tree now.
http://blog-yard-garden-news.extension.umn.edu/2017/07/dealing-with-japanese-beetles.html
 Your tree may also have other problems so please check out the information about why a birch might drop leaves in summer.
http://homeguides.sfgate.com/birch-leaf-turning-yellow-summer-65959.html
answer.author: Claire Kari

management instructions: check the top of the tree with binoculars

title: Boxwood Browning #795600
question: We have some transplanted boxwood about a year now that are turning brown. I am having a hard time figuring out why. They get a light watering every day as it is hot here in Houston. Any ideas where to start. I am in Brazoria county TX. Thank you

answer.response:
From the pictures and your comments, I believe you are over watering it and either drowning its roots or promoting root rot fungus.


If it has been in the ground a year it should only need to be watered once a week in the absence of rain.  Faily watering will keep the soil too moist.  Especially if you have heavy clay soils that are common in your area.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows leaves of a boxwood plant that appear to have brown tips or edges, which could indicate several issues such as overwatering, underwatering, nutrient deficiencies, salt accumulation, or pest infestations. Given the location in Brazoria County, Texas, with heavy clay soil and hot weather, some common challenges for boxwoods include:

1. **Overwatering**: Clay soils retain water longer, leading to root rot if the plant is not allowed to dry out properly between waterings.
2. **Nutrient Deficiencies**: Boxwoods can suffer from iron deficiency, which might cause yellowing of the leaves with green veins (chlorosis).
3. **Salt Accumulation**: If the soil is heavily amended with fertilizers, salt buildup can occur, leading to leaf discoloration.
4. **Pest Infestations**: Boxwood adelgid is a common pest that can cause discoloration and leaf drop.

### Recommended Management Strategies:
1. **Inspect Soil Moisture**: Ensure the soil is not overly wet. Check the depth of the water penetration; if the soil stays wet for more than two weeks, consider increasing the interval between watering.
2. **Check for Salt Buildup**: Apply chelated iron or elemental sulfur to address any nutrient deficiencies. For salt buildup, leach the soil with water until clear, then apply an appropriate fertilizer.
3. **Monitor for Pests**: Look for signs of adelgids or other pests by closely inspecting the undersides of leaves. Treat with an insecticide if necessary.
4. **Adjust Fertilization Practices**: Use a balanced, slow-release fertilizer suitable for boxwoods. Avoid over-fertilizing, especially in clay-rich soils.
5. **Prune and Shape**: Prune dead or damaged foliage to promote new growth and maintain healthy appearance.

If the issue persists despite these measures, consider consulting a local horticulturist or agricultural extension service for further assistance tailored to your specific conditions.

title: Black locust? spreading #596918
question: BGE cut down one of my trees which I think was a black locust (maybe?) and now little babies are sprouting up all over in a huge radius around where the stump was.  How can I get this under control, please?

1.response:
The roots are still alive and have a lot of energy stored in them.  They will continue to put out shoots in an effort to survive for a while.  If you keep mowing them down, it will eventually exhaust the reserves and that will kill the roots.  

You could also try to speed up the process by spraying the shoots and leaves with a glyphosate herbicide, however this is a total vegetation killer and will kill anything it contacts, such as your lawn.  

Easiest thing is to just keep mowing and let the situation resolve itself.
 
Ellen

2.response: Yay!  That’s easy... thanks, Ellen.

title: Strange growth on oak? #768206
question: Wondering if you can identify this strange... gall?  Epiphyte?  Parasite?  On our swamp white oak.  Please see attached.  The tree is on the Huron River floodplain in Hamburg Township and is about 8 ft tall.  I've had no luck trying to identify it on the web.

answer.response:
Hello,

Swamp white oak, (Quercus bicolor), is a striking tree with peeling bark when it is young. Read more here: https://www.missouribotanicalgarden.org/PlantFinder/PlantFinderDetails.aspx?kempercode=q330

Like all oaks, swamp white oak is susceptible to attack from many insects and diseases including galls.

The growth on the leaves of your swamp white oak is a lobed gall caused by a stem gall wasp.

Galls form when the larva of tiny gall wasps feed on the leaves, twigs or branches and the tree responds by producing hormones which produce abnormal growth composed of plant tissue.

Oak trees support many different gall wasps. They usually are not harmful to the trees and it is difficult to control them with pesticides which would have to be applied in the spring when the wasps are so tiny that they cannot be readily seen.

Read more about galls here: https://www.missouribotanicalgarden.org/gardens-gardening/your-garden/help-for-the-home-gardener/advice-tips-resources/pests-and-problems/other/galls/gouty-horned-and-other-twig-galls.aspx

Thank you for contacting Ask Extension
answer.author: Susan I. Campbell

title: Weeping Crabapple Tree #834376
question:
Hello,
For the last 3-5 years my weeping crabapple tree gets what I believe is apple scab. I've sprayed it with a fungicide for fruit trees but in late spring/ early summer it always comes back. It drops its leaves, the leaves have spots and the turn yellow
I'd like to know what other steps I can take to prevent this from happening year after year. I'd also would like to know if pruning the tree at this time of year is okay to do. Would getting more air circulation help it? I certainly don't want to stress it out. Please help!!

answer.response:
Thank you for your question about apple scab on crabapples.

Keep in mind this is a cosmetic issue for home owners as this typically will not kill the tree. Apple scab is never fatal but disfigures the tree and reduces vigor.

Steps to take to help with apple scab disease.

1. Rake up and remove infected leaves from underneath trees. 
2. Avoid overhead watering. 
3. Plant resistant cultivars where possible but this doesn't help with an existing tree. 
4. Registered fungicides can be applied preventatively at 2-week intervals beginning at budbreak until after petal fall.

Pruning should be done in dormant times; winter to very early spring.   

Also make sure your tree does not have burnt looking branches that indicate fire blight.  When pruning a fire blight tree always go back 6-12” of healthy tissue and remove along with cankered area or to point of attachment. Then sanitize pruners with every cut with a disinfectant solution such as bleach.

Here are a couple of reference points:
https://www.canr.msu.edu/resources/apple_scab

https://extension.umaine.edu/gardening/2022/11/22/when-do-you-prune-crabapple-trees/

I hope this helps address your question, but if not you may respond.
answer.author: Karl Farwig - MGV

management instructions: Rake up and remove infected leaves from underneath trees.
Avoid overhead watering.
Apply registered fungicides preventatively at 2-week intervals beginning at budbreak until after petal fall.
Prune in dormant times; winter to very early spring.

title: Itea disease? #405348
question: Itea was planted in April in full sun. It seemed healthy. Now leaves have spots and are turning yellow. What is the proper action?

1.response:
Itea gets fungal leaf spots, but this is not typically a serious disease for these plants. You do not need to spray or apply any treatment, as that would not provide any "cure" at this point. Since it was just planted in April, it needs time to get established. These can get over-irrigated in the nurseries sometimes, which can contribute to the development of these leaf spots. We see this commonly, but it is not typically persistent is subsequent years. You can rake up and dispose of the fallen leaves. Keep it well watered during hot, dry periods, especially in this first year, to help it get its roots established.

title: Can you identify this pink flower?  Grew in yard very fast #215882
question: Can you identify what this flower is?  It took a week to grow 36 inches in height and fully bloomed.  Thanks

answer.response:
Yes, indeed - this is Lycoris radiata commonly called spiderlily. An old fashioned, persistent bulb that blooms once temperatures cool a little and late summer rains arrive. Blooms appear first, followed by long strap-like foliage. Allow the foliage to mature and when yellow, it can be cut. This process allows the bulb to be "energized - nourished" for next year's bloom. The best time to relocate them, is when the foliage yellows in spring. See our article at this location for more information:
http://aggie-horticulture.tamu.edu/newsletters/hortupdate/2009/Sep09/rainl.html

title: Critter tunneling in yard #736287
question: Hi  I occasionally get moles in my yard and believe there's a vast underground tunnel system that they created and I have a new critter that seems to be using those tunnels. There's no dirt mounds with this one and lately has become very, very aggressive and now have holes forming all over my yard. I've attached a couple of photos to see if I can get help identifying what this is and what might be a good plan to deal with them.  I have a few very active dogs and am very afraid one might hurt their leg in one of those holes.  Any help or advice you can give me would be much appreciated. Thank you.  Kris

answer.response:
Those sort of holes -- without any soil mounding -- typically means voles are active. Voles relatively easy to manage with ordinary mouse traps.

However, if your property backs up to a greenway, or other untended area, other voles will repeatedly move in to take up the vacancy. Even so, you will be able to gain the upper hand if you are persistent.
See, or download, the free publication  "Meadow Voles and pocket Gophers" at https://www.extension.uidaho.edu/publishing/pdf/PNW/PNW0627.pdf .
If the holes are restricted to one area of the lawn, protect your dogs by temporarily fencing it off.
answer.author: Jean R. Natter

management instructions: use ordinary mouse traps
temporarily fence off area to protect dogs

title: Lilac issue #850624
question: What is this gray film on my lilac? And how do I get rid of it? Thanks!

answer.response:
Hi Kellie,

Thank you for the very helpful photos.  With close up and wide angle photos and am able to say with relative certainty that your lilac bush (and pumpkin plant) have powdery mildew. It is a common fungus among squash and cucumber plants. If you noticed it first on your pumpkin plant, it likely infected your lilac bush. If you want a definitive diagnosis, please bring in or mail a sample. Here are instructions.  You can also drop off a sample at the Boulder County Extension Office at 9595 Nelson Rd, Longmont.  303-678-6238
Main points:
  • For the pumpkins, remove the infected leaves and throw in the trash. Do not compost. 
  • Since your lilac has such a widespread infection, treating with a fungicide as outlined in the resources below and intense pruning are advised.
  • Make sure you are not overwatering the area and there is sufficient air space at the base and around the plants.
Here are a couple of resources for Powdery Mildew on lilacs and Cucumbers, Pumpkins and Squash.

Your lilac bush could use some pruning to let more air circulate throughout. While it is best to prune lilac stems right after blooms fade (blooms appear on old wood), your shrub may benefit from a Rejuvenation Pruning now and Annual Pruning going forward. 

Best,

CSU Extension Boulder County Master Gardeners

title: black leaves on myrtle tree #752740
question: We noticed last summer that our myrtle (Bay) tree had a lot of black film on it's leaves with "eggs" or something on the back. It seems to be even worse this spring. Would like to know what it is and how to treat it.

answer.response:
Hello, and thank you for contacting Ask Extension about your bay laurel tree.

t appears your tree has a scale insect. These small insects protect themselves under a wax coating while they feed. Some of these sucking insects can transmit plant diseases. Scale is a difficult pest to control and there are many types of scale. Not all controls work on all species. I have compiled some information on controls for scale. 

Scale insects remove sugar-rich fluids from plants and eliminate a sticky material, called honeydew. The black fungus on the leaves is called sooty mold that grows on the honeydew. This mold decreases the aesthetic value of plants and stresses them further by blocking the sunlight needed for photosynthesis. 

FOLIAGE SPRAY

Horticultural oil is effective in spring or summer on broadleaf evergreens when sprayed soon after most crawlers have emerged and most scales are in the young nymph stage. Thoroughly cover with spray the plant parts where scales occur, typically on twig terminals and the underside of leaves.

With all insecticides, be sure to completely read and follow the product label instructions for safe and effective use. Insecticides can have unintended effects, such as contaminating water, poisoning natural enemies and pollinators, and causing secondary pest outbreaks. 

Complete spray coverage of infested plant parts with horticultural oil at the proper time provides good control of most scales. Horticultural oils (e.g., Bonide Horticultural Oil and Monterey Horticultural Oil) are specially refined petroleum products, often called narrow-range, superior, or supreme oils. Other nonpersistent, contact sprays for garden and landscape plants include insecticidal soap (Safer Brand Insect Killing Soap Concentrate II), neem oil (Bayer Advanced Natria Neem Oil Concentrate, Green Light Neem, Garden Safe Brand Neem).

These insecticides have low toxicity to people and pets and relatively little adverse impact on the populations of pollinators and natural enemies and the benefits they provide. To obtain adequate control, thoroughly wet the infested plant parts with spray, typically shoot terminals and the underside of leaves. More than one application per growing season may be needed, especially if the targeted pest has more than one generation a year.

Dormant Season (Winter treatment)

To control most scales overwintering on deciduous woody plants, thoroughly spray the bark of terminal shoots with oil during winter. For oak pit scales, sycamore scale, and other harder to control species, spray during the plant’s delayed-dormant period, which is after the buds swell but before buds open.

Precautions on Using Oils

Follow product labels, which may say to not spray certain plant species or mix oil with certain other products. Do not apply oil or other insecticides when it is foggy, freezing (under 32°F), hot (over 90°F), when relative humidity is above 90%, or if rain is expected in the next 24 hours. Especially at locations with hot weather, be sure plants are well irrigated before spraying foliage.

SYSTEMIC INSECTICIDES

These products may be for licensed professional applicators only. Neonicotinoids vary in effectiveness for scale control. Some are effective on one type of scale but not another, so positive identification of the species of scale insect is necessary. Systemics can translocate into flowers and have adverse effects on natural enemies and pollinators that feed on nectar and pollen. 

I hope this information is useful. If you have any other questions, please write again.
answer.author: Lynne Marie Sullivan

image description: eggs or something on the back of leaves
management instructions: use horticultural oil in spring or summer

apply insecticidal soap or neem oil
apply systemic insecticides (for licensed professionals only)

title: Weed identification & control #468947
question: I am trying to identify a vining weed that is infesting my flower beds.  It is mostly on my tall garden phlox, but also on other plants.  I've attached pictures and would like to know how to control it.

answer.response:
Hi,

I think this is hog peanut (crazy name, huh?). Here is some information: https://www.minnesotawildflowers.info/flower/american-hog-peanut

It can be controlled with glyphosate (the active herbicide in Roundup), but that is a non-selective herbicide and will kill any vegetation with which it comes into contact. You could try cutting down the stem of the weed and then applying glyphosate with a small paintbrush - again, great care must be taken so that the herbicide does not touch the desirable plants.

You can try pulling it out (which is what I would try first). Hog peanut is an annual weed, so if you can pull out most of the plants before they seed, you should be able to really knock back the weed going forward.
answer.author: Susan Trent

management instructions: Controlled with glyphosate
Cut down the stem of the weed and then apply glyphosate with a small paintbrush
Try pulling it out

title: Damage to holly bush #646954
question: Our holly tree looks to be taken over by some sort of pest or mildew (pictures attached - white pest (?) on the bottom of leaves and black chalky residue on the top) Can you help me identify what this is and how I might remedy the problem? Thanks so much for any help you can provide!

answer.response:
This looks like cottony camellia scale on the holly foliage. This insect has one generation a year. They are sucking insects that exude something called honeydew as they feed. Then a fungus called sooty mold grows on the honeydew causing a black coating to grow on the leaves.
You can prune out the heavily infested parts of the holly. Spraying with a summer rate of horticultural oil is recommended. Do not spray when temperatures are above 85 degrees.  Read and follow the label directions for information on usage and mixing dilution rate. Coverage will be difficult as you will have to target the upper and undersides of the foliage and bark. This can knock the insects back but will not eliminate them.
In the late fall (mid-October-November) you can spray again with a dormant rate of horticultural oil.

Another option if your holly is large is contacting a commercial landscaper as they have insecticides that cannot be applied by a homeowner.

The following is information from our website https://extension.umd.edu/hgic/topics/cottony-camellia-scale-shrubs

Deb
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a holly plant with leaves that appear to have some damage, possibly from insect infestation or disease. Given the time of year (June) and location (Baltimore County, Maryland), it's important to consider the typical pests and diseases that affect holly during this period.

### Potential Issues:
1. **Holly Leaf Miner (Aculops hollae)** - This is a common pest that can cause leaf damage by mining into the leaves.
2. **Fungal Diseases** - Such as powdery mildew or rust, which can cause spots on the leaves.
3. **Insects** - Aphids, mites, or other small insects could also be causing the damage.

### Management Strategies:
1. **Inspect the Plant Thoroughly**: Look closely at the leaves for signs of insect infestation or fungal growth.
2. **Identify the Cause**:
   - **Leaf Miner**: Look for small, white, serpentine mines in the leaves. Treatment involves horticultural oils or insecticidal soap.
   - **Fungal Diseases**: Look for powdery white spots or brown lesions on the leaves. Fungal diseases might require fungicides like neem oil or sulfur-based sprays.
   - **Insect Infestations**: Identify the specific insects and choose appropriate pesticides if necessary. For example, aphids can be controlled with insecticidal soaps or neem oil.
3. **Prune Affected Leaves**: Remove and destroy any leaves that show significant damage to prevent spread.
4. **Promote Plant Health**: Ensure the plant is receiving adequate water, sunlight, and nutrients. Good soil health and mulching can help the plant resist pests and diseases.
5. **Monitor for Recurrence**: Regularly inspect the plant for signs of recurrence and treat as needed.

### Recommended Actions:
- **Apply Horticultural Oil or Insecticidal Soap**: If leaf miner activity is suspected, apply a horticultural oil or insecticidal soap to the affected areas.
- **Fungicide Application**: If fungal diseases are evident, use a fungicide such as neem oil or sulfur.
- **General Care**: Ensure the holly is well-watered and fertilized appropriately for its needs.

By identifying and addressing the specific issue present, you can manage the problem effectively and maintain the health of your holly plant.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image you've provided shows a grassy area with seedlings growing among it. Given the background information, these seedlings appear to be an invasive species, possibly an unwanted plant that is competing with the desired grass for resources. Here are some recommended management strategies for dealing with this situation:

1. **Chemical Control**: Consider using selective herbicides designed to target broadleaf weeds. These products can be applied directly to the seedlings while being careful not to damage the surrounding grass. Always read and follow the label instructions carefully.

2. **Physical Removal**: While manual removal isn't feasible due to the large number of seedlings, physical methods like mulching can help suppress their growth. Apply a thick layer of organic mulch (like wood chips or straw) around the base of the seedlings to smother them. This method is less effective on larger seedlings but can be used as a preventive measure.

3. **Cultural Controls**: Ensure the lawn is healthy and well-maintained. A strong, dense lawn can outcompete the seedlings by using more water, nutrients, and sunlight. Regular mowing at the appropriate height and fertilizing when necessary can help the lawn stay competitive.

4. **Biological Controls**: If applicable, introduce natural predators or diseases that affect the seedlings but do not harm the desired grasses. This approach requires research and may not always be feasible or effective.

5. **Preventive Measures**: Planting a more competitive grass variety, such as one that is better adapted to the local climate and soil conditions, can prevent new invasions. Additionally, maintaining consistent and appropriate watering and fertilization practices can help the existing grass remain dominant.

Given that the seedlings are taking over the lawn, a combination of chemical control and cultural practices might be the most effective short-term solution. Always consult with a local extension agent or a professional landscaper for specific recommendations tailored to your location and the particular species of seedlings present.

title: leaves turning brown on my elm tree #335581
question: This spring my elm tree's leaves are turning brown and many are falling off. What's wrong with my tree? Is it going to live through this? Is there something I can do to stop the leaves from falling off? Is there a local expert (in Fort Collins, CO) you can suggest who can help me fix the problem? Thanks!

1.response:
Hello,

Your elm tree has elm leafminer, which is very common this year. Fortunately, it doesn't cause long-term harm and looks worse than it is. Treatment is unnecessary and wouldn't be effective at this point in the season.

Here is more information from CSU Extension: http://extension.colostate.edu/topic-areas/insects/leafmining-insects-5-548/

There are numerous natural predators of leafminers in our environment and sometimes doing treatment to control the leafminers results in destruction of these natural predators. 

These leaves will likely start to fall early, and it's important to rake them up and throw them in the trash to try to break the lifecycle of the insect next season.
1.author: Alison O'Connor

management instructions: rake up fallen leaves and throw them in the trash to break the lifecycle of the insect
qa_information.background info: the issue started this spring, location is Fort Collins, CO

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows an elm tree with leaves that have signs of leaf spot, which is a common disease affecting elm trees. This condition can be caused by various fungal pathogens and typically manifests as spots on the leaves, which can eventually lead to leaf discoloration and premature defoliation.

### Recommended Management Strategies:

1. **Fungicide Application**: Consider applying fungicides that are effective against the specific fungus causing the leaf spot. It's important to choose a fungicide that is registered for use on elms and that is labeled for the disease you're treating. Always follow the manufacturer's instructions carefully.

2. **Pruning**: Remove any affected or dead branches. This helps to reduce the spread of the disease and allows fresh air to circulate, which can help prevent the disease from spreading further.

3. **Cultural Practices**: Maintain good cultural practices such as proper watering and fertilization. Overwatering can increase the risk of fungal diseases, so ensure that the soil around the tree is well-drained. Avoid overhead watering, as this can promote fungal growth.

4. **Healthy Tree Care**: Ensure the overall health of the tree by providing adequate nutrients, water, and sunlight. A healthy tree is better able to fight off diseases.

5. **Biological Control**: Sometimes using beneficial fungi or bacteria that can suppress the pathogen can be an option. However, this approach is more complex and should be done under professional guidance.

6. **Monitoring**: Regularly monitor the tree for signs of new infections. Early detection and treatment can be crucial in managing the disease effectively.

7. **Consultation**: If the disease persists despite your efforts, it might be advisable to consult a local horticulturist or arborist who can provide tailored advice based on the specific conditions of the tree and the local environment.

By implementing these strategies, you can help manage the leaf spot issue and potentially slow down the progression of the disease on the elm tree.
