title: Why are my fig tree's leaves turning yellow/brown and falling off? #418554
question:
Hi,
We planted a small fig tree in our yard in Springfield at the end of May of this year. After we planted the tree, we filled the hole with compost. It is in full sun.

It seemed to be doing ok at first, though growing slowly, but in the last few weeks some of its leaves have turned yellow and brown and fallen off. We had been watering it daily, but then read that we should only water it once a week, so switched to doing that. It has not seemed to help, though, as a small number of leaves continue to turn yellow and brown and fall off.

We inspected the leaves and didn't see any bugs.

Do you have any suggestions about what we could try to make our fig tree healthy again?

Thank you.

answer.response: I think your intentions with the compost and daily watering were good, but their effects were quite the opposite.  Planting in native soil and watering deeply but infrequently (perhaps twice weekly for the first year at most) is the way to go.  Most likely the plant is suffering from root rot, which means even though you're backing off on the watering, it is lacking the healthy roots it needs to provide water to the leaves.  Couple that with hot weather and it's not good.  My recommendation is to dig it up, and if the roots look reasonably healthy, try planting it in a pot and keeping in a guarded environment for the rest of the summer where it won't have as great a demand for water as it would out in the open.  If the damage thus far is too severe, it won't make it, but that is true of leaving it where it is too, so you have nothing to lose by potting it up.  If it survives, try re-planting in the spring in just native soil.  Save the compost for a mulch on the top.
answer.author: The Question Asker

management instructions: Dig up the tree and inspect the roots.
If the roots look reasonably healthy, plant the tree in a pot and keep it in a guarded environment for the rest of the summer.
Re-plant the tree in the spring in native soil.
Use compost as a mulch on top of the soil instead of mixing it in.
qa_information.background info: The fig tree was planted in Springfield at the end of May, in full sun, with compost added to the hole. It was initially watered daily, then switched to once a week. The tree has been growing slowly.

The image shows a dried and yellowing leaf from a fig tree, which could be indicative of several issues such as nutrient deficiency, overwatering, or environmental stress. Given the context that the fig tree was planted in full sun and was initially watered daily but then switched to once a week, it's possible that the plant may have experienced overwatering followed by dehydration.

Here is a recommended management strategy:

1. **Assess Watering Schedule**: Review the watering schedule and adjust it accordingly. Since the tree was initially watered daily, it might need more frequent watering until it establishes itself. Once established, it should be watered less frequently, ideally every 5-7 days depending on weather conditions and soil moisture levels.

2. **Check Soil Moisture**: Ensure that the soil is not consistently wet. Use a moisture meter or dig down into the soil to check if it is drying out properly. Avoid overwatering, as this can lead to root rot.

3. **Nutrient Analysis**: If the leaves continue to show signs of distress, consider having the soil tested to determine if there are any nutrient deficiencies. This will help tailor the fertilization plan appropriately.

4. **Pruning and Maintenance**: Prune the tree regularly to encourage healthy growth and remove any dead or damaged leaves. This can help prevent the spread of disease and improve air circulation around the tree.

5. **Monitor for Signs of Disease or Insect Pests**: Inspect the tree for signs of disease or insect infestation. If present, take appropriate action such as using organic pesticides or fungicides.

6. **Mulching**: Apply a layer of mulch around the base of the tree to retain moisture and suppress weeds, which can help reduce competition for nutrients and water.

By closely monitoring the tree and adjusting care practices based on observed conditions, you can help the fig tree recover and thrive.

title: Identify a tree #725485
question: Please find attached a photo of the leaves from two trees on our property in Dearborn Heights, MI.  What disease is represented from the brown spot that all the leaves get during the Fall and what insects are eating the leaves?  Thank You.

1.response:
Good Morning,
Most likely your maple tree is reflecting a fungal infection that leads to a condition known as Maple Tar Spot. This infestation usually starts in late summer as small yellow spots on the leaves which typically go unnoticed. As fall progresses these spots gradually turn black. Fortunately it does not appear to harm the tree. See the following for more information:

https://www.gardeningknowhow.com/ornamental/trees/maple/maple-tar-spot-disease.htm

To prevent this from occurring in future years, this will provide some possible procedures:

http://blog.davey.com/2017/08/why-are-there-brown-or-black-spots-on-my-maple-leaves/
As for something eating the leaves Trees can survive loosing all their leaves as long as it doesn’t happen every year. Trees are also entering dormancy now so leaf loss now isn’t as much of an issue as it would be early in the season. The damage was probably done by Japanese beetles and they are gone now. Water the tree until the ground freezes if it doesn’t rain to improve its health. Trees need about an inch of water a week.
I hope this helps. Thanks for using our service.
1.author: Doreen Losacco

2.response: Thank you!
2.author: The Question Asker

3.response: Your welcome.
3.author: Doreen Losacco

management instructions: Water the tree until the ground freezes if it doesn’t rain to improve its health.
Trees need about an inch of water a week.

The image shows two maple leaves with signs of disease or damage. Specifically, there appears to be a dark spot on one of the leaves, which could indicate a fungal or bacterial infection, or it might be a natural discoloration due to environmental stress or other factors.

For managing such issues in a maple tree, here are some general recommendations:

1. **Identify the Cause**: Determine the exact cause of the leaf damage (e.g., disease, pest infestation, environmental stress). This can involve observing the condition over time and consulting with a local arborist or horticulturist who can provide a more accurate diagnosis based on the specific symptoms observed.

2. **Remove Diseased Parts**: If the damage is localized to specific areas of the leaf or small branches, carefully prune these out to prevent the spread of the disease. Ensure that you have proper pruning tools and that you make clean cuts at the point where healthy wood meets diseased wood.

3. **Use Fungicides or Pesticides**: Depending on the identified cause, fungicides or pesticides may be necessary. These should only be applied according to the label instructions to ensure they are effective and safe for the environment and the tree.

4. **Improve Tree Health**: Strengthening the overall health of the tree can help it better resist diseases. This includes ensuring the tree receives adequate water, nutrients, and sunlight, and that it is properly pruned to maintain good air circulation within the canopy.

5. **Monitor the Tree**: Regularly check the tree for further signs of disease or stress. Early detection can lead to more effective management strategies.

6. **Consult an Arborist**: For complex cases or if the tree shows significant signs of decline, consulting with a certified arborist can provide expert advice tailored to the specific situation.

In conclusion, the first step is to identify the cause of the damage, followed by targeted management actions such as pruning, potentially using chemical treatments, and improving the overall health of the tree.

title: What is this weed and how can I control it? #488271
question: This plant is invading my lawn and gardens. It forms a dense mat. Each leaf is rooted, unlike creeping Charlie, which it resembles in miniature. My first photo shows a quarter for scale. It flourishes in full sun and late summer. I don’t recall a problem in the spring, so believe it is an annual. It has no flowers and never gets taller than about an inch; the leaves stay small. Every year it has come back a little worse. When leaves are crushed, the scent is mild and grassy, not minty. Please help?

answer.response:
The weed looks like it may be a type of pennywort or dollarweed, Hydrocotyle spp.
It is a warm season perennial weed that spreads by seeds, rhizomes, and tubers. Dollarweed thrives in weak, thin turf with excessive moisture. The first defense against dollarweed is to reduce moisture levels and modify cultural methods (i.e., proper mowing height and irrigation).
Here is some information from Clemson on this weed https://hgic.clemson.edu/factsheet/dollarweed/

You will have to make some decisions.  In flower beds, you can use a systemic vegetation killer such as glyphosate.  This will kill everything.  If you have desirable plants you will have to shield them and follow label directions.

 In the lawn - if the lawn is over 50% weeds, you will have to consider total lawn renovation. This can be done up until mid October.  This includes having your soil tested http://extension.umd.edu/hgic/soils/soil-testing, decide on seed, kill the existing lawn with glyphosate, prepare the site for planting, and seed or install sod. Now is the time for lawn renovation for a cool season grass such as tall fescue. Tall fescue grows best in full sun to partial shade. Fine fescue is recommended if the lawn is mostly shade. Hard fescue is the best choice.
Here is our publication on Lawn Establishment and Renovation see page 7 and our website http://extension.umd.edu/hgic/lawns/lawn-renovation
http://extension.umd.edu/sites/extension.umd.edu/files/_docs/programs/hgic/HGIC_Pubs/lawn_pubs/HG102...
Here is more information from our IPM Report page 3 https://extension.umd.edu/sites/extension.umd.edu/files/_docs/programs/ipmnet/13Oct11L.pdf

If you need to spot treat only,  use a post emergent herbicide now and next growing season as soon as you notice the weed to reduce any further growth. You can use a combination herbicide that contains the following broadleaf weed killers: 2,4- D, dicamba, and mecoprop (MCPP) or MCPA. Follow label directions as caution needs to be used around the roots of trees and shrubs.

mh
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

answer.response: Thanks for your advice. I am not sure my weed fits this description, which is not to say it isn’t a relative of some kind. The areas where I see it tend to be dry, not wet. The leaf photo on the website you reference is shown below, and I have added another photo of mine showing the underneath side. Mine is almost heart-shaped but scalloped, with the stem at the innermost point, and the leaves never reach more than 1/2” across. title: Possible rose rosette disease #604419
question:
Hi,

Last year I noticed what appeared to be possible rose rosette disease on one of my Zephrine Drouhin roses. It just looked like some strange red growth and I was not totally sure if it was normal or not. I pruned off the branch and the rose bloomed fine this spring and I saw no evidence of it. This fall I’m seeing similar strange red growth on one of them again and I’m pretty sure it’s the same plant. How would I go about confirming if that is what it is? I know I need to get rid of the bush if that’s the case. I have about 50 rose bushes so if it spreads it would be pretty devastating:(

answer.response:
This does not look like rose rosette.  This looks like new growth on the rose.

Marian
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

answer.response: Thanks. I was worried because the new growth on this rose looks very different from the new growth on my other roses.. the leaves look very small and the stalks are very thick. Have you seen rose rosette in Howard County?
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Hi - The new foliage on roses can vary among different species. Yes, we have seen cases of rose rosette disease in Howard County. This does not look like it.
https://extension.umd.edu/hgic/topics/rose-rosette-shrub

Christa
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

answer.response:
Hello,

I have one rose bush with strange growth again this spring. I’m wondering if it could be herbicide damage from the neighboring yard... but still want yo confirm it doesn’t look like rose rosette. The growth is different than the rest of the new growth on the bush (last photo).
Thanks
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
We still don't think that this looks like rose rosette disease.
We do see some aphids, which can cause some leaf distortion.
It's impossible to rule out herbicide damage, though that can cause elongation and twisting. Young shoots are especially vulnerable to herbicide injury.
We would just keep an eye on it at this point.

Your first photo shows a missing strip of bark on the stem. We'd prune back to healthy tissue just above the next spur of growth.


Christine
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

answer.response: Thank you!
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response: You're welcome.
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

answer.response:
Hello,

I have some new growth on this same rose with distorted leaves and blooms. The rose did bloom earlier this spring but the abnormal growth is getting worse and I’m quite concerned. Do you still think this is not rose rosette or should I get it tested? I have a lot of roses and would be devastated if it spreads.
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
The foliage on this rose does not look normal. This looks diseased, possibly rose rosette. See our web page https://extension.umd.edu/hgic/topics/rose-rosette-shrub

At this point, we recommend that you dig up the rose, bag it and discard in the trash. Monitor your other roses for any symptoms.

Marian
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

answer.response: Can I replant another rose there?
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Rose rosette is not in the soil.  It is spread by insects.  Read the link provided above very carefully.  It's very possible that other roses may get it, so be on the alert.  

Also, when you dig up the infected rose, put a trash bag over the shrub to prevent the insects from falling off and spreading the disease to your other roses.  

 You can plant another rose, but wait 6 months or so.  See if other roses are infected and be sure the beds are clean before introducing more plants. 

 Ellen
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

title: Russian olive #789356
question: Hello, I have either a multi stemmed or small stand of 4-6 of these in my yard. They are about 10-15' tall and very difficult to access (between the fence and entangled in a large shrub). A few flowers have opened, and they are white with 4 petals. There are some long thorns on the thicker branches. Are these russian olive trees? If so, should they be removed and do you have suggestions for a difficult to access site? I can cut the trunks pretty low but digging them up may be impossible without damage to the shrub. Thank you!

1.response:
Hello, Abby:
Thanks for contacting the Jefferson county extension plant clinic.
It does appear from your photo that this is a "Russian Olive" (actually not an olive tree, though its fruits resemble olives, but a member of the Oleaster family). These trees can become invasive and therefore not desirable in the home landscape or pasture areas, though they can be used by birds for food (which is how the seeds are dispersed).
The attached document from the US Dept of Agriculture discusses Russian Olive control, directed at large acreage areas rather than the home landscape, but the control strategies can be used on a smaller scale, where practical.
Unfortunately, cutting back the trunks, which as you say is not very easy given the location, will not eradicate the plant, though that may be more practical than the careful use of an herbicide on cut stumps, as discussed in the USDA document.   (Foliar herbicide sprays could work but are not practical given the tree's entanglement with the desirable shrub). 
If you can carefully cut the trunks close to the ground and paint the exposed area with herbicide without touching the desirable shrub, this may begin to control the plant - you may need to do this in more than one season as other trunks grow from the root system.
Some of the herbicides in the USDA document may not  be available to home gardeners, though glyphosate and 2-4D are sold in retail garden centers.
(It is at least useful to remove flowers before they go to seed so that birds don't eat and scatter the seeds and generate more plants.)
https://www.fs.usda.gov/Internet/FSE_DOCUMENTS/stelprdb5410126.pdf

See also: https://www.extension.uidaho.edu/publishing/html/BUL976-Different-Treatment-Options-for-Russian-Olive.aspx#:~:text=%20Control%20Options%20%201%20Mowing.%20Russian%20olive,cutting%20with%20herbicide%20application.%20Trees%20are...%20More%20

https://extension.unr.edu/publication.aspx?PubID=3949#:~:text=A%20number%20of%20herbicides%20and%20application%20techniques%20can,4%29%2C%20triclopyr%20%28Garlon%C2%AE%203A%29%2C%20or%20imazapyr%20%28Arsenal%C2%AE%2C%20Habitat%C2%AE%29.

We hope you can eradicate this plant, but it is not easy to do and at best requires persistence.

Pat B
1.author: Jeffco Plant Clinic

management instructions: Cut the trunks close to the ground and paint the exposed area with herbicide without touching the desirable shrub.
Remove flowers before they go to seed to prevent birds from eating and scattering the seeds and generating more plants.

title: What kind of snake is this #617042
question: can you tell me what  kind of snake this is . On dauphin island Alabama

answer.response:
Thank you for your question. The snake in your photograph is a cottonmouth, scientific name Agkistrodon piscivorus. Alabama has one subspecies, the western cottonmouth, A. p. leucostoma, and two intergrades. Intergrades are the result of the mating between two subspecies. Alabama has an eastern x western cross and an eastern x Florida cross. The exact identity of your cottonmouth is difficult to establish from just a photo. The cottonmouth is a venomous species.

Typical length is approximately two feet, and maximum length can reach approximately four feet. They are found from Virginia south to Florida and west to Texas. They can be found in river swamps, backwaters and floodplains. They are also common in lakes, reservoirs, ponds, streams and wetlands.

They have a varied diet that includes small mammals, birds, fish, frogs, salamanders, other snakes and occasionally baby alligators.

Local snake lore indicates that this species is very aggressive towards humans, but scientific research has shown that this is not the case, and, in fact, most cottonmouths are reluctant to bite. Nevertheless, they should be enjoyed from a safe distance. There common name comes from a defensive threat display in which the snake throws open its mouth, revealing the white lining of the mouth.

If you'd like to learn more about snakes in Alabama, here is an excellent field guide:

Gibbons, Whit. (2017). Snakes of the Eastern United States. Athens: University of Georgia Press.

I hope this answers your question, and thank you for contacting Ask an Expert.

Jim
answer.author: Jim Burke

title: What is this pretty invasive plant in our front yard garden? #397770
question:
This rather pretty invasive flower has sprouted up in volume in mulch placed on the front garden of our townhouse in Baltimore's Bolton Hill.   We’ve lived here four years and never seen it before.  The stalks and flowers are about 14-15 inches high and the leaves spread out below.  I'm uploading a couple of photos.  We asked the master gardeners at the downtown Sunday market but they were stumped.  

Now it is going to seed.  Any idea what it is called and where it is native?  Do you recommend we encourage it or weed it out?

Thanks in advance.

Bill Hamilton
248 W Lafayette Ave
Baltimore, MD 21217
202 641-0350
Billhamilton@mail.com

answer.response:
Thank you for your question. This is Hyacinthoides hispanica. It is commonly called Spanish bluebell or wood hyacinth. It is not native to Maryland but rather originates from Europe and northern Africa. It is often planted in gardens and it reseeds. It is on the National Park Service's "watch list" as a plant that is potentially invasive in natural areas, including in Maryland. It is beautiful, but we recommend that you weed it out before it reseeds. 

CKC
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

answer.response:
Thanks.  That's helpful.  The plants are pretty well rooted.  Do you think we need to dig them up or just try to prevent reseeding by talking off the stalks with seed pods>


BH
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
We recommend that you dig them out (including the bulbs) and put them in the trash. Do not compost them.

https://www.rhs.org.uk/advice/profile?pid=426

CKC

title: Tomato borer #805335
question: I have a lot of tomatoes in my greenhouse that have holes bored in them.  I took a picture of some small beetles and have attached it.  Can you please help me and identify the beetle and how to get rid of it?  Thank you.

answer.response:
The insect in your photos is an immature stinkbug. They can cause damage on tomatoes, but not the damage showing in the photo. Stinkbugs can be picked off plants or there are some insecticides that can help control them (e.g., insecticidal soap [but be careful about applying it in hot conditions], neem and azadirachtin products).

Stinkbug feeding on tomato fruit leaves a discolored area on the fruit skin. The damage in your photo looks more like a physiological problem (cracking, catfacing) resulting from environmental stress (temperature fluctuations, irregular watering, etc).
This is a guide to some tomato fruit disorders and problems:
https://www.missouribotanicalgarden.org/gardens-gardening/your-garden/help-for-the-home-gardener/advice-tips-resources/visual-guides/tomato-fruit-problems.aspx

Additional pictures and information would help diagnosing the problems you may have.
answer.author: Stuart Reitz

use insecticidal soap
use neem and azadirachtin products

title: Spots on herbs #653884
question:
All of my herbs have whitish spots on the leaves. I see no bugs. I've attached photos.  Can you tell what this is? Thanks
Jean

answer.response:
Hi Jean - This looks like leafhopper damage on the herbs. They are a sucking insect. Typically they are gone by the time you notice the damage. Parasitoids and general predators (ants, spiders, ladybugs, lacewings) help to reduce their numbers. Keep weeds down especially perennial weeds that may harbor their eggs.

No chemical controls are recommended for this. It is okay to eat the herbs that do not have a lot of damage. Remove the badly damaged leaves and the plants should put out new growth. Here is general information about leafhoppers. https://extension.umd.edu/hgic/topics/potato-leafhopper-vegetables 

Christa

title: Diseased viburnum? #786645
question: Maybe I should be able to figure this out ..but ..

answer.response:
Hi Sandy! 

This damage is consistent with that caused by one of our native bird species, the yellow-bellied sapsucker (Sphyrapicus varius). https://news.maryland.gov/dnr/2018/02/01/habichat-sapsuckers/. They are small woodpeckers that drill two types of holes for feeding on sap- round holes and rectangular ones such as those seen on your viburnum.  Fortunately, the sapsucker damage does not usually cause any serious issues for otherwise healthy woody plants and trees.

If you do not like the appearance of the holes, you can prune the affected branches back and they will regrow. Wintertime is the only time you'll typically see sapsuckers, so your viburnum should be left alone until they return later this year!  Remember to only remove 1/3 of your viburnum at a time per year when pruning. More pruning tips can be found here: https://extension.umd.edu/resource/pruning-shrubs-and-hedges

Jamie
answer.author: Jamie Wiesner

answer.response:
HI Jamie,Thanks so much for the prompt response. So funny, I had a downy woodpecker at my feeder all winder and never did see the yellowbellied sapsucker.This pattern is on 4 major inner stems of this viburnum an no other plants were touched. So weird.
Thanks so much.
Sandy

title: Italian Cypress issue #327574
question: Our Italian Cypress started started developing the dead spot earlier this year.!Maybe in February. It's grown slowly but now seems to be getting critical. I hope that you may be able to tell what's going on and  provide some advice.  Thank yoj!

answer.response:
Based on your photos it looks like the tree has a root problem.  If the tree is a true Italian cypress, the tree may not be that winter hardy here.  You may have a cold spot in the area and the root system was affected.  
All you can do is prune out the dead growth in dry weather and keep well watered during dry periods.  It is possible the new growth may grow back bushy.
MH

title: Name that Moth #586926
question:

Could you please identify the moth in the photo I have attached? I looked for it in a book of butterflies and moths but couldn't find it.

Best regards,

Germaine

title: I have 12 year old cherry... #208623
question: I have 12 year old cherry laurels in my front garden that have been very healthy until I just noticed large branches of brown leaves and a type of white mold all over the branches.   I don't see any mold on the leaves, just the branches.  The leaves seem to be green and healthy, yellow or just brown and dead, nothing in between  I'm concerned that this will spread and destroy all 6 of my well established bushes.  I want to identify the issue and determine how/if I can control it.

answer.response:
From your photos it looks like white prunicola scale on the cherry laurels branches. This is a sucking insect that sucks plant cell contents from twigs and branches. This can cause dieback, which is usually preceded by leaf yellowing and premature leaf drop.
Here is some information on control. Prune out any dead or dying branches.
Now you can use a soft brush to remove. You will have to check for crawlers (there may be several generations and they are salmon colored) before you can spray. Wrap some of the branches with double sided sticky tape to monitor for crawlers. When you see the crawlers spray with a summer rate of horticultural oil. Follow all label directions. Do not spray when temperatures are in the high eighties in hot weather.
You can use a dormant oil to manage light infestations in the fall when trees drop their foliage. As long as it does not freeze within 24 hours.
mh
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

answer.response: Thanks for the information.  The problem is pretty wide spread so brushing off the branches may be an entire day project.  I'll have to suck it up and just dive in if I want to save my entire set of bushes in the front.  Wish me luck!

use a soft brush to remove scale

title: lanscaping river birch #259717
question: Why would half of the river birch in the landscaping die this year and not the rest?  The whole tree has had very yellow leaves this whole year.

1.response: This is chlorosis due to a nutrient deficiency, usually iron but can be manganese sometimes.  The problem is that while there is adequate iron in the soil it is in a form unavailable to the tree due to the high pH.  You might try applying a chelated form of iron as a fertilizer but do not expect to see very quick results as this may take a year before the leaves turn green.

title: hydrangea in distress #804598
question:
Dear Experts,

My hydrangea plant appears to be suffering from some disease and/or insect bites? The black spots and brown leaves are spreading. And the small number of flowers are dying.

Can you tell what's happening to it? How can I treat the problem?

Thanks,

Hanzhen

answer.response:
Hello Hanzhen,

Although we acknowledge it's an eyesore, this is fairly normal for how many Bigleaf Hydrangea varieties look this time of year, if it's any consolation. Several kinds of leaf-spotting fungi or bacteria can cause these symptoms, but fortunately they do not seriously harm the plant, despite looking a bit drastic. You do not need to treat the plant with a fungicide, nor would one be able to reverse the existing damage or cure an infection at this point. You can remove the fallen leaves this winter and throw them away, though, to reduce the likelihood of infection this widespread next year. It's not a foolproof measure because spores can still arrive on the wind, but wouldn't hurt to try.

If you irrigate the yard, make sure the foliage either doesn't get wet (just water the soil around the base of the plant) or water early enough in the day so it can dry by nightfall. Weather plays a large role in disease spread and severity, so an outbreak one year won't necessarily result in an infection that prolific the next. Wet weather and wet leaf surfaces generally allows for more successful spore infection of plant foliage, so maintaining good air circulation by not crowding plants and perhaps also thinning-out dense stem growth can help slow disease progression.

As hydrangea blooms age and fade, they usually dull in color and turn greener, or occasionally reddish, and then brown and dry. The state of the blooms in your photo look normal, though if they fade very quickly after opening, perhaps the plant is either drought-stressed or is planted in too much direct sun, since Bigleaf Hydrangea thrives in part-sun/part-shade. While full sun can help keep their leaves drier and therefore less vulnerable to infection, the higher light intensity can sunburn foliage, speed-up moisture loss, or fade flower colors. Some Bigleaf Hydrangea varieties are capable of producing new flowers throughout the summer and into autumn, but others just have the one bloom period earlier in summer and those flowers fade as blooming finishes. We can't tell which variety this is from its appearance alone, since there are dozens on the market these days, but if it is capable of reblooming, it will do so on its own. Avoid pruning it aside from thinning-out individual stems because this could interfere with the formation of flowers. You can, though, trim off just the spent individual flower clusters that are brown if you don't like the look.

The foliage does look slightly nutrient-deficient, which can happen if the soil is not acidic enough (acid soils have a pH value below 7.0). Soils near concrete home foundations or brick mortar sometimes have a soil pH that's too high for acid-loving plants to thrive because of minerals leaching out of those materials, and this makes it harder for their roots to absorb the nutrients they need. Fertilization sometimes helps, but when the pH is too high it needs to be lowered first, since the soil may already have plenty of nutrients in it. (In that situation, adding more doesn't help.) A soil test can reveal the pH level and let you know what, if any, adjustments are needed. Bigleaf Hydrangeas prefer a pH range from about 5.5 to 6.5, but not higher.

Miri
answer.author: Mira Talabac

answer.response:
Thank you very much for all the useful information, Miri! 

It had been hot and dry where my plant is lately. 

Good to know the plant is not dying! We will follow your advice and monitor the plant more.


Hanzhen
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response: You're welcome!
answer.author: Mira Talabac

management instructions: Remove the fallen leaves this winter and throw them away.
Avoid getting foliage wet when irrigating.
Maintain good air circulation by not crowding plants and thinning-out dense stem growth.
Trim off spent individual flower clusters.
Consider a soil test to check pH level.

title: Dying spruce trees #159361
question: These two spruces are about 15' fom each other, have lost their needles on lower half of tree over a period of 3 years, and are on a flat area that drains a slope from four condo units and their French drains and sump pump outflow pipes. In other words, damp but not "wet." Have lichens because on north side. Will re-needle? Will continue to de-nude and die?

answer.response:
Hello,

The photos you submitted show some dieback from the bottom up on your trees. This is usually an indication of a root problem. It appears that the trees were planted a bit deep, which may have put additional stress on the trees and their establishment. The past 6 months we have been subject to a great deal of fluctuation in moisture in northern Delaware, with rains coming heavy at times and leading to saturated soil. We also had a period of drought in September. The drain field adds to moisture when we get heavy rains. Evergreens also drop needles seasonally this time of year. You could dig down a bit around the base of the trees and check some of the roots to see if they are a good light color, or whether the roots are dark and show any rot. I would recommend that you re-evaluate the trees in the spring. Do not fertilize this season. The lichens on the trees are harmless and an indicator of good air quality.

Thank you for contacting Delaware Cooperative Extension,

Nancy
answer.author: Nancy Gregory

symptom description: lost needles on lower half of tree
management instructions: dig down around the base of the trees to check root color and rot
re-evaluate the trees in the spring
do not fertilize this season

title: Unhealthy Cheery Laurel  #849820
question: Planted this a month ago and health started to fail. I don’t think we over or under watered. Any advice to improve its health?

answer.response:
The leaf symptoms are exhibiting "scorch," which is usually due to abiotic causes. (Abiotic factors are those not caused by a living thing, so are not tied to a pest or disease but rather to environmental conditions.) Stress from too much or too little soil moisture, even for a relatively brief amount of time compared to the rest of the growing season, is often the culprit when leaves scorch, especially on plants still establishing in their first couple of years in the ground.

Was the plant's root ball loosened well or any matted roots disentangled when it was planted? Cherrylaurel can be sold potted or burlapped (the tag pictured suggests it was potted in a 6-gallon pot). Potted plants can easily become quite rootbound by the time they are sold, and the potting mix used in the container will retain and drain water very differently than the surrounding soil it's planted in. By well-loosening the roots just prior to planting, this not only helps them to establish by encouraging growth out into the soil that surrounds them, but also helps remove some of that potting mix from the core of the root ball so it can be blended with the soil from the planting hole. In doing so, this helps the soil more evenly absorb or drain water so the roots don't experience dry pockets or "bathtub"-like wet pools. Either situation would result in stress, affecting leaf health, and at worst, root dieback, though unfortunately the symptoms of damage can be delayed from the onset of stress, making determining exactly what happened difficult.

The best way to judge when plants need water is to feel the soil about 6 inches down in the root zone and watering thoroughly (for a plant this size, probably several gallons per session) once it becomes somewhat dry to the touch at that depth. If it is damp instead when checked to that depth, watering can wait. As a very rough guideline because this will partly depend on soil type, a Cherrylaurel of this size planted in mid/late summer might need a thorough watering once or twice a week if the weather is hot and mostly dry. (Rapid rainstorms don't always soak into the soil as much as we think they would for the volume of water falling, so plants should still be monitored after rain.)

Damaged leaves cannot heal and may fall off, but as long as the branches themselves remain healthy (since they have dormant buds under the bark that can help replace lost growth) and the roots remain in good condition, recovery is possible. That said, shrubs generally don't put out new growth this late in the growing season because they are preparing tissues for dormancy, so you might not see indications of regrowth and new leaf production until spring. Some of the browned leaves may be retained by the plant but others might fall off anytime between now and early winter, which would be normal for scorch symptoms. If more leaves "winterburn" during winter (this kind of scorch might not become evident until spring due to a delay in symptoms) then we would suspect the roots were damaged at some point and will have to catch up in regrowth to balance-out what amount of foliage they can support.

There's nothing you can do for now except to keep monitoring the shrub for watering needs as we enter fall, especially since central MD has been in a drought all season and in past years we have experienced autumn drought before. Don't fertilize, and if it isn't already, mulch the root zone to help moderate soil temperatures and moisture, but make sure the mulch isn't covering any part of the trunk/stem base.

Miri
answer.author: Mira Talabac

answer.response:
Thank you, Miri. This is very helpful. Based on this information I probably did not do a job managing roots before planting. I’ll take more care watering. Keeping fingers over the winter. 

Again than you. 

Sent from my iPhone

On Sep 14, 2023, at 10:29 AM, Ask Extension <ask@extension.org> wrote:

﻿

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a cherry laurel (Prunus laurocerasus) that appears to have some leaf discoloration and wilting, which could be indicative of several issues such as nutrient deficiencies, pest infestation, or environmental stress. Given that the plant was only recently planted and its health is failing, it's important to consider these factors:

### Potential Causes:
1. **Nutrient Deficiency**: Young plants often require more frequent watering and nutrient-rich soil to establish properly. If the soil lacks essential nutrients like nitrogen, iron, or magnesium, the leaves might turn yellow or brown at the edges.
2. **Watering Issues**: Overwatering or underwatering can also cause leaf discoloration. Ensure the soil is well-drained and watered consistently but not excessively.
3. **Environmental Stress**: Extreme temperatures or strong winds can stress young plants, leading to leaf damage.
4. **Pest or Disease**: Insects or fungal diseases can affect new plants, especially if they haven't fully established their defenses yet.

### Recommended Management Strategy:
1. **Check Soil Conditions**:
   - Assess the soil moisture level regularly. Ensure the plant is not sitting in standing water or drying out too quickly.
   - Add a balanced fertilizer (e.g., 10-10-10) if you suspect nutrient deficiency. Follow the manufacturer’s instructions on application rates.
   
2. **Watering**:
   - Water the plant deeply once a week during the growing season. Adjust according to weather conditions and soil type.

3. **Monitor for Pests and Diseases**:
   - Inspect the leaves and stems for signs of pests or disease. Look for mites, aphids, or any discoloration that might indicate a fungal infection.
   - Treat with an appropriate pesticide if necessary, ensuring you follow the label instructions carefully.

4. **Supportive Care**:
   - Provide additional support to the plant, especially if it’s still young and weak. Use stakes if needed.
   - Ensure the plant is in a location with adequate light and protection from harsh weather.

5. **Consult a Professional**:
   - If the plant continues to show signs of distress despite your efforts, consult with a local horticulturist or extension agent who can provide specific advice based on local conditions.

By addressing these potential issues methodically, you can help improve the health and vitality of your newly planted cherry laurel.

title: Dry patches on my grass #839910
question:
Hi, my name is Silvina. I just moved to this home, where they have installed (2 months ago) what I believe is Bermuda grass...? I also have some dry patches, and I wonder what are those, and how I can fix it. Last question, what is the optimal heigh I need to mow it, and how often it needs to be watered?

Thanks a lot in avance, I'd appreciate any help I can get!!!

Best,

Silvina

answer.response:
Hi Silvina,
   Since we are in the middle of the hottest and driest part of the summer, I believe your grass is going through a dormant .period to protect against summer heat stress.  Bermuda grass will turn brown in heat stressed conditions and then will revive with adequate rainfall.  
   Note: I have several areas in my yard that I allow this to happen instead of using lots of water to keep it evenly green.  
   If you want to improve the water holding capacity of those areas you can top dress with a 2 inch layer of compost & those areas will gradually do better. 
  Mow at the high to promote shade for the soil and help develop deeper root systems.  Setting your mower at 3 to 3.5 inch mower height during  these heat of the summer is advised. 
  Wishing you all the best!
Bob Kunkel
answer.author: Travis County Master Gardener

management instructions: Top dress with a 2 inch layer of compost to improve water holding capacity.
Mow at a height of 3 to 3.5 inches to promote shade for the soil and help develop deeper root systems.

title: Crape Myrtle issue #556531
question: I am having a problem with a Miami Crape Myrtle. Two years ago one of the main trunps died. There was a split near the base of the trunk. Since then I have noticed white patches all over the bark (picture attached). Last year another trunk did not leaf out in the the spring. Again, there was a split near the base. Another two trunks had some bark problem near the ground. I suspected Crape Myrtle bark scale and applied a drench of Imidacloprid in early summer of 2018. The shrub appeared heathy and the appearance of the bark improved and the  the damaged area near the base of two trunks appeared to be healed. This spring two additional trunks are dead, again with splits near the ground and white ares all over the bark. I doubt that it is weather related since I have grown the same variety of crape myrtle without problems for 20y. I can send a sample if needed but you may be able to diagnose from the two attached pictures. Thanks!

answer.response:
In past years, drought has been a big problem in Maryland in the summer, and crape myrtle sailed through that.  But, crape myrtles cannot tolerate wet, saturated soils.  Usually, that meant not planting in a "wet spot", but with the abnormal rain fall last year, and the wet cloudy year before, many plants that have never had problems with the soil where they are planted have died or declined from root rots and drowned roots.  

This may be what is going on with your crape myrtle.  We see no obvious disease or insect issues otherwise.  The white-gray patches are lichen, a harmless fungi/algae plant which only uses other plants for support.  However, when you begin to see a lot of lichen on plants where it was not, that can mean that the plant is declining.  Not due to the lichen, however. It's just an indicator.

 Improve the drainage around your crape myrtle, if you can. Otherwise, you may need a plant there that tolerates saturated soils.  Hard to say what the future holds, weather wise, with climate change and weather extremes predicted. 

Ellen

The image shows the trunk of a crape myrtle with signs of disease or insect damage. Given that the questioner has had success with Imidacloprid treatments in the past, it's possible that the current issue might be related to insect infestation or environmental stress. Here are some recommended management strategies based on the information provided:

### 1. **Further Inspection:**
   - Conduct a thorough inspection of the entire tree, including the trunk, branches, and leaves. Look for signs of insects (e.g., borers, aphids), fungi, or other pathogens.

### 2. **Pest Identification:**
   - If signs of insects are found, identify the specific pest. This will help determine if Imidacloprid can be used again or if a different treatment is needed. For instance, if it’s borers, you may need a systemic insecticide.

### 3. **Environmental Stress Management:**
   - Check the soil moisture levels and adjust irrigation as necessary. Ensure the tree is receiving adequate nutrients by testing the soil pH and nutrient levels. Consider applying a balanced fertilizer if deficiencies are detected.

### 4. **Pruning:**
   - Remove any dead or damaged branches to promote healthy growth and reduce the risk of further infection. Make clean cuts using sharp, disinfected tools to avoid introducing more pathogens.

### 5. **Tree Health Maintenance:**
   - Continue regular monitoring for signs of stress or disease. Early detection and intervention can prevent the spread of pests and diseases.

### 6. **Consultation with an Arborist:**
   - If the problem persists or worsens, consult with a local arborist or horticulturist who can provide expert advice tailored to your location and specific conditions.

### 7. **Reapplication of Imidacloprid:**
   - If Imidacloprid was effective in previous years, consider reapplying it at the appropriate time for pest control. Follow the manufacturer’s instructions for dosage and timing carefully.

### 8. **Consider Alternative Treatments:**
   - If Imidacloprid does not prove effective, explore alternative treatments such as botanical insecticides or fungicides designed specifically for crape myrtles.

By combining these strategies, you can better manage the health of your crape myrtle and potentially resolve the issue seen in the image. Regular maintenance and vigilance will also help maintain the overall health of the tree over time.

answer.response:
This is mulberry weed, a difficult weed to eradicate.  It's an annual and must come up from new seed each spring. Do not let it flower and produce seeds.  Pull it early and mulch the beds to prevent seed germination.

ECN

title: How to treat this big injury on my persimmon tree? #538393
question:
I found this big injury on my persimmon tree. It looks not completely healed by itself. I'd like to get some advice on how to treat it properly. In particular, I don't want it to evolve into something more severe and damaging to the other parts of the tree or the entire tree.

Please see the attached photos of the injury. More pictures available at: https://www.dropbox.com/sh/1jputyz3j1mv7vw/AAAT1FkkwxqcTFaoXjFpk_X8a?dl=0

answer.response:
Tree wounds are common and the causes include: broken branches; impacts, abrasions and scrapes; animal damage; insect attack; fire; etc. Wounds usually break the bark and damage the food and water conducting tissues. Wounds also expose the inside of the tree to organisms, primarily bacteria and fungi that may infect and cause discoloration and decay of the wood. Decay can result in structurally weakened tree stems and can shorten the life of a tree. Decay cannot be cured. However, proper tree care can limit the progress of decay in an injured tree.

Trees respond to wounding or injury in two ways: compartmentalization and the development of barrier zones.

When a tree is wounded, the injured tissue is not repaired and does not heal. Trees do not heal; they seal. If you look at an old wound, you will notice that it does not “heal” from the inside out, but eventually the tree covers the opening by forming specialized “callus” tissue around the edges of the wound. After wounding, new wood growing around the wound forms a protective boundary preventing the infection or decay from spreading into the new tissue. Thus, the tree responds to the injury by “compartmentalizing” or isolating the older, injured tissue with the gradual growth of new, healthy tissue.

Not only do trees try to close the damaged tissue from the outside, they also make the existing wood surrounding the wound unsuitable for spread of decay organisms. Although these processes are not well understood, the tree tries to avoid further injury by setting chemical and physical boundaries around the infected cells, reacting to the pathogen and confining the damage.

If the tree is fast and effective with its boundary-setting mechanisms, the infection remains localized and does not spread. However, if the boundary-setting mechanisms are not effective, the infection will spread. Most vigorous or actively growing trees are fairly successful in coping with decay-spreading mechanisms.

Tree wounds often appear ragged where the bark is torn during the injury. This is common during branch breakage and when the trunk of the tree has been scraped. To repair this type of damage, cut off any ragged bark edges with a sharp knife. Take care not to remove any healthy bark and expose more live tissue than necessary. If possible, the wound should be shaped like an elongated oval, with the long axis running vertically along the trunk or limb. All bark around the wound should be tight.

Research indicates that wound dressings (materials such as tar or paint) do not prevent decay and may even interfere with wound closure. Wound dressings can have the following detrimental effects:

  • Prevent drying and encourage fungal growth
  • Interfere with formation of wound wood or callus tissue
  • Inhibit compartmentalization
  • Possibly serve as a food source for pathogens

For these reasons, applying wound dressings is not recommended. Trees, like many organisms, have their own mechanisms to deter the spread of decay organisms, insects and disease

Filling large holes or hollows in the tree is generally done for cosmetic reasons. There is little data to indicate that a filled tree has better mechanical stability. However, fillings may give the callus tissue a place to seat, thus stopping the in-roll (folding) of the callus (Shigo 1982). Almost any filling can be used as long as it does not abrade the inside of the tree.

Filling a tree cavity is generally expensive and not recommended. Filling does not stop decay and often during the cleaning of the cavity, the boundary that separates the sound wood or the callus growth from the decayed wood is ruptured. Thus, this cleaning for cavity filling can have more detrimental effects on the tree than if it were left alone. Care must be taken not to damage the new callus tissue that has formed in response to the tree damage and subsequent decay.

Proper pruning should be used to remove dead, dying and broken branches; to remove low, crossing or hazardous branches; and to control the size of the tree. However, pruning of any kind places some stress on the tree by removing food-producing leaves (if the branch is alive), creating wounds that require energy to seal, and providing possible entry points for disease.

Pruning cuts should be made to maximize the tree’s ability to close its wound and defend itself from infection. When pruning, make clean, smooth cuts. Do not leave branch stubs. Leave a small collar of wood at the base of the branch. The branch collar is a slightly swollen area where the branch attaches to the trunk. Cutting the limb flush with the trunk will leave a larger area to callus over and a greater chance of decay organisms entering the wound. The optimal pruning time is in the winter (dormant season) when temperatures and infection rates are lower and when trees are not actively growing.

Conclusion. Healthy trees usually recover from wounding quickly. Try to keep wounded trees growing vigorously by watering them during droughts and providing proper fertilization. This will increase the rate of wound closure, enhance callus growth and improve the resistance to decay mechanisms.

Here are a couple of publications you may find useful:           

https://agrilife.org/treecarekit/after-the-storm/tree-wounds/           

https://ohioline.osu.edu/factsheet/HYG-3311-09

http://extension.msstate.edu/publications/publications/understanding-pruning-and-injury-wounds-fruit-trees

Hope this helps!
answer.author: chris Rusch

management instructions: cut off any ragged bark edges with a sharp knife
shape the wound like an elongated oval
do not apply wound dressings
do not fill large holes or hollows in the tree
prune dead, dying, and broken branches
make clean, smooth cuts when pruning
water and fertilize the tree to promote vigorous growth

title: Boxwood fungus - possible Blight? #792026
question: We have many boxwoods on our property in Annapolis, a home built in 1927. I believe these shrubs (there are 6 plants) are a variety of boxwood and they have a white fungus that we noticed about a month ago. Lower leaves on the plants are dying. Is this Boxwood Blight or something else? Is it treatable? What action should we take?

answer.response:
Hi Kerri!

Your boxwoods have a trifecta of issues, but none that will likely cause permanent damage. The photos show boxwood mite damage (white 'stippling' or specks on the leaves), boxwood psyllid (white secretions on the leaves), and some winter injury (the orange-burnt leaves).

Blasting the plant with the hose and trimming and disposing of the damaged leaves will help to reduce the pests and it will also remove the winter damage. Remember to only prune 1/3 of the shrub at any one time per year. Our guide to pruning boxwoods might interest you: https://extension.umd.edu/resource/boxwood-leafminer-shrubs

It does not look like the infestation is heavy enough to warrant spraying. If you see these next year, boxwood psyllid nymphs may be controlled with horticultural oil or insecticidal soap sprays in April and May. The psyllids will now be into adulthood, so if you must use a spray, you can use a registered residual insecticide in late May into June.

It is good to familiarize yourself with the signs of boxwood blight - you can check the stems for black 'lesions' or black spots. Usually by the time these would appear, about 50% of the boxwood would already be defoliated. 

Jamie
answer.author: Jamie Wiesner

Trim and dispose of the damaged leaves.
Only prune 1/3 of the shrub at any one time per year.
If necessary, use horticultural oil or insecticidal soap sprays in April and May, or a registered residual insecticide in late May into June.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows boxwood plants that appear to have some form of damage or disease. Common issues affecting boxwoods include boxwood blight, fungal diseases, and insect infestations such as boxwood adelgids. Here’s a detailed analysis and potential management strategies:

### Potential Issues:
1. **Boxwood Blight (Buxus sempervirens var. sempervirens)**:
   - Symptoms: Brown to reddish-brown lesions on leaves, often leading to leaf drop, and cankers on stems.
   - Management: Remove and destroy affected branches, prune healthy branches back into healthy wood, and apply fungicides if necessary. Avoid overhead watering to reduce moisture on foliage.

2. **Fungal Diseases**:
   - Symptoms: Fuzzy white or gray patches on leaves, stem rot, or wilting.
   - Management: Prune away diseased parts, remove infected leaves, and improve air circulation around the plant. Apply appropriate fungicides if the problem persists.

3. **Boxwood Adelgids**:
   - Symptoms: White, cottony masses on twigs and branches, stunted growth, and yellowing of leaves.
   - Management: Remove the adelgid-infested twigs by hand, spray with horticultural oil or insecticidal soap, and apply neem oil as a preventive measure.

4. **Environmental Stress**:
   - Symptoms: Yellowing or browning of leaves, overall poor vigor.
   - Management: Ensure adequate watering, proper fertilization, and avoid overwatering. Consider adjusting pruning practices to maintain air circulation and health.

### Recommended Management Strategy:
1. **Visual Inspection**: Carefully inspect the entire plant for signs of disease or pest infestation. Look for symptoms such as discoloration, deformity, or any visible pests.

2. **Pruning**: Prune dead or dying branches back to healthy wood. Use clean, sharp shears and disinfect them between cuts to prevent the spread of disease.

3. **Cultural Practices**:
   - Watering: Ensure consistent but not excessive watering. Avoid wetting the foliage, especially during the cooler part of the day.
   - Fertilization: Apply a balanced fertilizer according to the soil test results. Over-fertilizing can stress the plant and make it more susceptible to diseases.

4. **Chemical Control**:
   - If fungal diseases are suspected, use a systemic fungicide like mancozeb or thiophanate-methyl. Follow the label instructions carefully

title: Perhaps diseased maple? #800949
question: I have two 8-year old maple trees in my yard. Am wondering if anyone can tell me what is up with them.  They leafed out nicely in mid-May and all looked fine. Now, in late June/July many of  the leaves are wilting and turning brown around the edges.   It is worse at the tops of the trees. But looks like it might be spreading.  Help.

answer.response:
Hi Patti,
Thank you for contacting Ask Extension!
This looks like advanced stages of iron chlorosis which occurs when the tree can not take up adequate amounts of iron, which is necessary in the photosynthetic process. You can read more about it at the link below:
https://hnr.k-state.edu/extension/info-center/common-pest-problems/common-pest-problem-new/Iron%20Chlorosis%20of%20Trees.pdf
A foliar spray of iron sulfate or iron chelate may be necessary to correct the condition in the short term; in the long term you should make plans to lower the pH of the soil and/or add an iron supplement to the soil. All options are explained in detail in the article above. 
If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out. 
Thank you,
Julie
answer.author: Julie Crick

symptom description: leaves are turning brown around the edges
management instructions: A foliar spray of iron sulfate or iron chelate may be necessary to correct the condition in the short term.
Lower the pH of the soil and/or add an iron supplement to the soil in the long term.

title: What is on my tomato plant?  #808634
question: What is on my tomato plant? Do I need to worry about this?

1.response:
Thanks for your question.

We suspect that these bumps are tomato galls. Galls are cancerous types of plant growth induced by various stimuli. These typically can include insect invasion or environmental stress. This season (2022) we have had reports of gall formation in tomatoes similar to what you are observing. We believe that this is attributable to some of very hot temperatures during July. These small nodules in your picture should not be harmful to the plants nor to the tomato fruit. You can probably just ignore them. See the following for further information:

https://extension.umn.edu/yard-and-garden-insects/insect-and-mite-galls - :~:text=These aphid-like insects are,two galls and their causes.

https://www.purdue.edu/hla/sites/yardandgarden/plant-galls-not-always-harmful/

Thank you for using our forum.

title: Can someone i d this snake? #591588
question: Found this tiny guy in my backyard. He was bright red. I picked him up and he changed color to dark brown. When I released him , he turned red again.

1.response:
Thank you for your question. The photograph you sent is somewhat out of focus when I attempt to enlarge it, but this looks like a Brownsnake, scientific name Storeria dekayi. It is a nonvenomous species.

Typical length of adults is 9 - 12 inches. Maximum length is approximately 18 inches. They are common in many eastern and southeastern states. They are found in a variety of habitats. They are commonly found by homeowners under mulch, pine straw and leaf litter, where they spend their time looking for prey.

They feed on insects, insect larvae, slugs, snails and earthworms.

Here's a link to the Amphibians and Reptiles of North Carolina webpage where you can find out more about this species:

http://herpsofnc.org/brown-snake/

I hope this answers your question, and thank you for contacting Ask an Expert.

Jim

title: Flowering trees fungus? #677932
question:
Good Morning,
 I have 40-50 mature ornamental  flowering crabapple trees “not sure of this “ that produce leaves and fruit . The leaves drop early every year and look nearly void of leaves. I suspect a fungus? I have too many trees to afford a professional arborist to do the work. I hope to purchase a sprayer for the back of the side by side vehicle I have and do the job myself. I have pictures of the leaves to help identify the problem.

answer.response:
Gary, Thank you for the question.  This looks like apple scab. This is caused by a fungus Venturia inaequalis which over winters in the leaf debris.  Removing the leaves and spraying at the appropriate times can help reduce the problem. Check out the following links for additional information:

title: Mouse Identification #209378
question:
I live near La Pine State Park. I have recently discovered and trapped 4 mice inside my 17' travel trailer. The trailer is parked near my 6 year old storage shed - there is no evidence of mice inside my shed which periodically contains kitchen garbage inside of plasic bags. The trailer has been on both 
sides of Santiam Pass in the last 2 years. The mice appear gray with just a tinge of brown closer to the skin. Tails are gray on top and white on the bottom.   Are these Deer Mice? Hantavirus is my concern.
Also, do mice poisoned with bromethalin bait seek water or just die where they are nesting?

Jim in La Pine

1.response:
I would support your ID of the mice. Although Hantavirus has occurred in Oregon, a more general concern would be minimizing your exposure to wild rodents in an enclosed setting such as a trailer. Be sure to mist (such as a spray detergent like 409) surfaces before cleaning them or damp-mop. Make sure to shield your nose and mouth so that you don't inhale dried and aerosolized excretions of the mice. Bromethalin is a fast-acting toxin with no known antidote. Therefore I wouldn't expect animals to roam far before collapsing. Because of its toxicity and lack of antidote, bromethalin products are a hazard to non-target wildlife, pets, and humans, so be cautious with it.
To combat the mouse problem in the trailer, try to identify where they're entering (unless they have colonized the walls) and use steel wool and/or other tough materials to exclude them. Trap out the remaining animals and then monitor closely so you can quickly detect any further incursions.
I hope this information is helpful,
Dana
1.author: Dana Sanchez

Tails are gray on top and white on the bottom

title: Black Rot #263595
question: I have been growing a grape crop for about 15 years.  It has produced grapes for 8 of those years.  Starting with last year I noticed early there were brown spots on the leaves that spread to the grapes and ruined the crop. At the beginning of this year I started spraying the vine with captan every 2 weeks.  Things looked great until the last week.  We can't keep up with the spread of it at this point. Is this black rot and what do you recommend to stop it?

answer.response:
As long as the weather conditions are right - meaning warm temps and rain, you are unfortunately probably going to continue to see black rot on your grapes this season. The rain splashes the fungus around. New growth is particularly susceptible.

In addition to spraying the fungicide ever 7-10 days, cultural control is critical. Remove and destroy all mummified fruit and any leaves that show signs of disease. Good air circulation is really important, so if may be appropriate to prune the vines.

This fall a really thorough clean up around your vines will be essential for preventing black rot on next year's grapes.  Rake up all leaves and fallen mummies. Be careful to remove mummies that remain attached to the vine.  Prune out infected canes and be careful to remove infected tendrils. 

The following link has a paragraph about using fungicides as a protectant against the development of black rot.  You may want to do this next spring. 

http://extension.umaine.edu/ipm/ipddl/publications/5106e/
answer.author: Lynda Anderson

symptom description: brown spots spreading to the grapes
management instructions: Spray fungicide every 7-10 days.
Remove and destroy all mummified fruit and any leaves that show signs of disease.
Prune the vines to improve air circulation.
Rake up all leaves and fallen mummies this fall.
Prune out infected canes and remove infected tendrils.
qa_information.background info: The grape crop has been grown for 15 years and has produced grapes for 8 years. The Question Asker started spraying captan every 2 weeks at the beginning of the year.

title: Perennial Onion Issue? #638436
question:
Greetings!

For the second year in a row I'm noticing black spots on my walking onion foliage.  I'm assuming it's a fungal issue but not completely sure. Any advice on diagnosis as well as possible treatments (organic if possible) is welcome!

Many thanks!

answer.response: Thank you for the question. It appears that the lesions area result of purple blotch (Alternaria porri). The initial brown lesions will eventually turn purple as the fungal spores develop. Crop rotation is frequently suggested which may be a problem for your perennial crop. Avoiding leaf wetness by watering early so plants can dry during the day. Consider drip irrigation if you do not already have it. Sanitation (ie cleanup) is also important. Fungicides can help control the disease and should be rotated for best control.  Copper (e.g., cuprous oxide), mancozeb, chlorothalonil are the fungicides frequently used. check out the following link:https://cdn.shopify.com/s/files/1/0145/8808/4272/files/A3804.pdfI hope this helps,
answer.author: Barry Andersen

title: ? Wilt #414403
question:
Hi. I think I may have either wilt or blight in my tomatoes. Is there a way to confirm?  If it's wilt what is the best soil treatment?  I have read you can "bake" out by wrapping the garden soil in clear plastic. 
Thanks in advance!

1.response:
There are several reasons why tomatoes can wilt like this: root disturbance, lack of water, very hot weather, or a wilt disease. Fusarium wilt is the most common wilt disease in tomatoes in home gardens. There is really no cure for this, unfortunately. The best you can do is pull up the plant and discard it in the trash (do not compost it). If you can still find tomatoes at a nursery, there is still time to plant them. Put new plants in a different part of the garden (as fusarium can persist in the soil). In the future, look for tomato varieties that have fusarium resistance. https://extension.umd.edu/growit/fusarium-wilt-tomato-vegetables

ckc

title: What bug is this #816374
question: Found this bug in my house and I was wondering what it is. For scale, it is on the corner of a single sheet of toilet paper in the picture.

1.response:
This appears to be a Kudzu Bug. They feed on Kudzu vines, an invasive bean relative that tends to take over roadside vegetation and climbs trees. This non-native insect feeds on plant sap and doesn't harm people, but can be a nuisance because they try to overwinter indoors where it's milder than outside. In nature, they would seek-out crevices under tree bark, in tree cavities, in gaps between stones, or other sheltered spots. You can look for gaps and cracks in the home's exterior that may be allowing them to get inside and seal them to help keep more from getting in. Worn door or window weather-stripping or torn window screens are other common points of entry.

Miri
1.author: Mira Talabac

management instructions: seal gaps and cracks in the home"s exterior

repair torn window screens

title: new weed in the lawn #317827
question: A new weed has turned up in our St. Augustine lawn.  Is there any advice to rid the lawn of it.  It grows quickly and horizontally.  It is easy to pull out w/roots, thankfully.  Still it seems to quickly reappear.  I have also noticed it for the first time along the greenbelt trails on the northside of San Antonio.

1.response:
Hello,

Looks like young bedstraw weed.

Simply put, mow, mow and mow and or pull, pull and pull. This includes parameters as well.

Do not let these plants regrow, flower or set seeds.

Meaning, you may need to mow every three days during the major growing season.

Then, kick up the nutrition by fertilizing the area three times a year in mid-April, early June and mid-October,

XL2G pre-emergent herbicide should really be used for two years.

Applied in late February, early June and again in late August.

Good luck!

David Rodriguez -Extension Horticulturist

Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service

Bexar County/San Antonio
1.author: David Rodriguez

Mow every three days during the major growing season.
Fertilize the area three times a year in mid-April, early June and mid-October.
Use XL2G pre-emergent herbicide for two years.
Apply herbicide in late February, early June and again in late August.

title: How to prevent Roma tomato rot #717565
question: 95% of my Rona tomatoes have a black rot on the bottom, often consuming more than half of the tomato. What causes this and how can I prevent it?

1.response:
This is blossom end rot (BER), a common tomato disorder. It is caused by a calcium deficiency - not because the soil lacks calcium, but because the tomato plant cannot take in the calcium. There are several reasons that this happens: uneven watering and other weather related phenomena, root disturbance and over-fertilizing. Also, some varieties are more prone to get BER than others ('Roma' is notorious for BER). Tomatoes grown in pots have trouble with it, possibly because of uneven watering. Read here:https://hort.extension.wisc.edu/articles/blossom-end-rot/
The non-rot portion of the tomato is still perfectly edible. In the future, pay attention to watering and cultivating around the plants, and don't over fertilize. I'd also recommend switching to another paste tomato variety. There are varieties that allegedly aren't prone to get BER. Unfortunately, nurseries often offer 'Roma' as their only choice for paste tomato.
1.author: Dennis White

2.response: Thanks for the info - I will see if I can find an alternate tomato variety for next year's planting.
2.author: The Question Asker

title: Bug on vegetable leaves #419935
question: Can you identify the bug in this picture? It's about an inch long, black with one white stripe going vertically down its body. I have seen three or four of them in the garden so far. There are many small holes in my vegetable plant leaves, especially the eggplant, Can this bug be responsible? If it is not beneficial, can you suggest some controls? Thanks.

1.response:
The insects are blister beetles.  There is only one generation a year, and though they feed on many vegetable crops, their favorite is potatoes. Still, their numbers are rarely high enough for you to notice damage.  Some years their populations soar. In that case, wear gloves or use a hand broom to protect skin and knock them into a container of soapy water. Pyrethrum or neem may be applied to damaging populations.

title: Sweet Shrub #639799
question: Why are my Sweet Shrub leaves turning brown along the edges?

answer.response:
This looks like cold damage to the foliage.  Leaf buds and tender, newly developed foliage is most susceptible to late frost injury. Damaged plant tissue may become distorted, wilted, or even blackened. We have had quite a few reports of frost damage to many types of plants recently; you are certainly not alone.

There is really nothing you can do. Just give the plant time to put out new growth as the weather warms up and temperatures stabilize. As long as leaves still have some normal green tissue they can still conduct photosynthesis and produce energy to support the plant's growth.

Marian
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

management instructions: Give the plant time to put out new growth as the weather warms up and temperatures stabilize.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a plant with some leaves that appear to be wilting, yellowing, and possibly damaged at the edges. This could indicate several issues such as nutrient deficiencies, overwatering, under-watering, pest infestation, or environmental stress (like sunburn or heat damage). Since it's a sweet shrub (Calycanthus floridus), which typically thrives in moist, well-drained soil with partial shade, it's important to assess the plant's growing conditions.

Here’s a recommended management strategy:

1. **Watering**: Ensure the plant is receiving consistent moisture but not excess water. The soil should be kept moist but not soggy. Consider reducing watering if there is significant rainfall or if the area is prone to waterlogging.

2. **Soil Conditions**: Check the soil pH and nutrient levels. Sweet shrubs prefer acidic to neutral soil. Test the soil to determine if adjustments need to be made using fertilizers or amendments like peat moss or sulfur.

3. **Pest Control**: Inspect the plant for any signs of pests. If you suspect pests, identify them and take appropriate measures. Common pests on sweet shrubs include aphids, scale insects, and mites. Use insecticidal soaps or neem oil as natural remedies, or consult with a local extension service for recommendations.

4. **Shade and Sunlight**: Provide partial shade to protect the plant from direct sunlight, especially if the area experiences intense heat. Ensure the plant is not receiving too much direct sunlight, which can cause leaf scorch.

5. **Pruning**: If the leaves are severely damaged, consider pruning back the affected areas to encourage new growth. However, avoid pruning too much as this could weaken the plant.

6. **Mulching**: Apply a layer of organic mulch around the base of the plant to retain moisture, regulate soil temperature, and suppress weeds.

7. **Monitoring**: Keep an eye on the plant’s health over time. Regularly check for signs of recovery or further decline and adjust care accordingly.

If the issue persists despite these steps, consider consulting a horticulturist or a local nursery specialist who can provide more tailored advice based on the specific conditions of your location.

title: What is this weed or grass? #258677
question:
I have several wildflower beds that I grow from seed each year.  We live on the Gunnison River.  I am attaching a picture of the weed or grass that is taking over my flower beds.  There is more of it each year. It's out of control!  What is it and can anyone tell me how to get rid of it?
Thanks much,
Marilyn

1.response: Marilyn, This is Horse tail which is a perennial deep rooted (6ft) weed that spreads from tubers and rhizomes. Mowing or cutting it down is about your best option.  However, after a few years this might knock them back until they exhaust their root energy storage. Few herbicides will work and will take several years. Here is a link to the plant: http://wric.ucdavis.edu/information/natural%20areas/wr_E/Equisetum.pdf  I think the variety in the picture is Equisetum arvense. Good luck. Eric
1.author: Eric McPhail

2.response:
Thanks so much Eric. I'm glad to know what I'm battling, and it sounds like the battle will be ongoing.  I appreciate your help! 
Marilyn
2.author: The Question Asker

management instructions: Mowing or cutting it down is about your best option.
Few herbicides will work and will take several years.

title: Pine tree troubles #563185
question: I have been told that there are pine beetles attacking the pines in our neighborhood but I don’t know how to identify affected trees. I also think I have another problem pest as well leaving white web-ish material on many trees. Help!

answer.response:
The wooly mass of insects are called pine bark adelgid which are sucking insects. It is fairly common on white pine bark and usually not serious. These insects can be treated using horticultural oils or insecticidal soaps. See the following article from MSU Extension Educator Jill O'Donnell https://www.canr.msu.edu/news/pine_bark_adelgid_becoming_active_in_white_pines
The tree with the cracked bark may have had boresr but often pine borers are secondary insects coming in when a tree is already weakened which can be from a variety of problems including environmental issues, especially periods of drought that have occurred in last three summers.  Cannot tell why this tree declined for sure from this picture.
answer.author: Robert Bricault
