title: Why is my tree turning everything around it black? #260675
question: I have what I believe is an American elm that is probably 30+ years old.  The bark has turned black and has spread a grayish substance on my flagstone patio, brick planter and my deck.   What could be wrong and is it fixable?

1.response:
Thank you for your question. 

I will need several pictures. I will need pictures of the bark (close up and more broad), the grayish substance, the entire tree (including where it is planted in the dirt. 

If you do not have the capability to transmit the pictures electronically please let me know and I will give you different instructions.
1.author: Kerry Peetz

2.response: Here are the first 3 pics.
2.author: The Question Asker

3.response: These 3 are of the residue.  Let me know if you need more.  Thank you for looking at this!
3.author: The Question Asker

4.response:
Thank you for the pictures. 

Sooty Mold Damage.

This is a minor fungus that grows on the syrupy excretions of some insects that feed on trees. The fungus does little physical damage to the tree unless it is so severe that leaves coated with sooty mold cannot photosynthesize and create food for the tree. The insects may be a greater problem, but even then they may not be a major problem. The greatest effect is the aesthetic damage. Some people do not want to have dark bark on a tree that should have a lighter colored bark. Others are just worried that this is a problem that could permanently damage or kill their tree.

While permanent damage is possible, it will take years, so you have time to deal with the problem. The method of managing this problem is to manage the insects. The problem is probably due to aphids that feed by sucking juices from the leaves and twigs without chewing on them. They may be treated with several insecticides. However, if the damage to the tree is not too severe and the need for removal of the insects is not too urgent, try alternative methods to allow natural predators to assist. In the spring before the leaves appear, spray the branches and trunk with a horticultural oil spray (according to label direction). This will remove some overwintering insects with minimal damage to the beneficial insect population. As the tree begins growing and the insects begin excreting honeydew, it is time to spray. Use a strong jet of water to wash aphids from the leaves. Aphids will drop easily from the leaves when disturbed. Many will land on lower leaves, but washing will remove them to the ground. You may not be able to reach the top of an 80-foot-tall tree without a power washer or commercial spray device, but even if you don't reach the top of the tree, you can reduce the severity of the problem. This will also reduce the damage being done to the tree. Beneficial insects will help manage the problem in the top of the tree since you are not using insecticides that will kill them. The next line of defense will be to employ insecticidal soap (don't use in the heat of the summer) or other least-toxic insecticides. The purpose is to affect the aphid population with minimum impact on the population of beneficial insects.

Any time you use insecticides, organic or synthetic, it is important that you read, understand, and follow the label directions.
4.author: Kerry Peetz

qa_information.disease/issue identification: Sooty Mold Damage caused by aphids
symptom description: grayish substance on flagstone patio, brick planter and deck
management instructions: Spray branches and trunk with horticultural oil spray in the spring before leaves appear.
Use a strong jet of water to wash aphids from the leaves.
Employ insecticidal soap or other least-toxic insecticides if necessary.
Read, understand, and follow the label directions when using insecticides.

title: Plum Tree Issue #796643
question:
Hi, 
I have a plum tree that took damage to the roots last year. It really struggled and didn't produce fruit but I babied it through. This year started much better and it set fruit. During the last two months the leaves on parts of the tree have really slowed down. It doesn't look well at all. I was hoping you may know what it is and what I could do.

answer.response:
Dear Brandy,
There are several things that could be going on.  First, you most likely have aphids or white flies in the curled up leaves.  Also look for ants on the tree as they herd both those insects for their honeydew.
You need to remove all the grass around the tree.  It is sapping the nutrients from the tree.  Then put some petroleum jelly around the base of the tree.  That will keep the ants from going up into the tree. 
Use strong blasts of water to get rid of the ants if you have any on the tree and to some extent it will take out the aphids or white flies.
Also, looks like you may have a fungal disease where the leaves are brown or not growing at all.  You need to prune all those branches out and put them in the garbage.  Use alcohol on your pruners after every cut to kill any spores that might be on the pruner from the diseased plant material.
Purchase a sulfur spray and spray all the leaves top and bottom as well as the limbs after you prune. This can be done every 10 days but sulfur will burn so if you buy a concentrate, follow the directions exactly and wear protective clothing, gloves and safety glasses.
After you remove the grass, you can add some composted manure and water it in.  You can also use a non-manure compost as a mulch around the tree after you put the manure on.   Put it about 5 inches from the trunk so the rodents cannot hide in it and chew on the trunk and make the mulch as least 12 inches wide and about 6 inches deep.  
While it has been raining almost not stop, it looks like the weather is going to get hot and the mulch will help the soil stay moist.
You can switch off your sprays and it may help kill the fungal disease faster, like taking two antibiotics if you were sick.  You can purchase pure Neem oil online.  The Neem oils that come prepackaged in a mix have unknow ingredients in them.  If you use the sulfur and then pure Neem, both are organically approved and following the directions, you will be able to eat the fruit from the tree.  Both the sulfur and the Neem oil have restrictions on how often to spray.  Wait at least the 10 days between spraying the sulfur and going to the Neem oil.
The fungal disease on your tree looks severe.  Stay with the spray program as directed on the packages and watch the leaves for new growth.
Here is a link about planting, pests and disease:  
https://extension.oregonstate.edu/gardening/berries-fruit/fruit-tree-pest-management
and one more:
https://extension.oregonstate.edu/gardening/berries-fruit/planting-caring-fruit-tree
If you have further questions, please contact us again.
answer.author: Sheryl Casteen

answer.response:
Thank you so much! I really appreciate it!

Best regards,
Brandy Davis On Monday, June 20, 2022, 11:18:14 AM PDT, Ask Extension <askextension@eduworks.com> wrote:
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response: You are welcome, good luck.
answer.author: Sheryl Casteen

title: Help for my Hawthorn tree #676528
question:
Based on my research, I believe this is a type of Hawthorn, but I'm not sure which.  It has been growing against a structure for years and looks a bit stressed, but the berries this fall have been impressive.  I'm also concerned about this growth or disease on one of its limbs.
Can this tree be saved?  Should it? 
Thanks for any info you can provide!

answer.response:
This looks like a hawthorn but we cannot say what type. We notice thorns on the branches. In general hawthorn are susceptible to several disease and insect issues. 

This looks like a rust disease on the branch (right photo). The rust can form cankers (dieback/deadwood) on the branch or trunk.  In some cases cankers can come in where the thorns are. There are several types of rust which include cedar apple rust, cedar quince rust, and cedar hawthorne rust. It does not kill the trees but obviously are very disfiguring. This can be common in cool wet weather. In all cases, the disease has alternate hosts, one being a juniper tree or shrub and the other being a plant in the rosaceae family. Other pomaceous hosts may include serviceberry, apple, crabapple trees, etc.The most common alternate host in this area is the Eastern Red Cedar which is actually a juniper.

The disease is always lurking waiting for the right weather conditions to attack the tree. It is also air-borne and can be blown into the landscape on the wind. The best recommendation is to select disease resistant varieties. However, resistant varieties are not immune. Fungicides are not practical as you would have to spray consistently for two months in the spring in order to control it.  http://extension.umd.edu/hgic/rust-diseases-trees-and-shrubs

At this point there is nothing that you can do. If you have cankers on small twigs or branches, you can prune back to healthy tissue. No pruning is recommended for the large branch. Live with it and see if it gets worse. If so, you may decide to replace in the future. 

Marian
answer.author: Marian Hengemihle

symptom description: growth or disease on one of its limbs
cankers (dieback/deadwood) on the branch or trunk
management instructions: If you have cankers on small twigs or branches, prune back to healthy tissue.
No pruning is recommended for the large branch.
Live with it and see if it gets worse.

title: Help removing Joe Pye weed #458989
question: Several years ago I planted a couple of Joes in an out of the way area of the backyard. It thrived and a big stand grew. It’s not there anymore. Which is ok because plants have grown elsewhere and I like them because of the pollinators. However some have started taking over from other native plants. My gardens are 95% native so it breaks my heart  to remove these inconvenient plants. However today I spent hours trying to dig some out. If the long, dense fibrous roots weren’t enough there is also some hard impenetrable “growing part”. I will have to resort to some kind of chemical warfare. Any suggestions? Thanks

1.response:
Joe pye is not usually this rampant.  Send us some photos 

Otherwise, just pull them before they get any size and require digging or treating with herbicide. If you have to apply herbicide to some big plants, just get the plant low, leaving a few leaves to absorb the herbicide, or only apply to freshly cut stems. Hold the nozzle close and you will only need a tiny bit of herbicide. 

ECN
1.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

2.response: Thanks for the advice. I’ve been away for a couple of weeks and shall start working. The younger Joes I call easily pull out-less than 1-2 feet tall. The old guys 6-7 and more feet are tough. One pic is of the shovel that I was using to pry up the hard dense root are. It broke off. I can’t budge these guys today and the ground is too dry. These Joes are about 5-6 feet tall but I cut the tops off before leaving home.  Thanks
2.author: The Question Asker

3.response:
Yes, they are fast growers and it will take persistence to remove them. If the digging is too difficult, you can cut them down with loppers and apply a small amount of herbicide (glyphosate) to the cut stem to kill the roots (as described in our previous reply). You may need to keep after it for a while to get all of it out.

ckc
3.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

If you have to apply herbicide to some big plants, just get the plant low, leaving a few leaves to absorb the herbicide, or only apply to freshly cut stems.
Cut them down with loppers and apply a small amount of herbicide (glyphosate) to the cut stem to kill the roots.

answer.response: If the herbicide was applied according to label instructions, it is unlikely that the damage on the burning bush was caused by the weed killer. Check around the base of the shrub and make sure that the bark is intact and has not been stripped away by animals or weed whips. If the bark is intact, the shrub leafed out normally this spring and the damage was evident immediately after herbicide application, then it it is likely that the herbicide was responsible. In order for that kind of damage to occur, the concentration of the weed killer had to be too high. Unfortunately at this point there is nothing you can do other than flushing the root zone with water. Trees and shrubs can recover from minor herbicide damage. Scrape a little of the bark off the branches to see if they are alive. The interior wood should be light green to white. If the wood is tan to brown, the branch is dead. If the branches are still alive you can wait and see if the shrub pushes out new leaves. If it doesn't, you will have to replace it. Here is more information on herbicide injury: http://msue.anr.msu.edu/uploads/files/6-23%20Nursery%20grower%20checklist%20TOM%20herbicide%20injury...
answer.author: Charlene Molnar

answer.response: Thank you.

Here are the recommended steps for managing this situation:

1. **Monitor the Bush**: Continue monitoring the bush for signs of recovery or further decline. It's important to observe whether new growth appears from the dead branches or if there is any sign of regrowth from the treated areas.

2. **Evaluate the Herbicide Application**: Assess the method and timing of the herbicide application. Ensure that the application was done correctly and followed the recommended rates and timing as per the product label. Sometimes, improper application can lead to unintended damage.

3. **Consider Reapplication**: If the affected branches do not show signs of recovery within a reasonable time frame (e.g., a few weeks), consider reapplying the herbicide. However, be cautious and consult with a professional if you decide to proceed with a second application.

4. **Control Other Burning Bushes**: Since the other burning bushes nearby are very healthy, ensure that no additional burning bushes in the area have been inadvertently treated. This could require re-evaluating the boundaries and the method of application.

5. **Consult a Professional**: If the issue persists or if there are concerns about the effectiveness of the treatment, consulting with a horticulturist or a professional weed scientist can provide more specific advice tailored to your location and conditions.

6. **Alternative Management Options**: If the herbicide approach is not effective, alternative methods such as manual removal or biological control might be considered. However, these options should be evaluated carefully to avoid causing further environmental harm.

In summary, the immediate focus should be on monitoring the treated area, ensuring proper application of herbicides, and seeking professional advice if necessary to address the issue effectively and safely.

title: cherry tree disease #798288
question:
We have a huge older cherry tree (Royal Anne type) on which the leaves throughout most of the tree show disease (see photo). We've observed isolated areas of this in past years, but this year is much much worse, affecting almost the entire tree. The general health of the tree has not been great for several years, as the trunk has exhibited canker type oozing and bark peeling. But cherry production has always been great. Any idea what this is, and any suggestions for what we can do, if anything?
Thanks.

1.response: That looks like cherry leaf spot, a fungal pathogen that overwinters on infected cherry leaves. In the fall, rake up and destroy the infected leaves. Removing these leaves will reduce disease spores next spring. There are some fungicides registered for home use, they need to be applied at petal fall, shucksplit and again 2 weeks later. Shucksplit is when small, young fruit shed the papery sheath covering them shortly after bloom. Based on your description of cankers and oozing, it sounds like you are also dealing with bacterial canker. Where possible, prune out and destroy infected branches. It is recommended that you prune in the summer (e.g. June/July) when the weather is dry. For more on managing diseases in your home orchard, refer to: https://catalog.extension.oregonstate.edu/ec631
1.author: Erica Chernoh

qa_information.disease/issue identification: cherry leaf spot and bacterial canker
management instructions: Rake up and destroy infected leaves in the fall.
Apply fungicides at petal fall, shucksplit, and again 2 weeks later.
Prune out and destroy infected branches in the summer when the weather is dry.
qa_information.background info: The tree is a huge older Royal Anne cherry tree, and its general health has not been great for several years, but cherry production has always been great.

The image shows a wasp nest (likely a paper wasp or hornet nest) attached to the underside of leaves on a tree. Given that it is located close to a front door and the species is a hornet, which can be aggressive and potentially dangerous, the recommended management strategy should prioritize safety and professional assistance.

Here are the steps to follow:

1. **Contact a Professional**: It is highly recommended to contact a licensed pest control expert or an exterminator who specializes in wasp and hornet removal. They have the necessary equipment and expertise to safely remove the nest without causing harm to themselves or the bees.

2. **Do Not Attempt Removal Yourself**: Attempting to remove a wasp or hornet nest yourself can be extremely risky. The wasps may defend their nest by stinging anyone who gets too close. This could lead to serious injury or death if the individual is allergic to bee venom.

3. **Remove Any Attraction**: Before calling for help, it might be a good idea to reduce any attractants that could draw more wasps to the area. Remove any sugary substances, pet food, and other foods that might be left out. Ensure that any trash cans are tightly sealed.

4. **Use Barriers**: If you live near a nest but do not want to remove it immediately, you can create barriers around the nest to prevent wasps from entering your home. This can include sealing cracks in the foundation, covering vents, and using mesh netting over windows and doors.

5. **Monitor the Situation**: Keep an eye on the nest to ensure it does not grow larger or become more of a threat. If you notice signs of increased activity or if the nest starts to grow significantly, it may be time to call for professional help.

In summary, the safest and most effective approach is to contact a professional exterminator to handle the nest safely and effectively.

title: We have 2 emerald maple t... #189154
question: We have 2 emerald maple trees in our front yard, both about 25 yrs. old.  Both looked great last season and seemed to go through a typical fall, etc. in 2013. One of them came out of this last brutal winter pretty well, though it has a few bare ends of branches...overall looks pretty good, though.  The other tree, however, really has come back much more sparsely, with maybe 1/3 to 1/2 of the tree (distributed throughout the tree, not in any one area) not leafed out yet.  1) Could this be a "winter kill" situation?  2) Is there anything we can do to help this tree along this season...fertilizer, etc.?  Will wait for your fine advice! :)

1.response: Many trees have dieback this spring due to a combination of many factors.  Some of the factors are listed below.   Environmental factors include a severe drought, a colder than normal winter conditions, and late spring frosts after the buds broke dormancy. Trees that go into dormancy in a weakened condition, due to drought, poor nutrition, pests, root damage etc, are more susceptible to winter injury. The last few seasons many parts of the state have experienced drought. Drought can cause dieback for the next few years.  Trees branches with winter injury leaf out and then die, or don’t leaf out at all. Dark streaking can be seen in the sapwood of injured branches.  Many maple trees were planted to deeply.  Check to see if the maple has a natural flair at the soil line or does it do straight into the ground like a telephone pole. Do you see a root growing around the trunk of the tree at the soil line?  These are signs of stem girdling roots. Do you see any fungi or wounds on the trunk?  Is the soil compacted?  Did the tree leaves change colors early last fall? http://www.extension.umn.edu/garden/diagnose/plant/deciduous/maple/branchesdead.html Prune all dead twigs or branches back to within 1/4 inch above a live bud or flush with the nearest live branch. Do not remove a branch that reveals a green layer underneath when scraped with a knife. They should eventually develop new growth. A 3-inch layer of mulch will reduce water loss and help maintain uniform soil moisture and temperatures around roots.   http://www.extension.umn.edu/garden/yard-garden/trees-shrubs/how-to-hire-a-professional-arborist/
1.author: Pat Mack

symptom description: 1/3 to 1/2 of the tree is not leafed out
management instructions: Prune all dead twigs or branches back to within 1/4 inch above a live bud or flush with the nearest live branch.
Apply a 3-inch layer of mulch to reduce water loss and help maintain uniform soil moisture and temperatures around roots.
qa_information.background info: The trees are 25 years old and went through a typical fall in 2013, but experienced a brutal winter.

agmmu_question.answer: Prune all dead twigs or branches back to within 1/4 inch above a live bud

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows an emerald maple tree with some signs of stress or potential damage. Given the context provided, which includes the tree going through a typical fall in 2013 followed by a harsh winter, it's important to consider the potential impacts on the tree's health.

### Recommended Management Strategy:

1. **Assess the Tree Health**:
   - **Examine the Tree**: Look for any signs of bark damage, dead branches, or unusual discoloration. The tree appears to have some leaf loss, which could be a sign of stress from the previous winter.
   - **Check for Pest Infestation**: Inspect the trunk and branches for signs of borers or other pests that might be affecting the tree.

2. **Pruning**:
   - **Deadwood Removal**: Remove any dead or dying branches. This can help reduce the risk of further damage from wind or storms.
   - **Promote New Growth**: If the tree is stressed, pruning can help stimulate new growth and improve its overall health. However, avoid over-pruning as this can weaken the tree further.

3. **Watering**:
   - **Monitor Water Needs**: During the summer months, ensure the tree receives adequate water, especially if it's experiencing stress due to the cold winter. Water deeply but infrequently to encourage deep root growth.

4. **Mulching**:
   - **Apply Mulch**: Apply a 2-3 inch layer of mulch around the base of the tree, but not touching the trunk. This helps retain moisture and suppress weeds, which can compete for nutrients.

5. **Fertilizing**:
   - **Apply Fertilizer**: Use a balanced fertilizer designed for shade trees to provide necessary nutrients. Follow the manufacturer’s instructions carefully, as too much fertilizer can harm the tree.

6. **Staking**:
   - **Support Young Trees**: If the tree is still young and vulnerable, consider staking it to prevent wind damage.

7. **Protection from Pests and Diseases**:
   - **Monitor for Pests**: Keep an eye out for signs of pests such as aphids, borers, or scale insects.
   - **Apply Treatments**: If necessary, use appropriate insecticides or fungicides as directed by a professional arborist.

8. **Consult an Arborist**:
   - **Professional Advice**: Given the specific history of the tree, consulting with a certified arborist would be beneficial. They can provide a more detailed assessment and tailored management plan based

title: My lawn is getting torned by some rat-like creatrues and I need to identify them and how can I get rid of them? #870360
question:
Hello,

I have lots and lots of patches and pathways in my lawn.  I found some small rat-like animals on my lawn running in those pathways and I killed a couple of them with my shovel.   Now, I would like to identify the rat-like creatures and need to know how can I get rid of them completely and  also avoid them in the future.

I would appreciate if you could provide some help identifying the animal and to get rid of them.


Thanks.

answer.response: Hello, these are short-tailed shrews. As for eradication, I’m unfortunately unfamiliar with control methods. If there are many of them, you may need to consult a lawn care expert or pest control specialist. Otherwise setting snap traps or other type may be effective. Home garden centers or big box stores also carry a variety of products that may help, but can’t personally recommend any one product.
answer.author: Clay Wilton

answer.response:
Hello Clay,

  Thanks for your expert opinion and the reply to my question.  I appreciate that.  Someone told me that these are Moles/voles.  So,  Can I have one more person review this please and he/she may have a solution on how to get rid of this creature?

Thanks. Regards


On Tue, May 28, 2024 at 4:43 PM Ask Extension <ask@extension.org> wrote:
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
You're welcome. I don't believe there are other people that study mammals on this platform through MSU Extension, unfortunately. However, these are short-tailed shrews (Blarina brevicauda). Please see these two links for a comparison. Moles have extremely large paddle-like front feet and are quite a bit larger overall. Moles also tunnel underground and create raised mounds of dirt in the lawn; short-tailed shrews will create runways through the grass as it appears in your picture.

Short-tailed shrew identification

Eastern mole identification

Another distinctive feature of shrews is that the tips of their teeth are reddish brown, caused by an iron compound deposited during growth. Moles lack this trait, so if you still have any of the specimens, this is a sure way to distinguish the species.

Doing a Google image search using their scientific names (Scalopus aquaticus for eastern mole and Blarina brevicauda for shrew) will provide a wealth of good comparative images as well.

Unfortunately we also don't have a pest control expert on this platform through MSU Extension, so you will have to search elsewhere. Apologies.

 Best,
answer.author: Clay Wilton

answer.response:
Thanks, Clay for your detailed response.  I appreciate it.  I think I have enough information to proceed.

Thanks again.

title: Japanese beetles eating away my tree #581552
question:
Attached is a picture I took of these pests that are eating away at my tree that is a new snow crab tree as of 2 months ago. From the research I did it looks like Japanese beetles which are invasive species.

Is there someone that can come out to my house to get rid of them or let me know how I can get rid of them? I live in Crystal

1.response:
Thank you for your question.

Yes, indeed, Japanese Beetles are an invasive species.  They first appeared on the East Coast some years back and have relentlessly made their way westward.  The beetles you are now seeing came from eggs laid in 2018 from which grubs emerged that then spent the 2018-2019 winter in the soil.  These grubs emerged as adult beetles a few weeks ago. Hand removal of adult beetles and placing them in a pail of soapy water is considered to be the most effective means of dealing with them.  However as you remove the beetles from your gardens, more beetles will fly in.  This means that this will be an ongoing, daily battle for you.  A one-time treatment by someone visiting your property will only be a temporary solution.  As far as we know there is no spray that will repel Japanese Beetles.  You may want to consider trying to destroy grubs in your soil sometime towards August. These are grubs that will produce adults that will visit you in 2020. Many of these points are covered in the following two articles:

https://extension.umn.edu/yard-and-garden-insects/japanese-beetles

https://blog-yard-garden-news.extension.umn.edu/2017/07/dealing-with-japanese-beetles.html

Good Luck!!
1.author: Steve Hedman

management instructions: hand removal of adult beetles and placing them in a pail of soapy water
consider trying to destroy grubs in soil towards August

title: What kind of nest is this?  #470656
question: Found this green putty looking nest in our house that is under construction. Any idea?

1.response:
Hello,

This is the chrysalis stage of the monarch butterfly, confirmed with one of our UK Extension Entomologists.  He says it should emerge in 7 - 10 days.  Is it possible to leave the chrysalis hanging there until the butterfly emerges?  That would be the best case scenario.

If it must be moved, detach it carefully, keeping the stem intact.  Then carefully tie some light twine to the tip of the stem and suspend it in a landscape shrub.  With the way the butterfly will emerge, the chrysalis needs to stay in a hanging state.

Traci

title: Help #339900
question: Some of my blanket flowers have spots on their leaves. I have been using a copper based fungicide but it has not helped. What is causing the spots? Any solution?

1.response:
We also viewed your question #339639.  
Based on your photo it looks like the plant is infected with white smut, a fungal disease. This disease does not kill the plant but leaves may brown and fall off. Clean up any infected leaves that fall off. Remove infected leaves at first sign of this disease to lessen the spread and allow the fungus to survive over the winter. In general this disease is more a problem in nursery production where plants are closely spaced and there is overhead watering.
We do not recommend preventative sprays for this disease because you would have to spray from early spring through the mid-summer. At the end of the season if the plant is still infected, we recommend that you remove the plant to lessen chances of the fungus overwintering.
mh

title: Bartlet Pear with Fuchsia Pink bumps on Leaves? #788562
question:
Hi there, 

I planted my Barlet pear tree in fall of 2020. I purchased it from StarkBros as a bareroot. We used organic compost and fertilizer when planting the tree, and it did fine last year spring, and summer of 2021; just no blooms. This year we were excited because we had spring blooms after pruning. No signs of other problems on any of our newly planted fruit trees even after our Ice storm (all planted in  
Fall of 2020 during planting season). However, we noticed in late March early April that our Bartlet Pear tree had these Fuchsia pink bump and some our clustered together. We have tried Neem oil, organic orchard spray, and then recently a organic sulfur spray. Nothing has seemed to work. It seems to even be on newly emerging bud leaves that haven't even opened yet. I can't fine anything that looks like what the tree has online when doing my research. So I am hoping you can help identify what is attacking my pear tree before it spreads to the rest of my grove. Any help would be greatly appreciated.

answer.response:
Thanks for reaching out and for sending such great photos. Very helpful!  This looks like a problem caused by eriophyid mites. These microscope mites overwinter in the leaf buds & scales. The mites feed on the developing leaves and cause that thickening and discoloration.

Timing of the spray is really key. You need to smother the mites that are overwintering on the leaf buds before they start feeding. A fall application of lime sulfur can be helpful. Unfortunately, lime sulfur is really hard to find right now. You may need to call around to yard & garden,  hardware stores or farm stores to track some down. A spring application of superior/dormant horticulture oil right when the buds are developing will work, too. You'll have to keep an eye on the tree and cross your fingers there are some dry days when the buds are in the right stage. There is nothing to be sprayed right now so just mark your calendars for the fall & spring.  It may take a couple of seasons to get the problem reduced to an acceptable level. 

Find out more about the life cycle of eroiphyid mites here: https://pnwhandbooks.org/insect/tree-fruit/pear/pear-eriophyid-mite 
Take a look and let me know what additional questions you have.
answer.author: Brooke Edmunds

answer.response:
Thank you very much! I will try those things and hope for the best. Do you know if it spreads if near other trees. Is there something I can do to help protect/stop this from happening to my other trees now and also prevent it from happening in the future?

Sincerely,Elizabeth Hare 

Sent from Yahoo Mail on Android
On Mon, May 2, 2022 at 4:25 PM, Ask Extension<askextension@eduworks.com> wrote:
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response: This species of mite only damages pear trees. So other landscape trees or fruit trees won't be affected. But if you have other pear cultivars planted then give them the same lime sulfur or dormant oil spray. This will keep any small infestations from becoming an issue. Bartlett pear is quite susceptible to this mite (as you've noticed!) or cultivars may not have as noticeable symptoms. Take care!
answer.author: Brooke Edmunds

answer.response:
Thank you so much for your expertise. I am so grateful. Crossing my fingers my pear tree makes it! Have a great day.
Sincerely,Elizabeth Hare

title: Weed issue #313684
question:
Hello,
Over the years my once full grass has withered away in areas and given way to a particular type of weed. I cannot identify it from the pictures on the web, but I'm sure you all can. As for my grass (what's left of it) it is patchy. The ground is hard. Does it require lime? Aeration? Top soil and over seeding? We live in Clarksburg, MD (Montgomery County).The grass is in part shade in some areas and full sun in others. The area that struggles is in part shade. As for the weeds, I began to notice them about 2-3 years ago. They have gotten steadily worse over the years. I fertilize my grass typically once, in the early spring with Scott's Turf Builder. I would like to know the following:

What is this weed?
How do I get rid of it?
What can I do to get my grass to come back?

See my pictures that are attached.
Thank you.

answer.response:
The weed in your lawn looks like chickweed, a winter annual. Seeds germinate from late summer through fall. Weeds overwinter and continue to grow in early spring. Control with a broadleaf postemergent herbicide http://extension.umd.edu/sites/default/files/_images/programs/hgic/Publications/non_HGIC_FS/TT%2049%... when the weeds are actively growing in the spring. You can also control both with a preemergent applied in early to mid-September before it germinates. However, you would not be able to sow grass seed in the fall. Hand pull or mow soon to remove the seedheads before the plants mature. This one-time bagging of the clippings is recommended

Your lawn looks compacted and looks like it requires some renovation.  The best time is late summer through mid October.  Grass sown now needs to be able to make it through the stresses of summer.  You can test your soil now and results will give pH, liming, and fertilization recommendations. The best time to fertilize is in the fall. http://extension.umd.edu/hgic/soils/soil-testing

The best type of grass to sow is turf type tall fescue for full sun to part shade.  Your lawn looks compacted and there is a lot of competition for moisture and nutrients from the tree roots and lack of sunlight which is why the grass is not thriving. You will have to decide how you want to renovate the backyard. You have the option of lightly mulching around the tree roots and planting some shade perennials. This will also prevent lawn mower damage to the trunks. You can core aerate and seed the lawn areas not affected by tree roots.  See our publication on lawn renovation and overseeding http://extension.umd.edu/sites/default/files/_images/programs/hgic/Publications/HG102%20Lawn%20Estab...http://extension.umd.edu/sites/default/files/_images/programs/hgic/Publications/HG102%20Lawn%20Estab...

mh
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

management instructions: Control with a broadleaf postemergent herbicide when the weeds are actively growing in the spring.
Hand pull or mow soon to remove the seedheads before the plants mature.
You can also control both with a preemergent applied in early to mid-September before it germinates.
Test your soil now and results will give pH, liming, and fertilization recommendations.
The best time to fertilize is in the fall.
Core aerate and seed the lawn areas not affected by tree roots.

They live in Clarksburg, MD (Montgomery County).

title: What bug is this?  #351554
question: There are a large number of these crawling on the seed heads of this physostegia plant.  The plant seems ok but these bugs have moved in.  If they're beneficial I'll leave them be as the plant seems ok.  If not I'll remove the seed heads and dispose of them in a tied bag.  I've attached several photos.

answer.response:
The consensus among our entomological staff is that most of the bugs in the photos are nymphs of Sehirus cinctus, commonly known as 'Black Bug' which is a stink bug..   It is also known as the burrowing bug.   if control is required, use insecticidal soap, but avoid spraying during the heat of the day or late evening when plants are still stressed from the day's heat.  Spray in early morning when the bugs are present.
Your idea to bag and cut the plants is a good one.  
LS

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a Northstar cherry tree with what appears to be a problem involving the fruit or buds. It's important to identify the specific issue before recommending a management strategy. Here are some common issues that could be affecting cherry trees and possible solutions:

### Possible Issues:
1. **Bacterial Canker**: This disease can cause discolored or dead spots on the bark, which may lead to the death of branches if not addressed. Management includes pruning out affected areas and maintaining good sanitation by removing infected parts.

2. **Cherry Tree Fruit Fly**: This pest can lay eggs in the fruit, leading to deformities or the fruit dropping prematurely. Management involves cultural practices such as covering fruits with netting to prevent oviposition, and biological control using predatory wasps.

3. **Cherry Brown Rot**: This fungal disease affects the fruit, causing them to turn brown and fall off. Management involves removing infected fruit and pruning to improve air circulation around the tree.

4. **Cherry Bark Beetle**: These insects can bore into the bark and木质组织 (wood), potentially leading to tree decline. Management strategies include physical barriers like tree guards and tree wraps, and chemical treatments like systemic insecticides.

5. **Nutritional Deficiencies**: Insufficient nutrients can affect the tree’s health, leading to poor fruit development. Management includes soil testing to determine nutrient needs and applying fertilizers accordingly.

### Recommended Management Strategy:
1. **Visual Inspection**: First, carefully inspect the tree to determine the exact nature of the issue. Look for signs of insect activity, fungal growth, or nutrient deficiencies.
   
2. **Sanitation Practices**: Remove and destroy any infected fruit, leaves, or branches to prevent the spread of diseases.

3. **Pruning**: If the issue is bacterial canker or similar, prune out the affected branches at least 1 inch below the diseased area. Ensure clean tools are used and treated with a disinfectant between cuts.

4. **Cultural Practices**: Apply mulch to keep the soil moist and cool, which helps in reducing stress on the tree. Avoid overwatering, as cherry trees prefer well-drained soils.

5. **Insect Control**: If pests are present, consider using organic or synthetic insecticides depending on the severity and type of pest.

6. **Nutrient Management**: Test the soil to determine if there are any nutrient deficiencies. If necessary, apply appropriate fertilizers. Avoid overfertilization, as excess nitrogen can promote leafy growth at the expense of fruit production.

7.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a plant with slender, upright stems and small, delicate flowers, which aligns with the description of fringed willowherb (Epilobium ciliatum). The plant appears to be growing taller than intended, as it does not seem to be functioning as a ground cover as initially planted.

Given that the plant was originally planted as a ground cover but is now growing taller and not fulfilling its intended role, here are some recommended management strategies:

1. **Mulching**: Apply a layer of mulch around the base of the plant. This can help suppress weeds and reduce competition for nutrients and water. It might also encourage the plant to grow more vigorously in the desired manner.

2. **Pruning**: Consider pruning the plant to control its height. Regularly cutting back the stems can encourage the plant to develop a more bushy growth habit, resembling a ground cover. Be sure to remove any dead or damaged branches to promote healthy growth.

3. **Shade**: If the plant is receiving too much sunlight, consider providing shade or partial shade. Fringed willowherb prefers full sun to part shade, so adjusting the planting location could help.

4. **Watering**: Monitor the watering needs of the plant. Overwatering can lead to taller growth, while under-watering can stunt growth. Adjust watering according to the specific needs of the plant, ensuring it receives adequate moisture without being overwatered.

5. **Fertilization**: Fringed willowherb may benefit from a balanced fertilizer application, particularly if the soil is nutrient-deficient. However, avoid over-fertilizing, as this can encourage taller growth at the expense of spreading.

6. **Weeding**: Keep the area around the plant free of weeds. Weeds compete with the fringed willowherb for resources, so maintaining a clear area around the plant can help it thrive in its intended role.

7. **Transplanting**: If the plant is still growing taller than desired and is becoming an unwanted intruder in other areas of the garden, consider transplanting it to a location where it can be allowed to grow taller and more freely.

By implementing these strategies, you can manage the growth of the fringed willowherb and ensure it functions effectively as a ground cover.

title: Arborvitaes turning orange in areas #578642
question: These Arborvitaes were planted about 3-4 years ago.  I noticed in some spots the needles are turning orange.  They fall off if I touch them.  Is there an issue?

answer.response:

I hope this helps,

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a coniferous tree, likely an Arborvitae, with some areas of the foliage appearing reddish or discolored. This discoloration could be indicative of several potential issues such as nutrient deficiencies, pest infestations, or environmental stressors like drought or excessive moisture.

### Recommended Management Strategies:

1. **Identify the Cause**:
   - **Nutrient Deficiency**: If the discoloration is due to a nutrient deficiency, soil testing can help determine which nutrients are lacking. Adding the appropriate fertilizers (e.g., iron, manganese) can correct the issue.
   - **Pest Infestation**: Look for signs of pests such as aphids, mites, or borers. If pests are present, identify the species and apply suitable pesticides or biological control methods.
   - **Environmental Stress**: Check the plant’s surroundings for signs of stress, such as waterlogged soil or excessive sun exposure. Adjust watering and shading practices accordingly.

2. **Pruning**:
   - Prune off any dead or diseased branches to promote healthy growth and reduce the spread of disease.

3. **Water Management**:
   - Ensure consistent but adequate watering. Overwatering can lead to root rot, while underwatering can cause stress that manifests in discolored foliage.

4. **Fertilization**:
   - Apply a balanced fertilizer designed for conifers to ensure all essential nutrients are available. Follow the manufacturer’s instructions regarding application rates and frequency.

5. **Regular Maintenance**:
   - Regularly inspect the tree for signs of new problems and maintain good sanitation by removing any debris around the base of the tree.

6. **Consultation**:
   - If the issue persists after implementing these steps, it may be beneficial to consult a horticulturist or arborist who can provide more specific advice based on the local climate and conditions.

By addressing the potential causes of the discoloration promptly and systematically, you can help the Arborvitae recover and maintain its health.

title: I believe this is a varia... #616323
question: I believe this is a variant of a ribbon snake... but our small dog got poisoned last year..is this poisonous

1.response:
Thank you for your question.

The snake in the photo is a common garter snake, Thamnophis sirtalis. They are usually found around wet meadows and forest edges, but can occur in a variety of habitats far from water, including open valleys and moist coniferous forest.

Juveniles eat earthworms while adults feed on a variety of vertebrate prey, including frogs, toads, salamanders, fish, reptiles, and small mammals. Invertebrate prey include slugs and leeches.

They are a beneficial snake and are not venomous.

Ribbon snakes,Thamnophis saurita are a completely different species and are a common species of garter snake that is native to Eastern North America. They too are not venomous

title: Pacific madrone #869470
question: Hello! My pacific madrone seems to have some kind of disease, and I’m wondering if there’s anything I can do for it. The leaves have nearly all browned and fallen off the tree. Some are still green, but the tree overall looks quite ill.

answer.response:
wow, that is really hammered.  There are numerous diseases that can affect madrone, but this looks like it may be caused by canker diseases of the stem (canker are caused by fungi that kill the bark).  In the last photo of the tree base, there is dark streaking on the stem, that may be a canker disease.  The branches also seem to be diseased all thru the crown.  

Here is a link to diseases and insects of madrone, it may be helpful:  https://extension.oregonstate.edu/sites/default/files/documents/ec1619.pdf

this particular tree seems really affected, I have not seen anything this bad before, but the canker diseases can girdle the stem and kill everything above the canker.  Also the dead branches appear to be blackened, which indicates a canker.

I don't think there is much you can do.  Madrone are really hard to treat.  Some arborists are experimenting with soil treatments, but it is pretty iffy. If the tree appears to die, you may want to cut it off at the base and see if it stump spouts new shoots.
answer.author: David Shaw

symptom description: leaves have nearly all fallen off the tree
branches seem to be diseased all thru the crown
dead branches appear to be blackened
management instructions: There is not much you can do.
If the tree appears to die, cut it off at the base and see if it stump spouts new shoots.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a Pacific Madrone (Arbutus menziesii) with signs of distress, such as drooping leaves and what appears to be a heavy burden of small flowers or fruits that could be causing the plant stress. Here are some potential management strategies that could help address the health issues observed:

1. **Pruning**: To relieve the plant of excess weight and improve air circulation, it may be necessary to prune off some of the heavy flower clusters and dead branches. This can help reduce the load on the plant and encourage healthier growth.

2. **Watering and Fertilization**: Ensure the plant receives adequate moisture during dry periods and that it is not overwatered. A balanced fertilizer can provide essential nutrients, but it should be applied carefully to avoid over-fertilization which can also harm the plant.

3. **Disease Management**: Inspect the plant for any signs of disease or pests. If fungal diseases are suspected, fungicides might be needed. Regular monitoring and timely treatment can prevent further damage.

4. **Supportive Care**: If the plant appears weakened due to the heavy fruit load, consider providing support or staking to help stabilize the branches if they are leaning or breaking under the weight.

5. **Consultation**: Given the specific location and time of year, consulting with a local horticulturist or arborist would be beneficial. They can provide more tailored advice based on the regional conditions and the specific needs of the Pacific Madrone.

6. **Pollination Management**: In some cases, heavy fruit loads can lead to reduced flowering in the following years. If the current issue is primarily due to overproduction, managing pollination by hand or using pollinators like bees could be considered, though this is generally not a common practice and should only be done under expert guidance.

7. **Environmental Adaptation**: Consider the local climate and environmental conditions. If the area experiences frequent droughts or extreme weather events, ensuring the plant is well-adapted to these conditions might be necessary.

Implementing these strategies requires careful observation and attention to detail. Monitoring the plant's response to these measures will help determine their effectiveness and whether additional actions are needed.

title: Spotted Lanternfly? #838798
question: This little, unafraid, guy located itself upon a weed in my backyard.  It looks as if it might be a spotted lanternfly.  Is it?  If so, it was located on the eastern edge of Pikesville in the Mt. Washington Zip code in the county.

1.response:
Hi Jo C,

Thank you for your question.  Yes, the insect looks like a SLF nymph and you can report it to Maryland Dept of Agriculture if you want, although high rates of SLF infestation in Baltimore County are already known.  You can read more about SLF at this link https://extension.umd.edu/resource/spotted-lanternfly-management-residents#:~:text=are%20urged%20to-,report%20sightings,-of%20Spotted%20Lanternfly.

Interestingly, the bush that the nymph is on appears to be a porcelainberry.  Porcelainberries are invasive and should be removed.  It is a cousin to grapes which is one of the hosts favored by SLF.  If you have any further questions, please do not hesitate to contact us.  Happy gardening.

Bob

title: Aster yellow or mites?  #843829
question:
Last year I submitted a photo of my coneflower and it was thought my coneflower had mites. I cut off all of the flowers. This year it is happening again. I'm unsure which problem I have and what to do about it.
Thanks for any help.

answer.response:
Hi Janet,

The photos you shared this week are classic symptoms of Aster yellows. However, there is a chance the distortion of the flower is caused by a mite. 

What does the rest of the plant look like? Is it otherwise healthy? Do the leaves look strong and green? Aster yellows typically effects the entire plant, weakening it and/or making it look unhealthy, maybe yellow or distorted leaves. Mites typically only attack the flower. 

This website from Missouri Botanical Garden has good information and images. 

More information and photos from Ohio State University. 

Personally, I would remove this plant from my garden. Aster yellows is spread by leafhopper insects and I wouldn't want to take the risk of it spreading to other plants (Aster yellows impacts a shocking number of plants). However, before you pitch the plant, if you would like a definitive diagnosis, you can send in the plant to the MSU Plant and Pest Diagnostics lab. 

Lindsey K. Kerr, MS, MHP (she, her, hers)
Consumer Horticulture Educator
Michigan State University Extension
answer.author: Lindsey Kerr

management instructions: Remove the plant from the garden to prevent the risk of spreading to other plants.

title: Bionic Weed - Wont Die #550801
question:
Good Afternoon,
                               I ve included a pic of a weed that's in one side of my Mulch bed. They multiply very quickly.I've tried to kill them with Ortho,RM43,Gas. anything I can think of but they wont die and keep coming back. Now I just dig them up. NOBODY has been able to rid them. Any help would be appreciated.Thank you

1.response:
This is Canada thistle. It is a non-native invasive plant and it is very difficult to get rid of. Pulling will not dent it. Never till a bed of it, because each tiny piece can generate a new plant. 

Here is our webpage on Canada thistle: http://extension.umd.edu/hgic/canada-thistle Be sure to use the links provided to get information on control options. 

If you dig these plants, you must get every bit of root. If you spray with a systemic herbicide containing the ingredient glyphosate, that can kill the roots, but that product is also a total vegetation killer and you must shield your desirable plants from any contact from the herbicide. Expect to spray more than once. Timing is crucial. Read the link information carefully.

Christa
1.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

management instructions: If you dig these plants, you must get every bit of root.

If you spray with a systemic herbicide containing the ingredient glyphosate, that can kill the roots, but that product is also a total vegetation killer and you must shield your desirable plants from any contact from the herbicide.
Expect to spray more than once.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The plant in the image appears to be Canada thistle (Cirsium arvense), which is known for its rapid multiplication and persistence despite various treatments. Here are some recommended management strategies for controlling Canada thistle:

1. **Physical Removal**: As mentioned in the background information, manual removal is effective. Digging up the roots completely is crucial because Canada thistle can regrow from root fragments left behind. Ensure that all roots are removed to prevent new plants from sprouting.

2. **Cultural Practices**: Regularly mowing the area can help reduce the establishment of new thistles by keeping the ground surface free of debris and reducing the chances of seed germination. Avoid compacting the soil, as this can promote root growth.

3. **Chemical Control**:
   - **Herbicides**: Use selective herbicides specifically targeted at broadleaf weeds like Canada thistle. Products such as 2,4-D, dicamba, or triclopyr can be effective when applied correctly. Always read and follow the label instructions carefully, as these chemicals can be harmful if not used properly.
   - **Pre-emergent Herbicides**: Applying pre-emergent herbicides like atrazine or pendimethalin can prevent seeds from germinating before they reach the soil surface. These should be applied early in the growing season, usually in the fall or spring.

4. **Biological Control**: While less common, biological control using specific insects or pathogens that target Canada thistle can be an option. However, this method is typically more applicable in large-scale agricultural settings and may not be feasible on a smaller scale.

5. **Integrated Pest Management (IPM)**: Combine different methods to manage Canada thistle effectively. This includes a mix of physical, chemical, and possibly cultural controls tailored to the specific environment and conditions.

6. **Monitor and Repeat Treatments**: Canada thistle is persistent, and it may take multiple rounds of treatment over several years to fully eradicate it. Regular monitoring and prompt action to remove any new growth are essential.

By combining these strategies, you can better manage the spread and persistence of Canada thistle in your garden or landscaped area.

title: Septoria leaf spot #592925
question:
Hello I been growing tomatoes for few yrs now. I've came across leaf spot on the leaves .this is a epidemic. I been using potassium bicarbonate (green cure and other fungacides) but  idk what one works the best. I've done research  but still can't land on 1 product ik will kill this fungus.  Pls lmk what u thk ...
Ty and have a wonderful day.

1.response:
Hello,

Septoria can be tricky to deal with. Remember that whenever we use a pesticide to control plant disease, we aren't going to cure the plant, we a just going to slow disease development down. With this in mind, a product with the active ingredient chlorothalonil may help, but it would have to be applied before you start to see symptoms to work well.

If you want to manage things organically, you will be limited to cultural practices.  Remove infected leaves as they appear, and at the end of the season be thorough when removing crop debris. Don't put tomatoes in the same spot in the garden for 2-3 years.  Weed, prune, and stake tomatoes so that there is good airflow, and water when the amount of time leaves will be wet is limited.  All of this will help reduce the amount of septoria (and other tomato diseases) you see in future years.
1.author: The Question Asker

management instructions: Use a product with the active ingredient chlorothalonil before symptoms appear.
Remove infected leaves as they appear.
Remove crop debris thoroughly at the end of the season.
Avoid planting tomatoes in the same spot for 2-3 years.
Weed, prune, and stake tomatoes for good airflow.
Water when the amount of time leaves will be wet is limited.

title: Hop is being eaten.  #408018
question: I can't find any bugs or slugs. Something is eating it up. It's still growing but I don't know for how long.

1.response:
Hi and thanks for contacting Ask an Expert.
Your picture suggests earwigs. You cannot find them because they come out at night, eat and then crawl into small spaces to spend the day. They are out in record numbers from what I hear from other gardeners in the area and in my own garden and containers. They eat most anything.
However, hops have a number of pests and diseases that plague the plant. I have added a link from Washington State University - quite a long book but if you look at page 47 and view the rest of the book you will find the pests with lots of pictures and then the predators (the good guys).  Look carefully at the good guys as larvae, they often will eat twice or more times as much as the adult insect. 
I recommend putting out tuna cans or small cat food cans on the ground near the hops, minus most of the tuna filled with a vegetable oil about 1/4 inch full. Use small amounts of the juice or oil from the tuna with a tiny piece of tuna in the can.  Most any canned seafood works though.  The bugs will crawl in and drown.
Put them out in the evening and if you have pets, pick them up before they go outside in the morning. They love the contents and you will not be able to see what crawled in during the night. Could also be slugs, but I do not see any slime trails. Another possibility is Japanese beetles but I have not heard any mention of them outside Portland. That, of course, does not mean they could not be out there.  If you find earwigs, make sure you put the cans out every night, until you no longer are seeing any bugs in the oil.  If it fills up, dump the batch and make a new one.
If you do decide to use a pesticide, look for bottles that have 'OMRI approved' on them.  These pesticides are usually less toxic, however, the tuna can idea is proven.  I have gathered about 50 earwigs in various areas of the garden in one night. If you have fruit trees they will crawl up and usually eat into the fruit near the stem - when ripe.  
Another preventative measure is to put a cardboard ring around the base of the hops, depending on how many plants you have this may take a lot of time.  I use cardboard, cut about 5 inches wide.  Dig a small trench around the base in the soil and make a connected circle with the cardboard.  Paint the cardboard with petroleum jelly or you can buy a produce called Tanglefoot and put that one.  Wear gloves, Tanglefoot is really sticky.  Put the jelly on thick about one-two inches down from the top on both sides (just in case they are inside the circle).  This will prevent any bugs from crawlng up the stalk to the leaves from outside the ring.  This is a great preventative measure for ants that 'herd' aphids.  Ants protect aphids from predators. 
Since your picture shows a fence, I would check little cracks where one piece of wood may cover another.  Knock the wood to jar the bugs to the ground or use spinosad insecticide to spray them.  This is toxic to all insects but you must actually spray them to kill them.  So you can avoid killing the pollinators.
Please feel free to recontact us if you have further questions.  
http://msue.anr.msu.edu/uploads/234/71503/Hop_Field_Guide_Third_Edition.pdf
1.author: The Question Asker

management instructions: put out tuna cans or small cat food cans with vegetable oil to trap and drown bugs
use OMRI-approved pesticides
create a cardboard ring around the base of the hops with petroleum jelly or Tanglefoot to prevent bugs from crawling up
check for bugs in little cracks in the fence and use spinosad insecticide if necessary

question:
Would you please look at the attached and let me know what is wrong with this plant? I have 2 star jasmine plants with yellow spotted leaves that dry up and then fall off.
Is there anything to be done for it? Your opinion and advice will be greatly appreciated as I have not been able to get an answer for this anywhere.

answer.response:

If in pots, when was the last time they were transplanted?

answer.response:
Thank you for your quick reply.

I have used an all purpose fertilizer. They were planted in 2017 and did OK during the first year.
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Thank you for the images. I have several more questions for you.
- When did you first notice the bright yellow leaves?- What is the sun exposure - north, south or?- How do you keep weeds down other than the bark mulch?- How often do you water?
- What is the watering system? Hand; sprinklers; drip; or?- How long does the water system run; and how often?
answer.author: Jean R. Natter

answer.response:
First noticed yellow leaves with brown spots about a year ago. It has become progressively worse.
Southern exposure
Weeds are hand pulled
Sprinklers are used for watering. 3 Times per week for 10 minutes each time.
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
The brown spots are the most likely insignificant.

The more important is a root problem. I suspect the plants are seriously stressed due to receiving too little water -- that is, the roots are dry. (I also see that the Hebe shrubs look stressed, too; the reason is probably the same.) Both require average moisture whereas their companions -- the festuca grass and viburnum shrubs -- thrive with less.
Each time you irrigate, probe the soil with a trowel. For both the star jasmine and the hebe, the soil should be uniformly moist to 8 to 10 inches. Ten minutes won't accomplish that because the leafy top sheds the water/rain.
I also wonder about the  overhead for the sitting area. Is far enough to the side that it sheds rainfall, too?
Anyway, the bottom line is to verify how how moist the soil is and for how long. You might need to water deeply just once ever 3 weeks during the warm months. But keep that trowel at the ready -- check the soil now and then.

P.S. Your garden and sitting area are lovely, It must be very nice place to sit outdoors on a pleasant evening.
answer.author: Jean R. Natter

answer.response:
Thank you so much. 
I will start watering more and checking soil moisture.

I really appreciate your time and input.
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response: You're welcome. It's my pleasure
answer.author: Jean R. Natter

Check the soil moisture by probing with a trowel to ensure it is uniformly moist to 8-10 inches.
Verify soil moisture after irrigation.

title: Tomato Disease #428899
question:
Is this Late Blight or maybe something different or a combination of diseases? All photos are from one plant, a yellow pear variety. The yellow color and size are consistent with the many healthy tomatoes we have harvested from the same plant this year.
Thank you for helping!

answer.response:
It does appear your plants have late blight. It is caused by a fungus like infection that rapidly spreads and causes decline of the whole plant. It is important to remove all plant and fruit waste dispose of in the garbage. It is unlikely to survive in the soil as it requires spores and ideal weather conditions. Tomatoes are disease prone and take a lot of nutrients from the soil. Because of this it is recommended you rotate the areas you grow them in. As additional precaution you can purchase disease resistant varieties. I placed a link below to an article on late blight. 

http://www.extension.umn.edu/garden/fruit-vegetable/plant-diseases/late-blight-tomato/

answer.response:

title: Beetles that love figs #771580
question: This yr I learned to maximize flavor that figs should not be picked until quite soft.  The downside of this is if a day late, the European hornets are on them, and then a cpl wks ago this beetle has arrived.  Some figs have them completely covering the surface.  They look like bark beetles but since aren't on the bark I assume not.  There are some faint goldish/copperish markings on the rear section that did not show clearly in the pics.  Can you identify and advise if any other damage is likely and if any measures are warranted.  Thanks

1.response:
This appears to be a scarab beetle species called the Dark Flower Scarab (Euphoria sepulcralis), which is a native insect. It is reported to feed on tree sap and a wide variety of flowers and fruits. Its grubs feed on roots and organic detritus in soil.

You could try covering the figs you are waiting to harvest with mesh bags (like small cinchable organza bags used for party favors) to keep the larger insects at bay, though we don't know if wasps or beetles would try to chew through them. Granted, on shrubs with lots of fruits, this would be tedious, plus difficult to do if the wasps have already found them. (Perhaps wait for a rainy day when the insects are less likely to be foraging. Or, next year, try enclosing the entire plant with a netting-covered cage, since you don't need to worry about excluding pollinators with figs.) No sprays are recommended, nor would they likely be very effective. Unfortunately we don't have any other suggestions for how to keep them repelled while not resorting to coating the fruits with something unpalatable or hard to wash off.

 

Miri
1.author: Mira Talabac

2.response:
That appears to be it; thanks.  I've never seen these as I've dug and planted a 4k sq ft mostly ornamental garden during the past 4 yrs, so maybe they were attracted here by the figs and now will stay.  Will their offspring eating sap and roots (by grubs) do consequential damage to the garden?
On Tue, Sep 14, 2021 at 4:23 PM Ask Extension <askextension@eduworks.com> wrote:
2.author: The Question Asker

3.response:
We aren't aware of this beetle species being a pest in the garden, so the grub feeding probably won't be a concern.

Miri
3.author: Mira Talabac

title: There are a lot of these Inside and Outside the House. What are They? #133962
question: This time of year I find these inside and outside the house. It's as if nests hatch and the babies - whatever they are - are everywhere. What are they? Are they harmful or dangerous?

1.response:
The multi-legged creatures you see around your home are millipedes.  These arthropods are harmless and simply stumble into your home through tiny gaps near a ground-level door or window.  They feed on decomposing vegetation and are usually found in mulch around the foundation of a home.  You may want to rake any mulch that is touching the foundation of your home away for several inches. 
The safest way to eliminate them from inside your home is to vacuum them, step on them, or sprinkle diatomaceous earth around sources of moisture in your basement or on the ground level, especially laundry areas, sump pumps, well water tanks, etc.
LS
1.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

title: Backyard Grapevine Disease? #171065
question: Hello! We moved into a house several years ago that has a lovely old grapevine in the backyard. I've been told they're Concord grapes, but I'm not sure. Every spring, the leaves come in lush, and the grapes begin to sprout. But early-mid summer the leaves start to show a lacy deterioration and the grapes shrivel and turn black and dry before ever maturing. I'm attaching a picture of the leaves & can send a picture of the grapes, too, if that's helpful. Is there anything we can do? Thank you so much!

1.response: The tattered leaves are an insect problem. It could be several insects, but that low level of damage does not bring any specific insect to mind. Either way I do not believe that this leaf feeding is important in your situation. You also described the fruit turning black and shriveling up. This sounds like black rot. The best control for you is a fungicide spray at bloom, another 10-14 days later, and a third 10 to 14 days after that. The berries become resistant to the disease about 4 weeks after bloom. Captan is a common homeowner fungicide and you should be able to get it or a mixture of it and an insecticide at a big box store or your local garden store.Here is a link to grape insects and diseases in New Yorkhttp://nysipm.cornell.edu/factsheets/grapes/
1.author: Mark Longstroth

management instructions: Apply a fungicide spray at bloom.
Apply a second fungicide spray 10-14 days after the first.
Apply a third fungicide spray 10-14 days after the second.

title: bean plant problems #809540
question: We have planted a pole bean called Malabou and it is getting eaten by some insect. I can't see anything on the leaves but they are destroying the plant. What is it and how to organically combat it?

answer.response:
Hello there.  Your beans appear to have been eaten by some type of caterpillar.  The large chew marks are pretty definitive.   At this stage I am not sure that treatment is appropriate as I doubt that the plants have the time to recover (or can recover) and produce a crop.  

Bt or Bacillus thuringiensis  variation kurstaki is a naturally occurring bacteria that stops caterpillar feeding almost immediately.  Organic variations of this pesticide are available.  Bt  is quite effective.   In the future monitor your plants more regularly and once such type of predation that your photos show occurs verify the problem is a caterpillar and treat immediately.  Caterpillars start out quite small and rapidly increase in size as they eat.  The bigger the caterpillars the quicker your plants are reduced to sticks. Usually, they are quite easy to spot once they enlarge.  Many are predominantly green in color and when small can be more difficult to see.

If you choose to treat read the instructions on the label and take whatever protective measures are recommended on that label to protect yourself.
answer.author: Debra Lauer

management instructions: use Bt (Bacillus thuringiensis) pesticide
monitor plants regularly for early detection
read and follow label instructions for pesticide use

title: bugs on apple tree  #829655
question: I have one apple tree, a hybrid with four kinds of apples. It's about 10 feet tall. I planted it three years ago. This is the first time I've seen any bugs on it. Photos are included. Most of them appear to be on a top branch, but these were on a lower branch. Also, the apple production seems to be lower this year than in the past. Is my tree in danger? I don't use pesticides in my yard. Please advise!

answer.response:
Hi- we cannot clearly see the insects but assume they are aphids based on the leaf symptoms (curling, cupping, distortion). 


Rosy apple aphids and green apple aphids are two of the more common species that feed on apple foliage.

Wooly apple aphid is less prevalent in home orchards but there has been an uptick as a result of the egg-laying injury to apple shoots caused by the 17-year periodical cicadas in 2021.

Natural enemies (predators and parasitoids) help keep aphid populations in check: 

  • Predatory Insects & Predatory Spiders
  • Parasitoids
Sometimes insecticidal soap or horticultural oil sprays are warranted.

It is difficult to grow apples organically because they are vulnerable to numerous insect pests and diseases.

You may have fewer apples this year for many different reasons, including temperature extremes, freezing weather when flowers were open, and poor pollination. 

Apple information:
  • Growing Apple Trees in a Home Garden
  • Tree Fruit Purchasing and Planting
  • Watering, Fertilizing, Harvesting, Spray Schedule Apples
  • Training and Pruning Apple and Pear Trees
  • Apple and Pear Diseases
  • Apple and Pear Insect Pests
  • Apple Problems not caused by Diseases or Insects
Jon
answer.author: Jon Traunfeld

answer.response:
Hi, Jon. Thanks for the information. I'm pretty sure my tree has rosy apple aphids. I can see a clump of curled leaves on a branch at the top of the tree. From what I found in one place lower down (the leaves I pulled off to photograph) I'm sure that clump is full of aphids. If I cut off the affected part, will that help? And if I do nothing, will the aphids eventually kill my little tree?

On Fri, May 12, 2023 at 4:03 PM Ask Extension <ask@extension.org> wrote:
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Hi- it's fine to cut and remove leaves heavily infested with aphids. Check every few days for signs of predatory insects feeding on the aphids and signs of parasitism- aphids that are distended, tan-brown in color, and not moving. You may see holes in these aphid mummies where ting wasps have emerged after feeding internally as larvae inside the aphids. It is unlikely that the aphid feeding will weaken your tree. 
https://extension.umd.edu/resource/aphids-trees-and-shrubs
Jon

title: Unknown weed taking over landscaped areas of property #637860
question: I recently purchased a new home in Carroll County. The previous owners had much of the front of the property landscaped. Over the last few weeks I have noticed an explosion of growth of what appears to be some kind of weed in many of the landscaped areas. It seems to grow in a mat under low-lying landscaping, but is also poking up through some flowering bushes along the front porch. The most distinctive feature that I have identified is that it seems to have well defined joints and segments. When I have tried manually pulling the weeds out, they like to separate easily at the joints without much pulling effort and I never seem to be able to find where they originate in order to pull out the roots. They also seem to have some small flowering buds on the segments and the leaves appear in sets of 2, usually at the joints in the segments. The leaves are small and oval-ish in shape, but do come to a slight point. I have included some pictures with the hope that someone can help me identify this plant and provide some tips on how to remove it and keep it from coming back. I can try to provide more detailed pictures if need be. I will admit, that the landscaped beds are probably due for a re-mulching soon so maybe that will help overall, but any other suggestions in the meantime would be welcome.

answer.response:
This looks like chickweed (Stellaria sp.). It is an annual plant that thrives in cool weather and is most often found in moist shady areas (but can move into other areas as well). Chickweed is native to Europe and Asia and is common now in most areas of Maryland. 

In ornamental beds, you can handpull now.  It is dying back or has already set seed.  Seed can remain viable for about 10 years.  Mulch can help to keep seed down but it may blow in from other areas, get spread by animals, etc. Make sure it is no thicker than several inches away from the base of stems.
No chemical control is recommended. You can also apply a preemergent in the fall to prevent germination. Look for the active ingredient trifluralin, as in Preen and other products. Follow label directions.

In lawns the most natural solution to getting rid of it would be to hand-pull or dig it out before seed dispersal. Seed can remain viable for about 10 years. It is getting ready to dieback and set seed. No post emergent weedkillers are recommended now as it dying on its own. If possible to prevent seed dispersal, perhaps you can bag your clippings when you mow this time.
A preemergent applied in late summer/early fall can help prevent chickweed from germinating, however, you will not be able to sow grass seed.
You will find more information on our website. https://extension.umd.edu/hgic/topics/common-chickweed

Here are tips  for weed management https://extension.umd.edu/hgic/topics/tips-lawn-weed-prevention-and-management

Marian

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The plant in the image appears to be chickweed, which is a common weed that can proliferate quickly in disturbed soil or areas with rich organic matter, such as those that might have been affected by recent landscaping activities.

### Recommended Management Strategy:

1. **Physical Removal**:
   - **Manual Weeding**: Regularly pull out chickweed by hand, ensuring you remove the entire root system to prevent regrowth. This method is effective but requires ongoing effort.
   - **Gloves**: Consider wearing gloves to protect your hands from the irritating sap.

2. **Mulching**:
   - **Re-mulch**: As mentioned in the background information, it's likely that the landscaped beds need a fresh layer of mulch. Mulch helps suppress weed growth by reducing sunlight exposure and competition for nutrients and water.
   - **Organic Mulches**: Use materials like wood chips, shredded leaves, or straw, which can help break down and improve the soil over time.

3. **Chemical Control**:
   - **Pre-emergent Herbicides**: Apply pre-emergent herbicides if you prefer not to physically remove weeds. These chemicals interfere with the development of new weeds, preventing them from growing.
   - **Post-emergent Herbicides**: If chickweed has already germinated, post-emergent herbicides can be used. However, be cautious with herbicides around plants and consider their effectiveness on other desirable plants.
   - **Read Labels Carefully**: Always follow the manufacturer’s instructions on rates, application times, and safety measures when using any herbicide.

4. **Cultural Practices**:
   - **Watering Practices**: Water deeply but infrequently to encourage deep-rooted plants that are less susceptible to weed invasion.
   - **Soil Health**: Maintain healthy soil through regular testing and application of necessary nutrients and amendments. Healthy soil can better compete with weeds for resources.
   - **Regular Maintenance**: Keep the landscape beds well-maintained to reduce opportunities for weeds to establish.

5. **Biological Control**:
   - **Beneficial Insects**: Introduce beneficial insects like ladybugs, lacewings, and nematodes, which can help control the population of chickweed naturally.

By combining these methods, you can effectively manage the chickweed proliferation in your landscaped areas and maintain a more desirable aesthetic. Regular monitoring and maintenance will be key to keeping your newly landscaped property looking its best.
