title: Creepy Vine #773234
question:
Wondering what this fast spreading and fast growing vine is.
And, how to get rid of it!

answer.response:
Good Afternoon,

Information taken from below articles.

It looks like wild buckwheat.  Wild buckwheat can be controlled somewhat preemergence with Westar, Goal and Sureguard. It can be controlled post-emergence with glyphosate (Roundup) and Garlon. For glyphosate, use the original formula (4 lb/gallon of the IPA salt). It may take two applications to obtain control. Goal also has good post-emergence activity against wild buckwheat. 2,4-D (Turret) and clopyralid (Stinger, Lontrel) also have activity against emerged wild buckwheat.

http://nyis.info/invasive_species/mile-a-minute/

https://www.canr.msu.edu/resources/wild-buckwheat-fallopia-convolvulus

I hope this helps.  Thanks for using our service.

title: Hydrangea problem #641733
question: My well-established hydrangeas have developed drooping branches starting at the base of the plants. Now spots are appearing on the loves. What do you recommend?

answer.response:
This is likely a disease called anthracnose. Anthracnose pathogens have a broad host range, which includes a wide variety of commonly grown woody shrubs and trees. The fungus Colletotrichum can attack both leaves and blooms in the lower and upper part of bigleaf hydrangea plant canopy. Development of this disease is favorable in wet weather conditions. Heavily fertilized hydrangea may become more susceptible to anthracnose disease. First symptoms of this disease are the circular or slightly irregular brown spots forming on the leaves. The center of these brown spots turns to tan in color. Sometimes larger spots appear on border mid vein or other major veins in the leaf and they become clearly more angular in shape. When anthracnose developed under favorable environmental conditions, large, dark brown, irregular spots can spread across the whole leaves and flower petals. Several continuous days of wet conditions can produce masses of spores, which can be embedded in hydrangea leaf debris. Spores may spread by splashing water to the leaves and bloom clusters. Repeated showers, dew, and lengthened periods of heavy fog can speed up the rate of infection and the appearance of symptoms. The main source of anthracnose inoculum is the infected hydrangea. The following options are available for managing anthracnose on hydrangea such as taking cuttings from healthy plants; collecting fallen diseased leaves and removing blighted blooms from landscape plantings. Proper fungicide treatments can also protect susceptible hydrangea from anthracnose.

Here are some publications to check out:

https://www.uaex.edu/publications/pdf/FSA-7570.pdf

https://extension.oregonstate.edu/gardening/flowers-shrubs-trees/general-care-hydrangeas

Hope this helps!
answer.author: chris Rusch

management instructions: take cuttings from healthy plants
collect fallen diseased leaves
remove blighted blooms from landscape plantings
apply proper fungicide treatments

title: DOGWOOD TREE #275850
question: Why does my dogwood tree have all the bark rot on both the N & S side & appears to by dying & not growing at all?  Don't have a clue how old it is, but I've been watching it for 12 years.  I love it & would like to know what to do to save it's life.

answer.response: Dogwood trees in full sun like this one are under constant stress.  They usually lose bark because of freezing and thawing action in winter when exposed to full sun and also hitting with mowers and weed trimmers when young.  Both of these increase borer damage into the trunk leading to further bark loss.  There is really not much to do for a tree in this condition.  Killing grass and weeds for several feet around the tree and mulching about 2-3 inches deep is helpful.  Spraying with permethrin in May each year (lower trunk only) to prevent further borer damage may help.  Water when under drought stress is always a good idea in the heat of the summer.  Do not fertilze very much (3 pound 10-10-10 each May is enough).
answer.author: Tony Glover

symptom description: bark rot on both the N & S side
management instructions: Kill grass and weeds for several feet around the tree and mulch about 2-3 inches deep.
Spray with permethrin in May each year (lower trunk only) to prevent further borer damage.
Water when under drought stress.
Do not fertilize very much (3 pound 10-10-10 each May is enough).

title: Dead and dying oak trees in hills near Jefferson OR #847521
question: Our neighborhood is concerned about large patches of oak trees in our oak savanna woods that appear to have died this summer

1.response:
Hello,

We are seeing several things affecting Oregon white oak, but no widespread mortality.  Can you send pictures?  A picture of the site/setting, and a picture of one or two specific trees?

Also, can you check to see if you see white sawdust in the bark crevices?  Perhaps also include a picture of the tree trunk?
1.author: David Shaw

2.response:
Trees seem to be dying in groups or horizontal bands along the hills.  Happened very suddenly.

On Tue, Aug 29, 2023, 11:14 AM Ask Extension <ask@extension.org> wrote:
2.author: The Question Asker

3.response:
Wow.  I believe this is early fall leaf drop due to the intense summer drought we have had this year.  The higher temperatures we've had this summer have added to the dryness.

I don't think these trees are dying. I think they are just dropping their leaves early.  I've seen this before, but definitely not this amount.    But note how the trees are all located in one vertical band along the hillside.  This may be a where there are particularly dry soils.

The key way to decide if the trees are dying is to take a sharp knife and cut into the bark of the twiglets and see if the stem is still alive.  Also, cutting into the apical buds will also tell you if they are alive.  If the twigs and buds are alive, I believe these trees will make it.

Also, waiting until next spring is the true test of this theory.  If the trees green up next spring, we'll know it was early fall (summer) leaf drop.

Oregon ash is doing this same thing in the Willamette Valley just now.  Many trees have their leaves turning and brown.  But we've checked and the trees are still alive.  Poison oak is turning red already and dropping it's leaves too.
3.author: David Shaw

4.response:
Thank you so much!
Susan

On Wed, Aug 30, 2023, 9:13 AM Ask Extension <ask@extension.org> wrote:
4.author: The Question Asker

question:

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a patch of plants with small, green leaves that appear to be spreading through the grass and other vegetation. Given the context provided, these plants are likely the species *Campanula*, which can be invasive and difficult to manage if left unchecked. Here’s a recommended management strategy for controlling the spread of *Campanula*:

1. **Mechanical Removal**: Manually dig out the plants, being thorough to remove as much of the root system as possible. This should be done regularly, especially during the spring when the plants are actively growing.

2. **Chemical Control**: Use selective herbicides such as glyphosate or 2,4-D to target the *Campanula* without harming the surrounding grass. Be sure to follow the label instructions carefully, as applying the wrong concentration could damage the plants you want to keep.

3. **Cultural Practices**: Regular mowing can help prevent the spread of *Campanula* by keeping it from producing seeds. Also, ensure good soil health and water management practices to maintain a competitive environment for desired grasses over the invasive plants.

4. **Biological Control**: In some cases, biological control agents (e.g., insects or fungi) specific to the *Campanula* can be introduced, but this method requires careful study and approval from local authorities due to potential ecological impacts.

5. **Regular Monitoring**: Continuously monitor the area for signs of *Campanula* re-establishment or new growth and treat promptly. Invasive species can become established quickly, so regular checks are essential.

6. **Preventative Measures**: If the *Campanula* has already spread extensively, consider creating physical barriers like mulch or landscape fabric to prevent further spread until the plants can be removed completely.

By combining these strategies, you can effectively manage the spread of *Campanula* in your Ramsey County, Minnesota lawn and garden.

title: Money Tree Sap #446972
question: I've had a money tree (Pachira aquatica) for about three years and it's growing nicely. It gets plenty of light and I water consistently (once a week). However, it has developed small, clear, sticky, gelatinous droplets on the stems and leaves. I've done some research and came across pearl glands on similar plants, but have been hesitant to diagnose it. Are these pearl glands? If so, are they unhealthy for the plant? What should I do about them?

1.response:
We do not find any information about pearl glands on money plant.  It's more likely that these are drops of excess water that the plant is excreting.  This is a plant coping process known as guttation.

 It may mean that you are overwatering.  Although money plant likes moist soil, it is possible to overwater it.  Let the top inch or so of soil dry out between watering.  Keep in mind that plants do not grow as actively in the winter--if at all-- and thus do not need as much water.  Watering should be adjusted accordingly. 

ECN
1.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

management instructions: Let the top inch or so of soil dry out between watering.
Adjust watering according to the season, as plants do not grow as actively in the winter and thus do not need as much water.

title: Tomato spots #719125
question: Some of my tomatoes have yellow spots in them. It can be seen in the tomato wall under the skin. Also some of my tomatoes have what I think is blossom end rot. Could you help identify the disease and suggest a remedy?

answer.response:
So you do have two different things going on. The yellow spots are from Tomato Spotted wilt virus. There is no cure other than culturally rotating your plants and pulling out infected plants. Viruses can stay in the soils up to 4 years. So a four year rotation of different types of vegetables should be done( lettuce, onions, peas, beets, etc.)  You can also purchase virus resistant tomato varieties. If growing in pots, bleach the pots and put in new soil for next year. https://extension.colostate.edu/topic-areas/yard-garden/recognizing-tomato-problems-2-949/
On the tomato blossom end rot, this is from too much water or inconsistent watering. Some try to cure with calcium, but there is enough calcium in the soil already.  When watering is off, the plant cannot absorb calcium and other nutrients.  Tomatoes prefer deep infrequent consistent watering, kinda picky that way.  If plants wilt at night, its a heat thing, ignore them.  If wilted in the morning, and not a virus, water them.  https://planttalk.colostate.edu/topics/vegetables/1817-tomatoes-home-gardens/
You can eat either if the taste is ok, will not harm you.
answer.author: Susan Carter

answer.response: Thank you so much.  I've had the blossom end rot occur in a garden at another location and treated the soil with a little bit of calcium. So I wanted to be sure I did the right thing. Next year I will be using calcium. The virus is new but I planted a different variety of tomato plant this year. I'll go back to the previous variety of tomato next year. Regards.
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
I was saying NOT to use the calcium. This is a water issue. There is tons of calcium in our soils, in fact typically too much.  Blossom end rot is caused by an imbalance of water in the soil.
https://cmg.extension.colostate.edu/Gardennotes/717.pdf
answer.author: Susan Carter

qa_information.disease/issue identification: Tomato Spotted wilt virus and blossom end rot
symptom description: yellow spots in the tomato wall under the skin
management instructions: For Tomato Spotted wilt virus: rotate plants, pull out infected plants, and consider purchasing virus resistant tomato varieties.
For blossom end rot: water deeply and infrequently, and ensure consistent watering.

title: Rhododendron Die Off #244201
question: I have a wall of rhododendrons as understory bushes (under Oak Trees, on the edge of a woodland), that are dying off. When we had drought conditions for several years (five years ago), the tops of the rhododendrons started to die off. I've trimmed dead sections, but they still are slowly dying off. Now it appears I might lose several of these 15 ft tall bushes. I'm guessing these are probably 30 years old. A large part of the main trunk, near the base has split in several areas. See the photos of the splits/spotted leaves that are curling and dropping off. I'm guessing the cold wet winter finally killed the oldest one because the rain got into the split trunk, froze, expanded and killed the bush? Please, tell me what the spotted leaves mean. Is it a disease, or a condition I can correct? I do rake away the dead leaves and replace with seasoned bark mulch. I also fertilize lightly with miracle gro maybe twice a season. Cannot water, other than with 5 gallon buckets occasionally (too far from water source).

answer.response:
This looks like winter damage. http://extension.umd.edu/hgic/winter-damage-trees-and-shrubs

The photo with the rolled leaves is evidence of a canker or borers.  Affected portions should be cut out.  There is no curative spray.  Just keep sick portions cut out.   Rhododendrons can come back from the ground even if all of the plant is cut back to the ground.  Continue to remove dead leaves from the site.  Wipe clipper blades with alcohol between cuts.  Continue to water during drought when you can.  vw

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows rhododendron branches with some signs of damage or discoloration, possibly due to stress from previous drought conditions. Given the background information provided, here's a recommended management strategy:

1. **Monitor for Pest and Disease:** Check the affected areas for signs of pests like leaf miners or scale insects, which can be common in rhododendrons after droughts. If infestation is severe, consider using organic pesticides such as neem oil or insecticidal soap.

2. **Watering:** Ensure that the rhododendrons receive adequate moisture, especially during dry periods. Mulching around the base of the plants can help retain soil moisture. Consider installing a drip irrigation system if the area experiences prolonged dry spells.

3. **Fertilization:** Continue to fertilize lightly with a balanced, slow-release fertilizer suitable for acid-loving plants. Avoid over-fertilizing as this can lead to nutrient imbalances and root issues.

4. **Pruning:** Remove any dead or damaged branches to promote healthy growth. This will also help prevent the spread of diseases. Prune back to healthy wood, ensuring that you do not remove more than one-third of the plant at any time.

5. **Supportive Care:** Keep an eye on the rhododendrons for any further signs of stress or disease. Regularly check for signs of recovery, and adjust your care practices accordingly.

6. **Seasonal Maintenance:** Continue the seasonal practice of trimming dead sections, raking away dead leaves, and applying seasoned bark mulch as these steps can help reduce the risk of disease and improve overall plant health.

By following these steps, you should be able to support the recovery and ongoing health of your rhododendrons. If the problem persists, it may be beneficial to consult with a local horticulturist or gardening professional who can provide more specific advice based on the local climate and soil conditions.

title: Yellow patches (fungus or mold?) in grass #145879
question:
We found some spots in our yard where the grass looked blackened - the best way I can describe it is that it looked like someone had cleaned up dog poo from the yard, and it had left a mark. After that we found a few areas with slimy yellow splotches--at this point we thought an animal had vomited in our yard. The next morning we woke up to 4-5 large yellow patches that started slimy looking and throughout the day have browned a bit and now have almost a cauliflower texture. We assume the blackened spots we first found were areas where this had already occurred then burned away.  The affected areas are in distinctly different areas, although now that I think about it they are all on the parking strips (front and side) and seem to be near trees (that may or may not mean much, as we have trees lining our parking strip, however they do seem to be close to the trees--in fact one of the patches is on the woodchips surrounding a tree). I am surprised at how quickly this has appeared, as the patches are quite large (6-12 inch diameters)
The attached photos include: one of the blackened spots, then 2 pictures of the same yellow patch, one taken in the morning, the next in the afternoon (the more brownish one was the afternoon shot, they appear below in reverse order)

answer.response: What an interesting question!  It appears to me to be a fungus, but I have never seen one quite like it, so I will pass your question along to one of our pathologists.  Regardless of which fungus it is, what you are probably seeing is the fruiting body of a fungus that has been feeding on wood or other organic matter under the soil.  When conditions are right, the fungus will develop fruiting bodies very quickly that will then produce spores.  There really isn't much you can do except remove them.  They should not have any long term effect on your turf.
answer.author: Larry Rupp

answer.response: It looks like a slime mold. That is a fungus that is not a pathogen. The fungus is always in the soil and once or twice a year it forms these structure to reproduce. In a few weeks it will just disappear. The fungus can cover grass, mulch etc. The common name for one of the species is actually dog vomit fungus due to the way it looks. It is only a cosmetic problem and will not harm the grass or any other plants.
answer.author: Claudia Nischwitz

title: Why are these plants turning brown? #833410
question: I work in Iosco County and was asked why the plants that they planted in front of the building are turning brown and look like they are dying. They are watered daily. The location is sunny.  I did notice an orange insect in one of the photos as I uploaded it.

answer.response:
With out any additional information (when you planted them, frost, soil nutrition, fertilizer) and only looking at the photos you provided it appears that you may have several issues with the sweet potato vines.  
Possible causes of decline would be the late frost we had a week or 2 ago.  Sweet potato vines are not frost tolerant.  I suspect the larger brown patches on the leaves are frost damage.  Trim off damaged leaves.  The insect in the photo is a red spider mite.  The small dots were more than likely caused by spider mites feeding the leaves.  If the plants are not heavily infested, try spraying the leaves off to remove the mites.  Also check and spray the undersides of the leaves.  Did you fertilize the plants when you planted them? Adding a slow release granular fertilized is recommend at the time of planting (follow recommended manufacture guidelines), followed by a liquid fertilizer very 2 to 3 weeks after that. 

Thank you using Ask Extension.

Pam
MSUE Master Gardener
answer.author: Pam Voss

qa_information.disease/issue identification: frost damage, red spider mite infestation
symptom description: larger brown patches on the leaves
management instructions: Trim off damaged leaves.
Spray the leaves off to remove the mites.
Check and spray the undersides of the leaves.
Add a slow release granular fertilizer at the time of planting.
Use a liquid fertilizer every 2 to 3 weeks after planting.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows sweet potato vines with leaves that appear to be wilting, turning yellow, and some with brown spots or necrosis, particularly around the edges. This condition could be indicative of several issues such as nutrient deficiency, water stress, overwatering, disease, or pests. Given the background information that the plants are watered daily in a sunny location, it's important to rule out overwatering as a primary cause.

Here’s a recommended management strategy:

1. **Assess Watering**: Check if the soil is consistently moist but not overly wet. Overwatering can lead to root rot and wilting. Ensure the plants have proper drainage and consider adjusting watering frequency if necessary.

2. **Soil Inspection**: Gently dig into the soil near the base of the plant to check for root health. Healthy roots should be firm and white or light tan. Root rot might be indicated by soft, slimy roots or discoloration.

3. **Nutrient Analysis**: Test the soil to determine if there is a nutrient deficiency. Sweet potato vines require consistent levels of nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium. Applying a balanced fertilizer tailored to their needs may help.

4. **Pest Control**: Inspect the plants for any signs of pests. Look for aphids, spider mites, or other insects that can cause leaf damage. If pests are present, treat them with an appropriate insecticide.

5. **Leaf Diseases**: If leaf diseases are suspected, collect a sample of affected leaves and take them to a local extension office or garden center for diagnosis. Based on the results, apply the appropriate fungicide or other treatments.

6. **Sunlight and Airflow**: Ensure the plants are receiving adequate sunlight and good airflow. Poor air circulation can contribute to disease development. Prune dead or infected leaves to improve air circulation.

7. **Rotation and Maintenance**: Avoid planting sweet potato vines in the same spot year after year to reduce the risk of soil-borne pathogens. Maintain healthy soil practices and avoid overcrowding plants to ensure they have enough space to grow and thrive.

By addressing these factors, you can help manage the current issue and promote healthier growth of your sweet potato vines.

title: weed ID and control #823941
question: This tiny leafed weed is taking over my veg garden and creeping into the lawn. Smothering with mulch and trying to scrape it up has not worked. Wat is it and how to control/eliminate it please

1.response:
We think that you are dealing with a type of weed called Pennywort, in this case, Marsh Pennywort. 
Here is our page on it: 
https://extension.umd.edu/resource/marsh-pennywort

It is actually a native plant that grows in aquatic environments in Maryland. 
We would assume your landscape tends to be wet in that area? Does the soil dry out and get enough light (most vegetables need full sun) and air to grow your vegetables there?

It can be a difficult weed to control. Just scraping or pulling will likely just break off and leave roots. You could try digging and sifting out all of the plant parts that you can, but only try that when the soil has dried since digging in wet soil is never recommended as it can damage the soil structure.

They grow from a type of root system called a rhizome, which can send out 'stems' horizontally which makes smothering difficult.
We don't know if it will work, but if you try smothering again, do it for a long time.

Christine






https://extension.umd.edu/resource/pond-pest-management
1.author: Christine McComas

management instructions: digging and sifting out all of the plant parts
try smothering again, do it for a long time

title: Maple not fully leafing out #571248
question:
Our maple tree is only leafing out on the lower branches (see attached photo). What is causing this and how can I remediate it?

Thank you!

1.response:
The late season freeze-hail-freeze has caused trees to struggle. As trees leaf out in the spring, late freezes can severely damage or kill buds and new leaves. This will cause a tree to use stored energy to re-leaf so this can result in a slower second try, or fewer/sparser leaves.

It's a good sign the branches are flexible and not brittle. You can also take a sharp knife or use a fingernail to gently scrape a small piece of bark off of several small twigs. If the exposed twig is green, the branch is still alive. It appears in the photo that the tree has many buds on it, some quite large perhaps nearing leaf out. Take a close look at the buds to see if they are green (alive) or black (dead).

Take a wait-and-see approach for the tree. Make sure the tree receives adequate moisture and look for growth.

https://extension.colostate.edu/topic-areas/yard-garden/environmental-disorders-of-woody-plants-2-932/
1.author: Mari Johnson

symptom description: only leafing out on the lower branches
management instructions: Take a wait-and-see approach for the tree.
Make sure the tree receives adequate moisture.
Look for growth.

title: sap on silverberry tree #713936
question: I have some silverberry trees what were planted last fall and I just noticed that there is sap (I guess) coming off the trunks on some of the trees.  I have 6 trees.  I also notice that on some limbs, the leaves are turning red and I have noticed some japanese beetles too on the tree, but they seem to go for my flowers.  That's another issue!  The beetles are terrible.  But do you know what is going on with the trees?  do I need to treat them with something?  Also, the japanese beetles are destroying some of my flowers, do you have any recommendations for treatment? I've attached a couple photos of the silverberry trees.

answer.response:
The leaves in your photo look like Serviceberry (Amelanchier spp.), not Silverberry (Eleagnus commutata), which has has a distinct silvery leaf surface. I'm going to assume that those leaves aren't from the plant in question.

Silverberry is susceptible to stem cankers https://www.ag.ndsu.edu/trees/handbook/th-3-5.pdf the remedy for which is pruning out the canker and improved cultural care. If the canker is in the main trunk, that obviously is not an option https://planttalk.colostate.edu/topics/insects-diseases/1407-canker-diseases-deciduous-trees/

The fact that you've noticed leaves turning red is indication that the plants are stressed which is not surprising given this is their first season and conditions are record-breaking heat and drought; most trees in Denver are struggling. Stress will make your Silverberry more susceptible to pests and disease so my recommendation is check moisture levels at the roots using a screwdriver and adjust your irrigation practices if the soil is dry.  Even the most xeric plants need moisture until established.
answer.author: Denver Master Gardeners

answer.response: I'm sorry, I didn't check my spelling and you are correct.  I have 6 Serviceberry trees!  Would over watering also contribute to canker?  They are on a drip system, 4 days a week at 40 minutes.  I will read your attachments and follow the advice.  thank you for responding!
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Overwatering can be a stress particularly in clay soils with poor drainage. However, without knowing the size and numbers of your drip emitters, I can't say whether your 4 days/week x 40 minutes is too much, too little, or just right, although the fact that you are reporting "early fall" leaf coloring and stem cankers suggests that it's definitely worth investigating. These articles from CSU Extension about on setting up a drip system and the care of recently planted trees may help:

https://extension.colostate.edu/topic-areas/yard-garden/drip-irrigation-home-gardens-4-702/

https://cmg.extension.colostate.edu/Gardennotes/635.pdf
answer.author: Denver Master Gardeners

management instructions: prune out the canker
improve cultural care
check moisture levels at the roots and adjust irrigation practices if the soil is dry

The image shows a young serviceberry tree with signs of stress or potential disease. The bark appears to have discoloration, which could be indicative of various issues such as sunburn, mechanical damage, or fungal infections. Given the context that the trees were planted recently and are experiencing extreme heat and drought conditions, it's important to address these issues promptly.

Here are some recommended management strategies:

1. **Watering**: Since the trees are on a drip irrigation system, ensure that they receive adequate water. Despite being on a schedule, check the soil moisture regularly to see if additional watering is needed. The frequency and duration of the drip system might need adjustment based on local conditions and soil type.

2. **Mulching**: Apply a layer of organic mulch around the base of the tree to help retain moisture and moderate soil temperature. Ensure the mulch does not touch the trunk to prevent potential rot.

3. **Pruning**: Remove any dead or damaged branches to promote healthy growth and reduce the risk of infection. This can help the tree focus its energy on remaining healthy parts.

4. **Fertilization**: Consider fertilizing the tree with a balanced, slow-release fertilizer suitable for young trees. This will provide necessary nutrients to support growth during stressful conditions.

5. **Sun Protection**: If the tree is suffering from sunburn, consider using a temporary shade cloth or painting the trunk with white latex paint to reflect sunlight and reduce the risk of further damage.

6. **Monitor for Diseases**: Keep an eye out for signs of disease, such as additional discoloration, deformities, or the presence of pests. Early detection and treatment can prevent the spread of diseases.

7. **Consult a Professional**: If the issue persists or worsens, consult with a local arborist or horticulturist who can provide more specific advice tailored to the local conditions and species.

By implementing these strategies, you can help the serviceberry tree recover from the stress of heat and drought while promoting healthy growth.

title: Sick rhododendron  #455408
question: My “Ken Janeck” rhododendron is in bad shape. It’s 15 years old, brown curled leaves, no blossoms this spring. You can see rabbits chewed some top leaves, above the chicken wire. I don’t pay attention to it because it was fine. Can I cut off the worst stems,would feeding help, is it a goner?

answer.response:
Thank you for contacting AaE for help.

The brown leaves may be due to winter injury. Rhododendrons have shallow roots and if they are not sufficiently watered before the ground freezes or if the winter lasts too long, their green leaves which continue to photosynthesize and transpire throughout the winter can dry out. The brown leaves appear to be at the top of the plant and the leaves there were probably exposed to the sunlight above the snow.

Rabbits will chew on Rhododendrons.  I'd clean up the plant by cutting out the dead stems and leaves.

Next fall make sure the plant gets an inch of water each week until the ground freezes. Surround it with wire fencing for the winter to keep the bunnies away.
For further reading you might check out Common Problems of Rhododendrons and Azaleas put out by the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station.

Good-luck!
answer.author: Ellen Campbell

management instructions: Cut out the dead stems and leaves.
Water the plant with an inch of water each week until the ground freezes.
Surround the plant with wire fencing for the winter to keep rabbits away.

title: Resin type growth on Calamodin/Philippine Lime tree #621572
question:
Hello.  I was wondering what I should do about a growth on my Calamodin/ Calamansi/ Philippine Lime (citrus x microcarpa). There are 4 of these growths.  The growth feels like resin.  It is solid.  The tree is 7 years old (if it matters).  Should I be concerned about it?

Please attached photos.  

Thank you,
Joyce Jadik

answer.response:
Hello Joyce,

This appears to be sap flow (and hardening) from physical damage to the stems. You can gently remove it and see if it returns. We do not see any signs of pests or disease on the photos. Wood-boring insects and infections of the vascular tissue (sapwood, just under the bark) can cause sap oozing on other outdoor trees, but it would be highly unlikely in an enclosed indoor environment such as the room they are pictured in.

Miri
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

answer.response: Thank you very much for your response.  We currently have all the windows in the room open for pollinators to come to the flowers of the citrus trees.  If the calamnsi/calamodin tree has wood-boring insects should we spray neem oil on it?  What do you suggest?  Soap and water?  Should we also do a preventive spray/ treatment on the lemon and orange trees?  We are raising the trees organic.  Thank you so much for your patience.
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
They likely do not have wood-boring insects, and we would not suggest spraying unless a positive insect ID was made first, especially to protect the pollinators. This sap flow is likely from mechanical damage of some sort and can just be gently removed if desired. When temperatures moderate in another month, the trees would benefit from growing outside for the summer to have access to higher light and humidity. (Acclimate them gradually.)

Miri
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

title: Rare or Extinct bug #590165
question: I found a bug thats has butterfly wings grasshopper body and moth face. I've looked it up through photo on Google and it came back as so many different things. I searched so long and finally found the same thing and its posted on this site but y'all wrote it off as just a grasshopper which it isn't. It's a little discombobulated but it shouldbe fine. I will send you my personal location if you would like a professional to come out and see it in person.

answer.response:
Sorry to say, but I am afraid that there is nothing special about the grasshopper that you have found. It is the very common Carolina locust (Dissosteira carolina). It is interesting as how well it is camouflaged at least until it flies. They are frequently found on country roads where they blend in with the dust, dirt and gravel until they fly and they expose their hind pair of wings which are black and edged in yellow. Here are a couple of links to additional information: https://bugguide.net/node/view/172151

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dissosteira_carolina

question: In addition to a cloud of whiteflies on my kale there were other different insects. Are they eating the kale or maybe the whiteflies?

1.response:
These appear to be Harlequin Bugs and they can be a common pest of kale, feeding on plant juices by sucking-up sap through the leaves. As noted in the linked page, exclusion from the crop is the simplest and most effective approach to managing them, where row cover is used to block access so plants are shielded immediately after planting. For now, just pluck off and squish those you can catch (or drop them into a pan of soapy water to drown) and remove all plant debris once you're done harvesting the plants (even if that's in spring) so it doesn't harbor pests or disease spores for the next planting.

Miri

title: Autumn Blaze Maple #601256
question:
jpg One shows a "fissure" or open area on the bark of my Autumn Blaze maple tree trunk. Might have been there for years.
jpg Two shows the same view but on the left is a new long opening in the bark where the occasional tiny ant crawled.

This is a large gorgeous tree as seen in 3rd jpg.

Is either of these something that needs treatment?

answer.response:
Maples are thin-barked trees, making them susceptible to frost crack. Was this tree wrapped the first several years during the winter? This may be the reason for the crack you noted may have been there several years. It is highly recommended that young (the first 4 years), thin-barked trees be wrapped November to April which helps insulate the bark from temperature fluctuations. Warm temperatures during the winter will bring the tree trunk out of dormancy, only to have temperatures drop resulting in the freezing of cells and tissue causing severe cracks.  


 

As far as recent cracks on a more mature tree, there is no single reason for bark splitting on trees. This crack may have started from a wound inflicted earlier in the tree's development. Sometimes a crack may remain in the internal wood, but growth or other factors can cause the crack to expand and split the bark. Fluctuating growth conditions also cause splitting of bark. Hot, dry weather (which slows growth) followed by wet or ideal growth conditions (such as cool and rainy June) may cause a growth spurt leading to splits in the bark.


 

Little can be done to help the tree deal with this type of injury. A healthy tree will form what is called “wound wood”, which is essentially a callus that forms over the injury. Healthy trees callus over quickly. Encourage health by fertilizing (if needed) in the spring, proper pruning and adequate irrigation in hot, dry weather. Do not fertilize in the fall, as that encourages new growth which is more susceptible to splitting. Do not remove the bark around the crack or attempt to paint or treat the damaged area. Bark splits generally close over completely leaving a slight ridge in the trunk where callus tissue has been produced.


 

As the tree grows, the bark becomes darker and becomes slightly raised with long, flared plates with ridges. The appearance will likely vary in color with brown, gray, or near black, often with an orange interior bark.


 

Finally, one notation on this tree. It appears that it was planted incorrectly which has caused what is known as ‘girdling roots’ which are roots that emerge at or slightly below the soil surface. Girdling roots cut into at least one side of the main trunk, essentially choking the tree and preventing movement of water and nutrients. This tree may start to show symptoms of decline at some point because of this. See the photo attached notating the girdling roots.
answer.author: Donnetta Wilhelm

title: browning leaves on avocado #326388
question:
My 1 1/2 year old avocado is losing its leaves to brown spots.

reasonably well watered


soil ph 5.5

answer.response:
Howdy from Texas!

The cause of this is excess moisture.  Whether by natural rainfall or applied irrigation, these plants don't like too much moisture. Modify irrigation controls and do anything to ensure good drainage to the area. If this plant doesn't respond and you want to try again, plant the tree where you get superior drainage and good airflow around the plant.

Best of luck

Boone
answer.author: Boone Holladay

answer.response:
Hi there...Well water can cause browning...but it could also be a fungus.....

Notice the pic on the right --there are some white spots in the brown section.
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Well hello again.

Yes, you are absolutely correct.  It could be a fungal pathogen or even potentially a bacterial pathogen. Both of which are brought on by excessive soil moisture, rain, and even high relative humidity. In which we have experienced all of the above. In terms of applying a topical fungicide, well, it couldn't hurt, but probably won't help much either.  Not at this point, at least. Focus on correcting some bigger constants. These being: increase airflow around the plant and through the canopy, increase soil drainage through drains or furrows, monitor and modify irrigation as needed to deliver what the plant needs and nothing more, and increase sunlight by trimming back surrounding vegetation. A fungicide may help minimally and quite temporarily, but these cultural practices will help greatly down the road.

Best of luck. Good day,

Boone
answer.author: Boone Holladay

title: Leaves not developing? #406184
question: This is June 11th and I have two trees I'm worried about. All the trees were sprayed before bloom with fruit tree spray. Two of the trees have under developed leaves. The Granny Smith is the whole tree and the red delicious is 80% under developed. Should I be concerned?

1.response:
The picture is very helpful.   Looks like roundup / glyphosate damage, maybe applied last year at the base of the tree or in the vicinity.   It was absorbed into the tree through foliage, maybe rootsuckers or tender bark and we see the effects this year.   We generally recommend that roundup application close to perennial trees be halted after about late June because at that point herbicide will get transported to the roots as the trees start sending reserves down to the roots, getting ready for winter.  If you are next to a field where roundup ready soybeans or corn are grown, sometimes there may be drift.  The particularly sensitive plants will show symptoms.  The pale strap-like leaves is the key symptom.  See the following article:

.http://msue.anr.msu.edu/news/glyphosate_damage_in_apple_and_cherry_orchards

Larger trees like yours usually will grow out of it but not always.   The only thing you can do is wait and see, provide adequate water.
1.author: William Shane

2.response:
I did apply Roundup late last summer and there were some suckers around some of the trees. I wont do that again. Thank you very much for the help.

Pat
2.author: The Question Asker

3.response: Would it be ok to prune the affected trees now or this winter? With condition of the trees, would it be adding too much stress on them?
3.author: The Question Asker

4.response: Prune at the normal time next Feb to early April.  Pruning now is stressful on the tree. A modest amount of summer pruning is okay for healthy tree, but not for your weakened trees.  However, dead limbs can be removed anytime.
4.author: William Shane

management instructions: Wait and see.
Provide adequate water.
Prune at the normal time next Feb to early April.
Dead limbs can be removed anytime.

title: Waxy substance on ficus leaves #725465
question: I have a waxy substance on the undersides of a 25-year-old ficus tree. It has been in the same window for seven years.  Have never had a problem. It does not go outdoors in the summer.  I would hate to lose it. I’ve tried an organic insecticidal soap. I have read online where someone else tried neem oil with no results. Any suggestions?

answer.response:
Hello, and thank you for contacting us. Are the waxy bumps in the same location on all the leaves? If so, it is probably not a pest as the text in your photo indicates.

On the other hand, if there are small hard bumps in scattered places on the leaves, your plant may have scale insects which are a common pest of ficus. It is important to determine what the bumps are in order to determine what remedy, if any, is required.

If you believe your tree has scale, here are the comments from one of the Extension universities:

"Contact chemicals are most effective when used to treat the juvenile (crawler) form of the insect before they have formed their protective covering. At this time horticultural oil and insecticidal soaps are very effective. (Both have very low toxicity...) These products can stain fabrics, so cover carpets, upholstery, and draperies if you apply these (or any other product indoors). 

Some authors recommend the use of systemic insecticides to kill the adult phase of this insect. Contact insecticides [mentioned above] are ineffective because of the scales protective covering, but systemic insecticides are absorbed into the plant and then into the insect when it feeds on the plant juices. These products are more toxic to us and our pets, so it is safest to apply them outside and leave the plant in a shady location until the chemical has dried.

Mechanical control [involves dipping] a cotton swab into rubbing alcohol and rub firmly enough to remove the insect (covering and all) from the stems and leaves. Some scale insects will rub off quite easily while others will require more effort. Take care not to bruise the plant when doing this.

Plants that are severely infested with insects may be treated (mechanically or chemically) so that their problems will not spread to other plants, or they may be discarded and replaced with healthy plants from a nursery. Problems are more easily treated now rather than in the middle of the winter when it is too cold to take houseplants outside for treatment."
answer.author: Lynne Marie Sullivan

answer.response:
Hello again,

I came across some additional information on identifying scale insects that you may find useful:

"Most scale insects are very small, usually ranging in size from 1/16 to 1/8 inch long. However, you will never see just one of them, which makes them hard to miss. Scale almost always appears in clusters. Unlike other insects, they are immobile once they lock themselves into place to pierce the plant and begin feeding on sap. If you see clusters of tiny shell-like bumps on the stems or leaves of a plant, there is a good chance you are looking at a scale.

Scale insects are usually divided into two groups: soft scale, and hard or armored scale. Soft scale is covered with a protective waxy substance and is somewhat easier to kill than hard/armored scale.2 Armored scale secretes a hard shell over its body for protection from predators. The shell also makes it difficult to use a pesticide because it has trouble reaching the insect inside."
answer.author: Lynne Marie Sullivan

title: Fuzzy leaf galls (insect?) #814013
question:
We along with neighbors (in Highland and White Lake) O.C.,  are finding an abundance of 'pussy willow like ' cream colored fuzzys, everywhere,  coming from Oak trees.  No one has seen before -- why now?  Are these related to a minute type of wasp? Any cause or cure?   Is it a problem 
or  benign?   Thank you!

1.response:
Hi there!
This is the woolly oak leaf gall, and they are being produced in great abundance this year. It's caused by a tiny wasp that is native and does not sting people. 
https://dickinsoncountyconservationboard.com/2017/10/10/what-is-the-fuzzy-stuff-on-my-oak-leaves/
Totally benign to the tree. I'm in Roscommon and people have been reporting them in record numbers this year, too! Weather patterns and other factors can cause insect populations to rise and fall; these are certainly present in record numbers this year!
Each of the galls house a larvae; if you'd like less of the galls next year, rake and dispose of them off site. 
Enjoy the fall colors!
-Julie
1.author: Julie Crick

2.response:
Great! Sounds like bird food for next yr.
Thank you so much!

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows garlic mustard (Alliaria petiolata), a non-native invasive species that can outcompete native plants in shaded woodland areas. Garlic mustard is particularly problematic because it spreads quickly and can disrupt the ecosystem by reducing biodiversity.

### Recommended Management Strategies:

1. **Manual Removal**:
   - **When**: During the growing season, typically in spring before the plants produce seed pods.
   - **How**: Hand pull the plants, making sure to remove the roots completely. Dispose of the plants in a sealed bag to prevent them from spreading seeds.
   - **Note**: It's important to remove the entire plant, including the root, as even small pieces can regenerate into new plants.

2. **Chemical Control**:
   - **When**: If manual removal is impractical or the infestation is extensive.
   - **How**: Use systemic herbicides specifically labeled for garlic mustard, such as triclopyr. Follow the label instructions carefully.
   - **Note**: Apply herbicides during the growing season when the plants are actively growing. Be cautious with chemical application to avoid harming native plants or other wildlife.

3. **Biological Control**:
   - **When**: Not applicable in this scenario unless specific biological controls are available and approved for the area.
   - **How**: Some regions have introduced biocontrol agents like the garlic mustard weevil (Liriomyza alliariae) which feeds on garlic mustard but does not harm native plants. However, this method requires careful monitoring and approval from local authorities.

4. **Preventive Measures**:
   - **Seed Collection**: If you notice garlic mustard seedlings, collect the seeds and dispose of them properly to prevent new growth.
   - **Raising Awareness**: Educate others about the importance of managing garlic mustard to prevent its spread. This includes teaching people how to identify it and how to remove it correctly.

5. **Restoration of Native Plants**:
   - **After Control**: Once the garlic mustard is controlled, it’s important to restore the area with native plants. This helps to re-establish the ecological balance and support biodiversity.

### Safety Precautions:
- Always wear protective gear (gloves, long sleeves) when handling garlic mustard.
- Be aware of the potential health risks associated with certain herbicides. Wear appropriate safety equipment and follow all label instructions.
- Dispose of treated plants and debris responsibly to prevent contamination.

By implementing these strategies, you can effectively manage the garlic mustard invasion in your wooded area, helping to preserve

title: Septic mound grass #834515
question: Several years ago we planted “no-mow” grass on the septic mound. It is being overtaken by tall wide- blade grass. Is there a product that can eliminate the undesired grass and protect the fescue?

answer.response:
Any product that would kill one grass will kill the others as well.  If it were a broad leaf plant there are products that work but a grass is a grass.  Without a closeup of the undesirable grass with roots attached I can’t accurately assess what you are trying to get rid of. One option is to kill all the grass and start over.

Another option—since your mixture contains several fescues, you might check with the supplier and see if you can get more of the desired grasses to out compete the undesired by overseeding in the fall or early spring.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a label for a "No Mow Fine Fescue Mixture," which suggests that it is a seed mix designed to be low-maintenance and suitable for areas where mowing is not desired. The issue described in the background information involves an overgrowth of undesired grass on a septic mound in Nicollet County, Minnesota.

Given the composition of the mixture (which includes various types of fescue grass), it seems that the mixture might be suitable for maintaining a dense, low-growing ground cover. However, if the undesired grass is outcompeting the fescue species, a more targeted approach might be needed.

Here are some potential management strategies:

1. **Chemical Control**: Apply a selective herbicide that targets broadleaf weeds while sparing the fescue. Be cautious with herbicides near septic systems to avoid contamination.

2. **Mechanical Removal**: Regularly hand-pull or use a small trowel to remove the undesired grasses. This can help reduce competition and allow the fescue to regrow.

3. **Mulching**: Apply a layer of mulch around the septic mound to suppress weed growth. This can help create a more favorable environment for the fescue to thrive.

4. **Fertilization and Watering**: Ensure that the fescue receives adequate nutrients and water. This can sometimes help it outcompete other grasses.

5. **Cultural Practices**: Mow the area regularly to keep the grass short and dense, which can help reduce the growth of weeds. Even though the mix is labeled as no-mow, regular trimming might still be necessary to manage the spread of undesirable plants.

6. **Re-seeding**: If the problem persists, consider re-seeding the area with a higher percentage of fescue or a mix that better suits the local conditions and climate.

It's important to consult with a professional, such as a landscape or agricultural expert, before applying any treatments, especially when dealing with septic systems. They can provide guidance tailored to your specific situation and ensure that any treatment does not cause harm to the septic system or the surrounding environment.

title: October Glory Maple Tree is dying #150898
question:
Our October Glory ( Or Sunset Glory?) maple tree appears to be dying from the crown (top) of the tree.  The tallest branches are no longer leafing out and as you can see from the photos, and more branches further down appear to be dying each year.  The tree is about 20 years old. We started noticing the leafless two summers ago.  The limbs that are "dying " are too high to examine.

There is a damaged spot on the trunk of the tree near the soil line that looks like the bark is damaged and exposes the inner trunk. (Photo attached.)  It looks like there is a bit of mold in there. 

Are the lying branches drought damage?  Or are they from the damaged spot in the trunk?  Is there anything we can do to stop the damage?  Patch it ?  Use some chemicals ? Or is our lovely tree dying a slow death.

Thanks for any expert advice you can give us..

answer.response:
Thank you for sending the pictures!  It certainly helps with diagnosing the problem.

The picture of the lower trunk shows me a few things that I believe are the cause of your problem.  The damaged section of the lower trunk is one part of the problem.  There may have been a physical injury there, although I think the rest of the picture indicates another possibility.

It appears that your tree has a trunk-girdling root.  The surface roots on the left side of the trunk don't grow outwards away from the tree, but appear to be heading in a circle to surround and choke the tree.  In fact, that little strip of live wood beneath the open wound appears to be a sideways root. 

Girdling roots form most often from improper planting.  Roots grow where it's easy, and many times, we make the planting HOLE the easiest place to grow, instead of the rest of the yard.  The roots, instead of extending outward into the compacted soil of the rest of the yard, begin to grow around and around the inside of the planting hole...like a houseplant will if it's been kept in a pot too long.  After a few years, the trunk expands (by adding rings) to the point where it contacts the sideways-growing root.  Since that root is embedded in the soil, it can't be pushed out of the way, and so the tree begins to strangle itself.

Note the way that the trunk on that side doesn't flare outwards, like a normal tree.  It goes into the ground straight, almost like a telephone pole.  This indicates that the roots and vascular tissue that should have been growing and expanding on that side are being restricted.

There is no way to fix this problem once the symptoms start showing up.  You could cut the girdling roots (although you will need to excavate downward at least a foot or two to find them all), but the problem is, these are probably the major remaining live roots of the tree.  If you cut them, there may not be any other roots to take over keeping the tree alive.

The tree will continue to slowly decline and die back over the next couple of years.  I would begin making plans now to replace it when it no longer provides enough shade or beauty for your yard.

You can read more about girdling roots at this page:  http://www.missouribotanicalgarden.org/gardens-gardening/your-garden/help-for-the-home-gardener/advi... .
answer.author: Larry Caplan

symptom description: tallest branches are no longer leafing out
more branches further down appear to be dying

title: What is this bug and how can I get rid of it? #550873
question: I have an office that has a Koi pond and plants in the atrium. I also have these pesky little bugs that fly around and multiply like crazy. I bomb the office once a month just to knock the numbers down. I also have a pest control service that sprays monthly. We also clean the pond every other month. I still cant get rid of them. At night I place bug zapper lights out and in the morning I have a circle of dead bugs around the lights. I would say a couple hundred every night. Sometimes in the atrium there is a swarm of them flying around in a ball about 15 feet in the air. I put extensions on my hose and suck them up, but no matter what I do I cant get rid of them. It just seems like I can get the numbers down to a smaller amount, but they always come back. They seem to be attracted to people. I have had them fly up peoples noses before, or in their mouth, even when there aren't a lot of them. .

answer.response:
Those appear to be midges and the larvae will be living in the pond area which is where treatment should be focused.   You can treat the pond area with a Bacillus thuringiensis kurstaki product which works on mosquito and midge larvae or you can add some Gambusia (mosquito eating fish) to the pond.
You can find more ideas here:https://content.ces.ncsu.edu/biology-and-control-of-non-biting-aquatic-midges
answer.author: Wizzie Brown

management instructions: treat the pond area with a Bacillus thuringiensis kurstaki product
add Gambusia (mosquito eating fish) to the pond

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a midge, which is a type of small fly often found in areas with standing water or near aquatic environments. Given the context provided, the presence of a koi pond and plants in an atrium, as well as the frequent bombing of the office by pests, suggests a significant infestation problem.

Here’s a recommended management strategy for addressing the midge infestation:

### Habitat Modification
1. **Pond Management**: Since the koi pond is a potential breeding ground for midges, it's crucial to maintain it properly.
   - **Regular Cleaning**: Ensure that the pond is cleaned every two months as mentioned, and remove any organic debris, leaves, or decaying plant matter that can serve as breeding sites.
   - **Water Circulation**: Use aerators or fountains to keep the water moving, which can help reduce mosquito larvae and prevent midges from laying eggs in still water.

### Physical Control
2. **Bug Zapper Lights**: Continue using bug zapper lights to trap adult midges, especially at night when they are most active.
3. **Insect Nets**: If possible, cover the koi pond with insect nets to physically block midges from entering and laying eggs.

### Chemical Control
4. **Insecticides**: Although pest control services are already in place, consider additional targeted treatments for midges if the infestation persists.
   - **Bacillus thuringiensis israelensis (Bti)**: This biological insecticide is effective against mosquito larvae and can be applied directly to the pond water without harming beneficial insects.
   - **Fogging**: For more localized areas within the office, fogging with approved insecticides may be necessary, but always follow safety guidelines and use them according to the manufacturer’s instructions.

### Integrated Pest Management (IPM)
5. **IPM Approach**: Combine all the above methods into an integrated approach to manage the midge population effectively. Monitor the situation regularly and adjust your strategies based on feedback.

### Prevention
6. **Avoid Attracting Midge Adults**:
   - **Proper Waste Disposal**: Keep trash and food scraps away from the pond area.
   - **Sealing Off Entry Points**: Ensure that there are no openings in the walls or windows where midges can enter the office.
   - **Plants and Decor**: Keep plants and decorations away from the pond edge to avoid attracting midges.

By implementing these strategies, you can significantly reduce the midge population in your environment, making the office a

5.response: Ahhh--that's better! That's a sassafras tree. The green twigs, when scratched, smell like root beer, and was, in fact used to flavor rootbeer. We used to make sassafras tea from the roots when I was a child, but there is some evidence that it's carcinogenic, so it is no longer considered edible. title: Red Oak tips of branches with new leaves being chewed off by squirrels  #764424
question:
My Red Oak tree is having the tips of branches with new leaves being chewed off by squirrels. Lots of them. I was wondering if this is bad for the tree. Also I was wondering why the squirrels are doing this. 
My yard is full of leaves every day and a lot of little branches with new leaves are hung up in the tree. I watch the squirrels reach as high out on the branch as they can and chew off the new growth. This is pruning he tree. I am not sure if this is a good thing or not.

1.response:
After looking closer at my Red Oak I see it is infested with what I think is kermes scale. I looked these up on the internet. I attached pictures. I noticed a lot of wasps flying around the scale which I think is a good thing. I made a video of the wasps going after the scale but I can not attach movies.   There is also a lot of sap coming out of the wounds in the tree.

Can you tell me how to treat the tree for this problem and what tree service is a good one to ask for help with this?
1.author: The Question Asker

2.response:
The biting off of the branch tips will not likely hurt the tree. I am including the URL to information from the University of Nebraska, Lincoln, that may shed some light on what is happening. They are dealing with an ash tree, but the principles are the same. If you have other questions, get in touch after looking at the information.
https://extension.unl.edu/statewide/buffalo/Yard/Squirrels%20Pruning%20Trees%20January%209%202016.pdf
Another Source:
https://wildlife-damage-management.extension.org/how-do-i-stop-squirrels-from-cutting-my-branches/
Best,
Marvin
2.author: Marvin Reynolds

3.response: What do I do about the scale?
3.author: The Question Asker

4.response:
What do I do about the scale? How do I treat it and who should I have do it?

Sent from my iPhone
On Jul 29, 2021, at 9:35 AM, Ask Extension <askextension@eduworks.com> wrote:

﻿
4.author: The Question Asker

5.response:
The scale may be controlled with a spring dormant oil spray application completed before the oak trees leaf out. Preferably before budding. This will smother the insects before they can turn into an adult. Fall time sprays with a pyrethroid insecticide including active ingredients permethrin, lambda-cyhalothrin, or bifenthrin may be applied. Spray the entire tree. A strong sprayer may be needed to reach the top of the tree. Here are two links to information that can help.

https://planttalk.colostate.edu/topics/insects-diseases/1400-11-kermes-scale-oak-trees/

https://hnr.k-state.edu/extension/info-center/common-pest-problems/common-pest-problem-new/Kermes%20Oak%20Scale.pdf

Good luck,

Marvin
5.author: Marvin Reynolds

6.response:
Is there a systematic pesticide that can be injected into the ground and taken up by the tree that can help with keremes scale?

Sent from my iPhone
On Jul 29, 2021, at 11:23 AM, Ask Extension <askextension@eduworks.com> wrote:

﻿
6.author: The Question Asker

7.response:
Imidicloprid can be injected into the soil to treat for kermes scale. It may take up to a year before the treatment takes effect.

https://planttalk.colostate.edu/topics/insects-diseases/1400-11-kermes-scale-oak-trees/

Best,

Marvin
7.author: Marvin Reynolds

8.response: What do I do about the scale?
8.author: The Question Asker

9.response:
If the infestation is low, often people don't treat. They let the natural predators help with the problem. You can treat with a dormant oil spray early in the year. It can help with the scale and has a low impact on predators. That can give you a double impact. You can also use the systemic treatment with imidacloprid. Check with local farm supply companies to see if they have it in stock. Follow the label directions to have the most effective use. You can also treat with insecticides before they develop the hardened shell. I am including the URL to information on managing different types of scale from Purdue University. It has treatment recommendations.
https://extension.entm.purdue.edu/publications/E-29.pdf
Best,
Marvin
9.author: Marvin Reynolds

title: Peeling Bark #811340
question: Hello.  I have a young Chinkapin oak in my yard with, as you can see, peeling bark. The tree was planted on March 31st and I noticed at that time that there were cracks in the bark on one side.  The bark on that side is now peeling heavily.  Can you tell me what would be causing this? Thank you in advance.

answer.response: I just wanted to add that, other than the bark, the tree appears to be very healthy
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Hello Alexa,

Thank you for contacting Ask Extension.  You have a question about the bark peeling on the trunk of your Chinkapin Oak.  It looks like sunscald is causing this condition.  The tree was planted on 31 March.  Here in Colorado Springs, we had some dramatic spring temperature fluctuations and a May heavy wet snow which damaged many trees this year.  If your tree  had leaves or it was not winter hardened and growing outside  before being planted, it could have been susceptible to this disease. 

Here is some information from Utah State University.  Oaks are listed as being susceptible to sunscald.

https://forestry.usu.edu/news/utah-forest-facts/sunscald-injury-or-southwest-winter-injury-on-deciduous-trees

"Sunscald or southwest injury refers to damage incurred though the killing of active cells within the trunk and limbs of sensitive trees during winter months. Young trees with thin bark are most susceptible to sunscald injury. The injury occurs when exposed bark on the tree warms up on sunny days and previously dormant cells within the plant become active in response to the warmth. Research has shown that the south side of a tree can be as much as 77°F warmer on a cold winter day than the north side of the tree. The newly activated cells lose some of their cold-hardiness and are injured when temperatures drop below freezing during the nighttime hours. Resulting damage includes discoloration and cracking of the bark. The portions of trunks and branches facing south and southwest warm the most because they get the most direct sun and because they get sun later in the day when air temperatures are warmest."

I am also including some more information from Colorado State University.

https://planttalk.colostate.edu/topics/weeds-cultural-problems/2111-sunscald-trees/

https://extension.colostate.edu/topic-areas/yard-garden/environmental-disorders-of-woody-plants-2-932/

Please see the information below about how to water trees during a drought.  Drought stressed trees are more susceptible to sunscald.

https://extension.colostate.edu/topic-areas/yard-garden/watering-a-home-landscape-during-drought-7-240-2/

A newly planted tree has some additional irrigation needs  in order to successfully establish its root system.

https://cmg.extension.colostate.edu/Gardennotes/635.pdf
answer.author: Barbara S.

answer.response:
Thank you for your diagnosis and information. From what I understand, there’s really no treatment for sun scald. It’s just a matter of trying to keep the tree as healthy as possible while it recovers. The tree is well watered, so drought isn’t really a problem for it.
I would like your thoughts regarding the use of a specialized tree paint like IV Organic Tree White Wash, or IV Organic Plant Guard which contains an insecticide as well as the white coating. I normally don’t use pesticides, but I’m willing to consider something localized if it will protect the tree from boring insects.  
Or perhaps just a light colored tree wrap? If so, what is the best time of year to use it? Thank you for your assistance. It really is a lovely tree and I don’t want to lose it.

On Wed, Sep 21, 2022 at 4:48 PM Extension Foundation <askextension@eduworks.com> wrote:
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Hello Alexa,

I am providing information about how to use tree wrap, this could help protect your tree from further damage this winter.  It is recommended that you apply light colored wrap around Thanksgiving and remove it early spring around the middle of April.  It is important to remove the wrap each year.  The wounds can be an entry point for insects.  

https://cmg.extension.colostate.edu/Gardennotes/653.pdf

Paint could be useful for young trees that have not been damaged by sunscald but it is not recommended for damaged trees.  The wounds should not be sealed.

The following quote is  from: 

https://forestry.usu.edu/news/utah-forest-facts/sunscald-injury-or-southwest-winter-injury-on-deciduous-trees

"Damage from sunscald injury may eventually heal, but the damaged areas should not be painted or filled with any sealing substance such as paint or tar. However, wrapping with light colored tree-wrap can help. Usually sunscald damage in the northern hemisphere occurs on portions of the tree with south or west exposure."
answer.author: Barbara S.

symptom description: cracks in the bark on one side
management instructions: Apply light colored tree wrap around Thanksgiving and remove it early spring around the middle of April.
Do not seal the wounds.
Keep the tree well watered.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a chinkapin oak with peeling bark. This condition is not unusual and can occur due to several factors, including natural aging, environmental stress, or disease. However, since the tree appears to be otherwise healthy, it's likely that the peeling bark is not a serious concern.

Here are some management strategies you might consider:

1. **Monitor Regularly**: Keep an eye on the tree for any signs of decline or changes in the bark condition over time. If the peeling continues or becomes more severe, it could indicate a problem that requires further attention.

2. **Inspect for Other Issues**: Check the rest of the tree for signs of disease or pests. While the bark peeling itself may not be a major issue, there could be underlying problems that affect the health of the tree.

3. **Prune if Necessary**: If there are dead or diseased branches near the peeling area, these should be pruned to prevent the spread of disease and to maintain the structure of the tree.

4. **Watering**: Ensure the tree is receiving adequate water, especially during dry periods. Chinkapin oaks prefer well-drained soil and can benefit from consistent moisture.

5. **Mulch**: Apply a layer of mulch around the base of the tree to retain moisture, suppress weeds, and regulate soil temperature. Be sure not to pile mulch too close to the trunk, as this can lead to issues like stem girdling or fungal infections.

6. **Avoid Damage**: Protect the tree from physical damage caused by lawn mowers, string trimmers, or other equipment. These activities can harm the bark and potentially weaken the tree.

If the peeling bark persists or worsens, or if you notice other symptoms such as leaf drop, discoloration, or dieback, consult with a local arborist or horticulturist for a professional assessment. They can provide specific recommendations based on the tree’s overall health and the conditions of the bark peeling.

title: Webs on Barrel Oak tree trunk #134433
question:
We have a webbing on the tree trunk and inner branches of two of our Barrel Oaks that looks more like silk that is wrapped around each trunk or branch. It does not spread into the leaves but just stays along the bark of the tree.
Thank you for your advice on treatment.

1.response:
It looks like your tree has some barklice. Barklice are harmless, and the webbing formed by some species does not harm the tree. The presence of barklice indicates that a suitable habitat for them exists. Since the tree-dwelling species eat fungus, lichen, and organic debris, they could be viewed as beneficial insects. Control of such insects is unnecessary; however, if you consider the webbing to be unsightly, you could use a high-pressure stream of water to remove it from the trees.

Here are some links with more information:
http://www.clemson.edu/extension/hgic/pests/plant_problems/hgic2365.html

http://aggie-horticulture.tamu.edu/galveston/beneficials/beneficial-41_barklice2_Cerastipscus_sp.htm

Thanks for the question.
1.author: Paul Winski

title: Vine trrying to take over trees and bursh #847988
question: Located this vine which I have never seen before in its location.  I am cutting it down to ground level as spraying would effect other trees and natural landscape.  Am I causing more issues with cutting or do I need to use a weed killer and eliminate/risk an entire area of woodland. It is amazing how fast it grows, trying to overtake other vegetation.   Thank you for your help.

1.response:
Hi Mary

   It's kind of hard for me to tell from the picture you provided what vine that could be. The leaf shape is similar to a smilax species, but I am not sure on an id for the vine. You should be fine cutting it down to ground level and/or pulling what roots and vines you can. That would definitely be my recommended first course of action. An if that doesn't work we can always move on to more extreme measures. If it is a relatively new plant though i think pulling/cutting it should damage it enough to keep it from returning. Especially with the drought we've been experiencing. However, without being able to get a good id on the plant I hesitate to say with certainty that it will work. If you could provide me with some close up pictures of the stems and leaves I may be able to give a more direct answer to your question. 

   I hope this helps some. An if you are able to get more pictures of the vine. I would gladly look into it further for you. If you have any other questions or concerns please feel free to reach out to me or the extension. Happy Gardening!!!
1.author: Jeramiha Englund

title: Yellow branches Meyer lemon #564531
question:
My Meyer lemon gave us a lot of lemons the first year we planted it (outdoors in decomposed granite soil). Very hot in the summer, cool winters with some short bouts of freezing.

This is year 2 and some of the branches turned yellow, many lost their leaves, and remaining leaves are yellow and green. The branches are all splayed out. It gets drip for an hour twice a week.

I have more photos. Can only submit 3 here.

answer.response: The short bouts of freezing temperatures may have damaged the tree. While lemons can tolerate some cold weather, they may not survive freezing temperatures. The tree may recover somewhat this season, however it may not produce well. The tree may need to be moved or sheltered in a warmer environment during periods of very cold weather in order for it to survive.

title: New lawn full of weeds #455783
question: Help! My husband and I replanted our back yard a few weeks ago. Before we did, we leveled a huge mound of soil left behind by the previous owners. We sprayed the grass before leveling, and now we have lots of weeds coming big up with the new grass. What do we do?

answer.response:
Hello,
Unfortunately it looks like your pile of soil had quite a few weed seeds in it which germinated with the grass seed. It is common for some weeds to germinate with a new lawn, however this looks like more of an extreme case. Typically you should be able to wait until the lawn is more established (after about 6 weeks) and then use an herbicide for broadleaf weeds for lawns. However, I am worried in some areas that the weeds may out compete the grass and you may not end up with a good stand of grass. In the worst spots you may need to spray out the weeds and reseed. I would recommend bringing in some of the weeds into the local extension office to have them identified, especially for the sections of lawn with more scattered weeds, that way if you use an herbicide for this weed as your lawn is more established you can be sure that the herbicide will work well for your particular weeds.

Here is info for your local extension office:
http://extension.oregonstate.edu/yamhill/find-us

Thank you for using Ask an Expert!
answer.author: Heather Stoven

management instructions: Wait until the lawn is more established (after about 6 weeks) and then use an herbicide for broadleaf weeds for lawns.
In the worst spots you may need to spray out the weeds and reseed.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a recently replanted backyard with a significant amount of weed growth emerging from the soil, which was likely a result of the previous grass being sprayed before the soil was leveled. Here's a recommended management strategy to address the weed problem:

### Step-by-Step Strategy

1. **Identify the Weeds**:
   - Determine the type of weeds present. Common weeds that might be growing include dandelions, crabgrass, or other broadleaf weeds. If unsure, you can consult with a local nursery or garden center for identification.

2. **Prevent Further Growth**:
   - Apply a pre-emergent herbicide to prevent more weeds from sprouting. These products work by blocking the roots of seeds from developing into plants. Be sure to follow the label instructions carefully as pre-emergents are effective only when applied before the seeds germinate.

3. **Spot Treat Existing Weeds**:
   - Use post-emergent herbicides on existing weeds if they are not effectively controlled by the pre-emergent. Post-emergent herbicides target actively growing weeds and are applied directly to the leaves. Always read and adhere to the application guidelines on the product label.

4. **Mulching**:
   - Apply mulch around the base of plants and trees to suppress weed growth. This will also help retain moisture in the soil and improve the overall health of your lawn.

5. **Regular Maintenance**:
   - Maintain regular mowing and watering schedules to ensure your grass is healthy and competitive against weeds. A strong, healthy lawn can naturally suppress weeds through shading and competition.

6. **Fertilize**:
   - Apply a balanced fertilizer to promote healthy grass growth. This will make your grass stronger and more resistant to weed invasion.

7. **Consider Mechanical Control**:
   - Use a hoe, hand trowel, or other tools to physically remove small weeds manually. This method is effective but requires consistent effort to keep the area free of weeds.

8. **Check for Underlying Issues**:
   - Ensure there are no underlying issues such as poor drainage or compacted soil that could contribute to the weed problem. Improving these conditions can help your lawn thrive and outcompete weeds.

By following these steps, you should be able to manage the weed problem and enjoy a healthier, more uniform lawn in your newly replanted backyard.
