title: Save My Blonde Boxwood #553633
question: My local nursery suggested I send my information to your site. They suspect boxwood blight, but I want to be sure before I remove my precious plant. I purchased/planted this boxwood as a pair of tiny, 6-inch saplings in June 2012. Approximately one month ago, portions of the plant began browning. There are no bugs or spots on the leaves. On inspection of the interior, some of the bark is peeling away on a couple of the larger stems. Please help me save my blonde boxwood, if it is possible. Any guidance on what is attacking my plant and solutions for correcting the problem would be helpful. I have additional photos to share, if needed. Thank you!

answer.response:
From your photos, this does not look like boxwood blight. Our thought is that this is the nasty work of voles. Voles or meadow mice are active all year round and are notorious for tunneling through mulch (especially in the winter), going underneath shrubs and gnawing on the bark. They are very fond of boxwood. In the third photo, we noticed some missing bark. This type of feeding girdles the stem which eventually dies. So you need to look underneath the shrub to see what is going on. You will need to prune out any damaged stems. The time to do this is now before the new growth begins.
Please see the following information from our website, including vole management,
http://extension.umd.edu/hgic/topics/voles

Deb
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

management instructions: prune out any damaged stems

title: Maple Tree #655745
question:
To whom it may concern,
 We live in Fennville, Michigan.  We purchased this Autumn Blaze maple tree from a local nursery 4 years ago.   
 We planted it in our front yard which faces south. We do have sandy soil.   The tree did develop some tar spots the past two years.  This  year though, the leaves are already wilting and have different black spot and some with raised red spots.  The trunk also develop a green fungus like substance.  I have attached a few picture.  Is there something going around that is effecting maples?  Looking to see if you know what it could be and it see how to treat it.  Any help would  be appreciated.  Thank  you in advance.

Kristin Doornbos

answer.response:
Maple anthracnose has been a common occurrence this year.  Anthracnose can be a fairly common spring disease on maple leaves in some years. There are several different fungi that cause anthracnose. One of the fungi (Kabatiella) causes newly developing leaves to shrivel and turn black, while older leaves develop dark brown lesions along the leaf veins. Fungal leaf diseases do not often threaten the long term health of the tree, but can be severe under certain conditions. Wet springs, and much of Michigan has seen a wet spring this year, usually cause increases of fungal diseases. Read more here: https://ag.umass.edu/landscape/fact-sheets/maple-anthracnose

The "green fungus like substance" on the trunk are actually lichens that commonly will grow on just about any surface under the right conditions, but are harmless to trees. Read more here:  https://www.canr.msu.edu/news/what-s-that-growing-on-my-tree
answer.author: John Harville

answer.response:
Thank you for your quick response. The provided information was very helpful. The article mentioned spraying the tree with a copper hydroxide + mancozeb, The first application should be made at or just before bud break to protect new growth from initial infection in spring. Is it okay to spray the tree with that now  or would it be best to wait til next spring when its starting to bud?

Kristin
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
To spray now would be of no help. When the buds are swollen and begin to peek out come spring would be the optimum time. This is assuming maple anthracnose is indeed the correct diagnosis, which we can't make from this vantage point. For that you could send a sample to Diagnostic Services for a small fee.  https://www.canr.msu.edu/pestid/

Or you could involve a Certified Arborist, one who specializes in these matters. Find one or more Certified Arborists in your zip code at www.treesaregood.org Go to the Find an Arborist tab. Arborist evaluations are not expensive and where you can learn exactly what is going on in your tree. Plus he/she will be qualified to  handle the timely treatment complications as well, if desired. 

Good luck!
answer.author: John Harville

symptom description: green fungus like substance on the trunk
management instructions: Spray the tree with copper hydroxide + mancozeb at or just before bud break to protect new growth from initial infection in spring.

title: Our magnolia bush is infe... #598301
question: Our magnolia bush is infected with something. So many bees around & looks like little bubbles on the branches & white scales on back of leaves. Do I need to get rid of this bush?

1.response: The tree/shrub is infested with magnoila/tuliptree scales.  These are one of the largest soft scale species we have in the U.S.  An application of horticultural oil (3-4% v/v) once the plant has gone dormant followed by a soil application with one of the systemic neonicotinoids (a.i.s = imidacloprid, thiomethoxam, clothianidin, or dinotefuran) next spring should provide some level of control to help the plant.  An application of horticultural oil (1-2% v/v) next mid-August should help follow-up controlling some of the scales missed by previous applications.  The scale produces copious amounts of honeydew which contains sugars the flies, wasps, bees, ants and other insects are attracted to as a readily available food source.  This scale is one of the easier scale species to control, but requires vigilance and consistent effort.  Products mentioned above are available at garden centers or box stores.  Good luck.
1.author: Brian Kunkel

title: Growth on plum tree #615015
question: I have abnormal growth on my plum tree. How can I get rid of it

1.response:
Hello,

This a fungus known as black knot. You should prune it, and any others you find, off the tree while the tree is dormant- right now is a good time to prune. Make the cut  about 6 inches below the knot into the healthy part of the branch. Take the pruned sections and bury, or you may burn it if you are allowed to burn debris in your area. Do not leave it on the ground, because this spreads more fungal spores in the area. Examine the surrounding area for wild cherry, cherry, plums or other trees that show these knots and remove them, too.

Here are details, with recommended resistant trees, and fungicides you can use after the knots are removed. Fungicides only prevent new knots when applied at the correct time, they do not cure existing knots.

https://www.canr.msu.edu/news/your_plum_trees_versus_black_knot

Thank you for using our service.
1.author: Laura Sheffer

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a cluster of what appears to be black mold or fungus on the roots or trunk of a plum tree. This could potentially be caused by a fungal disease such as Phytophthora root rot, which is common in Michigan and can affect many fruit trees.

### Recommended Management Strategy:

1. **Identify the Cause**: Confirm the diagnosis by consulting with a local horticulturist or plant pathologist. They may need to take samples for further testing to identify the specific fungal species and determine the appropriate treatment.

2. **Remove Affected Parts**: If the disease is localized (e.g., only affecting a small part of the root system), consider removing and destroying the affected areas to prevent the spread of the fungus.

3. **Prune Diseased Areas**: Remove any dead or diseased branches and prune back healthy branches to improve air circulation and reduce stress on the tree. Ensure that pruning tools are sanitized after each cut to prevent the spread of the fungus.

4. **Apply Fungicides**: Depending on the severity and the type of fungus, fungicides such as chlorothalonil or thiophanate-methyl might be necessary. Follow the manufacturer’s instructions carefully, as fungicides can be harmful if not used correctly.

5. **Improve Soil Conditions**: Enhance soil drainage and aeration by adding organic matter like compost or well-rotted manure. This can help the roots recover and promote healthy growth.

6. **Water Management**: Avoid overwatering, especially during wet weather. Ensure the tree is watered deeply but infrequently to encourage deep root growth.

7. **Monitor the Tree**: Regularly check the tree for signs of recovery or new infections. Early detection and treatment are crucial for managing fungal diseases effectively.

8. **Resistance Practices**: If the disease persists despite these measures, consider planting resistant varieties of plum trees in the future. Resistance breeding programs have developed varieties that are more tolerant to certain fungal pathogens.

By addressing the issue promptly and taking preventive measures, you can help manage the disease and increase the chances of the plum tree recovering and thriving.

title: Hi, my oregano plant has ... #191968
question: Hi, my oregano plant has little black spots all over the upper leaves.  It seems to all spread to my ligularia.  Do you know what it is?  And how to treat it?  I tried removing as much of it as I could, but it keeps showing up.  Thanks

1.response: I would suspect some sort of fungal infection if you hadn't said that you are able to remove some of the spots.  I think you may be seeing caterpillar or slug droppings.  Have you noticed and chewed leaves?
1.author: Mary Courteau

2.response: I'm sorry to be confusing - when I said remove it, I meant remove the effected area of the plant and put in the trash.  Here are a couple of photos.
2.author: The Question Asker

3.response:
Some insects, probably aphids, are feasting on your plants.  Aphids are pretty common insects and there are few gardens that totally escape damage.  They frequently show up on my oregano and a few other plants.  I don't like spraying, especially my edible plants, so I just rinse them off with a hose and wait for the "good" insects to realize there is an all-you-can-eat aphid buffet and reduce the population to an acceptable level.  

There are a couple of chemical controls if you prefer, but note that anything that kills bad insects also kills the good ones, so you may not be a lot better off.  Please see the following for your options:
http://www.extension.umn.edu/garden/insects/find/aphids-in-home-gardens/
3.author: Terri Seiler

title: Bug on tomato leaf #804723
question: This bug was found on a tomato leaf. It’s alive and eating the leaves. I found another as well. I’ve posted in 3 Facebook groups and no one knows. Do you think it’s a tomato hornworm?? Help!

answer.response:
Thanks for the question.

Nope, tis not a hornworm. However the resolution of the picture is not the best. My best guess at this time is that this is a Three-Lined Potato Beetle (Lema daturaphila). For whatever reason they seem to be rather abundant this season (2022). But, and this is an important but, these beetles are rarely found on tomatoes. Perhaps this critter just happened to land on your plant? See:

https://extension.unh.edu/resource/three-lined-potato-beetle-fact-sheet-0 - :~:text=Three-lined potato beetles are,with three lengthwise black stripes.

My suggestion at this time is just to pick it off your plant as well as any others that may alight. I am hesitant to suggest the spraying of any insecticide as this may have negative impacts upon the edibility of your tomatoes. Just keep monitoring the situation and if there appear any negative effects upon your plants, please get back to us and we can look further into your situation.

Best of luck
answer.author: Steve Hedman

keep monitoring the situation

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows what appears to be tomato hornworms (Manduca quinquemaculata) on a tomato leaf. Tomato hornworms are caterpillars that feed on various plants, including tomatoes, and can cause significant damage if not controlled.

### Recommended Management Strategies:

1. **Hand Picking**: Regularly inspect your tomato plants for hornworms and remove them manually. This method is effective but labor-intensive, especially if you have a large number of plants.

2. **Insecticidal Soap**: Apply an insecticidal soap solution directly to the hornworms and leaves where they feed. This is a natural and effective way to control their population without using harsh chemicals. Be sure to read and follow the label instructions carefully.

3. **Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt)**: Bt is a biological pesticide that targets only caterpillars and is safe for other beneficial insects. Apply the Bt solution according to the instructions on the product label.

4. **Hornworm Moth Trap**: If you suspect you may have an infestation, set up traps for the adult hornworm moths. These traps can help reduce the population before the larvae hatch.

5. **Natural Predators**: Encourage beneficial insects like ladybugs, lacewings, and parasitic wasps by maintaining a diverse garden habitat. These natural predators will help keep the hornworm population under control.

6. **Neem Oil**: Neem oil is another organic pesticide that can be applied to tomato plants. It disrupts the development of hornworms by preventing them from feeding properly. Apply it according to the directions on the product label.

7. **Cultural Practices**: Maintain healthy plant practices such as proper watering, fertilization, and pruning. Strong, healthy plants are less susceptible to pest infestations.

8. **Rotate Crops**: Avoid planting tomatoes in the same location year after year to prevent build-up of pests and diseases.

By implementing these strategies, you should be able to manage the tomato hornworm population effectively and protect your tomato plants. Monitor your plants regularly to ensure early detection and treatment of any new infestations.

title: What is this weed? #409414
question:
This weed has taken over in the last few weeks. It is a vine that spreads over the ground really fast over bushes, anything. It sticks to itself and when weeding it I end up rolling it up in a big bundle and yanking it out of the ground. It's less sticky after a rain. The stickiness is weird--no thorns or stickers, just a little sticky!
In these photos it covered two box bushes and some iris. I already weeded enough to fill 3 garbage bags and there is more.
I'm trying to get rid of it before it goes to seed.

answer.response:
This looks like one of the vetches, an annual, based on its fast growth.  Could be sparrow vetch (4 seed per pod) or narrowleaf vetch. Regardless, pull and bag ASAP, as we can see that some pods are already mature and popping open.  Keep doing what you are doing. 

This is such a huge infestation that perhaps one plant escaped notice last year, or was not removed until after it reseeded.   To prevent a problem next spring, cover the soil with 3-4 layers of newspaper in this area and top with mulch so that no seeds can germinate. You may continue to see these seeds pop up for a few years, because seeds can remain viable in the soil for years. Learn to recognize the seedlings and remove quickly. Stay on top of it until you have exhausted the seed "bank."  

ECN
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

answer.response: Thank you! Is there something other than newspaper? I get news online now. The bed is about 2 1/2 feet wide, then there is a brick gutter, then about 6 inches up to the stone foundation of the house. I'm looking for something to put on that last strip--ground up tires, anything. I could put weed killer on the gutter and landscape cloth in the intervals between the lilies and irises. Your point about a seed bank makes sense.
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
You could try cardboard, paper bags, or kraft paper and cover with mulch.  If you see any weed growth pull immediately.
If you use landscape fabric and mulch, the weeds can eventually grow on top of the fabric. Also, if you eventually want to plant in that area, it is difficult to do so with fabric in place.
Rubber mulch is not an effective choice in controlling weeds. It does decompose and may contain contaminants.  See the attached link on rubber mulch https://puyallup.wsu.edu/wp-content/uploads/sites/403/2015/03/rubber-mulch.pdf
mh
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

title: Browning on Unknown (Willow?) Tree #801001
question:
The photos are of a treee in our front yard in Salem.  Every year or two we get some brown sections.
Can you tell us what's causing them and how to prevent this from happening?

Thank You!

answer.response:
Dear Richard,

Thank you for contacting Ask Extension. The intermittent appearance of the browning and the fact that it appears to be on one side of the tree would indicate the problem is occasional root die-back which is most likely caused by environmental conditions. Heat or lack of water to the root could cause this.

If the browning is confined to this face of the tree, I suggest it may be the fact that a portion of the roots are covered by the concrete sidewalk. If you irrigate, try watering on the opposite side of the walk to encourage the roots to grow out to the moisture. The tree may need more water in general, and it would be very beneficial to have 3 to 4 inches of wood chip mulch out to and beyond the drip line of the tree. 

It does not appear serious, however, as extreme weather events become more common, you (and your tree) should be prepared. Try these suggestions and see if the symptoms dissipate over time.
answer.author: Lynne Marie Sullivan

symptom description: brown sections on one side of the tree
management instructions: Water on the opposite side of the sidewalk to encourage roots to grow out to the moisture.
Apply 3 to 4 inches of wood chip mulch out to and beyond the drip line of the tree.
Increase watering in general.

title: Another request to identify a succulent please??? #353593
question:
As mentioned in earlier questions, I live in Southern Spain and rarely see a plant labelled in the nursery/garden centre. Can I ask if anyone can identify this one for me? Growing well in direct sunlight and needs very little water. Recently flowered - tiny yellow flowers at the tip of the spike.

None of the Plant apps on my cell/mobile have identified anything I have photographed!

1.response:
These thin pencil-like plants are not easy to identify by sight. The two I know about you can tell apart by the sap. Caution: the white sap is toxic so don't get on skin or in eyes.
If it has white sap, it is a Euphorbia, likely Euphorbia tirucalli (Pencil Cactus or Pencil Tree). There are other pencil-shaped Euphorbia, so do an image search for those. Try terms "stick-like" or "tubular" as well.
Possibly the flower, the plant size, and branch/leaf size will tell help you tell them apart. Here is an information page from the University of Arkansas about the pencil cactus: http://www.uaex.edu/yard-garden/resource-library/plant-week/pencil-cactus.aspx
I thought the yellow flowers would help tell these apart, but the other plant this might be has yellow flowers too. To see photos, do an internet image search with the plant name and add "yellow flowers". The option that does NOT have white sap is one of the plants in the Rhipsalideae tribe of plants, Hatiora salicornioides. Your plant doesn't have the same joints on the stems, so I don't think this is the identification. Still, look at images online and see if they match the type of flower you saw.
1.author: Jacki Dougan

2.response: I have noticed that there is a thick, sticky white sap when a stem breaks and it is irritating to the skin. I have to wash my hands immediately if I get any on me. Thank you for your response. Looks as if you were spot on!! Much appreciated!
2.author: The Question Asker

species: euphorbia tirucalli (pencil cactus or pencil tree)

image description: tiny yellow flowers at the tip of the spike

title: Hercules beetle? #723127
question:
Hi, I was wondering what type of beetle this is. It was found in a parking lot on a drizzly September morning. It’s about 3 inches long. Is it a Hercules beetle? Is it native to Maryland? If not, is it invasive or problematic?
Thank you!

1.response:
This looks like a male Hercules Beetle. This is the largest beetle found in eastern North America and not considered invasive or a problem. They use the hollows of large trees and rotting logs for part of their life cycle.

Here is a page that explains more about them: http://bugoftheweek.com/blog/2019/12/16/a-giant-among-beetles-hercules-beetle-dynastes-tityus

Marian

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a coniferous tree that appears to be suffering from leaf discoloration and possible dieback. This condition could be indicative of several issues such as environmental stress, disease, or pest infestation. Here’s a recommended management strategy based on the provided background information:

1. **Assess the Cause**: Determine the exact cause of the leaf discoloration. Common causes include:
   - **Disease**: Check for signs of fungal or bacterial infections. Symptoms can vary but may include discoloration, browning, or wilting of leaves.
   - **Pests**: Look for signs of insect infestations such as spider mites, aphids, or borers which can cause leaf damage.
   - **Environmental Stress**: Assess if the tree is experiencing excessive heat, cold, drought, or excessive moisture. Ensure the soil is neither too dry nor waterlogged.

2. **Water Management**: Since the water in the ground is tested normal to wet, ensure the tree is not overwatered. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other issues. Monitor the soil moisture levels regularly and adjust watering as needed.

3. **Pruning**: If the tree has significant dead branches, prune them back to healthy wood. Pruning should be done when the tree is dormant to minimize stress and reduce the risk of disease spread.

4. **Fertilization**: Test the soil pH and nutrient levels to determine if fertilization is necessary. Apply appropriate fertilizers according to the test results to ensure the tree receives the correct nutrients.

5. **Consult an Expert**: If the issue persists after implementing these steps, consider consulting with a professional arborist who can provide a more detailed diagnosis and treatment plan specific to your tree's needs.

6. **Monitor Regularly**: Regular monitoring is crucial to detect any new issues early and manage them effectively. Keep track of the tree’s health and make adjustments as necessary.

By following these steps, you can help manage and potentially resolve the issues affecting the tree.

title: Will This Make Me Itch??? #588027
question: This is everywhere in my friend's yard.  Is it the itchy kind of sumac?  Wondering because we want to remove some of it.  Thanks!

answer.response: It appears to be tree of heaven, Ailanthus altissima. You should wear gloves when handling tree of heaven although most people will not have a reaction to it. You can confirm that it is tree of heaven and not sumac by crushing a leaf to smell it. Sumacs have a pleasant, citrusy scent and tree of heaven leaves smell like burnt peanut butter. Most sumacs are not poisonous. You can read more about controlling tree of heaven here, https://extension.psu.edu/tree-of-heaven.

title: Dogwood - Kousa Snowboy leaf discoloration #831217
question:
For the second year, our newly planted Kousa Snowboy has leafed in with curling leaves and discoloration on almost all leaf clusters. It get good moisture and very little direct sunlight. It is in open shade 95% of the day with only direct sun in late afternoon. the photos show the leaf discoloration from the top side and bottom side. I did find some insect silk under just a few of the leaf clusters as shown in one photo. I did not detect any silk in a larger percentage of the leaf clusters, and nearly all leaf clusters show discoloration and curling. There are more photos if that would be helpful. 

Thanks!

answer.response:
The leaf symptoms fortunately appear minor and resemble scorch, which is just physiological (as opposed to pest- or disease-caused) damage, likely from weather conditions or soil moisture fluctuations. It's good if the roots have stable access to moisture as dogwoods are not highly drought-tolerant (and our season to date has been drier than normal with periods of mild drought in much of MD). If you aren't already monitoring it for watering needs, just in case it's getting dry, feel the soil around six inches deep in the root zone and water well only if it's becoming somewhat dry to the touch at that depth. Dogwood leaf symptoms from over-watering or overly-wet soil often don't appear until the roots have been struggling for some time.

The silk is probably from a young or small spider and isn't a concern. The few silk-producing insect pests of dogwood don't appear this early in the season and would make a much more prominent silken "nests" from gregariously-feeding caterpillars, so would also be resulting in some defoliation. Dogwoods are vulnerable to a few leaf infections (more so the native species than the Kousa varieties) but this year most trees seem to have bypassed a significant infection event due to our drier spring weather. Even so, some leaf spotting could be due to comparatively minor fungal issues. A fungicide isn't warranted (nor can it cure any existing infection) and may risk harming pollinators or other organisms while also not guaranteed to work well, which is why we generally discourage their use. For now, just keep monitoring the tree for watering needs and feel free to send us updated photos if you notice worsening or different symptoms.

Miri
answer.author: Mira Talabac

answer.response:
Hi Miri,

Thanks so much for the detailed response! I will check the water level in the soil.

Cheers,

Bill

title: lawn weed #248199
question: Can you identify this weed?  The plant grows in my lawn every year.  In the early spring it looks just like fine turf grass like Titan or Rebel when they first come up.  It is nice and soft and blends in with the yard.  but as soon as it gets hot or dry it starts to die turning brown,  The patches usually are about a foot in diameter.  The roots are like tiny bulbs strung together.  The soil becomes dry and powdery so the roots break free very easily when pulled up.  Also, what can I do to get rid of it?  I am thinking of using a lawn patch product from Ortho, but I am afraid that the roots of this weed will sruvive and just choke out the new grass again next year.  I killed it off with round up a few years ago and it has slowly return.

1.response:
I cannot tell from the photo, but I suspect the culprit is annual bluegrass (Poa annua).  This grass is a winter annual that germinates in the fall, stays small through winter, grows and produces seed in the spring, and then dies when the heat of summer sets in.  Here is a link to photos and information:  http://oak.ppws.vt.edu/~flessner/weedguide/poaan.htm.  If this does not appear to be annual bluegrass, you can take a sample into your local Extension Office for identification.  Find your local office here:  http://www.ext.vt.edu/offices/index.html.

The best defense against annual bluegrass is a thick, healthy lawn.  So yes, do fill in those bare spots with a patch product, seed, or sod – just remember you will have to provide irrigation during the summer to these spots to keep the new grass alive and avoid bare spots in the fall where the annual bluegrass can grow again. 

Because this is a winter annual that produces seed that falls to the ground and germinates in August, you may consider making an application of pre-emergent herbicide to control at that time.  Here is a link to the Virginia Pest Management Guide recommendations:  https://pubs.ext.vt.edu/456/456-018/Section05-Lawn.pdf. Pages 5-22 and 5-18 &19.
1.author: Debbie Dillion

management instructions: Fill in bare spots with a patch product, seed, or sod.
Provide irrigation during the summer to these spots to keep the new grass alive.
Consider making an application of pre-emergent herbicide in August to control seed germination.

The patches are usually about a foot in diameter. The roots are like tiny bulbs strung together. The soil becomes dry and powdery so the roots break free very easily when pulled up. It was previously killed off with round up a few years ago and has slowly returned.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a patch of annual bluegrass, which is a common lawn weed that can be challenging to manage due to its ability to persist even after treatment. Here's a recommended management strategy:

1. **Preventive Measures**:
   - **Fertilization**: Apply a balanced fertilizer that includes nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium at appropriate rates and intervals to promote healthy turf growth and compete against weeds.
   - **Aeration**: Core aeration can help improve soil structure and reduce compaction, which aids in better water penetration and root development, making the lawn more competitive against annual bluegrass.

2. **Control Measures**:
   - **Regular Mowing**: Maintain the lawn at an appropriate height (typically 3 inches) to encourage deeper root growth and reduce the opportunity for weeds to establish.
   - **Mulching**: Apply a thin layer of mulch around plants and trees to help suppress weeds by blocking sunlight from reaching their seedlings.
   - **Irrigation**: Water the lawn deeply but infrequently to encourage deep-rooted grasses and reduce the spread of shallow-rooted weeds like annual bluegrass.

3. **Chemical Control**:
   - **Pre-Emergent Herbicides**: Use pre-emergent herbicides like pendimethalin or haloxyfop-potassium in the late winter or early spring to prevent annual bluegrass seeds from germinating. Apply these chemicals according to the manufacturer’s instructions.
   - **Post-Emergent Herbicides**: If the annual bluegrass has already germinated, use post-emergent herbicides such as glyphosate or triclopyr. These should be applied carefully to avoid harming desirable grasses. Always follow the label directions and consider applying during cooler temperatures and avoiding periods of drought or extreme heat.

4. **Cultural Practices**:
   - **Avoid Over-Sowing**: Avoid excessive seeding or over-fertilizing which can lead to a dense thatch layer that favors annual bluegrass.
   - **Dethatching**: Remove thatch buildup using a dethatcher if it becomes thick, as it can hinder proper nutrient absorption and water penetration.

5. **Mechanical Removal**:
   - **Hand Pulling**: Manually remove small patches of annual bluegrass. While time-consuming, this method can be effective for smaller areas.
   - **Cultivator**: Use a cultivator to loosen the soil and remove the roots of annual bluegrass, although this might require multiple passes to ensure all roots are removed.

6.

title: Identify this weedy grass and how to get rid of it #448523
question: It doesn't appear to be crabgrass.  It grows slightly elevated in mounds. Last year we had almost no crabgrass but more of these mounds.  How do we kill it off.  I thought about digging them out and planting grass seed.

answer.response:
Appears to be tall fescue, a turf type that is often found in small percentages in bluegrass seed mixtures because it is more drought tolerant, meaning if the lawn is stressed, the small tall fescue population would thrive.  When things go awry however, growing conditions can favorite it to multiply more robustly, becoming an  unsightly clump.  It has to then be physically removed or sprayed out with glyphosate (Round Up).  The clump can be dug out being careful to remove all root material lest it return, adding soil before reseeding.  If spraying know that    today's Round Up comes in different forms. After using the regular Round Up reseeding can take place 7-10 days later.  Avoid anything that says long lasting which would have a residual affect that would delay reseeding considerably.   You can read more about tall fescue here:
http://purdueturftips.blogspot.com/2015/03/weed-of-month-for-march-2015-is-tall.html

Good luck!
answer.author: John Harville

management instructions: physically remove
spray out with glyphosate (Round Up)
The clump can be dug out being careful to remove all root material lest it return, adding soil before reseeding.
reseeding can take place 7-10 days later after using the regular Round Up

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows patches of grass with what appears to be an overgrowth of crabgrass, which is a common problem in lawns. Crabgrass can outcompete other grass species like tall fescue, especially during warm weather. Here’s a recommended management strategy for the issue:

1. **Identification**: Confirm that the patches are indeed crabgrass by observing its characteristics such as its upright, coarse stems and the small, round seeds at the end of its branches.

2. **Prevention**:
   - **Mulch**: Apply mulch around plants and trees to reduce light reaching the soil, which can help prevent crabgrass from germinating.
   - **Proper Fertilization**: Maintain a healthy lawn by fertilizing regularly with a balanced fertilizer. Avoid excessive nitrogen, as it can promote rapid growth of crabgrass.
   - **Watering**: Water deeply but infrequently to encourage deep-rooted grass, which can compete better against crabgrass.

3. **Chemical Control**:
   - **Pre-Emergent Herbicides**: Use pre-emergent herbicides in late winter or early spring before crabgrass seeds germinate. These products work by preventing crabgrass seeds from growing into seedlings.
   - **Post-Emergent Herbicides**: If crabgrass is already established, use post-emergent herbicides. These products target existing crabgrass and should be applied when the crabgrass is actively growing.

4. **Physical Removal**:
   - **Hand Pulling**: Manually pull up crabgrass seedlings while they are young and before they set seeds. Be thorough to ensure you remove all roots.
   - **Tilling**: Till the affected areas to disrupt the crabgrass roots and seed bank. This is effective but can be labor-intensive and may damage the soil structure.

5. **Cultural Practices**:
   - **Regular Mowing**: Keep the lawn mowed at the recommended height (typically between 2.5 to 3 inches). This helps control crabgrass by shading the ground where it can germinate.
   - **Aerate the Lawn**: Aerating the lawn can improve soil health and allow grass to grow stronger and more vigorously, which can outcompete crabgrass.

6. **Maintenance**:
   - **Keep the Lawn Healthy**: Regularly inspect the lawn for signs of stress (e.g., yellowing, thinning) and address issues promptly. A strong, healthy lawn is less susceptible to crabgrass invasion.

By implementing these strategies, you can effectively manage and reduce the

title: Can you help me identify this weed? #795861
question: My neighbor has this plant growing wild in his flower bed. It has been spreading to my yard. Can you help identify and how I can control from growing in my yard. I have attached pictures of the plant and seedling that start popping up in my yard.

answer.response: I believe that is the common milkweed.  They do tend to spread with underground roots and by seed.  While they are young you can pull them.  Make sure to get the entire root.  Also, if you keep cutting them down, they will eventually die.  You can paint the leaves of the plant with a broadleaf weed killer but pulling/digging is probably best.
answer.author: Barbara Harlan

answer.response: The plant appears to be elderberry (Sambucus canadensis). Elderberry produces fragrant, white flowers in large flat-topped clusters in June and early July. Elderberry is native to Iowa.

question: We have branches from bottom up that loose needles. If we trim tree it continues to spread upward. There are galls on some trees. Most have black growths on dead branches. Trees are closely planted and mixed species. Affects mostly spruce.

answer.response: It looks like you could have needle cast disease. Colorado spruce are very susceptible. It isn't possible to make the trees grow needles back onto the limbs where they are gone. title: How to help my Sugar Maple #800308
question:
Hello,

We planted our Sugar Maple tree in the fall of 2020. Overall, it is doing pretty well. However, I believe it may have been sun scorched earlier this summer. (Pictures for reference) I was wondering if 1) This is indeed sunscorch and what to do to prevent further damage. And 2) If this is not sun scorch, what is wrong with the tree and how can I fix it? We love this tree and want to make sure it lasts for many years to come! Thank you for your insight and any advice you can give.

Also, the picture of the full tree is being taken from the south pointing north. So the left of the picture is the west side. It gets very windy sometimes and is in direct sun.

answer.response:
Hello Natalie,

Based on the images that you provided, I believe this is leaf scorch on your maple leaves

Quick Facts
• Leaf scorch can appear as leaf spots or a burn along the margin of the leaf.
• Improper watering is the common cause of leaf scorch.
• Too much fertilizer can cause leaf spots and marginal burning.
• Scorched tree leaves can drop prematurely.

Leaf scorch typically appears in July and August as a yellowing between leaf veins and along margins and browning of the leaf tips. Since these parts are the last to be supplied with water from the roots, they are usually the first to be affected. Leaves with scorched margins may look unappealing, but they still help the plant with photosynthesis, creating food for new, undamaged leaves to emerge. Resist the urge to remove scorched leaves.

Once leaf scorch has occurred, there is no cure. The leaves that have already turned brown will not recover, The dehydrated portions of the leaf will not turn green again, but with proper water management, the tree may recover. Prevention of scorch needs to begin with winter watering. BUT as long as you water it properly, the rest of the tree should survive. Deep watering is recommended – a slow, deep soaking of the soil at the roots.

Links on Leaf Scorch:

Please read the section on Leaf Scorch in this MSUE Bulletin at this link: https://www.canr.msu.edu/uploads/files/MapleEnvironmentalStresses_MSUE-1213.pdf

http://plantclinic.cornell.edu/factsheets/physiologicalleafscorch.pdf

https://extension.colostate.edu/topic-areas/yard-garden/leaf-scorch-2-911/

If you want to get a confirmed diagnosis from the MSU Plant and Pest Diagnostics Lab on the MSU campus (Just to make sure it is NOT Bacterial Leaf Scorch)

Please e-mail your images to the MSU Plant and Pest Diagnostics Lab on the MSU campus. Prior to bringing or sending physical samples. Images can be sent to pestid@msu.edu.

MAKE SURE IN THAT E-MAIL YOU INCLUDE YOUR NAME, ADDRESS, AND PHONE NUMBER!!

They may be able to ID your problem without seeing a sample. A lot has to do with the quality of your images and yours look good!!


THE LAB WILL LET YOU KNOW IF A SAMPLE NEEDS TO BE SENT - There is a $20-25 dollar fee (if they need a sample sent).
Lab phone: 517-355-4536
Hours of operation: Monday through Friday, from 8:00 AM to 5:00 PM.

PLEASE READ BELOW ON PREPARING YOUR SAMPLE

From the lab: Please do not ship samples on Fridays. Due to the current COVID-19 circumstances, please allow additional processing time. They thank you for your patience and understanding.


Every sample must be accompanied by a completed submission form. Please place the form in a separate resealable bag to prevent it from getting damp or soiled. The form is at this link:
https://www.canr.msu.edu/pestid/uploads/files/MSU-DS-Form-012-001-version6.0.pdf


Complete details of submitting a sample are at this link: https://www.canr.msu.edu/pestid/submit-samples/

Another option (more expensive), you may want to hire a certified arborist. Certified arborists have training in plant selection, care, diseases/pests; and have passed a certification test. They can do an onsite evaluation of the tree. You can find certified professionals in your zip code here: https://www.treesaregood.org/findanarborist/arboristsearch

Hope this helps - Thanks for using our service!! Any other questions, please let me know!!
answer.author: Melville Kennedy

symptom description: burn along the margin of the leaf
management instructions: Deep watering is recommended – a slow, deep soaking of the soil at the roots.
Resist the urge to remove scorched leaves.
Proper water management can help the tree recover.

title: Murder hornet? #641757
question: I found this in my backyard I took a few photos and a video and took screenshots from the video

answer.response:
Hi - This is a European Hornet, a long-established, non-native insect in our area. Queens of this species emerge from overwintering shelters in the spring to disperse and start new nests for the season. While this is a large wasp in general, queens are even larger than their workers and thus can be quite startling.

The recent news reports on the Asian Giant Hornet (Vespa mandarinia) have triggered a wave of concerned ID requests. The only confirmed sightings of this species were in Washington State and British Columbia, Canada, not in our region. The Maryland Department of Agriculture is monitoring for this pest. It has not been found in Maryland or anywhere in eastern North America.

Here are several pages with more information on both species:

https://extension.umd.edu/hgic/topics/european-hornets

https://extension.umd.edu/hgic/topics/asian-giant-hornet

Christa

title: Possible Spongy Moth Infestation #871445
question: Hello! I am a resident of Esopus, NY. I am abroad right now, but I'm submitting this on behalf of my dad who is home. This year he has noticed a lot of caterpillars. They've been eating plants in the garden and one of our large black walnut trees has been completely defoliated and others have been partially. I think it is the Spongy Moth but I'd like to confirm. I would also like to know what can be done to control the infestation and how we can help the trees, both ones that are already impacted and others nearby. I am particularly worried about the one that has been completely eaten. Black walnuts have a very short season to photosynthesize and it does not have a single leaf left on it. I've attached some photos of the caterpillar and the damaged trees. Thank you!

answer.response:
Hi Lauren

Yes, spongy moth is terrible this year. From what we understand, we are in year two of a three year cycle. I'm so sorry to hear about your dad's black walnut. 

I've attached an information sheet with some suggestions for managing the infestation (though it's very difficult since even if you're managing them, they will still migrate in from your neighbors). With any luck, the infestation may be over by the end of June, fingers crossed.

Keeping your trees as healthy as possible is important at this time, so deep watering during dry spells this summer and fertilize your trees. This can help during next summer when we most likely will experience another round of the infestation (bad news, I know).

Thank you,

Catherine

Cornell Master Gardener Volunteer

keep trees as healthy as possible

title: pond weeds #205258
question:
These plants appeared in our pond this spring.  They are growing rapidly.
What kind of plant are they? Will they be a problem? How can we get rid of them?

answer.response:
Hi,

Based on your photos you have variable leaf pondweed. It's a little tough to tell, because the plant picture is short on details I need for a positive ID. If you can, you might want to contact http://www.miseagrant.umich.edu/people/brandon-schroeder/ at Michigan Sea Grant and he might have more local details and be able to assist with plant ID. Be sure of the ID - If you aren't treating the right plant with the right material, you are wasting your time and money.
I'm pretty sure about the pondweed ID, and it is a native plant that is great for fish habitat and pond health. If you feel the need to control the amount (a healthy pond will have 30% native vegetation to support fish and wildlife), you can treat with herbicides. However, that is like cutting grass, and is not a permanent fix. Long-term, we find most plant problems are nutrient problems. A vegetated buffer of 6-10 feet is desirable rather than cutting to the edge of the pond to intercept runoff and nutrients. Resident Canada goose populations will add lots of bacteria and nutrients and should be discouraged. Fertilization of lawn areas around the pond is not a good idea, and should be avoided. for more information on pond ecology and plant management, visit http://extension.psu.edu/natural-resources/water/ponds. The permitting information is not useful for Michigan, for that, speak to Brandon, but the plant management information all applies.
In general, pondweeds can be limited by using a shading agent in the spring (when most management should begin) like Aquashade. Aquathol-K, Komeen, Reward/Weedtreen-D, and Sonar all work on pondweeds, but I don't know which ones are approved in Michigan. Treat no more than 1/3 to 1/2 of a pond at a time if you have heavy vegetation to avoid fish kills from depleted oxygen.
answer.author: Diane Oleson

management instructions: Treat with herbicides.
Create a vegetated buffer of 6-10 feet to intercept runoff and nutrients.
Discourage resident Canada goose populations.
Avoid fertilization of lawn areas around the pond.
Use a shading agent in the spring like Aquashade.
Treat no more than 1/3 to 1/2 of a pond at a time if you have heavy vegetation to avoid fish kills from depleted oxygen.

Regularly introduce fish species to eat the weeds
agmmu_question.answer: Use a shading agent like Aquashade in the spring

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows Variable Leaf Pondweed (Potamogeton crispus), which is a type of aquatic plant that can grow rapidly and become invasive in ponds and other bodies of water. In Alpena County, Michigan, as observed on August 7, 2014, the presence of this species can be problematic due to its tendency to outcompete native vegetation, alter water flow, reduce oxygen levels, and potentially affect fish habitat.

Here are some recommended management strategies for controlling Variable Leaf Pondweed:

1. **Mechanical Removal**: This involves physically removing the plants from the water using specialized boats equipped with rakes or other tools designed for aquatic vegetation. This method can be effective but may need to be repeated multiple times depending on how quickly the plant regrows.

2. **Chemical Control**: Herbicides such as diquat or chlorpyrifos can be used to control Variable Leaf Pondweed. These chemicals are typically applied in the early stages of growth to minimize the risk of drift onto nontarget areas. However, it's crucial to follow all label instructions carefully and consider the environmental impact before application.

3. **Biological Control**: Introducing biological controls like certain types of algae or insects that feed on the pondweed can help manage the plant population. However, this approach requires careful consideration and should be evaluated by experts to ensure it does not have unintended negative effects on the ecosystem.

4. **Preventative Measures**: Implementing practices such as creating buffer zones around the pond with native vegetation can help prevent the spread of pondweed into the water. Additionally, maintaining good water quality through proper waste management and limiting nutrient runoff can also help deter the growth of invasive aquatic plants.

5. **Physical Barriers**: Installing physical barriers such as underwater netting or floating barriers can help contain the spread of the pondweed by preventing it from moving further into the pond.

Given the rapid growth observed in the image, a combination of mechanical removal and chemical control might be the most immediate and effective approach. It's important to consult with local aquatic weed management professionals or state agencies to ensure the chosen methods are appropriate and compliant with local regulations.

Avoid fertilization of lawn areas around: **Physical Barriers**: Install physical barriers such as underwater netting or floating barriers to contain the spread of the pondweed.

title: rose bush apical meristem death and flower deformation #353108
question:
hello, I have nearly 100 rose bushes and this summer, for the first time, they almost all are showing these symptoms: curled leaflets on leaves adjacent to the apical meristem, death of the apical meristem (and 1-3 buds below the apex), deformed flowers, and deformed flowers growing on very short side shoots. The flowers that do form are smaller then before. I've had rose curculio weevils for the past two years and have been controlling them as possible by picking them off the plant. I have not seen any weevil larvae or adults for several months. I have bark mulch under my bushes as of last year and have not replenished the mulch this year. I have black spot and septoria on pretty much all my roses, and rust and sooty mold on a few. I try to control these through garden hygiene, as commercial systemic fungicides did not work last year.

What could be causing the deformed flowers and apical death? I am pruning the affected canes back to the first healthy bud and removing deformed flowers as soon as they are noticed. All rose debris is sent off site and not mulched or used in the garden.

answer.response: I have been doing lots of research on rose pests and diseases and I am thinking you may have rose midge. These critters lay eggs in the forming buds and would not be visible until they got larger and you cut into the rose tissue to look for them.  They can cause the bud distortion as you describe.  I also read about your already known problem with rose curculio and the leaf spot diseases.  The photos you sent seem to rule out major leaf spot issues.  Rose midges emerge from the tissue and drop to the ground to pupate in the ground and as such can be very difficult to control.  What I recommend is that you bring multiple samples to your OSU County Extension Office for a Master Gardener to look at.  Your photos are good but do not provide the magnification to allow a specific identification of the issue.  Since you seem to have a lot of issues, rose curculio, septoria, rust and blackspot, I think it wise to bring in samples so that what is going on with your roses can be definitively identified.  Continue to remove the diseased tissues, I would take the further step of sealing the debris in plastic to prevent escape and return to your garden prior to removal from your property.  Do not throw  debris into yard waste containers but into the trash.  Some rosarians go so far to put down a barrier to ‘catch’ the rose midges before they enter the ground to prevent them from pupating.  Since you have so many plants you will want to make sure of the identification before taking such measures.  After identification, the Master Gardeners should be able to provide you with information on controlling what is attacking your roses.  They can also discuss fungicide use with you to deal with your fungal issues.
answer.author: Debra Lauer

image description: curled leaflets on leaves adjacent to the apical meristem
deformed flowers growing on very short side shoots
management instructions: prune affected canes back to the first healthy bud
remove deformed flowers
seal debris in plastic to prevent escape and return to garden
do not throw debris into yard waste containers but into the trash
consider putting down a barrier to catch rose midges before they enter the ground

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The plant species visible in the image is Lysimachia nummularia, commonly known as moneywort or creeping Jenny. This species can be highly invasive in aquatic environments, particularly in slow-moving streams like those found in the Gunpowder River system in Maryland. The management strategy for invasive plants like Lysimachia nummularia in aquatic systems should focus on preventing its spread and reducing its presence in natural waterways.

Here are some recommended management strategies:

1. **Physical Removal**: Manually remove the plants from the stream bed and surrounding areas. Care must be taken to avoid disturbing the streambed too much, which could lead to erosion or harm aquatic life. It is often best to remove small patches at a time and to contain the removed plants rather than simply discarding them back into the stream.

2. **Chemical Control**: Herbicides can be used to control Lysimachia nummularia. However, chemical treatments should be applied with caution to avoid harming other plants or aquatic organisms. Always follow label instructions carefully and consider the environmental impact of using chemicals. Treatment may need to be repeated if the plants regrow.

3. **Biological Control**: Introducing biological controls, such as specific insects or diseases that target Lysimachia nummularia, might be an option. This approach requires careful evaluation and monitoring to ensure that the introduced organism does not cause unintended ecological harm.

4. **Preventive Measures**: To prevent the spread of Lysimachia nummularia, it is crucial to manage the surrounding vegetation and maintain healthy native plant communities. Native plants can help stabilize the streambank and provide habitat for beneficial insects and other organisms, which can help suppress invasive species.

5. **Educational Outreach**: Educating landowners and property managers about the dangers of invasive species and the importance of responsible management practices can help reduce the introduction and spread of Lysimachia nummularia and other invasive species.

6. **Stream Restoration**: Restoring the stream ecosystem by removing excess sediment, improving water flow, and enhancing riparian vegetation can make the environment less favorable for invasive species and more suitable for native flora and fauna.

In summary, a combination of physical removal, chemical control, and preventive measures, along with educational outreach, would be effective in managing the spread of Lysimachia nummularia in the Gunpowder River system. It's important to work closely with local environmental agencies and conservation groups to develop and implement a comprehensive management plan.

incorrect.**Physical Removal**: Manually remove th: If it is in the water, you cannot use a broadleaf weed killer that is sold for land plants.

title: How to get rid of yellow jackets  #804805
question: We have what looks like yellow jackets between a rock and the base of a very large oak tree. We tried peppermint oil with no luck. We did not want to harm the tree. Any suggestions? Thx

1.response:
If you cannot avoid the area until the Yellowjackets are gone, then a wasp spray is the best solution to kill the nest workers. It will not harm vegetation if used as directed on the product label. If you can give the nest a wide berth and prefer not to use pesticides, you can leave them alone and the nest will die out by winter (they don't re-use them the following year).

Miri

title: I just had a swarm of bee... #325993
question: I just had a swarm of bees arrive at my house last night. They are hanging in a tight wad about a foot from the ground.  What do I need to be aware of

1.response:
These honey bees are only resting there temporarily while they seek a new home. If you leave them alone they should not bother anyone, and they should be gone in a few days.  Your main concern might be that if your home has any gaps or holes in the siding, the swarm might decide to move into your wall.   If this happens,  they can be very difficult to remove. 

If you would like to find to have the swarm relocated, you can find a local beekeeper to help you:
http://www.ohiostatebeekeepers.org/associations/local-associations/

title: What type of invasive tree is this? #596318
question:
Hi,
I have a large fast growing tree on my lot line. I have never seen its seeds, or if there is a neighboring tree with seeds but smaller seedlings are sprouting everywhere in my yard and I actually moved them from the lawn to various places in my yard as my husband told me they are beech trees. Well, they are not beech trees. The bark is not smooth. I tried many plant identification apps but I can't find an exact match.

INFO: The Leaves pictured are from a 4 ft seedling. Some of the leaves are 7 inches long. The leaves are opposite each other and staggered and have serrated edges. The top side of leaf is very coarse. The bottom of the leaf is smoother and a bit lighter. The large tree is probably 50 ft tall and has one straight trunk. HELP! I need to know if I planted a problem species everywhere so I can pull them up before its too late.

answer.response:
There are several distinguishing features of the leaves that would seem to point to a beech tree (short petiole, leaf length, parallel venation, toothed (dentate), etc.)  If I understand correctly you have ruled that out due to a course barked tree nearby yet you also indicated there are other trees in the area. Do you notice any debris from the trees (like beech nut) or other seed structures?  A picture of the nearby, fast growing tree could and other trees could assist in the identification.  There may be some details not apparent in the pics. A closer view of a leaf and of a branch could help. 
I look forward to your response,
answer.author: Barry Andersen

answer.response: It has coarse bark and the top of the leaf is course. I do not see a similar tree in neighboring yards. I have not seen any nuts. I will try to get a closer picture of the branch and leaves. The tree's branches and leaves are quite high up so I can reach them. I will try to use a pole saw and get a piece down. A beech I would welcome. I am afraid it is an Elm.
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
I believe you are correct about it being an elm. Siberian elm is a distinct possibility. Two things don’t seem to fit; the seven inch leaves and the offset where the leaves meet the petiole. The immature leaves may not have the offset. Siberian elm can also hybridize with red elm. Check out the link:
https://www.minnesotawildflowers.info/tree/siberian-elm
answer.author: Barry Andersen

answer.response: The Siberian is an invasive too and have weak wood. I don't know what this means: "offset where the leaves meet the petiole" . I do know these leaves are symmetrical at the base and most elm pictures I see are not symmetrical. There are many holes in the leaves of the large tree as something likes to eat on it. I don't see that with other elms in the area. I may have to wait for seeds to know what this tree and its seedlings are. If it is a Siberian Elm I am pulling the seedlings out.  I did see one butternut husk in my yard near the tree and I got excited but I see Butternuts have leaves that are not staggered. https://www.mortonarb.org/trees-plants/tree-plant-descriptions/siberian-elm-not-recommended
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Here are some leaves from one Siberian Elm. Notice the differences in serration and the offset/asymmetry on the base of some of the leaves whereas some leaves appear symmetric. Also note the size of the leaves. These trees frequently drop limbs and are infested with european elm flea weevils.  Check out the following links:
https://www.illinoswildflowers.info/trees/plants/sb_elm.html
https://www.minnesotawildflowers.info/tree/siberian-elm
(https://www.canr.msu.edu/news/elm_trees_attacked_early_in_season_by_european_elm_flea_weevils).
answer.author: Barry Andersen

answer.response:
I have found some big green lobed nuts that appear to be Hickory nuts under the tree today but there is no way this could be a Hickory as the leaves are not identical across from each other. :(

So should I pull all the seedlings? No one is likely to have a use for them? I hate killing trees when there is such a lack of trees.

answer.response: Your picture looks very much like an elm! How long are the leaves?

title: Bark chewed almost all the way around on Burning Bushes #790349
question:
1. Is there any hope for these bushes? they seem to be green at the moment.
2. Is there anything that can be done to nurse them through this assault on the bark?
3. They had been left alone for many years and this year, the bunnies attacked 3 of our bushes.  Should we be protecting them through the winters from animals?
4. We have also planted butterfly weed as well maybe 3 times in the past 3 yrs. If bugs aren't eating them, then the animals are.  But other neighbors grow it with no issue.  What are we doing wrong? We planted a beautiful orange color but now looking for something more hardy and less delectable to animals.  Any ideas for a drought resistant, sunny, salt resistant (culdesac) and not delicious to bunnies or deer?
Thanks

1.response:
If that bark is gone all the way around, your shrubs will die.  Nutrition will not be able to travel from the roots to the top.  If the other side of those stems is still whole, the shrub will probaby survive but struggle.  Yes, your shrubs should be protected by fencing during the winter.  I surround my foundation planting yews with poultry wire each fall to prevent rabbits from nesting under them and eating the bark.  I just removed my fencing last week.  As far as your butterfly weed (Asclepias tuberosa), it should have been okay.  It is not a preferred plant for animals.  Please read through this article to see what has happened that you can correct.  
How to Grow and Care for Butterfly Weed (thespruce.com)
You could also try Yarrow or Nepeta (Catmint).  Both of these perennials are not so tasty and forgiving of growing conditions.
1.author: Barbara Harlan

symptom description: bark chewed almost all the way around
management instructions: protect the shrubs by fencing during the winter
use poultry wire to prevent rabbits from nesting under the shrubs and eating the bark

question: Can anyone help us ID these seeds. They were found near the area where tomatoes were growing in my niece's garden in Eagle River, Alaska. 1.response:
These look like chokecherry seeds, from the European bird cherry (aka May Day) or the Canada red chokecherry (leaves turn purple mid season).  Attached is a picture of these seeds. The seeds you have pictured are darker, but I think that is because the seeds in my picture were cleaned thoroughly. Your seeds could be from another chokecherry or small fruited cherry shrub.  Differentiating the seeds between species of chokecherry is difficult, and I am most familiar with the first European and Canada Red because they are considered invasive species.  The picture I attached includes both of these species to aid in differentiation. 

These could  have gotten there from a nearby tree that dropped seeds and fruit, birds perching after eating, or rodents that are storing them.

title: Broad leaves weeds #646660
question: Took a photo but will not send. can not get rid of these +broad leaf +weeds in central NY. Only way is digging. Too many. Used Scott Dandelion and Weed killer but does not work even different strengths.Is there another brand that will work Sorry Safari will not take my photo.

1.response:
Hi,

Without seeing the weed it is difficult to give a suggestion of how to control it. There are many stubborn broadleaved weeds. Usually persistence is necessary. You might have to use a combination of digging up the larger ones and using herbicides on the smaller ones. Herbicides need to be applied when plants are actively growing and follow the directions about whether or not, it should be watered in. Most weeds are actively growing this month so June is a good time to apply a broadleaved weed killer. If you applied it earlier, it might have been too cold for a lot of active growth to occur. Perhaps you could bring the weed down to a large, local garden center that sells lawn care products. Maybe someone could identify it for you and recommend which herbicide to use.
1.author: Dawn Pettinelli

management instructions: Use a combination of digging up the larger ones and using herbicides on the smaller ones.
Herbicides need to be applied when plants are actively growing and follow the directions about whether or not, it should be watered in.
Bring the weed down to a large, local garden center that sells lawn care products for identification and herbicide recommendation.

The image depicts three individuals enjoying a casual outdoor gathering, possibly a social event or a community meet-up. However, the background information provided pertains to a gardening or landscaping issue rather than a social one. The problem described involves the presence of broad leaf weeds in Onondaga County, New York, specifically around the time mentioned (June 5, 2020).

Given the information about the failure of Scott Dandelion and Weed Killer at various strengths and the abundance of weeds that cannot be easily dug up, here are some general recommendations for managing broad leaf weeds:

1. **Physical Removal**: If possible, hand-pull the weeds while they are small. This can be effective for smaller areas.

2. **Mulching**: Apply a thick layer of organic mulch over the soil to smother the weeds. This blocks sunlight from reaching the weed seeds and roots, preventing them from growing.

3. **Herbicides**: Consider using selective herbicides designed for broadleaf weeds. Always follow the instructions on the product label carefully as different herbicides have different application rates and conditions.

4. **Pre-emergent Herbicides**: These prevent new weeds from emerging by blocking the germination of seeds. They need to be applied before weeds start to grow.

5. **Post-emergent Herbicides**: These kill already existing weeds. Make sure to apply them when the weeds are actively growing and the weather conditions are suitable for absorption into the plant tissue.

6. **Biological Control**: Some species of fungi and bacteria can control certain types of weeds. These products may be available for use on ornamental plants.

7. **Cover Crops**: Planting cover crops like clover or alfalfa can help suppress weeds by competing for resources and creating a dense ground cover.

8. **Regular Maintenance**: Keeping the area well-maintained with regular mowing and weeding will help reduce the seed bank of weeds.

It's important to note that the effectiveness of these methods can vary depending on the specific type of weeds, environmental conditions, and the overall health of the plants you are trying to protect. Consulting with a local Extension Service or horticulturist might provide more tailored advice based on your specific situation.

title: Azalea problem? #854118
question: What is this? What can I do about it? Image attached.

answer.response:
This is azalea leaf bug, a sucking insect,   Stephanitis pyrioides.  Drought stressed plants are more susceptible to lace bug attack. Azaleas in the sun are reported to be nearly twice as likely to be infested. There are azaleas that show some resistance to azalea lace bug. High pressure water applications directed at leaf underside may dislodge the wingless nymph stages.
There is full information on this insect at this OSU website:

title: Arizona Ash damaged in 2021 Winter Freeze #753090
question:
Hi,

My name is layne and I live in Lakeway, TX.  I have attached a picture of a tree in my back yard.  I am pretty sure it is an Arizona Ash tree.  After our drastic freeze this past winter, the buds on the limbs really took a hit and have not leafed out.  However, as you can see on the trunk and lower limbs there are a lot of sucker branches growing. There is no green foliage in the upper part of the tree.  (it looks like there is but that is a branch from another tree)

I am considering having the 4 or 5 large vertical limbs cut off above where the suckers are.  Is this advisable or should I just have the entire tree removed?

Thanks,

Layne Thomas
512-261-8922

1.response:
Hi Layne,
It is taking a long time for some trees to recover from the freeze - and frankly, I am not sure that anyone knows exactly how long it will take. Nevertheless, sections that have not leafed out by now are most likely not going to do so.
I would not cut down the whole tree, since the roots are clearly intact and you seem to have strong growth near the bottom. However, you need to establish whether the tree section above the current growth is dead or alive. If you are able to get above the current growth, you may want to try and scratch back the bark to see if it is green underneath. You could also try cutting one of the smaller branches to see if it is dead (dry and brown) or showing signs of life (green and moist).
If the top section of the tree is dead, it should be removed or it will rot and become a danger-risk. You can always leave the lower section. It may take a couple of years to recover, but it would seem a better option than losing the whole tree.

Liz

title: White patches on my lawn #591753
question: White patches on my lawnThis white substance just showed up on all the bare spots of our lawn. It is all in the shade. What is it and how should I treat it?

answer.response:
Thanks for the question.

I am intrigued by the shape and distribution of these white patches.  I also find it interesting that they rather quickly appeared.  This is not what I would expect if it was some type of fungal disease.  Did you have any heavy rain storms just before the appearance of these spots?

Many thanks!!
answer.author: Steve Hedman

answer.response: Yes there have been several heavy storms. It rained again last night. Some areas seem to have cleared a little, but others have not. When I touch the substance it appears to be light brown and feels like fine green sand. The worst part is underneath are very large dying ash tree. We also have a dog But don’t see how that just affects the bare spots.
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Thanks for your response.

Here’s my guess.  What you are observing are the remains of recent rain runoffs.  It looks as if your latest picture shows a rock mulch.  If so, I do not know what type of rock.  My guess would be some type of limestone.  Read this from:  https://www.landscapedesigns.bz/archives/V17-gravelmulches.htm

“Limestone gravels such as White Marble, Washed White, Lime Screenings, Roadway gravels and most other light colored gravels in this part of the country are composed primarily of Calcium Carbonate aka Limestone. While this is the cheapest stone you can purchase in this part of the state, it also dissolves quite rapidly when exposed to water. Since our rainfall is slightly acidic, the limestone reacts with our rain and melts the stone. If you don’t realize how quickly this actually happens, take a look at the new rock outcrops along a new highway and then look again a few years later. As the stone dissolves, cavities result, some expanding to become very large, such as the Cave of the Mounds. Didn’t you ever wonder where the limestone gravel or sand went that allowed a cavity to form under your driveway? This disintegration of the limestone gravels under your walks, driveway, patio, and around your trees, shrubs and flowers changes the chemistry of the soil into an alkaline or higher pH medium.”

Please correct me if I’m wrong in my guess, but this would explain the rapidity with which these spots occurred.  Also if you look at the center and the right pictures that you initially sent, don’t the white spots resemble some type of water flow?

I will be very interested in hearing back from you to see if this explanation is plausible.  If correct, then we can discuss remedial steps.

Many thanks!!
answer.author: Steve Hedman

answer.response: I think you may be right. This is a picture of the type of rock or stone we have in the yard. Thanks for the help!
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Thanks for getting back to me.

I assume that you want grass to grow in these spots.  Assuming that this is leachate from the rock mulch, you may want to consider replacing it at some point.  This may or may not be a task you will want to do.  Generally we do not recommend the use of stone as a mulch due to, among other things, the problem that you now face.  Another drawback to rock mulch is that it can lead to overheating of the soil.

I assume that you will now want to repair these white areas with grass.  You will be faced with two issues, one minor and one probably significant.

1).  The minor one is that this leachate contains carbonate compounds which could potentially raise the soil pH.  Since soil has great buffering potential, any pH increase would probably not be significant.

2).  The major one is that there has been an increase in the salt content of the soil under these areas.  Unless dealt with, it may be difficult to grow grass again in these spots.

A few years back I had to deal with a similar problem of yours when a large bag of fertilizer spilled onto my yard.  Based upon my experience with that, I would suggest doing the following:

1).  Do NOT attempt to rake these areas as this will only mix the salts into your soil  Rather get a wet/dry shop vac and vacuum these areas.  It sounds strange but it will work.  After you are done doing this, you may have to clean or replace the air filter on the vac.

2).  Using a push-broom, brush these areas to sweep up any salt remaining on the surface of the soil

3).  Extensively water, water, water these areas so as to dilute remaining salts and wash them away.  Do this over a period of three or four days.

4).  Spread a layer of top soil over these areas to a depth of an inch or so.

5).  Reseed.  Now is an excellent time for grass seed to germinate and grow.

Let us know if you have any questions.

Good Luck!!
answer.author: Steve Hedman

symptom description: white patches on bare spots of lawn
white substance feels like fine green sand when touched
management instructions: Do not attempt to rake the areas.
Vacuum the areas with a wet/dry shop vac.
Sweep the areas with a push-broom to remove remaining salt.
Extensively water the areas over a period of three or four days.
Spread a layer of top soil over the areas to a depth of an inch or so.
Reseed the areas.

title: My redbud didn't bud this... #187357
question: My redbud didn't bud this spring and it's looking scraggly.  Can I do anything? Should I be worried?

1.response:
This was a very harsh winter for many reliable perennial plants.  We have had many reports of trees and shrubs that have survived a number of years, only to die, or show lots of die-back this spring.

Even though Cercis canadensis, or Redbud trees are occasional tree/shrubs here in Minnesota, most of their varieties are more solidly zone 4 or higher.   It is very probable that your tree simply couldn't handle the very cold temperatures, the deep frost and the wicked winds of the winter of 2013-14. http://www.treehelp.com/redbud/

I have two redbuds that were planted in 2005.  One of them survived for  two years.  The other has survived without any help (supplemental water, fertilization or mulching), but each year I see die-back on this tree.  At the same time, the Minnesota Arboretum has some spectacular specimens of Redbud trees that have survived for a long time but these trees are sheltered in a forest that may help to mitigate the cold winters.

You can, and should cut back all of the dead wood on this tree once you are certain that the branches are dead.  
https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:GVQLfefrVRMJ:hort.ufl.edu/database/documents/pdf/tree_fac...

Make sure that you are watering the tree until frost sets in this fall.
Mulch around the roots to the drip-line of the canopy with 4 inches of mulch - leaving a good 2-3 inches from the trunk free (don't pile mulch up against the trunk).

All that being said, if your tree doesn't leaf out soon I suspect that it is dead, or very nearly so. It will be very hard for this plant to recover.   You may want to replace it sooner rather than later. 
I hope this information is helpful.  Please contact AaE again if you have further questions.
1.author: Mary Courteau

management instructions: Cut back all of the dead wood on the tree once you are certain that the branches are dead.
Water the tree until frost sets in this fall.
Mulch around the roots to the drip-line of the canopy with 4 inches of mulch, leaving a good 2-3 inches from the trunk free.
qa_information.background info: The tree experienced a harsh winter with very cold temperatures, deep frost, and strong winds.

title: Hibiscus leaf & holes in leaves #874748
question: I’ve noticed holes in my 2 year hibiscus plant . I was wanting to ask would be using some neem oil be helpful ?

answer.response:
Lee Ann, 

Thank you for writing in with your question. I was trying to determine what insect could be causing the holes in your hibiscus. Other than the relatively few holes, the plant looks healthy. I'll start by ruling out certain pests.

Two common pests of hibiscus and many other plants are aphids and spider mites, but neither of those cut holes into the leaves.  https://extension.umn.edu/houseplants/hibiscus Another pest is the hibiscus sawfly which also produces different damage. https://content.ces.ncsu.edu/hibiscus-sawfly Mealybugs are another possibility but again not likely. https://citybugs.tamu.edu/2017/08/07/mealybugs-hibiscus-common-summer/ Lastly, Japanese beetles will also damage hibiscus but they skeletonize the leaves which would look very different. See the image in this link. https://ask2.extension.org/kb/faq.php?id=772572

I also thought of leaf cutter bees. They like to cut holes in leaves to use in lining their nests and protect the eggs of their offspring. Most often though they cut multiple holes into a leaf. The bees are harmless and good pollinators. See this link for more than you may want to know. :-) https://entnemdept.ufl.edu/creatures/misc/bees/leafcutting_bees.htm#:~:text=Biology%20(Back%20to%20Top),pollen%20and%20a%20single%20egg.

You can certainly use Neem oil on your plant and you will not do any harm. However, as Master Gardener Volunteers we prefer know what were treating. My suggestion is to look at the underside of the leaves. Do you see any bugs? Is anything crawling on the plant. The images don't show anything but you were trying to capture the holes.  If you find anything, please write back and send images.

Thank you. Sincerely, Sabine
answer.author: Sabine Kuhn

management instructions: use Neem oil
look at the underside of the leaves for bugs
