title: Terrible orange scum on my cedar tree #449690
question:
I just discovered a disgusting orange scum growing on my cedar tree that looked healthy until this past week.  Can you identify what looks like fish roe growing on my tree?  See photos attached.

Sandy McGraw
2965 St. Peters Church Road, Waldorf, Maryland 20601
301-645-2973   sandymcgraw@comcast.net

answer.response:
Good Morning!
This is cedar apple/pear/quince rust (a Gymnosporangium rust disease) and is very common on cedar in the springtime. Members of the genus Juniperus (like Eastern red cedar and juniper) are a host of one of the life stages, like you are seeing now. The fungus doesn't really cause harm to cedars, but the spores from this stage are spread to apple, pear, quince, hawthorn, and related species where they can damage leaves and fruit. It is possible to prune out the fungus on the branches, but on large trees there would almost certainly be infections on areas that are out of reach for pruners. There is no practical way to manage it with chemicals. The best way to manage this disease is to plant varieties of apple, hawthorn, pear, ect that are resistant to rust. Again, this will not damage the cedar.
Check out the links below for more information.
https://extension.umd.edu/hgic/rust-diseases-trees-and-shrubs
https://www.extension.umn.edu/garden/yard-garden/trees-shrubs/cedar-apple-rust-and-gymnosporangium-r...
answer.author: Luke Gustafson

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a branch of a cedar tree with a large, orange, string-like growth that appears to be a type of fungus, possibly **Cedar Apple Rust** (Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae). This fungus is known to infect various conifer species, including cedars, and can cause significant damage if left untreated.

### Recommended Management Strategy:

1. **Identify the Type of Fungus**: Confirm the type of fungus present by consulting with a local extension agent or a professional arborist. Cedar Apple Rust can be identified by its distinctive orange fruiting bodies on the underside of leaves and branches during the spring and summer months.

2. **Remove Infected Parts**: If the infection is localized, you may need to prune out the infected branches. Use clean, sharp pruning tools and disinfect them between cuts with rubbing alcohol or a 10% bleach solution to prevent spreading the fungus to other parts of the tree.

3. **Prune for Ventilation**: After removing infected parts, prune the tree to improve air circulation around the remaining branches. Proper ventilation helps to reduce the humidity and moisture levels around the tree, which can slow the spread of the fungus.

4. **Apply Fungicides**: Consider applying fungicides specifically designed to control Cedar Apple Rust. Follow the manufacturer’s instructions carefully, as improper application can harm the tree. Fungicides can help manage the spread of the fungus but should not be relied upon as a sole treatment method.

5. **Monitor for Reoccurrence**: After treating the infected area, continue to monitor the tree closely. Cedar Apple Rust can reappear in subsequent years, especially if conditions favor its growth (high humidity, wet weather).

6. **Maintain General Tree Health**: Ensure the overall health of the tree by providing adequate water, proper fertilization, and protection from pests and diseases. A strong, healthy tree is better equipped to resist fungal infections.

7. **Consider Professional Advice**: If the infection is extensive or if the tree is stressed, it might be advisable to consult a professional arborist who can provide more tailored advice based on the specific condition of the tree.

By following these steps, you can help manage the issue and potentially prevent further damage to your cedar tree.

title: Invasive Red Insects on Plants, Soil and Landscaping #834873
question: What can I do to eliminate these insects without harming my plants.  Are these insects harmful to plants?

answer.response:
These are called Boxelder Bugs. They are a common native insect found on and around maple trees. Their feeding does not harm the trees or any other garden plants. There is no need to use any insecticidal treatment to control them. They are mainly a nuisance. If you find them bothersome, they can be hosed off or brushed off from areas where you see them (e.g., on house siding).

Christa

title: I am growing peaches but ... #137615
question: I am growing peaches but they have worms in them.  How do I keep the worms out?

1.response:
These worms are part of the life cycle of a beetle by the name of Plum curculio. Laying their eggs inside the skin of plums, peaches, apples, pears and other stone fruits, folding a flap of skin over the eggs. Once hatched the larvae eats its way to the center of the fruit.

Control by spraying with an insecticide during the late stages of the flower bloom, when the pedals begin to fall off through the shuck split.

I've pasted a link below for the fact sheet "Plum Curculio And Its Control" from OSU Extension office along with a picture of Plum curculio...

http://ohioline.osu.edu/hyg-fact/2000/2043.html

Thank you for submitting your question to "Ask an Expert" and good luck with your peaches!
1.author: Tom Allbright - MGV

title: Weed Overgrown  #786776
question: Can you please identify the his weed and give me advice on how to permanently get rid of it. It has taken over about 1000 sq feet of yard.

answer.response:
This is a healthy stand of ground ivy (aka Creeping Charlie, Glechoma hederacea). It is an introduced perennial species that reproduces both by seed and stolons (above ground stems that root at the nodes).

In the lawn, probably the best herbicide for creeping Charlie is triclopyr, which is marketed as many things, like Ortho Weed B Gon Chickweed, Clover, and Oxalis Killer (which comes in a ready to use hose application form or a concentrate to mix). Other lawn products that target broadleaves and contain 2,4-d, dicamba, and/or mecoprop can also suppress this weed, but triclopyr is more effective.

Here’s some specific info on triclopyr:
Triclopyr is a growth regulator/synthetic auxin herbicide (Group 4) that exhibits activity on annual and perennial broadleaf plants, vines, and woody plants and is most often used for control of brush and poison ivy in grass pastures, non-crop areas, right-of-ways, etc. Triclopyr will not injury grass when used at labeled rates. Triclopyr is absorbed primarily by the foliage of plants but can also be absorbed by cut stems and roots. Injury symptoms associated with low rates of exposure include distorted growth, leaf cupping, stem and petiole twisting, stem swelling, chlorosis of the growing points, wilting, and eventual tissue death (necrosis). The death of the plant can take several weeks and in the case of well established perennials like this, it may take more than one application.

Triclopyr, like other Group 4 herbicides (e.g. 2,4-D, dicamba, mecoprop, etc.), is susceptible to movement via drift and volatilization, particularly when conditions are hot (85F+) and dry and/or breezy (winds greater than 7-10 mph). This is where you’d want to be careful to avoid injury to ornamentals nearby....usually it is lower growing things like vegetable gardens next to lawns is where we see issues with 2,4-d and dicamba. I believe that triclopyr is less volatile than both dicamba and 2,4-d. Triclopyr is mobile with water movement that occurs shortly after application (such as precipitation events and irrigation), so applying when dry weather is expected for several days would be advised to avoid it moving with water to unwanted areas.

Re-entry into treated areas by people and pets can occur once the product has dried (or according to the label if it specifies a different interval).

Always be sure to read and follow all labeled directions to ensure maximum effectiveness and personal and environmental safety.

After you have achieved your desired level of control the work isn’t over. You need to do two important things. 1) Make sure you have a robust/vigorous stand of grass in your lawn to create a competitive environment for weeds. Practices could include re-seeding areas where the grass stand is thin, fertilizing the grass (early-spring and/or early-fall), watering when conditions are dry, and increasing your mowing height (~3.5", this last one will not help with tall fescue but will help with broadleaves and stress management). 2) You need to be on the lookout for weeds emerging from seed. Some weeds can linger as seeds in the “seed bank” of the soil for decades! Controlling these weeds could include the use of a preemergence herbicide (e.g. products targeting crabgrass control) or manual removal of emerged plants. More information on lawn care from the MSU Turfgrass Team can be found on the following website: https://www.canr.msu.edu/home_gardening/lawns/

If you have any questions, please feel free to write back here or email me directly at hiller12@msu.edu
answer.author: Erin Hill

answer.response: One other follow up comment, it is likely too cold to apply any herbicides to control your ground ivy now. For these types of herbicides to most effective the target plant needs to be actively growing. We usually say that is when average temperatures are at or above 50F. Another way I like to think about it, once the grass is growing and people are mowing consistently, that is a good indicator that a herbicide will be absorbed and effectively moved throughout the plant to maximize effectiveness (and save you time and money).
answer.author: Erin Hill

management instructions: Use triclopyr, a growth regulator/synthetic auxin herbicide (Group 4) that exhibits activity on annual and perennial broadleaf plants, vines, and woody plants.
Apply triclopyr when dry weather is expected for several days to avoid it moving with water to unwanted areas.
Re-entry into treated areas by people and pets can occur once the product has dried.
After achieving desired level of control, ensure a robust/vigorous stand of grass in the lawn to create a competitive environment for weeds.
Be on the lookout for weeds emerging from seed and control them using a preemergence herbicide or manual removal of emerged plants.
Apply herbicides when the target plant is actively growing, usually when average temperatures are at or above 50F.

title: Weed ID #555406
question: Hi!  This creeping weed has been invading one of my flower beds for the past two years.  I've tried to identify it to no avail, although I'm afraid it does look a lot like gout weed.  Do you know what it is, and if so can you recommend an effective battle plan? It grows in a north-facing garden.  I avoid products such as RoundUp, and instead have been fighting it off with only temporary success by drenching it with boiling water and spraying it with Bonide Burnout.  Thank you for your assistance.  Cindy Howard

1.response:
Hello
From the photos, this plant does appear to be goutweed, i.e. snow on the mountain.
One method you can try is smothering with black plastic. If there is only the goutweed in the location that you want to kill, cover the area with black plastic and secure it. For best results, remove any green growth and leave the plastic in place through the summer.  Upon removing the plastic, you want to try to remove any of the dead plant parts, especially the rhizomes, i.e. underground stems, that may re-sprout if they get water and light. They are quite pervasive and the reason why this plant is so successful at spreading.

Here is a resource from the Plant Conservation Alliance that explains more about this weed: https://www.invasive.org/weedcd/pdfs/wgw/goutweed.pdf
1.author: rebecca krans

2.response: Aaaaaaargh, that is not at all what I was hoping to hear. :'(  Thank you so much for your advice and quick response.  I'd already considered the black plastic method but the bed contains a variety of perennials, plus shrubs and hardscape that the weed is weaving into.  From the link you attached it appears that glyphosate is the only effective alternative, do you agree?  Perhaps a combo of weed barrier where possible and very careful use of glyphosate everywhere else?
2.author: The Question Asker

3.response:
Given the proximity to desirable perennial plants, spot treatment with glyphosate alone or in combination with the non-permeable plastic barrier is likely the best option. Glyphosate is a systemic herbicide, so it will move within the plant for a more complete kill, unlike the boiling water and the more natural herbicide you mentioned earlier which only kill contacted tissue. The other advantage of glyphosate is that it has no activity once it reaches the soil due to binding with organic matter and clay particles and therefore replanting area is not an issue. Spot treating can be done by painting the herbicide on the goutweed using a sponge, brush, or rag to avoid drifting spray on to desired plants. There is also a product out called Roundup Precision Gel that looks like an oversized stick of deodorant that is designed for very targeted applications. Glyphosate is most effective for perennial control in the fall but can be applied anytime the plants are actively growing (temperatures consistently above 50F). Repeat applications with glyphosate may be necessary given the level of establishment that this population appears to have.

When using products containing glyphosate there are a few important points to consider. First, as with any pesticide, remember to read and follow all labeled instructions. Second, glyphosate is a broad-spectrum herbicide, meaning it will injure or kill other plants contacted during the application, so care is needed to avoid green plant material, exposed roots, and injured bark of desired plants. Third, be sure that the product you choose has only the active ingredient glyphosate or glyphosate + pelargonic acid. Products with additional active ingredients may have other unwanted effects and may delay the planting of other plants in the coming season(s).
3.author: Erin Hill

4.response: Thank you very much, I sincerely appreciate your assistance!  Happy spring!
4.author: The Question Asker

Remove any green growth and leave the plastic in place through the summer
Remove any of the dead plant parts, especially the rhizomes
Spot treatment with glyphosate alone or in combination with the non-permeable plastic barrier
Paint the herbicide on the goutweed using a sponge, brush, or rag to avoid drifting spray on to desired plants

title: Pine tree health #657169
question: We moved to the Pacific Northwest from last year. In our house there are 4 pine trees. In two of them, most of the leaves especially the lower branches seem unhealthy through spring, leaves and sticks are just not green at all. Can you advise on what to do or what kind of professional could help us with those trees?

answer.response:
Your trees look like they are suffering from drought stress. It's been hot and dry for the last 4-5 summers and many conifers are showing signs of stress from dry soil.

You might water the trees deeply several times this summer. Use a soaker hose or another form of slow/steady water distribution.

The dead/dying branches could be pruned out to make the trees look better.
Consult with a certified arborist for on-site advice. Get a quote from several companies. If you want to verify services, post another question here on Ask an Expert.
Good luck.
answer.author: Weston Miller

answer.response: Thank you.
answer.author: The Question Asker

management instructions: Water the trees deeply several times this summer.
Use a soaker hose or another form of slow/steady water distribution.
Prune out the dead/dying branches.

title: Bug identification #408141
question:
I am getting eaten alive by something in my house that seems to be located in my bedroom or bathroom.  At first I thought it was mosquitos because of the size and shape of the bites.  I have been seeing the insects in the attached pictures in my bathroom sink around the drain and also on the tiled bathroom floor near the toilet and shower.  The insects are about the size of a grain of fine-ground pepper and they might be mistaken for a fleck of dirt if they didn't move.  

Any ideas what these little beasties are, what is attracting them, and how I might be able to get rid of them?  Also, they don't seem to fly, but they do jump.  Could they be the source of the bites that are driving me mad?

Any help or guidance you might be able to provide would be greatly appreciated!  Thank you!

answer.response:
These insects are called springtails.
They do not bite.
Here is a page about them: http://extension.umd.edu/hgic/springtails
You may need to dehumidify the area.

title: Weed identification #395800
question: I have a invasive weed that can grow quite tall if left alone.  The roots 'travel' so the plant has been popping up everywhere.  It has a broad, veiny leaf and a hollow stem.  I have no idea how to get rid of it since pulling it out does not work.  What is this stuff and how do I get rid of it?

answer.response:
That is mile a minute vine. Here is a quote from Cornell University Extension on controlling it.
"Mile-a-minute weed can be controlled with commonly used herbicides in moderate doses. The challenge with herbicides is mile-a-minute’s ability to grow over the top of desirable vegetation, and spraying the foliage of only the mile-a-minute weed can be challenging. Pre-emergent herbicides (herbicides that prevent seed germination) can be used with extensive infestations, often in combination with spot treatments of post-emergent herbicides (herbicides applied to the growing plant) for seedlings that escape control. Small populations are better controlled with post-emergent herbicides"
answer.author: Eileen East

management instructions: Mile-a-minute weed can be controlled with commonly used herbicides in moderate doses.
Pre-emergent herbicides can be used with extensive infestations, often in combination with spot treatments of post-emergent herbicides for seedlings that escape control.
Small populations are better controlled with post-emergent herbicides

title: basswood linden #359889
question: My basswood has been dropping leaves this summer. If you look at the underside of the tree, the bottom side leaves have black spots. I had a tree removal guy tell me over the phone it was fungus and he has seen several cases this year. the picture below should clearly show the black dots. Is this indeed fungus? If so, what is the disease called? what steps should be taken to save the tree? Your assistance in this matter is greatly appreciated.

1.response:
This looks like linden leaf blotch. Yes, it is a fungus. These kinds of diseases do not usually pose a threat to the tree's health, unless a significant portion of the canopy is destroyed for two or three years in a row. We had a great deal of rain this year, so leaf spot diseases are popping up all over. I don't recommend any treatment except careful cleanup in the fall. Here is a reference:
http://www.extension.umn.edu/garden/yard-garden/trees-shrubs/management-of-leaf-spot-diseases/

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a plant with small, white flowers and green leaves, which appears to be a privet (Ligustrum). Privet is a common shrub that can grow rapidly and may become invasive if not managed properly, especially in locations like Anne Arundel County, Maryland, where it might outcompete native plants.

### Recommended Management Strategies for Privet:

1. **Hand Removal**:
   - Regularly remove any new growth by hand or using gardening shears.
   - This method is effective but labor-intensive and requires ongoing effort.

2. **Physical Barriers**:
   - Install physical barriers such as netting or mulch around desired plants to prevent privet from spreading roots into their vicinity.
   - This can help contain the spread of the plant and reduce competition for resources.

3. **Chemical Control**:
   - Use herbicides that target broadleaf weeds effectively.
   - Products containing glyphosate (e.g., Roundup) or triclopyr (e.g., Arsenal) can be applied to the foliage or soil around the base of the plant.
   - Apply herbicides carefully to avoid harming surrounding plants and wildlife.
   - Always follow the manufacturer’s instructions and local regulations regarding pesticide use.

4. **Cultural Practices**:
   - Maintain healthy, diverse native vegetation in the area to compete with privet.
   - Ensure that the soil is well-aerated and nutrient-rich to support the growth of native plants.

5. **Mechanical Methods**:
   - Regularly prune the plant to control its size and shape, which can help slow its spread.
   - Mulching heavily around the base of the plant can suppress its growth by reducing light penetration and competition for water and nutrients.

6. **Biological Control**:
   - Investigate and potentially introduce biological controls, such as insects or pathogens, that specifically target privet.
   - Consult with local extension services for appropriate options.

By implementing a combination of these strategies, you can manage the spread of privet and protect the biodiversity of your environment. Regular monitoring and maintenance will be crucial to ensure long-term success.

title: Flying beetles  #792572
question: What are these beetles? They have suddenly appeared and are attacking the leaves of my rose bushes, and other greenery. The insect almost appear to almost swarm. Further, how do I control them. We have not seen them previously.

1.response:
This is an adult rose sawfly. Larvae of this insect are a pest that defoliates roses. As the adults fly, it is challenging to achieve effective control. You will likely soon see the larvae, which can feed on the bushes. 

The larvae can be handpicked off or sprayed with an insecticide such as neem oil or insecticidal soap. Stronger broad-spectrum insecticides with the active ingredients of bifenthrin, cyfluthrin, malathion, or cabaryl will also kill larvae. However, these are moe likely to kill beneficial insects too.
1.author: David Lowenstein

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a small insect on a leaf of a plant that appears to be a rose bush. Given the context provided, it seems like the insect may be a pest affecting the rose bushes. Here's a recommended management strategy for the issue:

1. **Identify the Pest**: The insect in the image resembles a sawfly, which can be a common pest for roses. Sawflies lay their eggs on the leaves or stems of the plants, and the larvae feed on the leaves, causing significant damage.

2. **Physical Removal**: If the infestation is light, you can manually remove the insects by picking them off the leaves and stems. This method is effective for small populations but impractical for larger infestations.

3. **Use Insecticidal Soap**: For a more targeted approach, you can use insecticidal soap. This is a natural solution that disrupts the insect's waxy coating, leading to dehydration and death. Apply it as directed on the rose leaves and stems.

4. **Introduce Beneficial Insects**: Encourage the presence of beneficial insects such as ladybugs and lacewings, which prey on pests like sawflies. These beneficial insects can help control the population naturally.

5. **Apply Neem Oil**: Neem oil is another natural option that can be applied to the affected areas. It acts as a pesticide and also deters the insects from laying eggs.

6. **Monitor Regularly**: Keep an eye on the rose bushes regularly to monitor the pest levels and adjust your treatment plan accordingly. Early detection is key to managing pests effectively.

7. **Maintain Plant Health**: Ensure the rose bushes are well-watered and fertilized to maintain their overall health. Healthy plants are better equipped to resist pest infestations.

By implementing these strategies, you should be able to manage the sawfly infestation on your rose bushes effectively.

title: Quercus virginiana root / branch abnormality #388855
question:
i have seen in various young oak trees abnormal  woody structures in there branches (ball like) now i ve noticed it in a transplant tree roots, it had similar wooden aglomerate ball like structures, Can you identify what is the cause of it and is there a way we can try and stop this pest?
thank you.

answer.response: These "galls" are caused by insects.  The insects are usually tiny gall wasps, that lay there eggs in actively growing tissues.  The developing larvae then produce plant hormone-like substances that cause the tree tissues to encompass and protect them as the tiny wasps mature.  The holes are where the adult has emerged.  The insects are not considered harmful, and do not require any efforts to control them.  If the trees are not doing well, it is not likely caused by the wasps.
answer.author: David Appel

title: Killer hornet? #713303
question: My name is Roxanne Baird owner of Lake George Family Campground in Harrison and I think I killed a killer hornet. Sending you a picture to confirm if you could please let me know or direct me to someone who can help that would be great. Thanks 989-588-4075

1.response:
Hello Roxanne,

That is a Cicada Killer Wasp.

These spectacular insects are known scientifically as Sphecius speciosus (Hymenoptera: Sphecidae).  They are the largest wasp that occurs in Michigan.  They occur in all states east of the Rocky Mountains and prefer to dig their burrows in sandy, bare, well-drained soil exposed to full sunlight.  The wasps feed on flower nectar while the immature or larval stages feed cicadas that are provide to them by the female wasp.  Like other solitary wasps with no large colony to defend, cicada killers usually ignore people as they go about their business of digging holes and hunting for cicadas.  A mound of fine soil surrounds the burrow of each female cicada killer.  Since colonies of burrows are common, infested lawns usually contain several mounds that can smother the grass.  However, they prefer to nest in areas of sparse vegetation, and rarely infest thick, vigorous turf. 

Cicada killers overwinter as larvae in the soil.  Pupation occurs in the spring and the adults emerge in mid-June to early July.  Emergence continues throughout the summer.  Females feed, mate, and dig burrows for several weeks before hunting for cicadas in nearby trees.  Excess soil thrown out of the burrow forms a regular, U-shaped mound at the entrance. 

The females search tree trunks and lower limbs for cicadas.  The wasp stings its prey, turns the victim on its back, straddles it, and drags it or glides with it to the burrow.  Each burrow includes several cells where larvae are raised.  Each cell is furnished with at least one cicada (sometimes two or three) and a single egg before being sealed off.  Female eggs are provisioned with 2 or 3 cicadas while males are only get one.  As a result male cicada killers are much smaller than the females.  Males establish territories near nesting females and aggressively defend their territory from other intruding males.  The eggs hatch in 2-3 days.  Depending on the number of cicadas in its cell, the larva feeds for 4 to 10 days until only the cicada's outer shell remains.  During the fall, the larva spins a silken case, shrinks, and prepares to overwinter.  Only one generation occurs each year. 

Despite their large size and impressive stinger, cicada killers do not readily sting and one can stand amongst their burrows and watch them work without fear of being stung as long as one remains considerate and respectful, i.e., don’t try and catch one with their hands.  Most people I talk to however seem reluctant to get that close and would rather kill them off.  Cultural practices can prevent or eliminate the establishment of cicada killer colonies.  Adequate lime and fertilizer applications accompanied by frequent watering to promote a thick growth of turf and can usually eliminate a cicada killer infestation in one or two seasons.  For those not willing to tolerate the wasps, treating the nest openings with Sevin (spray or dust) will eliminate the wasps.  Be sure to read and follow all instructions and safety precautions found on the label before using any pesticide.

Read more than you will ever care to know about cicada killers at:

http://web.archive.org/web/20141022032916/http://sites.lafayette.edu/hollidac/research/biology-of-cicada-killer-wasps/

Regards,
Howard
1.author: Howard Russell

management instructions: cultural practices to promote thick turf growth
adequate lime and fertilizer applications
frequent watering
treating nest openings with Sevin

title: Juniper branches dying #793425
question:
A month ago i planted a hedge with Juniperus Cinensis Blue Point bushes. All the plants were very health looking when I bought them at Costco. They are about 4.5 ft tall and some of them were root bond so I pulled the roots apart when I planted them. 
The branches on many of them are starting to die. Most of the dead branches are on the bottom of the plant but some are in the middle. I have clay soil so I did amend with compost. I have not watered too much because the soil holds moisture. 
What do I do?

answer.response: I found one warning when researching "The Blue Point Juniper is super easy-going and adapts well to a variety of different types of soil. The only soil feature that is an absolute no-go for this tree is poor drainage."  You say you amended with compost.  I hope you used quite a bit and mixed it well with your clay.  It is too late to say wrong plant/wrong place but you seem to be very aware of the challenges.  Your shrubs may be suffering transplant shock as they were quite large when you planted them and you did mention some were root bound.  Try digging a small hole in the mixed soil and add water.  See how long it takes to drain.  If it just sits there without draining, you still have a problem.  If it is gone within a couple hours, your additions have helped.  It may be that you will have to allow them to adjust.  Later you can trim the brown portions (the needles but not the branches) and it should fill in.
answer.author: Barbara Harlan

symptom description: branches on the bottom of the plant are dead
branches in the middle of the plant are dead
management instructions: Check drainage by digging a small hole and adding water to see how long it takes to drain.
Trim the brown portions (the needles but not the branches) later and it should fill in.
Allow the plants to adjust.
qa_information.background info: The plants were 4.5 ft tall and some were root bound when planted. The soil is clay and was amended with compost. The plants were healthy when purchased.

title: Hackberry Tree galls #656398
question: I have a newly planted Hackberry in my yard.  Something seems to be eating at the leaves and approx 1/3 of the leaves have galls (see pics).  I have not seen any insects on the leaves.  Do you have any advice on what is causing this and how to treat?

answer.response:
Thank you or your question about Hackberry Tree Galls. The galls are likely caused by a tiny insect that lays its eggs on the underside of the leaves. Although they are not very attractive they do not harm the tree. Normally, we don't need to treat for Hackberry Nipple Gall, since it's considered mostly cosmetic.

 

There are two publications that will give you some background and that you can use to verify that this is the problem your tree is having.

 

The first is an overview of the Hackberry Nipple Gall

http://csuhort.blogspot.com/2017/08/hackberry-nipple-gall-name-alone.html 

 

The second is a fact sheet on insects and mite galls. This one emphasizes that these galls are difficult to treat because the pesticide application must coincide with when the insects are laying their eggs. Take a look at the table at the bottom.

https://extension.colostate.edu/topic-areas/insects/insect-and-mite-galls-5-577/ 

 

I hope this is helpful. Let us know if you have any other questions.

 

Paula
answer.author: Arapahoe County Master Gardeners

title: Dying branches on a red azalea #361191
question:
Individual branches began dying on a 35 yr-old red azalea that has bloomed beautifully for over 35 years. Image 2094 and 2095 show some of the new die-off. The large bare  spot on IMG_2092 shows the space left by many dead branches that died this spring as well as a few new dead branches. How can I arrest this gradual die-off?  These images were taken after i pruned it in may this year.
History: For many years the azalea suffered from lace-bugs (on which a soap spray didn't work) which I controlled with malathion.  About four years ago, I had to treat a nearby dwarf Alberta spruce with Bayer 3-in-1 insect control and found that it also controlled the lace bugs so I discontinued the malathion. The azalea gets full sun in the afternoon. The soil is not compacted.  It's been pruned by hand into the ball shape you see, cutting the shoots and about every 5 years more severely to control size--always by hand,  The azalea was purchased from, and planted by a local (Howard County) nursery.  It's about 3.5 ft in height, and is the only one of three like it, planted at the same time, with this die-off problem.

answer.response:
Based on your photos the azalea may be subject to a canker disease called Botryosphaeria dieback. Symptoms are scattered dying branches on an otherwise healthy plant Cankers are more common on stressed plants due to poor maintenance or site problems.  The pathogen can infect all ages of stem tissue through wounds, pruning cuts, and leaf scars. Heat, drought stress, and winter injury can increase disease incidence. Your azalea looks like it is planted in a tough site.  It is located in a sunny area near a driveway which can absorb and reflect heat. This makes the area hotter.  Azaleas are prone to lacebugs in a sunny area.  
AT this point, all you can do is prune dead wood or branches.  Make sure mulch is no thicker than several inches and keep away from the base of the stems.  Keep the shrub well watered during dry periods.  Azaleas grow best in morning sun and afternoon shade.
Here is our publication on this issue page 5 http://extension.umd.edu/sites/default/files/_images/programs/hgic/Publications/HG51_IPM_Azaleas_and...
mh
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

symptom description: large bare spot from dead branches
management instructions: prune dead wood or branches
keep mulch no thicker than several inches and away from the base of the stems
keep the shrub well watered during dry periods

title: Pear Tree - Some Brown Leaves #466490
question:
This pear tree is starting to get some Brown leaves in the past month.   Any idea on what this could be?  What can i do to correct this issue?  

Thanks, 
Eric

answer.response:
This is fire blight, a bacterial disease affecting apples and pears. At this point you will need to let the disease run its course.  In the spring you will need to prune out signs of cankers from the disease, cutting at least 6 inches into healthy limb tissue.  

The following is a good summary of symptoms and pruning strategies.

http://msue.anr.msu.edu/news/prune_out_fire_blight_in_the_winter
answer.author: William Shane

answer.response:
Bill - Thanks for the feedback!

Eric

In the spring, prune out signs of cankers from the disease, cutting at least 6 inches into healthy limb tissue.

Based on the provided background information and the image description, it appears that the issue with the pear tree might be related to disease or pests, which are common problems affecting trees in Michigan during the summer months. Here are some steps you can consider as a management strategy:

1. **Identify the Issue**: Determine whether the problem is due to a disease (like apple scab, rust, or blight) or pests (such as aphids, caterpillars, or borers). Observing the leaves, branches, and overall health of the tree will help in identifying the specific issue.

2. **Prune the Tree**: Remove any dead or diseased branches to prevent the spread of infection and improve air circulation around the tree. This can help reduce the risk of further damage from diseases.

3. **Apply Fertilizer**: Ensure the tree is well-nourished. A balanced fertilizer can provide essential nutrients like nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium, which are crucial for healthy growth and disease resistance.

4. **Use Organic Controls**: If the issue is identified as a pest infestation, consider using organic controls such as neem oil or insecticidal soap. These products are effective against many pests and are safer for the environment compared to chemical pesticides.

5. **Monitor Regularly**: Keep an eye on the tree regularly for signs of reoccurrence of the issue. Early detection and intervention can help manage the problem more effectively.

6. **Seek Professional Advice**: If the issue persists despite your efforts, it may be beneficial to consult with a local horticulturist or arborist who can provide more specific advice based on the location and type of issue observed.

By following these steps, you can manage the issue effectively and ensure the health and longevity of your pear tree.

title: please identify this small tree/shrub #597354
question: A number of these plants are growing on a local property and the owner wants to know what they are,  if they are invasive and how to get rid of them. They are growing in Houghton County Michigan.

answer.response:
Thank you for the pictures. This looks to be Autumn Olive which is considered an invasive in Michigan. Below is a link from the Dept. of Natural Resources which will provide you with more information on how it spreads and how to control it.  
https://www.habitatmatters.org/autumn-olive.html
This plant is native to Asia and was brought into the U.S. in the 1830's as an ornamental and for creating wildlife habitat and erosion prevention. Unfortunately the birds love the berries (although they don't provide much energy for them) and seeds are spread easily.  Below is a link to another article reviewing the best options for controlling this invasive shrub.  https://www.canr.msu.edu/news/autumn_olive_one_invasive_shrub

title: Bees nesting under house siding #807635
question: Hi!  Recently bees have moved in the intersection where the house’s blacktop driveway meets the brick siding.  This area is next to the front entry steps.  I am not sure if they will move/die by winter or if someone can remove them.  The look like what I called bumble bees.  I will attach a photo.  Any direction would be helpful.  Thanks!  Susan Kundel

answer.response:
Thanks for your question.

As you correctly surmised, this is an Eastern Bumble Bee (Bombus impatiens). It is the most common bumble bee in Minnesota. They nest underground so it is not surprising that you found them near your siding which is, presumably, very close to the ground. They generally are rather passive but if provoked or if they suspect their territory is being intruded upon, they will attack and sting. Look at their name: they are “impatient” when it comes to defending their territory. The stings are momentarily painful but certainly not serious. Just apply a watery mixture of baking soda and water to the area and the pain will quickly dissipate. The other thing to keep in mind is that once the cooler temperatures of October arrive, you will not see these critters any more. They will have all died. My advice is to just give them a wide berth for the next few weeks. After that you will not see them anymore. It is extremely unlikely that they will return next spring (2023) to this same area. Also please keep in mind that in their comings and goings at this time, they are serving an extremely important role as plant pollinators. See the following:

https://apps.extension.umn.edu/environment/citizen-science/bee-atlas/bumble-bees/SpeciesDetail?beeSpeciesId=1

http://www.minnesotaseasons.com/Insects/common_eastern_bumble_bee.html

https://www.inaturalist.org/guide_taxa/783945

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bombus_impatiens - :~:text=The specific name (the latter,and so are "impatient."

Good Luck!!
answer.author: Steve Hedman

management instructions: give them a wide berth
apply a watery mixture of baking soda and water to the area if stung

title:
Hi

I have forwarded pi... #154345
question:
Hi

I have forwarded pictures to Mary Kay Malinoski and attached one here.

Have a major problem on west side of four mature white pine.  95% of visible bud growth on west side for this year looks like the picture submitted (Typical).  There is a minor problem on the east side (5%).  do not know if this is insect or other damage. 

Only one of several cut open did contain a single larvae.  One, pictures sent, had a spent cocoon attached to it.  The rest that I have cut open look like the "interior" picture sent to Mary Kay.

Impression is that once the 2012 needles drop the west side of the trees will be completely bare.  See "Possible 2012 Damage".  Assume this will eventually kill the trees?

Wes Earp

1.response:
Thank you for the additional photographs.  They were examined by several members of our professional staff and the consensus among all of them is that there is no visible evidence of insect or disease.  In fact, the damage strongly resembles herbicidal damage.  Your tree appears to be an Austrian pine instead of a White pine, and Austrian pine is very susceptible to a disease known as Diplodia Tip Blight, but some of the more classic symptoms of that disease are absent.  Also, the tips of the branches are more 'distorted' in appearance which is strongly symptomatic of herbicidal damage.
The question might be asked: was some form of broadleaf herbicide applied to the soil in the general vicinity of the tree's root zone?  Such an application could have been made earlier in the year, perhaps in the spring. 
No treatment is necessary.  Simply wait and see how the tree responds in the spring.  You should see new growth sprouting from each branch just below the damaged area.  If you wish, you can then remove the damaged tips. 
LS
1.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

2.response:
Hi,

Thanks for the response.  The trees are White Pine not Austrin.  But, you are most likely correct in in your conclusions.  The damage is limited to one side of the trees and all are in a row along the the property line.  We do no lawn maintenance other than mowing but several of the properties that abut ours do use lawn care companies.  This would be the second case of herbicide damage this year from a neighbor's activities. 

This damage reaches heights of 40 feet or more suggesting a highly volatile compound.  The damage is approximately five feet inside the property line but the companies don't respect it, so an application could have been made right up to the "drip line".  Is this typical of 2,4 D or other broadleaft compounds?  Or, is it more likely a case of bad timing with regard to wind direction, temperature, or microclimatic affect?

Wes Earp
2.author: The Question Asker

3.response:
There are two herbicides that have demonstrated damaging effects on needled evergreens.  Imprelis is no longer available,  but the other, Dicamba,  is still available in many formulations, even those available to homeowners.  This herbicide is included in several combination products.
Both can move through the soil, although topical application sometimes results in surface movement.  2,4-D and glyphosate are more capable of volatilization and airborne drift.
LS
3.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

interior of bud growth is damaged

Wait and see how the tree responds in the spring.
Remove the damaged tips after new growth sprouts from each branch.

title: Black strawberries  #597762
question: Just as they are getting ripe my strawberries are turning black. Very disappointing. Could be isolated. Last photo of good berry is from another plant about 4 feet away. Help?

answer.response:
Your strawberries may have Anthracnose or Colletotrichum sp.The fungus is spread by splashing water. Strawberries with anthracnose develop distinct round sunken brown to black blotches with no smell.

http://apps.extension.umn.edu/garden/diagnose/plant/fruit/strawberry/fruitdiscolored.html https://ohioline.osu.edu/factsheet/plpath-fru-16
answer.author: Pat Mack

answer.response: Thank you, that is very likely with all the rain we've had. Any suggestions for prevention or treatment?
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response: Pick and remove infected berries in order to reduce the amount of inoculum.The fungus overwinters on infected plants, plant debris and mummified fruit. Remove as much old, infected plant debris as possible. In order to obtain effective disease control, fungicides should be applied before the disease develops. Fungicides with copper, Captan or Bacillus subtilis listed as the active ingredient provide some protection from anthracnose fruit rot. Plant in full sun. Keep plants from being crowded. Water early in the day to reduce the amount of water on the flowers and fruit. Use straw mulch under the plants.
answer.author: Pat Mack

management instructions: Pick and remove infected berries.
Remove as much old, infected plant debris as possible.
Apply fungicides with copper, Captan or Bacillus subtilis before the disease develops.
Plant in full sun.
Keep plants from being crowded.
Water early in the day.
Use straw mulch under the plants.

title: Spots on tomatoes  #840885
question: I have just started getting tomatoes but several of them have spots on the bottom.   In the future how can I prevent this

1.response:
Thank you for writing.

This is typical for blossom end rot. https://extension.umn.edu/plant-diseases/tomato-disorders#how-to-control-blossom-end-rot-3103312

A couple tips, 
1 remove affected fruit and discard right away.  New fruit can be healthy. 
2 With snips that are cleaned with lysol or alcohol between plants, cut off the lower six inches of branches.  
3 Then carefully apply 1/2 - 1 inch of mulch in order to retain more even watering in the soil.

title: Unknown Vine or Trunk  #397240
question: I am wondering if you can tell me what this type of vine is.  It seems to be killing our other trees.  I have started cutting them and when I do, there is some type of liquid that is coming out and it looks like it is stripping its own bark off.  Our property abuts Grass Lake which is in Howard Lake. Wright County.   I would like to know what is the best way to start getting rid of them.  They have no leaves or buds whatsoever, just a trunk.

answer.response:
We can't identify the vine by viewing photos of the bare trunks. Please submit your question again after the leaves have developed and attach sharp photos.

Based on what we can see, we speculate that the offending plants might be grape vines but we can't be sure.

When the leaves emerge, you may be able to determine whether the plants are grape vines by comparing them with this photo.

https://pestid.msu.edu/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/Wild_Grape_Leaf.jpg

If grape vines are present, this bulletin explains how to control them.
http://extension.psu.edu/natural-resources/forests/private/tools-resources/publications/invasive-pla...
answer.author: Bob Bystrom

answer.response: This vine does not have leaves nor will it produce any. It is just a trunk or whatever it is called.  It also re-roots in the ground producing more shoots,
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
We don't know of any vines with woody trunks that produce no leaves (at least at their tops) unless the vines are dead. Would it be possible to send us sharp photos of the shoots you mentioned?

By the way, sap often flows copiously from grape vine trunks cut in early spring.

Please compare these grape vine trunks with the those shown in your photos to see why we thought the plants might be grape.
http://www.prairiefarmer.com/sites/prairiefarmer.com/files/uploads/2016/01/05/grapevines_good_bad_bo...

http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-QcENC-6c5l8/T6GNztJ266I/AAAAAAAAAHQ/mPTnWXRFxoA/s1600/Wild+Grapevine.JPG
answer.author: Bob Bystrom

answer.response:
Well, I guess I should not have second guessed your response.  Indeed they are grapevines.  I thank you so much. Now, the question is:  how invasive are these vines and what do we do to at least get them to a minimum, since they seem to be killing out our other trees.  And they are very creepy.  :)  Thank you again for your responses, it is much appreciated.

Deb Mattison

763-443-7687
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Cutting is a good way to begin controlling the vines. This excerpt from the Pennsylvania State University bulletin we brought to your attention addresses the subject in more detail:

"There are three chemical herbicides available to control grape. Dicamba can be applied as a foliar spray, basal bark, or spot application. Fosamine herbicide works as a foliar spray. 2,4-D herbicide can be used as a selective treatment when applied as a stump treatment, basal bark spray, or tree injection. Caution must be taken when using any of these herbicides, because they will kill non-target broad-leaf under-story plants, seedlings, and saplings.

The preferred method of grape control is by mechanical means. Severing the vines one to two feet about the ground works as a very effective control methods as long as the vines are growing under a forest canopy. After cutting, the vine will likely resprout. However, the sprouts and entire plant will die within three years, if in heavy shade. This method works because grape is shade intolerant. If this methods is tried in a young stand when the trees are under 18 feet tall and the forest floor receives a large amount of sunlight, the grape sprouts may be able to grow back into the tree crowns."
answer.author: Bob Bystrom

answer.response:
Thanks so much Bob.  Have a great day and thank you again.

Deb Mattison
answer.author: The Question Asker

management instructions: Cutting is a good way to begin controlling the vines.
Severing the vines one to two feet about the ground works as a very effective control methods as long as the vines are growing under a forest canopy.
Dicamba can be applied as a foliar spray, basal bark, or spot application.
Fosamine herbicide works as a foliar spray.
2,4-D herbicide can be used as a selective treatment when applied as a stump treatment, basal bark spray, or tree injection.

The image you provided shows an area with grapevines that appear to have been cut or pruned. The signs of recent cutting include visible cuts on the trunks and branches, as well as the presence of liquid exuding from these cuts, which is consistent with the description of the grapevine species.

Given the background information, the issue seems to be the spread and potential impact of the grapevine species on other trees. Here are some recommended management strategies:

1. **Physical Removal**: Manually remove any remaining grapevines. Ensure that all roots and shoots are removed to prevent regrowth. This can be time-consuming but is effective if done thoroughly.

2. **Chemical Control**: Use herbicides specifically designed for control of invasive plants such as grapevines. These products can be applied directly to the cut surfaces to kill the plant tissue and prevent the spread of roots. Follow the manufacturer’s instructions carefully.

3. **Cultural Practices**: Establish and maintain healthy native vegetation around the affected areas. This can help compete with the grapevines and reduce their ability to thrive.

4. **Monitoring and Prevention**: Regularly monitor the area for any new growth of grapevines. Preventive measures, such as maintaining a buffer zone free of grapevines, can help manage the spread.

5. **Community Efforts**: Engage local residents and landowners in managing the invasive species. Collaboration can lead to more comprehensive and effective control efforts.

6. **Regulatory Actions**: Report the issue to local authorities or environmental agencies responsible for managing invasive species. They may have additional resources or regulations that can help address the problem.

By implementing these strategies, you can help mitigate the negative impacts of grapevines on your property and the surrounding environment.

title: What is this tree disease and what's the best way to get rid of it? #212521
question: I've started to notice this on a few trees in my yard. The leaves eventually fall off and die.  Thought perhaps it's a fungus at first.  Looking for the best way to get rid of it.

answer.response: This is one of the leaf spot diseases trees get late in the season. There is no control for it once the leaf is infected, so you don't need to do anything for it except remove the fallen leaves from around the tree. It is not necessary to spray for this because it do not harm the tree significantly.
answer.author: David Vandergriff

title: Withered baby apples  #831985
question: Tree looks healthy, some apples are ok but most are dry shriveled clumps.

1.response:
Looks like you may have some fire blight going on here. Fire blight is disease cause by the bacterial pathogen Erwinia amylovora. It is a risk when it is warm and moist during the bloom period. You will want to prune the diseased stems out to prevent further spread of the pathogen in the tree. Make cuts at least 12 inches below infected/symptomatic wood, sterilize pruners in 10% bleach solution between cuts.

https://pnwhandbooks.org/plantdisease/host-disease/apple-malus-spp-fire-blight
1.author: Nik Wiman

title: Control of Fruit Flies Indoor Basil #655400
question:
A friend of mine grows basil indoors in a somewhat enclosed terrarium.  Lately he has noticed a lot of bugs as he describes in the quote of his email below.  Attached are 3 photos that may help in identification of the insect.  My thinking is that they may be fruit flies and I know how to create the vinegar and soap in a jar trap to kill the adults if they are fruit flies.  My thinking is also that the damp soil may be the breeding ground.  If so, how would one safely kill the eggs and larvae and still be able to eat the basil?

Quote: "As far as I can tell there aren’t any nibbles on the leaves. It’s more of they’re just a nuisance to see. I got a photo of the larva form of them which do have red eyes. They’re white grubs with red eyes in that form. 

I would say when they’re in their fly form they flit about. They don’t really fly that much. The fly looking ones have teeny tiny legs. And if it helps I only see them on the underside of the leaves. They’re never on top of the leaves. That could just be coincidence by I don’t know. 

They’re only between the plastic wrap and the window. No where else in the house.

The basil is in the front bay window of the house so not in the kitchen where all the other food is."

answer.response:
Hi- yes, these are fruit flies. The basil is safe to eat after rinsing leaves to remove any larvae. Larvae feed on organic material.
https://extension.umd.edu/hgic/topics/fruit-flies
Jon
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

answer.response: Is there any safe way to kill the eggs and larvae in the soil?
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Hi- we are not aware of any safe insecticide that could be applied to potting soil to kill eggs and larvae. Reducing the adult population with a vinegar trap and by removing any soft or rotting fruits from countertops is the surest way to reduce the overall population. It's also possible that there are fungus gnats in the potting soil. They can be eliminated by allowing the top of the media to dry out before watering.
Jon
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

answer.response: Many thanks!!!
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response: You are quite welcome.
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

management instructions: create a vinegar and soap in a jar trap to kill the adults
reduce the adult population by removing any soft or rotting fruits from countertops
allow the top of the media to dry out before watering to eliminate fungus gnats
rinse leaves to remove any larvae

title: Mold (?) Fungus (?) on maple tree roots - Probably a ext specialist question #803737
question:
I am removing buried landscape rock on top of good landscape fabric.  It's around a very grown maple tree.  The tree trunk is probably 6-8 ft away from the garage.  The drip is over the garage.  Roots have migrated thru the humus on the rock.

I started watering this maple last summer (despite a ban - evil me).  I have been watering (maybe 3x so far this summer) with an overhead sprinkler that may have hit where this mystery substance is growing.  So this could be something that grew in the heavily shaded, wet, not the best drainage area.

At first I thought it was a long forgotten dog pile I missed.  But when I picked it out of my rock swifter, it was squishy.  Then I thought the contractors cleaned off some white silicon in that area because that was the texture this was.  But I just kept uncovering more.  It even started to cover rocks themselves.

The tree provides fabulous shade for the house.  It's between multiple utilities lines coming into 2 houses.  So I don't want to lose this tree let alone pay to have it removed.

1 - Do I need to worry about the maple or do some type of preventative care.  I haven't found it in other areas around the tree.  Just next to the garage.

2 -  Can I use the rocks around some hostas in a egress window well?

answer.response:
This may be a fungus, as you've guessed, growing around the roots because of the fabric, watering, compaction, and shaded position.   Does the tree look healthy?  Has it kept all of its leaves, and do they show no sign of disease?   You can try to remove the fungus by carefully digging around the affected roots. Rinse off the root ball with your hose, and carefully cut away the affected sections.  Use a fungicide to help prevent more fungus from forming, and add new soil.  Also see the attached link for information about various fungi that affect maple trees.
https://apps.extension.umn.edu/garden/diagnose/plant/deciduous/maple/branchesfungi.html

The stones may carry the fungus, so completely wash them before reusing them.
answer.author: Diane McGann

answer.response:
Any impact on hostas?
On Sunday, July 31, 2022 at 08:44:46 AM CDT, Ask Extension <askextension@eduworks.com> wrote:
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response: If you clean the rocks thoroughly before using them and then place them around hostas, the fungus should not spread to those plants.
answer.author: Diane McGann

Rinse off the root ball with a hose, and carefully cut away the affected sections.

title: Insect Identification  #870314
question: Is this a Gypsy Moth Caterpillar? If so, can they be sprayed? We are finding them on our spruce. Any info or advice would be helpful. Thanks

1.response:
Correct, this is spongy (gypsy) moth. We are in the middle of an outbreak in parts of Mid and west michigan.

It's too late for insecticides to have much efficacy on the caterpillars once they've reached these sizes, as they'll pupate within 1 - 2 weeks anyway. 

You could wrap sticky bands are barriers around the trees to prevent them from climbing up. See here: https://www.canr.msu.edu/resources/using-bands-to-protect-shade-trees-from-spongy-moth

In early August and later, keep an eye on the trunk of trees for any egg masses. If you spot them, scrape off into a bucket of soapy water to prevent the eggs from hatching in the next Spring.

For next season, insecticides are most effective for the smaller life stages of spongy moth caterpillars. Bt kurstaki, and contact insecticides with one of the following active ingredients may provide relief: carbaryl, cyfluthrin, cyhalothrin, cypermethrin, deltamethrin, permethrin.

See here for additional information on control: https://fyi.extension.wisc.edu/spongymothinwisconsin/pest-management-2/management-guide-for-homeowners/
1.author: David Lowenstein

2.response:
Thank you for the quick response. 

Get Outlook for Android
From: ask=extension.org@mg.extension.org <ask=extension.org@mg.extension.org> on behalf of As
2.author: The Question Asker

scrape off egg masses into a bucket of soapy water

title: Maple Tree Looking Sick #847224
question: Hi. We have two, approximately 15 year old, maples lakeside. Last year we began noticing one looked less full, and wasn’t thriving. This year its’ leaves are already changing while its’ neighbor is in full, green leaf still. The trunk must have been damaged by a lawn mower early on, but it looks like the bark healed. I put 7  Jobe fertilizer  spikes around the perimeter of the tree about a month ago. I haven’t noticed any insects on it. Do you have any idea what’s wrong with it? And any suggestions? It receives plenty of water via a sprinkler system…. Thanks for any advice.

answer.response:
Good Afternoon,
A maple tree that turns red in summer might have a case of iron chlorosis. It’s caused by high pH in your soil, which in turn causes an iron deficiency. If the pH is above about 7.5-7.7, the iron gets tied up chemically and is not available to the plant, even though there still could be iron present in the soil.  It is possible to correct the underlying soil pH problem by applying elemental sulfur or acidifying fertilizers. Soil pH testing and corrective recommendations are included as part of the Michigan State University Extension Soil Test Kit Self Mailer program. 

Why is my maple tree leaves turning red in the summer? – MassInitiative

I hope this helps.  Thanks for using our service.
answer.author: Doreen Losacco

management instructions: correct the underlying soil pH problem by applying elemental sulfur or acidifying fertilizers
qa_information.background info: The tree is approximately 15 years old, has a history of lawn mower damage to the trunk, and has been fertilized with 7 Jobe fertilizer spikes about a month ago. The tree receives plenty of water via a sprinkler system.

agmmu_question.question: What management practice should be applied to address the soil pH issue depicted in the image?

apply elemental sulfur or acidifying fertilizers
add organic mulch to the soil surface

2. **Assess Trunk Damage**: The tree has a history of lawn mower damage to the trunk. This can lead to decay and weaken the tree. Inspect the damaged area for signs of decay and consider applying a protective sealant around the damaged area to prevent further damage and promote healing.

3. **Check for Proper Fertilization**: Since the tree was recently fertilized with Jobe fertilizer spikes, ensure that the application rate and timing were correct. Over-fertilization can cause root burn or other issues. If you suspect over-fertilization, consider flushing the soil with water to leach out excess nutrients.

4. **Evaluate Watering System**: Ensure that the sprinkler system is functioning correctly and providing adequate moisture to the roots. Root damage from over-watering or under-watering can also affect the health of the tree. Adjust watering if necessary to match the tree's needs.

5. **Prune for Health**: Prune dead or diseased branches to improve air circulation and reduce the risk of disease. This will also help the tree conserve energy and resources.

6. **Consider Professional Advice**: If the tree continues to show signs of distress, it may be beneficial to consult with a professional arborist who can provide a detailed assessment and tailored management plan.

7. **Maintain Regular Inspections**: Continue to monitor the tree regularly for any signs of decline or new issues. Early detection and intervention can help prevent more severe problems.

By addressing these areas, you can help maintain the health and vitality of the maple tree.

title: Trees in my yard are said... #154374
question:
Trees in my yard are said to be severely infested with Hemlock elongate scale. Scale is on the underside of the needles. Do you what treatment options are available? And do you know how effective these treatments are? Instead of treating the trees, would it make sense to just let them die as they are quite old trees? Photo attached

Thank you! Mary Klein

1.response:
Unfortunately, a heavy infestation of Hemlock Elongate Scale insects can kill a mature hemlock.  If discovered early enough, it is possible to reduce the damage and to control the insects.  Although we cannot see the entire tree in your photograph, it does appear that the background foliage is severely thinned out and there is obviously some die back.  If the tree still has about 60% recoverable foliage, you could spray now with horticultural oil and then consider applying a soil drench of a systemic insecticide in early spring.  Hemlocks are difficult to maintain in our area even under the best of circumstances.
LS

title: Mint plants #762434
question: This year my peppermint and regular mint seem to have white spots on the leaves.  Is this simply due to poor soil? Are they safe to eat?

answer.response:
Hi Tania. Your mint is not suffering from poor soil but more likely a leaf sucking pest like leaf hoppers, spider mites, thrips, etc. These pests suck the chlorophyll from the leaves, leaving white spots on the leaf surface.

Thrips will leave behind little black specks of frass (bug droppings) and often distort new leaf growth, so I doubt that is your pest, going by your photos. And, while there's not much to do about leaf hoppers, mites can be treated fairly easily. First, they like it hot and dry (which we've seen a lot of lately). By hosing down the plant regularly -- especially the undersides of the leaves -- you'll change their preferred environment and, possibly, create an environment that invites predatory/beneficial mites in, which will feed on the pest mites. You could also use an insecticidal soap, but only on mildly damaged leaves. Water in the evening and use the insecticidal soap in the early morning, when the plant is fully hydrated and the least stressed. If you fertilize, hold off for a while. Mites love excess nitrogen.

If your plant is heavily damaged, which it doesn't appear to be in your photos but things can change rapidly, removing and disposing of the plant is your best option to prevent spread. Be sure to clean up and dispose of all fallen plant debris as well.

I hope this helps, let us know if we can assist further.
answer.author: Katie Grant

answer.response:
Thank you do much

title: juniper bushes ( shrubs) #847774
question: Our juniper is showing yellow leaves on the top of the plant. Stalk has white markings .

answer.response:
Thank you for contacting Ask Extension!

To help you a bit, this is a Threadleaf False Cypress. It resembles a juniper, and usually has the same diseases and insects as a Juniper but it is a Cypress.

After looking at your pictures, It appears that you might have more than one problem. First, in the third picture, you definitely have scale. The scale crawlers appear in the spring, adhering to needles to begin feeding on plant juices. Scale covering can remain attached to the needles for several years. Severely-infested plants turn yellowish-brown and the plant appears to be in need of fertilizer or water. Plants can decline due to scale feeding over time and may be killed by severe infestations. Treatment needs to occur during the spring, when crawlers are moving.

I have included several references on how to treat your cypress and when.

https://datcpservices.wisconsin.gov/pb/pests.jsp?categoryid=43&articleid=2376&issueid=304

https://bygl.osu.edu/node/697

https://www.canr.msu.edu/news/juniper_scale_crawlers_are_active_in_michigan

https://extension.psu.edu/juniper-and-minute-cypress-scales

Second, it appears that some of the plant that does not have scale, could have Phomopsis Tip Blight. This disease is caused by the fungus Phomopsis juniperovora and begins by infecting the tips of branches smaller than the diameter of a pencil. The new, immature growth becomes infected while the darker green, mature foliage remains resistant to infection

I have included several references concerning this disease also (and remember, that junipers and cypress do have similar diseases and insect problems):

https://hgic.clemson.edu/factsheet/juniper-diseases-insect-pests/

https://hort.extension.wisc.edu/articles/phomopsis-tip-blight/#:~:text=Phomopsis%20tip%20blight%20is%20caused,moisture%20or%20humidity%20is%20high.

Usually, a shrub will have multiple problems when it is stressed. The shrubs look older, but if they are not mulched, have consistent dry or wet roots, and not getting enough sun (4-8 hours for these plants), that could put them into stress mode, and make them more susceptible to diseases and insects. Before treating, check to see if the plants have any of these issues, and if you can do something to help eliminate some of the stress.
answer.author: Diane Hayes

answer.response:
Thank you so much! That is a big help.

title: Zoysia grass #859718
question: My neighbor’s zoysia grass is starting to grow into my lawn.  Is there any way to get rid of it?

1.response: Can I post a photo at this point?
1.author: The Question Asker

2.response:
You are welcome to share photos if you'd like; just attach the image files to your reply, or paste the images into the body of the reply itself.

Zoysia, as a perennial plant, will need either physical removal (digging it out) or barriers to root spread, or treatment with a systemic herbicide to kill the entire plant once it has invaded a particular area. (Such herbicides will also kill any other grass the spray coats.)

If a physical barrier like garden edging or solid fencing can't be used along the property line to keep the zoysia from creeping into the yard, it will be difficult to manage the problem long-term because physical or chemical removal may be your only recourse. Although keeping a cool-season lawn (fescue, usually) vigorous and dense can help out-compete most weeds, zoysia will likely be tough enough to hold its own against your lawn, making this approach not as reliable as it can be with other weeds like crabgrass. Some herbicides are selective towards certain weeds, but a chemical targeting one type of grassy weed (warm-season) among cool-season grass may be hard to find or use successfully. Unfortunately the opposite situation, having a cool-season grass mingling unwanted with a warm-season grass like zoysia, is easier to chemically treat since the zoysia will be dormant when the cool-season grass resumes growth (and when it will be vulnerable to herbicide). The reverse doesn't really happen though, since zoysia is in active growth in summer and fescue is not, but the fescue doesn't tend to go fully dormant with respect to having all of the foliage die (since foliage absorption is how those root-killing herbicides work).

Miri
2.author: Mira Talabac

3.response: Thank you, Miri.  I don’t see a way to send a photo, and pasteing  doesn’t work for me.  Thank you for sending the information.
3.author: The Question Asker

4.response: Found it.
4.author: The Question Asker

6.response:
Thank you for the photo. The sidewalk should help keep the zoysia from invading the main area of lawn (as it appears to be limited to the strip between the sidewalk and street so far), though your options remain the same for removal: physically blocking it with some sort of edging, digging it out when it spreads too far, or using herbicide (weed killer) as an alternative to digging to kill patches of zoysia that have grown where they are not wanted.

Miri

title: Blue Spruce and Pitch Mass Borer #766423
question: Hello - I've had a weeping blue spruce specimen tree off my patio for 20 years.  It (was) an incredibly beautiful tree for quite awhile and is currently about 20 foot tall.  One day the tree developed Needle Cast, and over a period of 2 years I was able to effectively treat the tree with a fungicide spray.  It hasn't dropped a needle all season - although the tree has lost much of it's mass.  I hadn't noticed in all the time the tree was stressed out that it also developed Pitch Mass Borer on the underside, which started dropping Sap onto my AC unit.  Davey tree Company figured out what it was and recommended I purchase a product called Tenguard and treat the tree in Spring and Fall - their words: "Spring and fall, the newly hatched larvae stays in the crevices of the bark. The goal is to spray them before they bore into the trunk."  I really want to save the tree and have the means and equipment to do it, so I purchased the product.  The infestation is too high up to reach physically, so I have to spray.  (BTW - I also drenched the soil with a systemic insecticide for long term caution called Dominion XL.  As well, a few weeks ago I sprayed the tree with Tenguard and the infestation seemed to stop for a few weeks but now it's back of course, because it was just a temporary fix in the middle of summer.   My question is when is the best time in Ohio to spray the larvae, and if successful, how long may it take to rid the tree of this infestation?

answer.response:
Hello,

There have been a few reports of pitch mass borer in the OSU Buckeye Yard and Garden Line publications in recent years. The general recommendation is to keep the tree healthy and avoid mechanical injury to the tree. It is also recommended to remove the pitch masses and dispose of them in the trash as they often contain the larvae. This will keep their numbers down. Spraying for the pitch mass borer is difficult because the larvae is located in the pitch mass or hidden in and under the bark and the spray will not come in contact with the caterpillar. That being said, spraying is more effective in the spring when the larvae are moving on the tree trunk. There was no mention of treatment with a systemic chemical in any article that I read.

Before you commit to a chemical treatment, it is important to get an accurate identification of the insect that is invading your tree.  If you can find evidence of the larvae inside of a pitch mass or the moth itself on the tree, it would be a good idea to send a sample to the C. Wayne Ellett Plant and Pest Diagnostic Clinic, run by the Ohio State University. The PPDC can confirm the identification of the pest and make additional recommendations for up to date management and treatment. If you should decide to treat the borer with a chemical, make sure that you follow all label directions accurately. Additionally, some chemicals are restricted and need to be applied only by a certified pesticide applicator.

Unfortunately, in recent years, the Colorado Blue Spruces planted in Ohio have become increasingly stressed by the area's climate. The Blue Spruce does not do well with extreme winter temperature fluctuations, summer heat and humidity, and prolonged periods of rainy weather. As they age, the spruces' defense mechanisms weaken and they begin to be riddled with disease and pests. 

I have listed the links for the articles below. I have also listed a link for the PPDC's website if you would like to send a sample to them. If you have more questions, please write back to Ask Extension.

Betsy B. - MGV

https://ocvn.osu.edu/news/osu-buckeye-yard-garden-line

https://bygl.osu.edu/pdf/2014/BYGL-2014-21.pdf

https://web.extension.illinois.edu/focus/?problem=pitch-mass-borer

https://ppdc.osu.edu/
answer.author: Betsy Betagole - MGV

answer.response: I sent you a follow-up email requesting the timeframe in Spring and Fall the larvae is active in Central Ohio.  Thank you.
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Hello
The pest is too high up to get a sample and I am going to spray.  Davey Tree has already identified the issues.  I simply need to know when the larvae is active in Central Ohio - both Spring and Fall.  Do you have some date ranges??  The periods of 'Spring' and 'Fall' are way to broad to nail a timeframe.  
Thank you,
FLHunter(614) 779-1566

title: Fuji Apple Tree Disease #834787
question: I live in Mosier, Oregon and have an issue with a possible condition on my Fuji Apple tree. I'm not sure if it is Powdery Mildew or something else. As can be seen in the attached pictures the leaves turn brown with a reddish tint to them. I only have a few places on the tree that show the condition, but do not want it to spread. Please advise.

answer.response:
That is a prime example of Fire Blight, the crook it gives the branch is distinctive. (https://treefruit.wsu.edu/crop-protection/disease-management/fire-blight/)

The treatment is to cut off the affected branches at least 12 inches below where you see the infection, and dispose of the branches. I am happy to provide further help as needed, or more clear pruning instructions.

title: I have an ornamental cherry tree and found these bugs (see photos) today, what do I do? #832628
question: Hello, it suddenly occurred to me today that my ornamental cherry tree ( I think it is, I've only owned this house for a couple of years) did not bloom, so I went over to it to take a closer look and the leaves at the ends of each branch were caked in tiny black bugs! I've attached pictures. What are they and what should I do about them?

answer.response:
Hello!

From your photos, it looks like you have an infestation of black cherry aphids (Myzus cerasi). The curling of the leaves also points to aphids. 

There are two options for control.

1. Cultural control- Spray the aphids with a strong stream of water. Be sure to get underneath the leaves. I recommend starting with this to see if it is enough control. Most of the aphids should move to alternate hosts by mid-summer, so this should only be a temporary problem. Water may provide enough control until then.

2. Chemical control with insecticides- This may or may not be a good idea depending on your situation. The recommended pesticides are toxic to bees. They can also kill the natural enemies of the aphids. It can also be difficult to get the chemicals underneath the leaf curls.

To prevent the problem in future, be sure to not over fertilize with nitrogen and to not over water. These cause succulent growth, which is exactly what aphids like.

Resources:

Cherry-Black cherry aphid | Pacific Northwest Pest Management Handbooks (oregonstate.edu)

Black cherry aphid | College of Agricultural Sciences (oregonstate.edu)

Black Cherry Aphid | WSU Tree Fruit | Washington State University


Regards,

Leo Sherry

OSU Extension Master Gardener Volunteer
answer.author: Leo Sherry

get underneath the leaves
avoid over fertilizing with nitrogen
avoid over watering
