title: Bugs and Tomatos #123538
question:
Hey,

Can you please explain what happened to my tomatoes?

Thanks!
Alex

1.response:
It looks like you have blossom end rot.  This is a physiological disorder that is not caused by a pest or disease but rather is due to low levels of calcium in the fruit.  Control of blossom end rot is dependent upon maintaining adequate supplies of moisture and calcium to the developing fruits.  

Symptoms can occur at any time during fruit development and are apparent one the end of the fruit opposite the stem.  In the beginning you will see a small water soaked spot appear which enlarges as the fruit develops.  Over time this will usually darken and turn leathery.  All of this occurs because alarge amount of calcium  is needed for normal cell growth.  During rapid fruit growth if the cells do not get enough calcium, then the fruit doesn't grow correctly and blossom end rot occurs.  The low levels of calcium may be due to low levels in the soil, drought, excessive moisture or fluctuations between high and low levels of water.  All of these reduce calcium uptake in the plant.  

Making sure you have adequqte calcium in your soil is a good first defense, so make sure to get a soil test and add nutrients as recommended.  Also, when you plant tomatoes early in cold soil blossom end rot is likely to develop on the first fruits, with the severity of the disease often subsiding on fruits set later.  So, planting tomatoes in warmer soils helps to alleviate the problem.  To help limit water fluctuations having irrigation is helpful.  Mulching of the soil is often helpful in maintaining adequate supplies of soil water in times of moisture stress.   Here is link to a fact sheet from Cornell University of blossom end rot as well. http://vegetablemdonline.ppath.cornell.edu/factsheets/Tomato_BlossRt.htm
1.author: Barbara Liedl

symptom description: water soaked spot on the end of the fruit opposite the stem
spot enlarges as the fruit develops
management instructions: Maintain adequate supplies of moisture and calcium to the developing fruits.
Get a soil test and add nutrients as recommended.
Plant tomatoes in warmer soils.
Use irrigation to limit water fluctuations.
Mulch the soil to maintain adequate supplies of soil water in times of moisture stress.

title: Tree Leaves Disease ID Request #833662
question: I purchased a home two years ago with some large mature trees (at least 40 years old). My Silver Maple has leaves that appear to be rotting and falling off. Unfortunately, this is happening to the majority of the leaves (even high up in the tree from what I can see). Can you tell me what's going on? It's next to a similarly sized Sugar Maple with the top of the tree in full sun and the lower branches in a mix of sun/shade. The branches don't seem to have a lot of leaves in general. See close up photos. Thanks for your help!

answer.response:
Hi,

This appears to be Anthracnose, which is a common disease that is occurring right now on many shade trees.

It is mostly seen on Oak, Maple, Sycamore and other shade trees. In most cases it isn't a major health concern to the tree and new growth will push out the older leaves - if they are still attached- as the season progresses. Usually the symptoms clear up with weather changes into the summer too. It will not transfer to the turf grass.

It helps trees to recover if you can lesson their stress symptoms. With the drought weather and going into the summer, if you can supplement watering when it doesn't rain, that should help as well. Water deeply so it can soak into the entire root zone of the tree.

To be proactive for next year, you can rake up and discard any fallen leaves which will help with the overwintering of the disease and also make sure to rake and dispose of leaves this fall as well.

You shouldn't need to use additional fertilizer and this could be excessive. The tree is capable of getting enough nutrients from the area soils anyways. If you use leaf litter (that is not infected with anthracnose) or mulch once a year to help keep soil moisture and add decomposing organic matter back into the root area, that is usually sufficient.

Let us know if you have further questions with this.

Emily
answer.author: Emily Porter

management instructions: Supplement watering when it doesn"t rain.
Water deeply so it can soak into the entire root zone of the tree.
Rake up and discard any fallen leaves to help with the overwintering of the disease.
Use leaf litter or mulch once a year to help keep soil moisture and add decomposing organic matter back into the root area.

title: Spotted leaves, Pear Tree #625854
question:
We’ve just planted a couple Bartlett pear trees a few weeks ago. Now the leaves are beginning to come out after blooming and one branch has rusty spots on it. Could be pear rust? Just wondering if they should be sprayed right away, maybe removed before it spreads to more branches?
Thank you for your help!

answer.response:
The speckled, slightly raised areas are caused by pearleaf blister mites (Eriophyes pyri), a common problem for pears, especially 'Bartlett' and 'Anjou' during a particularly moist, rainy spring. These mites are far different than the spider mites you may be familiar with. They are microscopic.
Affected leaves may drop prematurely. Loss of foliage weakens the trees, reduces shoot growth, and interferes with fruit maturation and fruit bud formation. But because the trees were just planted, it's a wise idea to avoid fruit set for at least 3 years. Doing so will allow the trees to establish a sturdy root system.

A spray won't help this season because the damage is already done. Our official plant disease handbook suggests "Plan on taking action the following fall or spring. . ."

"Lime sulfur - Applications in the fall can significantly reduce populations. . . the following year." {But you likely will have problems finding a retail source for home gardens. You might try local farm stores.)- "Superior oil - Apply in the spring as buds begin to swell."
answer.author: Jean R. Natter

symptom description: speckled, slightly raised areas on leaves
management instructions: Avoid fruit set for at least 3 years to allow the trees to establish a sturdy root system.
Apply lime sulfur in the fall to reduce populations.
Apply superior oil in the spring as buds begin to swell.
qa_information.background info: The trees were just planted a few weeks ago and are Bartlett pear trees.

title: Cherry tree problem #716603
question: Hi! One of our Yoshino Cherry trees has a problem! Does it need treatment? Please see photos. Thanks!

answer.response:
You are seeing the symptoms of cherry shot hole disease. Wet spring weather is ideal for the development of this disease and we have had a lot of questions about this recently. Both a fungus and a bacterium can cause shot hole disease in cherries, and distinguishing between the two pathogens is challenging. Neither will be controlled by sprays applied after symptoms have progressed to this point. Some defoliation also occurs as a result of this condition.

The good news is that trees produce many more leaves than they need to feed themselves via photosynthesis, and in most cases mature trees can sustain some of this damage and recover in future years. No treatment is recommended. Remove and dispose of fallen leaves to reduce fungal inoculum around the planting area. This does tend to be a chronic issue in cherry trees in this area, and it is typically worse in wet weather years. Here is more about cherry shot hole and how to manage it. https://extension.umd.edu/hgic/topics/cherry-shot-hole-flowering-cherries

We cannot see around the base of the trees. You can also check to make sure the trees  are not planted too deeply. A properly planted tree flares at the base of the trunk at the soil line where it joins the root system. If you cannot see this,  carefully remove the soil from the circumference of the trunk to the point where the trunk flares out into root growth. https://extension.umd.edu/hgic/topics/planted-too-deeply

Looks like you are also protecting the trunks from deer damage. You may want to carefully remove the grass from around the trunk out to the dripline of the tree. You can mulch with an organic mulch and make sure mulch is no thicker than several inches and away from the trunk. This can help to prevent competition with the grass for moisture and nutrients and lawn mower and string trimmer damage in the future.
 
Also, water the trees during dry periods.
Here is more on ornamental fruit trees https://extension.umd.edu/hgic/topics/ornamental-fruit-trees-preventing-diagnosing-and-managing-problems

Marian
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

management instructions: Remove and dispose of fallen leaves to reduce fungal inoculum around the planting area.
Check to make sure the trees are not planted too deeply.
Carefully remove the soil from the circumference of the trunk to the point where the trunk flares out into root growth.
Remove the grass from around the trunk out to the dripline of the tree.
Mulch with an organic mulch and make sure mulch is no thicker than several inches and away from the trunk.
Water the trees during dry periods.

title: White spots on Zinnia leaves #811070
question: What causes a white fungus or mold like spots on the Zinnia’s leaves, and what can be done about it.

1.response:
The white spots on your zinnia leaves are caused by a very common fungal disease called powdery mildew. This disease may detract from the appearance of your zinnias, but it does very little damage. Fungal spores are spread from one plant to another by wind or splashing water. Powdery mildew fungi thrive with cool, humid nights that stimulate spore production and warm (70 to 80 F), dry days that allow for spore spread.

There's not a lot you can do to change the weather--the onset of cooler nights in the autumn contributes to the prevalence of this disease; however, there are a couple of things you can do to minimize this disease next year:

1. Space your plants far enough apart to provide good air circulation.

2. Avoid overhead watering, as water remaining on the plants contributes to the damp environment many powdery mildews need to spread.

3. Destroy all infected plant material at the end of this year's growing season (do not compost).

4. Look on seed packets for resistant zinnia varieties next year.

Fungicides are available to help prevent the spread of powdery mildew once it is noticed on your plants; however, fungicides will not "cure" the plants of this disease. It generally is not necessary to use a fungicide if you follow the suggestions above.

Here is some additional information on powdery mildew:

https://extension.umn.edu/plant-diseases/powdery-mildew-flower-garden
1.author: Sharon Globig

symptom description: white fungus or mold like spots on the leaves
management instructions: Space plants far enough apart to provide good air circulation.
Avoid overhead watering.
Destroy all infected plant material at the end of the growing season.
Look for resistant zinnia varieties.
Fungicides can be used to help prevent the spread of powdery mildew.
qa_information.background info: none

title: Maple Leaf concern #752246
question:
Hello!  In the past few days I've noticed lots of leaves that have withered and dropped from the silver maple (I believe) in our front yard.  I've attached a photo of one of the leaves I picked up on the ground.
Is this due to the late freeze that we had?  Have you seen this damage before?  Do I need to get an arborist to check out the health of the tree?  FYI, the tree is less than 20 years old.
I actually live in the Fulton Heights Neighborhood area, less than 2 miles from your extension office.
Thanks so much for any assistance you can provide!

1.response:
I have indeed seen this before, and no, you do not need to consult an arborist nor is it caused by recent frosts.

This is a fungal disease called maple anthracnose and is generally only a cosmetic issue. Under ideal conditions, however, the disease can be severe, leading to premature defoliation and contributing to decline when other diseases and/or insect pests are present. Healthy trees may undergo defoliation in spring shortly after leaf out but are able to flush a new set of foliage and recover. Young trees are more susceptible to lasting damage while older, established trees typically suffer only minor growth losses.

Anthracnose fungi overwinter within leaf tissue and in infected twigs and buds. In the spring, fruiting bodies are produced and spores are spread by wind and splashing rainwater. Infected leaves are the primary source of inoculum and should be removed
from the site and destroyed (not composted). If the disease is severe, infected shoots should be pruned out, as they can also harbor the pathogen. This sanitation practice is the most important management step you can take and will reduce the amount of spores present to infect new leaves and shoots the following spring.

Maintaining tree vigor through adequate fertilization, watering,
mulching and pruning will help lessen the impacts of the disease.

The link below will give you some additional information.

https://www.canr.msu.edu/news/maple_leaf_blister_and_anthracnose_two_foliar_diseases_that_can_appear_on_s
1.author: Sharon Globig

symptom description: leaves have dropped from the tree
management instructions: Remove infected leaves from the site and destroy them.
If the disease is severe, prune out infected shoots.
Maintain tree vigor through adequate fertilization, watering, mulching, and pruning.
qa_information.background info: The tree is less than 20 years old and is a silver maple.

title: What's eating my impatiens? #811249
question: I have 5 impatiens plants in my screened in porch. I purchased them all on July 3rd and up until last week they have all been growing beautifully. They all are in mostly shady areas, receiving 2-4 hours of sun each day (max!). Something has been eating all of the leaves and flowers off of the plants. I am extremely confident that it's not an animal since the plants are all in the screened in porch (with doors that lock) and nothing that big can get inside. There are a few small holes in the screens that are big enough for flying insects to get in, but that's all. Whatever "it" is, the damage occurs overnight. And "it" also seems to be big enough/strong enough to push small amounts of soil onto the floor (see pic). In the first pic you can see how much damage has been done to one of the plants and in the other pic you can see how healthy the plants used to be and the leaves and soil on the floor. Any help you can give me regarding what is causing the damage - and what I can do to stop it - is much appreciated! Thank you!!

answer.response: I have 5 impatiens plants in my screened in porch. I purchased them all on July 3rd and up until last week they have all been growing beautifully. They all are in mostly shady areas, receiving 2-4 hours of sun each day (max!). Something has been eating all of the leaves and flowers off of the plants. I am extremely confident that it's not an animal since the plants are all in the screened in porch (with doors that lock) and nothing that big can get inside. There are a few small holes in the screens that are big enough for flying insects to get in, but that's all. Whatever "it" is, the damage occurs overnight. And "it" also seems to be big enough/strong enough to push small amounts of soil onto the floor (see pic). In the first pic you can see how much damage has been done to one of the plants and in the other pic you can see how healthy the plants used to be and the leaves and soil on the floor. Any help you can give me regarding what is causing the damage - and what I can do to stop it - is much appreciated! Thank you!!
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Hi Stacey!

This is a cool little mystery! The white coating on the leaves and defoliation tells us that downy mildew is the culprit. We can see many of the fallen dead leaves in the photo. Check out our page on this common disease that impacts impatiens.  You will want to bag and discard (do not compost) the diseased plant to prevent spread. Fungicide is not curative, so it will not have any effect on your symptomatic plant; they must be applied preventatively. 

We do list a few resistant and tolerant species of impatiens on the page linked above; these might be good replacements for the plant lost. 

It's tough to see from the photo, but there appears to be stippling on the leaves which could be from the sucking feeding parts of thrips. You can use some yellow sticky paper traps to catch them, but otherwise no control is necessary. 

Jamie
answer.author: Jamie Wiesner

answer.response:
Hi Jamie!
THANK YOU so much!! Wow - I never would have thought it was downy mildew! You are amazing!

I am so appreciative of this information and all that you do at the Extension!!

Have a wonderful weekend!
Best, Stacey
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response: You're welcome.

title: Spruce tree needle loss #396833
question:
Over the past year my evergreens have been dropping needles and leaving bare branches on the lower branches of the trees especially on the north side of the trees. 
1) What could be the cause?
2) Should I remove the dead branches?
3) What is causing this?
4) What can I do to prevent further loss?

1.response:
A combination of factors is likely causing your spruce tree to lose its lower needles. As the trees in your yard mature their canopies are growing closer together and reducing the amount of sunlight reaching the tree’s lower branches. Spruce trees need full sunlight and will grow poorly in shade.  The spruce tree may not be getting enough sunlight to support the lower branches.  Prune out the dead wood. Spruce trees that are grown in crowded settings with poor air circulation are often predisposed to fungus infections.  Some fungus infect the needles on the lower branches of the tree first and move upwards into the tree canopy. You may need a hand lens to see the signs of the different fungus. The following sites will help you determine whether your spruce tree also has a fungal infection.
http://www.extension.umn.edu/garden/yard-garden/trees-shrubs/spruce-tree-diseases/fungi-associated-with-needle-loss/index.html http://www.extension.umn.edu/garden/diagnose/plant/evergreen/spruce/branchesdead.html

http://www.extension.umn.edu/garden/diagnose/plant/evergreen/spruce/branchesdead.html

http://msue.anr.msu.edu/news/whats_going_on_with_blue_spruce

https://web.extension.illinois.edu/plantclinic/downloads/Plant%20Clinic%20Report%20Spruce.pdf

   Try to reduce stress on the spruce tree by providing water during periods of drought and mulching the area around the tree.
1.author: Pat Mack

symptom description: bare branches on the lower branches of the trees
management instructions: Prune out the dead wood.
Reduce stress on the spruce tree by providing water during periods of drought.
Mulch the area around the tree.

title: Wild apple identification help please #604387
question: These apples grow wild in the woods on our far. So excited to harvest them!  Just wondering if you could help ID them.  Lots of large apples this year! Thanks!

answer.response:
This is difficult to do without being able to turn the apple in my hand, look at the calyx end, feel the weight, taste it, etc.  It could be that these trees grew from seed and so are not any named variety.  Is each apple from a different tree?   

I am going to assume these are named commercial varieties and not more obscure heirloom varieties. 

The yellow apple on the left is Crispin / Mutsu like.  

The second one from the left has coloration of Ida Red.  This variety has white flesh, tart flavor, somewhat soft, somewhat McIntosh-like skin.

The third from the left looks somewhat like a Wealthy apple.  This variety ripens late, firm flesh, more of a cooking apple as it is not a particularly good fresh market apple.

I don't have a good guess for the apple on the extreme right.

title: Bare Patch, Front Yard Garden, How to rehabilitate it #436676
question: The accompanying photo shows a bare patch, roughly ellipsoidal, surrounding my front yard bird feeder. I added hardwood chips to the path (lower left) leading to the ellipsoidal area as well as to the area itself. The results were not what I had expected, so I've since removed all the chips. The bare spot is not very pleasing visually, so I'd like to rejuvenate the soil, which I suspect has experienced a shift in pH and/or other possibly deleterious changes. Your suggestions about how to effect this would be most welcome. I'm not necessarily wed to planting grass seed and/or overlaying sod, so I'm wondering if you can recommend some low-growing, ornamental grasses or other plants requiring less constant tending than turf grass to help transform this "arid" patch. Many thanks and happy holidays!  For the record, I was facing NNE to take this photo, so principal sun exposure (5-6 hrs. daily) comes from the right side of the view.

1.response:
Sunflower seed has allelopathic properties.  The seed shell or hull has toxic chemicals that hinder or kill other plants.  Judging by the number of squirrels in your photo, we suspect there is a great deal of sunflower seed in use.  The toxic chemicals will build up in the soil. It could take years for the toxins to break down and wash away.  We do not have any research on what plants can withstand sunflower seed toxins. Established shrubs seem to do better.  Planting large shrubs may also be successful. Some people have switched to shelled sunflower seed to avoid this problem. 

You may not be able to be much to grow under and near the birdfeeder. If you want to keep using sunflower seed, you may want to make a purposeful oval or other pleasing shape of mulch to make the bare area fit in your landscape better. A paver or brick/stone edging will make it look tidy.  The constant scratching of squirrels and pecking of birds also disrupts plant growth and makes new plantings problematic. Another option is to pave the area with flagstone or similar thin pavers to create a pleasing hardscape. 

ECN
1.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

management instructions: Consider switching to shelled sunflower seed.
Create a purposeful oval or other pleasing shape of mulch to make the bare area fit in the landscape.
Use a paver or brick/stone edging to make the area look tidy.
Pave the area with flagstone or similar thin pavers to create a pleasing hardscape.
Plant large shrubs, which may be more successful in withstanding sunflower seed toxins.
qa_information.background info: The area receives 5-6 hours of daily sun exposure from the right side, hardwood chips were previously added to the area but have since been removed, the area is near a bird feeder with frequent squirrel and bird activity.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a yard with multiple squirrels actively moving around, likely attracted by the bird feeder which is visible on the left side of the image. The ground appears bare in some areas where the previous layer of hardwood chips has been removed, exposing soil that may be attracting squirrels due to its accessibility and potential food sources.

Given these observations, here are some recommended management strategies:

1. **Provide Alternative Food Sources**: Introduce feeders specifically designed for birds or other small animals to reduce the attractiveness of the bird feeder to squirrels. This can help deter them from raiding birdseed.

2. **Use Squirrel-Proof Feeders**: There are various types of feeders designed to prevent squirrels from accessing the seeds. Some models use a baffle system, while others have hinged lids or spinners that rotate to keep squirrels at bay.

3. **Install a Feeder Guard**: A metal cage or netting around the feeder can protect it from squirrels. The cage should extend several feet below the feeder to prevent squirrels from reaching the seed.

4. **Eliminate Attractive Elements**: Ensure that there is no food or water source (other than the intended bird feeder) that could attract squirrels. This includes removing any spilled food or birdseed from the ground.

5. **Maintain the Area**: Regularly clean up any fallen seeds or bird droppings to keep the area tidy and less appealing to squirrels.

6. **Consider Physical Barriers**: Installing a physical barrier like a fence around the perimeter of the garden can help prevent squirrels from accessing certain areas. However, this should be used as a last resort, as it might disturb the natural habitat and behavior of wildlife.

7. **Educate Neighbors**: If multiple gardens in the neighborhood are experiencing similar issues, sharing information and solutions can help collectively manage the problem.

By implementing these strategies, you can create an environment that is less attractive to squirrels while still being welcoming to birds and other wildlife.

title: White torn tomatoes leaves #794397
question:
I bought tomatoes from SAP school benefit that arrived May 4 and various weather issue didn’t allow safe planting. Stored under grow lights for almost a month in garage. Plants grew leggy and TALL.
I planted in groups of 3 in three locations starting on June 1 . Most look terrible now 
And seem to get white areas , tears or holes 
And some curl up . Is this sun scald or a fungus? Never in25 years have I had this happen. Can they be saved? Should I remove and dispose of in trash? Will soil be affected? Can in remove snd plant again same soil this year?Very disappointed . I usually have HUGE and very productive plants (12-16 )of sweet 100 cherry every year.  Pictures below. I live in St. Anthony Park, St. Paul. Appreciate any help.

answer.response:
This looks more like over fertilization but it could also be sun scald or a combination.  The early leggy growth and excess sunlight suggest over fertilization. Overwatering can also cause this. Lack of certain nutrients such as iron can cause this also.  Read more at the following website.  The tomato in the top picture looks beyond saving.  The bottom looks like it might be okay if the conditions are corrected.
https://www.gardeningknowhow.com/edible/vegetables/tomato/tomato-leaves-turn-white.htm
answer.author: Marykay Haas

management instructions: Correct the conditions to save the plants.
qa_information.background info: The plants were stored under grow lights for almost a month in a garage before being planted outside in groups of 3 in three locations on June 1. The plants grew leggy and tall before being planted outside. The Question Asker has never had this issue in 25 years and usually has huge and productive plants.

title: What am I #609989
question: Can someone please tell me what this baby is?

answer.response:
Thank you for your question. The snake in your photograph is a Ball Python, scientific name Python regius. This species is native to central and western Africa. It is one of the most popular pet snakes, due to its usually mild disposition and small size. Adult females average 3 - 5 feet, and males are usually 2 - 3 feet in length.

Using various genetic traits, breeders have developed various morphs, which are snakes that exhibit other than normal colors and pattern variations. One website indicates there are currently over 7,000 different morphs for this species. I am not an expert on morphs, but your snake looks like it may be one of the "spider" morphs.

Here's a care sheet for this species published by Reptiles magazine that you can use to ensure you are providing an appropriate environment and habitat for your snake:

http://www.reptilesmagazine.com/Care-Sheets/Snakes/Ball-Python/

I hope this answers your question, and thank you for contacting Ask an Expert.

Jim

title: Anthurium leaf issue #738049
question: I bought this anthurium in mid-February at Seward coop. I have six other anthuriums that are all doing great. I found this condition about 2-3 weeks ago. I took my leaf to Mother Earth and they thought it was something in the soil. They also had new anthuriums who's leaves looked just like plant. What is up?

answer.response:
Hello!  Happy to help.

The disease looks to be bacterial because of the shot holes and the slightly yellowish ring around the blackened areas.  I see it all throughout your plant which means you can't simply cut out the affected leaves and expect to contain the problem.  I recommend taking the plant back to the seller for a refund.  Definitely keep it away from your other plants and wash your hands and any utensils used on this plant before touching other plants.  (Plant distancing and hygiene.)

If you prefer, you can get a definitive diagnosis by sending in a symptomatic leaf to the U of MN Extension Plant Disease Clinic.  Here is the link to their site where you'll learn about their services, prices, and how to submit a sample.


Good-luck!
answer.author: Ellen Campbell

title: scarlet runner bean leave curling and spotting #183234
question: My scarlet runner bean's leaves are curling on the edges and getting brittle and the leaves are getting spots.  I sprayed it with a a product that says it is a fungicide, insecticide and miticide.  It doesn't seem to be working.

1.response:
You can stop spraying. The leaf changes occurred because your plant ran short of water, perhaps during our recent session with higher than normal temperatures.  During hot spells, container plants may need to be watered several times each day.  Also helpful is to either move the pot to a shaded site during the heat or to rig temporary shade.

Runner bean plants can become quite large.  Next time you plant them, consider using a much larger pot or, if possible, planting in the ground.
1.author: Jean R. Natter

symptom description: leaves are curling on the edges
management instructions: Stop spraying the fungicide, insecticide and miticide.
Water the plant more frequently, especially during hot spells.
Consider moving the pot to a shaded site during the heat or rigging temporary shade.
Use a larger pot or plant in the ground for future plantings.

title: Lawn care  #240904
question:
Hi,

I have this "weed" (?) growing amongst my grass very aggressively.  Would you be able to identify it for me and provide a potential treatment?  Thanks in advance!!

Usman

answer.response:
It is Poa Annua, which is an annual bluegrass. It grows very quickly and aggressively in the late winter and early spring. It was very aggressive this year. In the home lawn it is very difficult to control. There are some chemical controls that are used on golf courses and Athletic Fields, however they are not labeled for home use. It can be cut out and then reseed the area if you want to take the time to do that. It still will not give you 100% control because the plant produces 1000's of seeds in a year to repopulate the plant. The link is to a fact sheet that talks about cultural control of poa in residential lawns from the University of Georgia..


http://extension.uga.edu/publications/detail.cfm?number=B1394
answer.author: Jeff Fowler

management instructions: It can be cut out and then reseed the area

title: Tomatoes #488441
question: What causes these holes in tomatoes whether they're green or ripe?

1.response:
Tomato Fruit Worms

It looks like damage from Tomato Fruit Worms. Here is a good reference on tomato diseases.
http://www.missouribotanicalgarden.org/gardens-gardening/your-garden/help-for-the-home-gardener/advi...
For control of these pests see you can use Insecticidal Soap of the insecticide Sevin.

title: What is affecting my peony leaves? #261273
question: Could you let me know what is affecting the pictured peony leaves? It gets plenty of sun, and reasonable air circulation, but always looks sickly and each year the leaf blotches get worse. Anything I can do to treat this? We are located in Ontario, Canada, and the zone is 5.

1.response:
Phytophthora Blight

Figure 2. Phytophthora blight often invades the crown and causes a wet rot.

The symptoms of blight caused by this fungus, Phytophthora cactorum, may be confused with the symptoms produced by Botrytis sp. The stems, leaves, and buds can be affected by both diseases. However, with Phytophthora blight, there is no felty growth or sporulation on the plant surface when in a wet environment. Infected parts become dark brown or black and somewhat leathery. The entire shoot may turn black and die (Figure 2). Cankers may appear along the stems and cause them to fall over. While Botrytis sp seldom invades the crown, Phytophthora sp often does, causing a wet rot to develop and destroy the entire plant. Because infections of this disease generally occur in the roots and lower portions of the stem, spraying with fungicides is of little value. Confirmed cases should be removed and destroyed, together with adjacent soil. Planting healthy clumps in new locations where the soil is well drained usually prevents further trouble.
1.author: Dennis Mielke

2.response:
Thanks for your response, Dennis M. Much appreciated.  So I guess no more Peonies in this particular location ;-(


Regards



Louise
2.author: The Question Asker

management instructions: Confirmed cases should be removed and destroyed, together with adjacent soil.
Plant healthy clumps in new locations where the soil is well drained.

title: Blackberries disease  #869096
question:
I received 10 Triple Crown Blackberry bare roots. Planted in planters and each plant was growing new leaves and looked healthy. However, after about 3 months  some of the plants leaves starting browning. Planted into ground about 3 weeks ago hoping this would help but all the plants seen to have some fading/silvering/browning than dying leaves.
I would like to know what is causing this. If there is a treatment, or if I need to remove them due to potential spreading   to other fruit plant?

answer.response: The fading color, necrotic patches and marginal reddening of leaves is typical of sunburn. We had some very abrupt hot and sunny weather a few weeks ago. Recent transplants are susceptible to sunburn like this especially if they go from greenhouse or shade into direct sun. To prevent this in the future you can use a white shade cloth until the plants are adapted to the new conditions. For now, I think the growing points should be ok and there is nothing you can do other than take good care of them watering as needed this summer.
answer.author: Jay Pscheidt

management instructions: Use a white shade cloth for future transplants until the plants are adapted to the new conditions.
Take good care of the plants, watering as needed.

title: Slow Development?  #317107
question: There is Japanese maple tree in the back yard that is not very "leafy" at this time of the spring season compared to previous years.  The plant is 5 to 10 years old; about 4 feet high and 4 feet wide; located in a partially shaded area with good drainage.  No indication of any pest damage.  Your recommendations/suggestions will be appreciated.  Thanks.

answer.response:
Your Japanese maple is suffering from cold damage.  Many plants, including other Japanese maples, in our area have suffered similar symptoms.  It appears that there was a sudden cold snap just as the buds were forming, or at some stage in their development, which resulted in many of the buds being damaged. While this year may result in a much narrower growth ring in the central trunk, the tree should survive.  It may help to provide supplemental irrigation during periods of dry, hot weather.  All plants would like to receive about 1 inch of rain water each week, so if we have an extended dry spell, you could place a garden hose under the canopy of the tree and allow the hose to trickle for an hour or so.
LS
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

management instructions: Provide supplemental irrigation during periods of dry, hot weather.
Water the tree with about 1 inch of water each week, or use a garden hose to trickle water under the canopy for an hour or so during extended dry spells.

title: Insect infestation on Hostas #799546
question:
What are these bugs that have appeared on my Hostas within in the last four days.  We returned from our cabin to find these clusters on several of our Hostas.  They do not seem to be destroying the leaves, just collecting on the tops.  

They seem to resemble small box elder bugs, but our box elder treee has been gone for almost two years, and I never saw these even when we had the tree.

Are they likely to harm the Hostas?
Should I be worried about other garden plants?
What should I do, if anything?

Thank you, Bonny Paetznick
3524 Adair Avenue North
Crystal, Mn 55422

answer.response: These are boxelder nymphs - the young stage of the adult boxelder. You can see the adult tending the nymphs in picture 2. They won't harm your hostas, but they can be a nuisance especially as we move into winter. You can blast them with water or knock them into a bucket of soapy water.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a large number of insects, likely boxelder bugs (Boisea trivittata), clustered on the leaves of Hostas in Hennepin County, Minnesota. Boxelder bugs are typically not harmful to plants and do not cause significant damage unless there is an extremely large population. However, their presence can be unsightly and may necessitate control measures if they become a nuisance.

Here are some recommended management strategies for dealing with boxelder bugs on Hostas:

1. **Physical Removal**: Gently pick off the insects by hand and dispose of them in soapy water. This method works best for small populations.

2. **Vacuuming**: Use a vacuum cleaner to remove the insects from the leaves. Be sure to empty the vacuum bag or container after use to avoid re-releasing the bugs into your garden.

3. **Insecticidal Soap**: Apply a solution of insecticidal soap to the affected leaves. This can be effective but should only be used as a last resort because it can harm beneficial insects.

4. **Habitat Modification**: Since boxelder bugs typically congregate on boxelder trees, removing the host plant will help reduce their numbers. In this case, since the boxelder tree has been gone for almost two years, this might not be necessary, but ensuring no other potential hosts are present nearby could be helpful.

5. **Encourage Beneficial Insects**: Some beneficial insects, such as ladybugs and lacewings, feed on boxelder bugs. Encouraging these insects in your garden can help control the population naturally.

6. **Cultural Practices**: Keep the garden clean and free of debris where boxelder bugs might hide. Regularly pruning and maintaining plants can also help reduce the number of hiding spots.

Given that the boxelder bug population appears to be substantial, the physical removal or vacuuming methods would likely be most effective in managing the infestation. If the population continues to grow, consider using a mild insecticidal soap as a supplementary measure. Always read and follow the instructions on the product label carefully before applying any pesticide.

title: Bugs  on bushes #834097
question: What bug and how do I kill this bug on my bushes.  It is eating away on the leaves.

answer.response:
Hello,

Based on what I see in the images - These appear to be aphids. Numerous aphids feed on trees and shrubs in the landscape. They may occur throughout the season when plants are actively growing. Some are vectors for viral diseases of plants. Aphids suck plant sap from leaves and stems, causing distorted growth, yellowing of foliage, and premature leaf drop. Aphids also excrete honeydew, a sticky substance that sooty mold fungi can grow on.

Management
Aphids have many natural enemies, including syrphid fly larvae, lacewings, lady beetles, and parasitic wasps. Soaps, oils, and other insecticides are also effective.

title: Spanish lavender tree browning and yellowing #652400
question: I planted my newly purchased Spanish lavender tree 3 weeks ago with the original container that has a drainage into a larger container. The plant had beautiful flowers and now they died off but my concern is the yellowish and brownish color of the plant itself. Is something going on with it? Or is it normal? Was the way I planted it wrong- smaller container in a larger container? Please, advice. I would be sad if I lost this plant. Thank you so much, karin

answer.response:
Thank you for your question. From a site entitled, "Everything Lavender" comes the following information which may help you understand why your lavender is not thriving. I hope it helps you to bring it back. It might also help you to go to Everything Lavender for even more information. 
Jeanne

One of the biggest problems and causes of Lavender dying out is the overwatering of potted Lavender or excessive soil moisture for those plants grown in the ground. Lavender grows in loose, slightly sandy or gritty alkaline soil that is fast draining. 

    Over wet soil conditions leads to fungus and root rot problems. This can cause wilted black leaves where the plant is dying back. Treatment involves cutting back of the diseased areas and allowing the plant to dry out. 

    Fungus can live almost anywhere. The most common fungii are Botrytis (gray mold) and Pytophthora (root rot.) They occur principally because of excess moisture either in the air or soil.

    What can you do? Clear out around the plant as much as possible such as removing dead leaves, stems or debris. Use a heat reflecting mulch of coarse builders sand, pea gravel or washed shells. Use proper spacing when planting to allow good air circulation.

    Frequently, once started it is too late to save a plant suffering from this condition. High humidity in the air can promote this type of problem as well. What do you do? You can take cuttings from the remaining healthy sections and root them to get a new plant.

    Lavender prefers loose soil that will not compact around its roots preventing the excess moisture from draining away. Place a handful of sand or small gravel in the bottom of your planting hole to allow for good drainage. 
    Plants occasionally wilt during the heat of the day to conserve moisture if it's really hot. If you see droopy wilting Lavender do not run for water but check back in the early evening and see if the plant looks different before fetching that watering pail.

    Plants can wilt from too much water meaning that the roots are waterlogged and cannot absorb what is there. If this happens your plant is a goner. The health of any plant starts with the roots. Happy roots usually mean healthy plant.

    Plants do well in dry, stony poor soils which makes it an excellent plant to grow on a hot sunny bank where the water can easily run off.

Yellowing Leaves or Foliage

     A Lavender with yellowing leaves is a common problem. Lavender leaves turning yellow are indicative of different things depending on planting conditions. A potted or container grown plant with yellowing foliage could indicate too much or too little nitrogen.

    Yellow leaves for those plants grown in the ground usually means a moisture problem so humidity and drainage need improvement . Yellow leaves with a gray or sooty black color is a fungal problem.Lack of Enough Light

     The second biggest problem is not enough sun. Lavender comes from a dry climate region that has tons of sun. This plant loves to sunbathe! Think about hot, sunny, breezy days at your favorite beach and you have what it likes.


Choosing the Wrong Location

     Frequently people plant Lavender where they want it to be and not where it prefers to be. Find a warm, sunny, airy location, and choose the right Lavender variety for your area. Prepare the soil if necessary by loosening it and adding sand to loosen compacted clay soils and promote much needed drainage.

This is one of the keys to success. A loose friable gritty slightly alkaline soil that is fast draining will make all the difference in the world.
answer.author: Jeanne Quintavalla

management instructions: Clear out around the plant as much as possible such as removing dead leaves, stems or debris.
Use a heat reflecting mulch of coarse builders sand, pea gravel or washed shells.
Use proper spacing when planting to allow good air circulation.
Cut back diseased areas and allow the plant to dry out.
Take cuttings from the remaining healthy sections and root them to get a new plant.

title: Identify a Spring Weed #556553
question: What is this weed that crops up every Spring? It is easy to pull up, but it takes a LOT of my good soil with its root structure. Thank you for your help!

1.response:
These weeds are bittercress, a Cardamine species, aka shotweed or popweed They are winter annuals that grow during the cool season. They are especially prolific and fling their seeds far and wide when their elongated green seed pods are disturbed.
Begin to watch for the seedlings when the fall rains begin. Then, continue to be watchful through the spring months. All during that time, pull them as you see them, before they enlarge and definitely before they flower. Or, where you have a dense planting as shown in your image, use a scuffle hoe, or a similar winged weeder, to cut them off at ground level before the small leafy rosette puts up a flower stem.
See "Stop the Popping" at http://marinmg.ucanr.edu/Marin_Master_Gardener_Help_Desk/Leaflet/d/ also "Bittercress" at http://hortsense.cahnrs.wsu.edu/Search/MainMenuWithFactSheet.aspx?CategoryId=6&ProblemId=2075
1.author: Jean R. Natter

management instructions: Begin to watch for the seedlings when the fall rains begin.
Continue to be watchful through the spring months.
Pull them as you see them, before they enlarge and definitely before they flower.
Use a scuffle hoe, or a similar winged weeder, to cut them off at ground level before the small leafy rosette puts up a flower stem.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a field of bittercress, which is a common weed that can be difficult to manage due to its invasive nature and the ease with which it can spread. The management strategy for bittercress should focus on preventing its spread and controlling its growth.

### Recommended Management Strategies:

1. **Mechanical Control**:
   - **Hand Pulling**: While effective, it requires significant effort and is only feasible on small areas. Be sure to remove the entire taproot as it can regrow from fragments left behind.
   - **Mulching**: Apply a thick layer of mulch over the area where bittercress is growing. This can prevent the seeds from germinating and also suffocate the existing plants if they are not too deeply rooted.

2. **Chemical Control**:
   - **Pre-emergence Herbicides**: These are applied before the bittercress seeds germinate. They work by disrupting the growth of the seedling’s roots, preventing it from emerging from the soil.
   - **Post-emergence Herbicides**: These are used after the bittercress has emerged. They target the leaves or stems and can be more effective when the plant is actively growing. Be cautious with chemical applications to avoid harming other plants or the environment.

3. **Cultural Practices**:
   - **Mulching**: Regularly applying a layer of mulch around the plants can help suppress the growth of bittercress by reducing the amount of light reaching the soil surface.
   - **Crop Rotation**: Avoid growing crops that are susceptible to bittercress in the same location year after year. Planting different types of crops can disrupt the life cycle of the weed.
   - **Healthy Soil Management**: Ensure that your soil is healthy and well-nourished. A strong, robust soil ecosystem can help suppress weeds naturally.

4. **Biological Control**:
   - **Weed Eaters**: There are certain species of insects and fungi that can be introduced to control bittercress. However, these methods are less common and may not be readily available in most regions.

5. **Regular Monitoring and Maintenance**:
   - Keep an eye on the area for any signs of bittercress regrowth. Regular monitoring will help you catch it early and prevent it from becoming a major problem.

### Specific Considerations for Deschutes County, Oregon:
- **Time of Year**: Bittercress tends to be most active during spring and early summer, so early intervention is crucial.

title: Spots on my Rhodie #788295
question: What is causing these spots on my Rhododendron?  Located on North side of house with East and West sun exposure.  Newport Oregon

answer.response:
It looks like you have a couple things going on.   Looks like caterpillar chewing on the leaves.  Caterpillars should only be a short term problem but can be handpicked if you see them.

The smaller, brownish spots are probably caused by a leaf spot fungus.  High humidity and frequent rainfall can help spread fungal spores.   This should not normally seriously damage a shrub but it could recur next season.    Here are some cultural controls you may want to consider:
 - Prune and remove any heavily infested plant material (dispose in trash);
 - Increase air circulation through selective pruning (usually air circulation is not a big problem with rhododendrons);
 - Do not overhead water (possibly use drip irrigation);
 - Clean up plant debris underneath and around the shrub each fall (fungal spores can overwinter in this debris and then be splashed onto leaves by rain and/or sprinklers causing reinfection).

If you want to consider use of fungicides, remember that fungicides are best at preventing fungal disease and most are not effective at eradicating it.  It is best to utilize cultural controls first to try to make the conditions less favorable for fungal infection.  

If you consider a chemical control, please read and follow all label instructions.    Here is some helpful information from the Pacific NW Plant Disease Handbook - https://pnwhandbooks.org/plantdisease/pesticide-articles/fungicides-disease-management-home-landscape
answer.author: Bill Hutmacher

management instructions: handpick caterpillars if seen
prune and remove heavily infested plant material
increase air circulation through selective pruning
do not overhead water
clean up plant debris underneath and around the shrub each fall

title: Help with lawn #866404
question:
I live in St Louis Park and have a grub problem. The critters (raccoons, birds,etc etc) are ruining my grass. I would like to know what & when to put down grub product that will be most effective immediately. Should I detach, aerate, over seed my lawn before or after grub application? I really need help to stop raccoons, birds or whatever is “detaching” my yard. I believe my lawn need nutrients also.
They are making holes everywhere.
Thank you for your expert advice. I can send you pics if you like.
Maggie Solomon

1.response:
Grubs most likely are the cause of the critter damage to your lawn, but now is not the time to try to eliminate them.  Wait until late summer, when grub treatment will be most effective.  See https://extension.umn.edu/yard-and-garden-news/whats-digging-your-yard for more information.  If you have a deep thatch layer you can aerate before applying grub treatment, but wait until fall to overseed.

Have patience if you can, and good luck with improving your lawn.

title: Burning Bush Problem #829839
question: I have 2 Burning Bushes near my porch.  One appears to be fine and the other has developed an issue with the leaves.  They are not opening on the bush.  Inspecting the leaves does not show any sign of bugs.  The leaves are closed in some areas of the bush, but some are fine.  The majority of the leaves are curled and closed. answer.response:
Dear Brenda,

Burning bushes prefer well-drained soil that is not compacted and not waterlogged. From the pictures you sent of your one burning bush near a terraced area, the droopy leaves that curl downward is often a sign of overwatering. The soil may be dense and difficult for the burning bush to have room to grow. https://apps.extension.umn.edu/garden/diagnose/plant/deciduous/hydrangea/curledcuppeddistortedleaves.html

Check and see if water pools around your burning bush that could be a sign that the soil is poorly drained. Add organic mulch around the burning bush and the area surrounding to help soil drainage. https://extension.umd.edu/resource/tree-problems-caused-excess-water

See if your downspouts drain away from the house and not into terraced beds.

Thank you for your question! Therese N. Michigan State University Extension Master Gardener Volunteer

You may also contact the toll free MSU Extension lawn and garden hotline at 1-888-678-3464 with your gardening questions or visit www.migarden.msu.edu for Smart Gardening resources.
answer.author: Therese Nagi

management instructions: Check if water pools around the burning bush.
Add organic mulch around the burning bush to help soil drainage.
Ensure downspouts drain away from the house and not into terraced beds.

title: Hydrangea plant #351524
question: Leaves have black spots. Please advice the solution for the problem. I am enclosing the picture of the plant

1.response:
Hello,

The picture you submitted shows a fungal leaf spot on your hydrangea.

The fungus Cercospora hydrangea causes leaf spot on common landscape hydrangeas and is favored by warm weather, rain, and high humidity. All types are susceptible, including bigleaf, oakleaf, panicle, and smooth-types. The plants are not killed by leaf spot, but it may reduce flowering and plant vigor. Symptoms include small circular purple spots which enlarge, and the centers of the spots turn tan or gray. Spores produced in the spots can be rain-splashed or wind-blown to other hydrangeas nearby to begin new infections. Heavily spotted leaves may turn yellow and drop from the plant, and fallen leaves can provide an overwintering place for the fungus. Management includes good air movement and light in plantings. Avoid overhead watering of the plants or water early in the morning so that leaves can dry off during daytime. Remove the worst affected leaves (when they are dry) to reduce disease spread. Clean out plant debris in winter to prevent overwintering of the fungus.  Fungicide treatments are recommended only on valuable plants with recurring damage every year. Fungicides containing active ingredients such as myclobutanil, or thiophanate-methyl may be applied just as spots are beginning to appear in early summer.


Thank you for contacting Cooperative Extension,

Remove the worst affected leaves (when they are dry) to reduce disease spread.
Clean out plant debris in winter to prevent overwintering of the fungus.
Apply fungicides containing active ingredients such as myclobutanil, or thiophanate-methyl in early summer.

title: Tree recovering from cicadas #849749
question:
We planted this tree a year or so before the cicada summer.  The insect damage left the remaining foliage in a dense clump. This year, we’re getting nice long new growth. The leaves in the older-growth area are beginning to blacken and shrivel. I don’t recall if this happened in past years.  Height is about 9 ft.  Diameter one foot above ground is 2.5 inches. 

Q1:  Should we prune to thin the tightly packed section?
Q2: Is the shriveling normal for this tree in September ?

And what’s the variety? I’ve lost the Sun Nursery invoice.

answer.response:
The leaf symptoms appear to be scorch, which is abiotic (meaning not caused by a pest or disease, at least not directly) in nature and suggests the roots might not have enough moisture. Scorch might not manifest right away, so drought stress any time in the prior weeks could be resulting in visible scorch now, even if recent rains might have been sufficient for the short term. Central Maryland has been experiencing drought for most of this year's growing season, and accumulated stress might be starting to damage some trees (and other plants) if they weren't being monitored for watering needs. Dogwoods as a group have limited drought tolerance and also prefer an exposure of mixed sun and shade; they can deal with full sun, but it's not the ideal. The proximity of a brick wall in this case might exacerbate any weather stress since it may be reflecting and/or radiating extra heat during summer as well as reducing air circulation through its canopy. Scorch cannot reverse itself but if the roots remain healthy and watering can be monitored up until the ground freezes, the tree will likely leaf-out normally next year.

Periodical cicada egg-laying damage can trigger branching in trees due to the stress on (or death of) the branch tips, but this greater degree of dense growth isn't necessarily something that needs correction. The best time to evaluate branch structure is during winter, when you can more easily observe where branches might be crossing over each other and rubbing bark, which is something to correct. That said, the best time to actually perform the pruning is early to midsummer for dogwoods; now is too late. While pruning in late winter won't necessarily hurt the tree, it will remove lots of flowers since the tree has pre-formed next year's flower buds by now, and they will lie dormant until flowering season next year without the ability to regrow if lost to pruning or weather stress between now and then.

Even though corrective pruning to remove defects that can worsen over time, like the aforementioned crossing branches, is best done when trees are young and the branches in question relatively thin, you also want to avoid over-pruning any one year. Removing more than about a quarter of a tree's canopy in a single growing season is not advisable given the stress it can cause the plant and potential stunting affect it could have on growth, since foliage removal limits the plant's ability to generate energy and store resources for later use.

There are several white-edged varieties of dogwood among American and Kousa (Asian) species, and they can look very similar to each other. Our educated guess for this tree, based on the variety's greater availability, the lack of obvious American Dogwood-style flower buds on the branch tips (Kousa Dogwood flower buds are more subtle), and general stature, is that this is Cornus kousa 'Samaritan'. A runner-up guess would be Cornus kousa 'Wolf Eyes', though as a more dwarf form, 'Wolf Eyes' usually looks shrubbier at this age (lower branches and rounder overall canopy), and its foliage also tends to curl inwards more, which we don't see here. When in bloom, dogwood species are easier to tell apart, with American (Cornus florida) having rounded petals and opening flowers before the foliage is very far along, and Kousa having pointed petals and opening flowers once foliage is fully expanded. Hybrids between these two, of which one or two might be variegated also, can have intermediate traits in terms of flower petal shape and when they bloom (between leaf emergence and when leaves are full size, usually).

Miri
answer.author: Mira Talabac

symptom description: leaves in the older-growth area are blackening
leaves in the older-growth area are shriveling
management instructions: Monitor watering needs to prevent further drought stress.
Avoid pruning now, instead prune in early to midsummer.
Avoid removing more than a quarter of the tree"s canopy in a single growing season.

The western boxelder bug, Boisea rubrolineata, and the red-shouldered bug, Jadera haematoloma, are indeed closely related (in the same family).

title: Maple Tree not leafing out #403491
question:
Planted in 2014, has doubled in size, now over 12 feet.
Has buds, branches are not dried or brittle. But no leaves.

Someone recommended spraying weekly with kelp.
Thank you
Nanci - Englewood, CO

1.response:
The late season freeze-hail-freeze has caused trees to struggle. As trees leaf out in the spring, late freezes can severely damage or kill buds and new leaves. This will cause a tree to use stored energy to re-leaf so this can result in a slower second try, or fewer/sparser leaves.

 

It's a good sign the branches are flexible and not brittle. You can also take a sharp knife or use a fingernail to gently scrape a small piece of bark off of several small twigs. If the exposed twig is green, the branch is still alive. It appears in the photo that the tree has many buds on it, some quite large perhaps nearing leaf out. Take a close look at the buds to see if they are green (alive) or black (dead).

 

Take a wait-and-see approach for the tree. Make sure the tree receives adequate moisture and look for growth. If your lawn is fertilized with Nitrogen-Phosphorus-Potassium (N-P-K), your tree does not need any additional fertilization of N-P-K.

 

Kelp is considered an organic fertilizer. It does not contain the major nutrients of N-P-K, but rather it is sometimes used to provide micronutrients: trace minerals, amino acids, vitamins and growth hormones that stimulates plant cell division. Wait to see if your tree leafs out before an application. There is more information on kelp at this link:

http://www.ext.colostate.edu/mg/gardennotes/234.pdf
1.author: Donnetta Wilhelm

management instructions: Take a wait-and-see approach.
Make sure the tree receives adequate moisture.
Check for growth.
Do not fertilize with N-P-K if the lawn is already fertilized.
qa_information.background info: The tree was planted in 2014, has doubled in size, and is now over 12 feet tall. Someone recommended spraying weekly with kelp.

title: Little black bug infestation #851160
question: A friend has an infestation of tiny black bugs, outside on patio. They are moving inside as it gets colder. They look like aphids but are black.

1.response: Hi Kathy, these appear to be springtails. Springtails typically are feeding on decaying organic matter, molds or mildews, fungal spores, detritus, etc. They are a helpful part of the decomposition process outside, and they are harmless, but to prevent them from coming indoors I would recommend making sure the doors/windows are well-sealed. Your friend can check for small gaps/cracks around the windows/doors where they may be entering from and seal those closed with a bit of caulk, and is also good to check for worn weathersealing around the door/window.
1.author: Alexandria Wenninger

management instructions: seal doors/windows
check for small gaps/cracks around windows/doors and seal with caulk
check for worn weathersealing around door/window

title: Blue Beach Tree white scale #643768
question:
We have an amazing old blue beach tree in our yard. Two years ago we saw white scale on one large branch. We remove the branch. 
This year, I see the scale n all of the tree bark. I tried a diluted mixture of Shaklee Basic H and water on the bark...as far up as I could reach without a ladder. Today, I looked and the white scale has NOT returned on the bark that I treated. I don’t see any ill effects either. Could this be a permanent solution to save our tree (and all beach trees?)

answer.response: A number of different pesticide treatments are somewhat effective against the beech scale insect.  However, there is no practical or affordable way to treat the entire surface of large trees in forest settings.  It only takes a small amount of the scale to allow the infection of the fungal disease that caused beech bark disease, so if you can't control all of the scale, a tree is still at risk.
answer.author: Erwin 'Duke' Elsner, Ph.D.

use pesticide treatments

title: Insect identification black bug on raspberry plant #804777
question:
Trying to identify a black bug beetle type appearance but doesn’t fly. Size 3-5mm, iridescent black , round body, and larger bug has red spot on belly and back.
Appears to be sucking on raspberry fruit.  Bug also seen on flowers in different area of yard. No apparent flower plant damage.

answer.response:
Hi Pam,

The insects you are seeing are immature (nymph stage) bordered plant bugs (Order: Hemiptera, Family: Largidae, Largus sp.). The immature stages are that iridescent black color, sometimes with red dots, while the adults are matte black with red-orange borders at the edges of the body. Here is a link to a photo of immature and adult bordered plant bugs so you can see them at their various stages of maturity....
https://bugguide.net/node/view/1161477/bgimage

Bordered plant bugs feed on flowers, leaves and fruits of a variety of plants. They aren’t generally considered pests, since they usually do minimal damage. However, if there are a bunch of them, they can do some noticeable damage to soft fruits (various berries, etc.). If you see bunches of these bugs and want to prevent damage to your plants, you could just gather up the individuals you find and freeze them to knock back the local population.

Hope that helps!
answer.author: William Gerth

management instructions: gather up the individuals and freeze them to knock back the local population

title: freeze damaged, or dead? #741578
question:
Hello,
We had 24 15 gal. sweet and sandanka viburnum installed in April 2020. The landscaper is not responding to my inquiries. They all look like they are dead from the freeze, but we have not done anything with them other than deep water once/week since the freeze.
The leaves are very dry and pull right off, but they are not falling off on their own.  The branches on some plants bend without breaking but others are brittle and snap in half.
I have attached 3 pictures.
In your opinion. do you think thy have a chance of survival, or are they dead?  Thank you in advance,
Thomas Kubiszyn
832-693-0507

answer.response:
Hi Thomas:

Thanks for your inquiry. It's sad to see photos like yours of all the freeze-damaged plants. Leaving them alone except for watering, as you've done, is the right process so far.

From what I understand, if the stems are brittle and snap in half, that plant is most likely dead.  The plants that have branches that bend without breaking have some hope, however.

Extension agent Matt Garrett has an article about dealing with freeze damage here: https://www.marshallnewsmessenger.com/opinion/matt-garrett-dealing-with-freeze-damage-on-plants/article_185239a2-7bb0-11eb-bc80-fb82d25bb943.html

Specifically, he says this about evergreen woody shrubs: 

"Evergreen Woody Shrubs (abelia, Asian jasmine, azaleas, banana shrub, camellias, eleagnus, fatsia, fig ivy, gardenias, Indian hawthorn, Japanese blueberry, ligustrum, loquat, loropetalum, oleander, pittosporum, privet, sasanquas, sweet olive, Texas sage, vibrunum, wax myrtle, etc.): Wait until they start to resprout from the existing stems or the ground, then cut away dead and leave what is alive and growing. Split stems will be dead. There will most likely be no blooms this year and all old foliage will most likely fall off. Many of these plants are from milder parts of southeastern Asia and simply aren’t used to zero degrees. Most broadleaf evergreens prefer milder climates while narrow leafed evergreens and deciduous plants are more adapted to colder climates."

I hope this is helpful.

Best wishes,

Gregory Thomas

Travis County Master Gardeners
answer.author: Travis County Master Gardener

answer.response:
Hello Mr. Thomas,Thank you for your prompt and informative reply, and for the link to the article.  Both were very helpful and are appreciated.  Best, Tom K.

title: Plant identification, please #750618
question: Are these fine leaf plants a type of fern?

1.response:
Thanks for the question.

Unfortunately they are not ferns. I say unfortunately because these are among the hardest invaders to eliminate. They are known as horsetails or Equisetum. They are one of the oldest living species on earth. Records exist indicating that they were here over 300 million years ago. They didn’t get to exist so long by accident. They are very tough and resilient plants. Herbicides, including glyphosate (Round Up), have no effect upon them. They reproduce by the release of thousands of spores that are wind-carried to new locations. If you try to pull one up, you will discover it has a very extensive and long root systems. But in pulling it up, you will be contributing to its further distribution, since even the smallest of root pieces left in the ground will give rise to a new plant. I hope these are not growing in a location you intend for something else as they are virtually impossible to eliminate once established. I have some in my gardens and I’ve just learned to live with them, talk to them, and plant around. See the following for further information:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equisetum

http://lifeofplant.blogspot.com/2011/03/horsetails.html

https://www.gardeningknowhow.com/edible/herbs/horsetail/horsetail-weed-control.htm - :~:text=In small areas, it may,at least one garden season.

https://peppershomeandgarden.com/how-to-kill-horsetail-weeds/

With respect to this plant you really have only two options: Just put up with them or try to dig them up on a monthly basis.

Good Luck
1.author: Steve Hedman

management instructions: Just put up with them
try to dig them up on a monthly basis
qa_information.background info: none

The ground is covered with a mix of dry, brown leaf litter and some fresh green leaves, indicating it might be spring or early summer. There are also some small green plants scattered around, adding to the diversity of vegetation in the area. The lighting suggests it is daytime, and the shadows indicate the presence of sunlight filtering through the canopy above.

title: Butterfly Bush #645885
question:
I have a butterfly bush that is being eaten by what looks like a mite. I want to spray a 3 in 1 spray that I bought from Valley View Farms. I have used this spray on my azaleas and roses but this will be the first time on the butterfly bush.
The active ingrefients are:
Tau-fluvalinate - 0.61%
Tebuconazole - 0.65%
Other Ingredients - 98.74%

1.response:
We would not recommend spraying your butterfly bush with that pesticide.

Butterfly bushes are tough plants with few problems.
As with any problem, correctly identifying the problem is the first step in learning what do do.
Could you please describe the issue you are seeing that makes you think it's mites, and even better, take a few photos of what you are seeing? Up to three at a time can be attached directly to this reply by using the Choose File tab below.
We'll be happy to take a look and advise.

It's important to know that the pesticide you are using is a pyrethroid that kills all kinds of insects, many of which are beneficial and naturally take care of landscape pests for us. It also contains a fungicide, which might be of use for your rose but not likely for your azalea or butterfly bush. The less pesticides we put into the environment, the better for us and the health of your landscape.


Christine
1.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

2.response:
Christine,
Thanks for the quick response.
Attached are two pictures one is of a leaf and the second is of the little black bugs that are on the underneath of one of the leafs.
This plant means a lot to our family.
Thanks and stay safe,
2.author: The Question Asker

3.response:
Good news for you.
The first photo shows what is just old incidental damage from a caterpillar or beetle that is long gone. The plant will continue to push out new leaves.
The second photo shows a red bug on the left edge that is not hurting anything, and it looks like, from the curling and the webbing that there may be a leaf rolling caterpillar under the edge. If you open it you can investigate. 
The black dots you are seeing look like caterpillar poop. The caterpillars and bugs act as bird food.
If only a small percentage of a mature plant has some damage and the rest of the leaves look well, not to worry. It is a natural part of a healthy ecosystem to support much biodiversity. 'Perfect'-looking plants are important to people who sell them, but as homeowners/gardeners, an acceptable level of damage is key to an overall healthy landscape.
Feel free to contact us again any time with your questions. 


Christine
3.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

4.response:
Christine,
Thanks for your response and I will keep an eye on it. At this time there are 4 leaves that are damaged and the rest of the plant is healthy.
4.author: The Question Asker

5.response:
A worrisome level of damage where you would consider taking action would be at about 30% of the plant.
We use a research-based holistic approach to landscape issues called IPM: Integrated Pest Managment. You can learn more about that here:
https://extension.umd.edu/hgic/topics/how-id-prevent-and-manage-plant-problems


Christine
5.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

title: peony foliage damage #560762
question: we had three peonies show foliage damage in a new bed.  most of the peonies were planted in the fall of 2018.  the soil is clayish.  28 peonies look good. Four had reduced growth.  nine did not emerge yet (dead?).  could this had been a moisture problem?  we did have a contractor spray weeds in the beds on site but I did not notice any weeds dead or alive in the peony bed.  could this have been the foliage problem?

answer.response:
These symptoms -- the yellowing and distorted growth -- are indicative of herbicide injury. https://extension.umd.edu/hgic/topics/herbicide-damage 

Given time, some plants eventually grow out of the symptoms of herbicide damage. There is nothing you can do at this point but wait and hope for the best. The plants need green foliage for photosynthesis and putting energy down into their root system so that they can survive the next winter.

If the soil in this area remained very wet over the winter, it is likely that some of your peony bulbs rotted. Most bulb plants will not tolerate poor drainage. You will have to replant the ones that didn't make it. https://extension.umd.edu/hgic/topics/bulbs

Christa
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

management instructions: There is nothing you can do at this point but wait and hope for the best.
Replant the peonies that did not make it.
qa_information.background info: The peonies were planted in the fall of 2018. The soil is clayish. A contractor sprayed weeds in the beds on site.

title: Pretty bush #624440
question: Anybody know what this bush is

answer.response:
Hello, Thanks for your question. It looks like a flowering quince or Botanical name: Chaenomeles speciosa

They are native to China, many varieties, many colors, some double blooms some single. Some have thorns, some produce an inedible fruit.

They are very hardy, drought tolerant and flowers early spring. Early pollinators and hummingbirds like the blooms. Prune flowering quince right after the flowers fade if you need to remove stray or dead branches. Blooms on second year wood. Some can get 8 to 10 feet tall and can be used as hedges. Others are dwarf.
answer.author: Lorraine Voll-Wallace

title: Flower bed problem  #783574
question: Attached is a photo of some type of vine covering a flower bed and is a huge problem. You have any idea what it is and how to get rid of it?

1.response:
In this photo, these "vines" appear to be tree roots. The root flare of the tree should be visible, however it is buried in the hill of soil/mulch surrounding the tree. This is an extreme example of the effects of volcano mulching and planting at an improper depth. This is not a healthy tree for that reason. The trunk looks decayed in spots near the soil line. 
The tree roots can be removed when the tree is removed. More information and photos here: 
Treemergency: Mulch Volcanos are Erupting in Landscapes!  https://bygl.osu.edu/node/1494
1.author: Carolyn Hufford - MGV

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a tree that appears to have been recently pruned or has bare branches, possibly indicating it is in its dormant season or is being prepared for spring growth. There are also areas of exposed soil and mulch, which might indicate recent landscaping work.

Given the time of year (March 9, 2022), it seems like the tree is likely in its dormant phase. This is a good time for pruning as it allows the tree to heal quickly without the stress of active growth. Here are some general management strategies you can consider:

1. **Pruning**: If there are dead, diseased, or crossing branches, they should be removed. Prune the tree carefully to maintain its structural integrity and shape.

2. **Mulching**: Ensure that the mulch around the base of the tree is properly applied. Mulching helps retain moisture, regulate soil temperature, and suppress weeds. However, it's important not to overmulch; a thin layer is sufficient (about 2-3 inches deep) and should be kept away from the trunk to prevent rot.

3. **Watering**: Depending on the weather conditions, you might need to water the tree to ensure it gets enough moisture, especially if the area has experienced dry spells.

4. **Fertilization**: In early spring, you can apply a balanced fertilizer to provide nutrients to the tree. Follow the instructions on the fertilizer package.

5. **Pest and Disease Management**: Inspect the tree for signs of pests or diseases. If needed, apply appropriate treatments according to the recommendations from a local horticulturist or extension office.

6. **Mulch Reapplication**: If the mulch has been disturbed, reapply it to maintain the benefits mentioned above.

7. **Mulch Ring**: Create a small ring of mulch around the tree trunk to help retain moisture and reduce weed competition. This ring should be wide but shallow, typically about 2-3 feet in diameter and 2-3 inches deep.

By following these steps, you can help ensure the health and vitality of the tree. If you notice any unusual symptoms or concerns, consulting with a local arborist or horticulturist would be advisable.

title: Black knot on plum tree? #783463
question: I found a couple spots of what I believe is black knot fungus on this plum tree in my orchard.  Should I remove the infected limbs below the fungal knots before the weather warms up?

answer.response: Yes, this is black knot. The dormant season is an excellent time to prune this out. Cut 4-6 inches below the knot. The knots indicate the tree was infected last year, and it's possible you may see additional black knots in the upcoming season.
