title: Leaves on rhododendron #631448
question: My rhododendron has some leaves that look diseased.  It is a huge, beautiful shrub and I don't want to lose it.  Can you tell me what is wrong and how I can treat?

answer.response:
Thank you for the image.
The rhododendron is not diseased. Instead, it was sunburned last year during one of our hot spells. Remove those leaves.
In the future, consider rigging temporary shade during a heat wave.

Rhododendrons need supplemental water every 3 to 4 weeks during our dry season to 8 inches deep. (Water from lawn sprinklers is not adequate.)  To determine if the soil is adequately moist, probe with a trowel.
Adding a 2-inch deep mulch of bark chips the soil surface is excellent for woody plants, and will slow evaporation losses. Start 6 inches from the trunk and extend the mulch outward to beyond the dripline.
answer.author: Jean R. Natter

answer.response: So good to hear my shrub is not sick.  I will try and take better care of it this summer.  There is only a small section with burnt leaves so that is good.  Thank you!
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response: You're welcome. Take care and be well.
answer.author: Jean R. Natter

management instructions: Remove the sunburned leaves.
Consider rigging temporary shade during a heat wave.
Provide supplemental water every 3 to 4 weeks during dry season to 8 inches deep.
Add a 2-inch deep mulch of bark chips to the soil surface, starting 6 inches from the trunk and extending outward to beyond the dripline.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a rhododendron plant with leaves that appear to have some discoloration and spots, which could indicate a fungal or bacterial infection or other stressors such as nutrient deficiencies or environmental factors like drought or overwatering. To address this issue, the following steps can be recommended:

1. **Identify the Cause**: Determine the exact cause of the leaf discoloration. This can often be done by examining the affected leaves closely under magnification or consulting with an agricultural extension agent who can provide a more precise diagnosis.

2. **Prune Affected Areas**: If the discoloration is localized, it may be beneficial to prune out the affected areas to prevent the spread of the issue. Ensure that you are using clean tools to avoid further contamination.

3. **Water Management**: Check the watering schedule. Overwatering or underwatering can both lead to leaf issues. Ensure the soil is well-drained and that the rhododendron receives consistent moisture but not excess water.

4. **Fertilization**: Assess if the plant might be lacking essential nutrients. Fertilize according to the soil test results. Use a balanced fertilizer suitable for acid-loving plants like rhododendrons.

5. **Cultural Care**: Ensure the plant is receiving adequate light, temperature, and humidity levels. Rhododendrons prefer partially shaded conditions and thrive in moist, acidic soil.

6. **Insecticides and Fungicides**: If the issue is identified as a fungal or bacterial infection, consider applying appropriate fungicides or bactericides. Follow the instructions carefully as these treatments need to be used correctly to be effective.

7. **Monitor Regularly**: Continue to monitor the plant for any signs of improvement or new symptoms. If the problem persists or worsens, seek advice from a local nursery or garden center specialist.

By following these steps, the health of the rhododendron can be improved, and the leaf discoloration should subside.

title: black spot on magnolia tree leaves #853825
question:
black spot on magnolia tree leaves
It has progressed a lot in the last 2 weeks
Tree is as tall as our 2nd floor windows on up

answer.response:
Hello,

Star magnolia, (Magnolia stellata), https://www.missouribotanicalgarden.org/PlantFinder/PlantFinderDetails.aspx?taxonid=282531&isprofile=1&basic=star%20magnolia

Is susceptible to leaf spot caused by insects, bacterial or viral diseases. However, the most common cause of leaf spot is caused by four common fungi. These fungi may cause leaf spot on other ornamental trees also. When environmental conditions are moist and the spores of these fungi are present, they can germinate on the wet leaves of many different plants. Therefore, the disease is likely to occur during rainy or humid weather.

Leaf spot is not considered a threat to a healthy tree. But it can be serious to trees under stress, such as young trees. It can be controlled by cultural practices. Because the fungus survives in compost and soil, it is best to rake up and dispose of any leaves or branches that have fallen to prevent any future infection. Increase air circulation around the tree by pruning out broken and rubbing branches and branches of neighboring trees that may encroach on the tree’s space. At the end of the growing season, prune out any infected stems and leaves and clean up and dispose of the infected material. Read more here: https://extension.umn.edu/plant-diseases/leaf-spot-diseases-trees-and-shrubs#identification-1156261

If the leaf spot is serious enough to warrant chemical intervention, it is necessary to identify the fungus causing the problem. MSU Extension’s Plant and Pest Diagnostic Lab can identify the fungus. Go to: https://www.canr.msu.edu/pestid/ to learn how to submit a sample.

Because fungicides are a preventative, not a cure, it is necessary to spray the plant before the fungus attacks the leaves. When using chemicals, read the label to ensure that it can be used against that disease on that specific plant. Follow the label directions on how to use the chemical.

A certified arborist can assess the tree. To find an arborist in your area, go to www.treesaregood.org, the website of the International Society of Arboriculture.

Thank you for contacting Ask Extension.

title: Unusual growth on coneflower #843578
question:
Hi,

Several of my coneflowers have an unusual growth coming out of them. The one in the attached picture is the most prominent of them. Do you know what it is? Is there something I should do about it? Cut the top off? Did up the entire plant? Ignore it?

Thank you very much for your time,
Ben

answer.response:
Hi Ben,

This is a disease called "aster yellows", which is a phytoplasma and is moved plant-to-plant via leafhoppers. Is it recommended that you remove the infected plants, since there is no cure once the plant is infected...and it can spread to healthy plants.

Here's a good publication from the University of Wisconsin: https://hort.extension.wisc.edu/articles/aster-yellows/ and from the U of Minnesota: https://extension.umn.edu/plant-diseases/aster-yellows

title: Citrus leaves wilting and dying  #819723
question: I have a two 10 year old citrus trees (calamondin) grown in a pot from seed. They summer outside and winter inside. They were neglected this year as the temps dropped I forgot them outside and they went through 25 degrees one night. One showed classic frost damage, wilted and dropped green leaves and the second one was barely damaged. Only the newest growth was killed. A few months later the mostly unfrosted one had several leaves that started to change color and dry up randomly across the crown. It appears to be some kind of disease. There is a distinct margin between healthy leaf and desiccated leaf. The discoloration starts at the tip of a leaf and progresses slowly up the leaves. It is only on older leaves. One healthy branch was cut off and placed in a glass of water and the same symptoms started a week later. I'm pretty good with tree diseases but can't find anything like this in citrus in my research. It looks very much like oak wilt but in a citrus tree.

answer.response:
Good afternoon, John,

Sorry to hear about your two citrus trees.  I think we've all been in your shoes at one time or another.

The desiccation I'm seeing in your photos is typical of frost damage. I suspect both your trees were damaged with that cold snap, they are just showing it in different ways.  It can take up to several weeks for frost damage to really manifest itself.  In fact most authorities recommend waiting until new growth shows in the spring before pruning out affected areas.  

From what I've been reading, a citrus tree losing its leaves after a frost is really a good sign sign since it means that while the leaves were killed, the wood is still healthy.  When the leaves don't fall, it can be an indication that the wood itself is dead or dying.  You can check this by rubbing your fingernail gently on the bark.  The underlying pith should be green.  Brown would mean the wood is dead.

Give them both some TLC over the winter and watch for new growth in the spring.  Do Not Overwater!!  With the loss of their leaves they are less able to make use of the water and soggy roots can lead to more problems.

I'm including some articles on frost damage to citrus trees from the University of Florida.  They should know their citrus trees.

https://blogs.ifas.ufl.edu/taylorco/2018/01/26/citrus-freeze-damage-symptoms-and-recovery/

https://blogs.ifas.ufl.edu/stlucieco/2022/01/31/tips-for-recovering-citrus-trees-after-a-freeze/

https://edis.ifas.ufl.edu/publication/HS1275

I hope this helps, John.  Good luck!
answer.author: Bill Kewley

answer.response:
Thanks Bill! 
As a PA forester, I've never dealt with frost damage on an evergreen hardwood. I appreciate the thorough response. All my research focused on disease and nutrient issues I should have known it was a delayed frost damage symptom(never crossed my mind). 
These are my babies, and I hope they both recover. I've read 2/3 of the articles you sent and will adjust my watering.

Thanks again, 

John


Sent from my Verizon, Samsung Galaxy smartphone

answer.response: Wishing you good luck with them, John!

question:
To whom it may concern,

I'm reaching out because I have a slight issue in my yard and not sure how to handle this.

I have a massive Stag beetle infestation in my yard,  it is now the beginning of June and they are out in full force by the thousands, just in my yard and my yard alone.  

My issue is, how do I get rid of them?  I understand there importance to nature but unfortunately it completely interrupts our nights if we want to have people over or hang out around the fire. 

Does grubex work?  I'm not sure who to reach out, I've talked to pest control they don't even know what a stag beetle is.  

If someone could please help.

Joe Waldoch

1306 131st Ln NE, Blaine, MN 55434

5.response:
Thanks for getting back to us.

Yes, this is most likely a Giant Stag Beetle (Lucanus placidus) though other species would be possibilities.  When I first read your question I thought that maybe you were observing cicadas.  At this time of the year, they emerge as adults from the water.  This is why I asked if you lived near a river or lake.  But clearly, you are not being visited by cicadas.

With respect to the stag beetles, the good news is that they should disappear within the next two weeks.  Right now they are very active in mating.  They prefer to lay eggs in rotting and decaying wood.  If you have such currently on your property, this may be a reason why they are visiting you.  Once that is complete, all the adults will die.  In the meantime, the best thing to do might be just to live with them.  Spraying pesticides about would have a detrimental effect on different pollinators.  GrubEx has no effect on adult beetles.  See the following for further information on these and related points:

http://www.minnesotaseasons.com/Insects/smooth_stag_beetle.html#:~:text=Smooth%20stag%20beetle%20is%20a,seen%20in%20aggregations%20on%20lawns.

https://ptes.org/campaigns/stag-beetles-2/faqs/#:~:text=Are%20stag%20beetles%20dangerous%3F,if%20you%20leave%20them%20alone.

https://www.gardeningknowhow.com/garden-how-to/beneficial/stag-beetles-in-the-garden.htm#:~:text=Stag%20beetle%20habitats%20lean%20towards,out%20near%20your%20porch%20light.

https://apps.extension.umn.edu/garden/diagnose/insect/general-curiosity-insects/beetles/medium/stag-beetle.html
Good luck; thanks for using our forum.

title: What's wrong with my tomato seedlings? #399656
question:
They started out nice and green, but leaves seem dry, yellow and pathetic now. I have them out on the deck and never let the soil dry out. 

I did have them in a closed greenhouse one sunny day - did they get fried? And will they still produce? 

Thanks!

1.response: Yes your plants got sunburned. You have to be very careful when exposing plants to the sun.  It needs to be done in very gradual doses.   You should probably carefully repot them in larger pots with good potting soil.  Let them have only morning sun for a week or so and some new leaves should develop.  Then, as I said, gradually expose them to the sun.  Don't let them bake in a greenhouse.   It is fine for them to be in there evenings and early mornings but the greenhouse either needs to be completely open to air circulation or you need to take them out where the plastic doesn't hold the heat.
1.author: Barbara Harlan

management instructions: Carefully repot them in larger pots with good potting soil.
Let them have only morning sun for a week or so.
Gradually expose them to the sun.

title: are they scales? #555670
question:
found them at one of my customer.

looks like scales to me,  their body are soft.  or maybe i'm wrong.

the tree is newly planted ( 6 months).  found the bug on 2 other trees.

answer.response:
This is calico scale.  Big, isn't it?  

This scale is usually controlled by beneficial insects.  Unless honeydew and sooty mold are a problem, no action is needed in light infestations, which seems to be the case here. You can manually scrape these few off the tree now, to ensure they don't spread.

In heavy infestation, you'll have to spray an horticultural oil with a systemic insecticide in April or early May.  
Refer to "Managing Insects and Mites on Wood Plants: an IPM Approach" for further details. 

 Ellen

title: Kentucky Coffee tree with split bark at base of trunk #777649
question: What is causing the splitting of the bark on my 2 year old Kentucky Coffee tree at the base of the trunk?  The bark wound is continuing to spread up the trunk.  The tree is located on the north side of a backyard in NW Denver and gets plenty of moisture. Is there anything to do to heal the bark wound and stop the bark from continuing to split?  Is it likely that the tree will die?  It has been healthy beside the bark splitting. Thanks

answer.response:
If that wound is on the south or southwest side of the tree, it was most likely caused by winter weather conditions. Winter sunlight is intense a mile high and when the sun is low in the sky and there is no canopy of leaves to cast shade on the trunk, tree cells get warmed up and become active but then burst when the temperature drop at sundown. It is a common but concerning problem.

My recommendation is clean the wound by cutting off any stray flaps of bark where insect pest could hide behind and try to create clean margins. Then wrap the trunk with tree wrap from Thanksgiving through Tax Day. If the wound has not completely girdled the trunk, the tree with time has the capability of healing itself with wound wood.

I also recommend pulling away any grass or mulch that might be resting up against the trunk which can result in nicks and cuts from lawn mowers and string trimmers. If mulch rests up against the trunk it can create too much dampness against the bark and lead to rot. Just pull it back a few inches: mulch is good for retaining moisture in the soil and roots but not good for the bark.

Here is some additional information:

https://source.colostate.edu/prepare-trees-winter/

https://extension.colostate.edu/topic-areas/yard-garden/environmental-disorders-of-woody-plants-2-932/
answer.author: Denver Master Gardeners

symptom description: splitting of the bark at the base of the trunk
bark wound continuing to spread up the trunk
management instructions: Clean the wound by cutting off any stray flaps of bark.
Wrap the trunk with tree wrap from late fall to early spring.
Pull away any grass or mulch that might be resting up against the trunk.
qa_information.background info: The tree is 2 years old, located on the north side of a backyard in NW Denver, and gets plenty of moisture. The tree has been healthy beside the bark splitting.

title: Boxwood Winter Damage #743642
question: Hi, some winter damage has just become apparent on my boxwood bushes. When I prune away the dead foliage, will the bush fill in again? And is there anything I can do next winter to prevent more damage? Thanks!

answer.response:
Your boxwoods should fill in nicely following pruning. Early spring, before they begin to flush, is the right time. 

You may wish to fertilize your boxwoods lightly and water it in well.  Provide a light application of mulch around the root base of the plant to help conserve moisture and impede competitive
weeds. Moisture retention will help reduce winter dessication. While generally not necessary, you can protect your boxwoods from winter burn by covering them with burlap next winter.
answer.author: Sharon Globig

answer.response:
Thank you so much! I appreciate the advice.

Cover with burlap next winter to protect from winter burn.

title: Sick looking Bay Laurel #631361
question: I’m wondering what I can do to help my Bay Laurel survive. I planted it a couple years ago. It gets regular watering through drip irrigation and I have added compost to it multiple times. It’s close to my chicken coop so it gets kinda dusty, but there are other plants by coop that do just fine. Anything I should be doing differently? Thank you!

1.response: Bay laurel (Laurus nobilis) is generally grown in our area as a small plant or tree in a container.. While it is a Mediterranean native, it is not hardy below 20 degrees. Many winters we do not reach temperatures that low, but certain areas of the county do experience lower temperatures on occasion. Obviously, a container plant can more easily be protected or brought inside when the threat of cold is present. Bay laurels thrive on moderate water. Your drip system may be giving the plant too much water and that is the reason for the brown tips on most leaves. But the major problem is the insect infestation on the stems and some of the leaves. Thank you for the photo, but it is not detailed enough to identify the white critters on the stems as whitefly or scale, both of which can sap the energy of the plant, eventually killing it.Scale is one of the most common enemies of bay laurel.. A horticultural oil spray or two will take care of the critters and not compromise the edibility of the leaves. It was not clear whether the leaves were dusty or affected by powdery mildew. You might want to hose off the plant to remove the "dust" and if it doesn't clean up, you probably need to  check it for  mildew.  Powdery mildew is common in the semi- humid temperatures such as our typical spring  weather, It can be treated with neem oil, horticultural oil, or copper soap fungicide. Given all these indications of the  bad health of the plant, you might be better off replacing the plant with a container specimen...
1.author: Marjorie Neal

management instructions: reduce watering
use horticultural oil spray to control infestation
hose off the plant to remove dust
treat powdery mildew with neem oil, horticultural oil, or copper soap fungicide

The image shows a bay laurel plant with some leaves that appear to be browning or dying. This could indicate several issues, such as overwatering, nutrient deficiencies, or pest infestation. Given the location and care history of the plant:

1. **Overwatering**: Since the plant is receiving regular drip irrigation, it's possible that there may be overwatering issues. Overwatering can lead to root rot and nutrient deficiencies as the soil becomes too saturated. Ensure the soil is well-draining; if it’s not, consider amending the soil with organic matter like compost to improve drainage.

2. **Nutrient Deficiency**: Despite adding compost, there might still be a lack of certain nutrients. Check for signs of nutrient deficiency such as yellowing of older leaves (which might indicate iron deficiency) or chlorosis. You can test the soil for nutrient levels using a soil test kit.

3. **Pest Infestation**: The presence of pests can also cause leaf damage. Common pests that affect bay laurels include spider mites, aphids, and scale insects. Look closely at the leaves and stems for signs of pests and their eggs. If pests are present, you may need to use an appropriate insecticide.

4. **Disease**: Diseases such as fungal leaf spot or blight can cause leaf discoloration. Inspect the leaves for signs of spots, mold, or other unusual growths. Treatments for these diseases often involve fungicides, but first ensure proper identification.

**Management Strategy:**

1. **Adjust Watering Schedule**: Reduce the frequency and duration of irrigation to prevent overwatering. Monitor the soil moisture levels regularly to ensure they are neither too dry nor waterlogged.

2. **Soil Test and Fertilization**: Test the soil to check for nutrient deficiencies. Based on the results, apply appropriate fertilizers to replenish any missing nutrients. Consider using a balanced fertilizer formulated for evergreen plants.

3. **Monitor for Pests**: Regularly inspect the plant for signs of pests. If pests are identified, treat them promptly. Use organic pesticides or insecticidal soaps if necessary.

4. **Fungal Treatment**: If disease is suspected, apply a fungicide specifically designed for use on bay laurels. Follow the instructions carefully.

5. **Mulch**: Apply a layer of mulch around the base of the plant to help retain moisture and suppress weeds, which can compete for nutrients.

6. **Pruning**: Remove any dead or diseased branches to promote healthy

title: What is wrong with my agave? #287624
question: It has developed yellow and Brown leaves, especially toward the bottom. Any info appreciated

1.response: From what I can see, it looks like the growing media is very wet. Agave is a desert plant and prefers a well drained soil that does not stay that wet. The easiest thing to try is to trim off the dead leaves, put the plant in a sunny window, and do not water again until the potting mix is almost dry. Then only water lightly again whenever the potting mix is almost dry. The second and better option is to repot the plant into a cactus or succulent houseplant potting mix and treat as described in option one. If the roots are still healthy, one of these approaches may help save the plant.
1.author: Jeanine Davis

2.response: Thank you!
2.author: The Question Asker

3.response: You are welcome.

title: Holes in plants #654061
question:
I have a number of plants this season that are riddled with holes, but am finding no insects, caterpillars/droppings, slug trails, or any other clues of what is causing the damage so I can treat accordingly.

I have attached photos of some affected plants. Any identification and advice would be appreciated.

Thanks.
Pam

answer.response:
Thank you for the images.
The shredded appearance of the damage strongly suggests slugs and/or snails. Both are certainly thriving during our recent wet weather.
You're most likely to find them if you go outdoors at 10 pm or so. Take a flashlight and be certain to check the undersides of leaves. When you find one or more of the culprits, drop them into soapy water. (If you're squeamish, use tongs or wear gloves.)
"Snails and Slugs" has a good description of their damage and describes a number of non-chemical management methods - http://ipm.ucanr.edu/PMG/PESTNOTES/pn7427.html.
answer.author: Jean R. Natter

answer.response: I've dealt with a lot of slugs in my 35 years of gardening, and I've never seen slug damage look like this before. There is no slime trail. Some of the holes are appearing up high on a vining plant, with no damage on lower portions of the same plant. I understand that slug/snail damage is worse than normal with the weather we've had, but if this is slug damage, these are the most creative and industrious slugs I've ever tangled with. :-)
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response:
Thank you for the update.
Not all slugs leave an obvious slime trail. Also, frequent rainfall and/or showers can wash off exposed slime
Slugs can, and do, climb. When you think about it, the freshest, most tender leaves are available higher on most plants. In my previous garden I'd occasionally find one curled up at the tip of a delphinium flower stem. The growing point of the stem was gone.
Keep looking at night. Sooner or later you'll find the culprits, who ever they are. If not slugs or snails, write back so that we can discuss their management.
answer.author: Jean R. Natter

management instructions: check for slugs/snails at night with a flashlight
drop them into soapy water
use tongs or wear gloves

title: Tree Leafing Issue #830557
question:
I have a pin oak (~10 years old) in my yard that had issues with growing leaves on part of the tree last year. That portion of the tree started growing leaves and they never matured - they stayed a light green color. 
This year that portion of the tree does not seam to have leaves growing. I would like to diagnose what is wrong with the tree and try to save it. I have included some pictures of the tree overall and of the bark that appears to have something growing on it.

answer.response:
The question i have is leaf color. Oak trees tend to get chlorosis where the leaves do not green up and tend to have light yellow. Do your leaves have that now? Oak trees tend to have that problem as the soil ties up the nutrients of magnesium and iron. Do the leave have a green vein? The bark pictures seem to be ok. You say one side of the tree did not recover. Another killer of oak trees is oak wilt. There is little chance of recovery if that is the problem. This can be caused by pruning when the tree is not dormant.
I have had a pin oak where i had chlorosis and i tried treating the tree. It did not work. The tree will grow but will lose branches and has a slow death. May i suggest you contact your local ohio state extension office. Before i sign of let me know if your leaves have the green vein and yellow leaves. Thanks.
answer.author: winfield sturgeon-mgv

answer.response:
Thanks for your reply! If anything the leaves have a brown tint to them. 

Paul

On May 17, 2023, at 2:24 PM, Ask Extension <ask@extension.org> wrote:

﻿
answer.author: The Question Asker

answer.response: looks like you have chlorosis Pin oaks are famous for this. Its tough to cure this problem. I have had it and tried many cures. Your soil is to alkaline. You need acid soil so try a sulfur based fertilizer. I tried the pellets in the bark but did not work for me or my neighbors. You need to get the compost and fertilizer in the top 2 inches of the soil. It will take time and remember to fertilize the root zone which is where the branches extend.
answer.author: winfield sturgeon-mgv

title: Bugs all over the under side of the leaves of my cucumber plants!! #574503
question:
Hello, I probably should have noticed this problem starting before it got this bad, but I've been so busy!! I've got what looks like a variety of different bugs in the under side of the leaves of my cucumber plants!! I need to know what they are so I can treat them accordingly. 
PLEASE HELP!!
Thank you, 
Jennifer H.

answer.response:
Hello Jennifer,

You have aphids on the undersides of your cucumber leaves.  The black ones are live and the tan ones are parasitized.  There is also white debris scattered around.  Hosing off the undersides of the leaves with a strong stream of water should get rid of them.  This article from OSU has additional information and pictures of cucumber aphids, Cucumber-Aphid  https://pnwhandbooks.org/insect/vegetable/vegetable-pests/hosts-pests/cucumber-aphid
answer.author: Anne Schmidt

title: All my hops are ill and dying. #473207
question: I have three different fence hops, different plants, not in the same place along the fence, cascade, centennial, chinook. Plants are established for 3 seasons and good yield and healthy plants all three years. This year had huge aphid infestation and not enough ladybugs. They cleared out a month ago but plants are now all yellowing and dying. Included two photos. Do not see any insects on the plants now. Is this a result of previous aphids or something else? Can you help me with a diagnosis? Will be cutting all back to the bases as do not expect any hops and all the current hops are diseased. The soil base vines of the plants look good. Thank you.

answer.response: Thank you for your question.  It would appear that your plants have an iron deficiency, which causes chlorosis (yellowing) between the veins of the leaves (interveinal chlorosis).  Here is an Extension article describing the condition.  Changing the soil to prevent this is possible, but first you should get a soil test to measure pH and nutrient content.  Here is a link to testing procedures and testing facilities.  I am only aquainted with A & L Agricultural Laboratories, which gives you recommendations for soil additives to cure the problem.  If you get this problem resolved before next year's crop, you should have healthy plants and hops.  Hope this is helpful.  Good luck!
answer.author: Kristena LaMar

symptom description: yellowing between the veins of the leaves
management instructions: Get a soil test to measure pH and nutrient content.
Change the soil to prevent this condition.

title: Possible fungus? #263807
question: Hi, I've got a Monterrey Oak tree we planted in February that over the last month has developed a white powdery film on some of its leaves.  Wondering what it is and how to treat it?

answer.response: The white spots appear to be powdery mildew, or perhaps another fungal pathogen, most likely caused by our extensive spring rain and prolonged cloudy days into the early growing season, when tree were putting out new leaves. The best recommendation is to leave the situation alone. The tree will eventually drop these leaves in the late winter and make new ones in the spring, so the use of fungicide is not recommended, as it would have no effect on resolving the problem. The tree should recover during the next growing season, if weather returns to normal.
answer.author: Daphne Richards

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows leaves with white spots, which could indicate a fungal infection or disease. Given that this tree was planted in February and the issue developed over the last month, it's important to identify the specific cause of the symptoms before applying a management strategy.

Here’s a general approach to managing the issue:

### Identification and Diagnosis
1. **Visual Inspection**: Look closely at the leaves for any signs of disease, such as the type of spots (size, shape, color), presence of mold or fungus, and if there are any visible symptoms on the undersides of the leaves.
2. **Fungal Spores**: If present, collect samples and bring them to a local extension office or plant diagnostic lab for confirmation of the type of fungus involved.
3. **Environmental Factors**: Consider the environmental conditions such as humidity, temperature, and irrigation practices, which can affect fungal growth.

### Management Strategies
If the diagnosis confirms a fungal infection, here are some potential management strategies:

1. **Fungicide Application**: Use a fungicide specifically targeted against the identified fungal species. Follow the label instructions carefully for application rates and frequency.
2. **Pruning**: Remove any severely affected leaves or branches to reduce the spread of the fungus and to improve air circulation around the remaining foliage.
3. **Water Management**: Ensure proper irrigation practices to avoid overwatering or underwatering, which can stress the tree and make it more susceptible to disease.
4. **Fertilization**: Apply a balanced fertilizer to promote overall tree health, but be cautious not to over-fertilize, as excessive nutrients can also stress the tree.
5. **Cultural Practices**: Maintain good cultural practices such as mulching, pruning for air circulation, and monitoring the tree regularly for early detection of new symptoms.

### Monitoring
Regularly monitor the tree for any signs of recovery or new infections. If the infection persists or worsens, consider consulting a professional arborist who can provide more specific advice based on the tree's condition and the identified pathogen.

By following these steps, you can help manage the disease and potentially prevent further damage to the Monterey oak tree.

title: Blue Spruce Die Back  #413032
question:
I am having a problem with two of my Douglas Blue Spruces in my yard.  One is far worse than the other.  

They both are experiencing considerable die back on the inside of the tree and seem to be getting worse each year. 
 
The tips are very lush and green but behind the tips there are no needles, just branches.  

The needles have never turned brown to my knowledge, they just are no longer there.  I have seen this issue on lots of Blue Spruces around Baltimore County and it seems to be an almost universal problem around Baltimore County (although some trees do not appear affected). 

I have also attached a picture of the front yard tree in 2013 and 2017 to show its decline.  The one in my front yard is a magnificent tree and I would hate to lose it.  Both trees are likely

answer.response:
Here is some information. Blue spruce can be susceptible to Cytospora canker and Rhizosphaeria needlecast, fungal diseases. All you can do is keep the trees well watered during dry periods,  make sure mulch is not thicker than several inches and away from the trunk, and Prune plant material during dry weather. No chemical control is recommended. 

Blue spruce, in general, are not really well suited for our area as they are native to climates further to the north. Cytospora canker occurs on trees stressed by drought or other site conditions. http://extension.umd.edu/hgic/cytospora-canker-spruce

Rhizosphaeria needle cast disease. The infection period is long - spring through midsummer. The needles are affected in the fall and needle drop occurs in the spring. Pruning out severely infected branches is the best control method on branches that show sparse growth. Spraying large trees with fungicides can be complicated - getting good coverage, timing, etc. and not recommended. For more information see the link on our website http://extension.umd.edu/hgic/evergreen-needle-cast-diseases-trees-and-shrubs

For an onsite diagnosis regarding the health of your trees contact several certified arborists for the best way to proceed http://www.treesaregood.org/
mh
answer.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

answer.response:
Thank you for this great information.  I believe that my trees are suffering from the Cytospora canker.  

It is sad to see that there is nothing I can to prevent other than water them during drought.  I will take steps to prune aggressively in the fall and have a nice bonfire.
answer.author: The Question Asker

title: Verticillium Wilt? #791843
question:
Hi! Thanks for this service. I read your writeup on Japanese Maples and Verticillium Wilt seems like is not common. I too have that as my #1 fear.  Here are pictures. The tree is on the north side of the home, afternoon sun.   It has been thriving for 25 years + and then bang! last year, we see this crazy die back. I read for causes and applied a general anti-fungal along with bone meal for root health.  This year it started off really well (no die back) and then turned to what you see on these pics.  I did a Ph test and the readings are ni 6.5-6.8 range.  I put down Ammonium Sulfate 21-0-0 fertilzer at what I think was suggested rate (3 lbs per 100sq). 
1. Is there a definitive test?
2. Seems like I should start pruning the affected branches.

Thanks for any help and advice. This tree is like a part of the family!  

Regards, 
Mark

answer.response:
Hi Mark!

What a beautiful tree! We think this looks like leaf scorch from cold damage, which is very common and will not cause any permanent damage.  The injury occurs on dry, windy, warm, or sunny winter days when the ground is frozen. Plants are unable to move water from frozen soil to replace water lost from the leaves. You don't need to prune out the damage as it will be covered by new growth in time.

If you want to read more about winter damage in the landscape, we have a great page here: https://extension.umd.edu/resource/winter-damage-landscape-plants

Jamie
answer.author: Jamie Wiesner

management instructions: No pruning is needed, as the damage will be covered by new growth in time.

title: Box Wood  #740043
question: Noticed that the box wood appears to have an infection and wonder what this is and what are the possible treatment options.

answer.response:
The damaged leaves appear to be symptomatic of Boxwood Leafminer, a common insect pest of boxwood. Fresh mines look a bit different than those that have aged over the winter, but regardless, damaged leaves will not heal; if this is an active infestation and not solely old damage, adult gnats will emerge later this spring. Plants that recover well will shed both their oldest and their most damaged leaves during the period of new growth later in spring, so expect that on a shrub this heavily impacted, it may be more dramatic than normal.

Here is our page on this pest, with information regarding control options: https://extension.umd.edu/hgic/boxwood-leafminer-shrubs  Some cultivars of Boxwood have greater resistance (none are immune) to this pest than others; if you opt for replacement and decide on another boxwood, look for those with both this benefit as well as high-rated disease resistance. This insect is not known to be problematic on any other garden plants.

Miri
answer.author: Mira Talabac

title: Noxious Grasses  #800423
question: The lawn at our church in Champlin, MN has a fast growing, thick, shiny leave plant that started last year & is spreading very rapidly. It is not quack or crab grass. I need help identifying this grass & if there is a herbicide that will destroy it. Thank you for your help.

answer.response:
Thank you for your question.

After consulting with various sources, this seems to be Purple Nutsedge (Cyperus rotundus). It is a perennial grass that can rapidly spread. It seems as if you are already observing this. It is not clear to me how you and your church were blessed with this invader. Other than killing everything off, the best advice is to dig it all up NOW before it goes to seed and spreads. Alternatively, you and your church can just live with it for years to come. There is no herbicide that will just kill this and leave the rest of your grass intact. See:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyperus_rotundus

https://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/17506

https://eorganic.org/node/5131

https://plants.ces.ncsu.edu/plants/cyperus-rotundus/

Good Luck!!
answer.author: Steve Hedman

management instructions: dig it all up NOW before it goes to seed and spreads

title: Honey Crisp blemish #851839
question: I have a single honey crisp tree with this blemish on the surface. Can you tell me what it is and how to prevent it for next year?

1.response:
Adding additional information provided by Melvyn:

My single honey crisp apple tree has a blemish (blight). It is unsightly, but I am told still eatable. I give several bushes to local food shelf, but it appearance would turn people off. How can a clean it? Just rubbing doesn't get it all. Is there a way to clean it more easily, like a low percentage bleach. I sent an earlier question, but this is a clearer photo. Secondly, how do I prevent it next year? Thank you.
1.author: Debra Heleba

2.response:
Hi Melvyn,

Thank you for your question!  The blemishes on your Honey Crisps are from Sooty blotch and flyspeck.  They are a fungi and are most severe in cool, wet weather. Affecting apple, crabapple, and pear trees, sooty blotch and flyspeck of apple are separate diseases, but both are normally present on the same fruit.

Both fungi overwinter on the twigs of many woody plants as well as apple and pear. The diseases are spread by these overwintering hosts. Spores of the fungi are windblown into and throughout the orchard; fruit infection can occur any time after petal fall but is most prevalent in mid- to late summer. These diseases usually appear on fruit late in the season.

As stated in the attached articles, spraying fungicide and by removing brambles (like wild raspberry canes) can help prevent this.  The disease are mainly superficial and rarely affect the quality of the fruit.  Bleach is not recommended as that is toxic to humans.  Removal of the fungus by washing, rubbing, or peeling the fruit results in fruit that is acceptable for cooking or eating fresh.

Make sure your apple trees have plenty of air circulation and good drainage.  

I hope this helps.  

Apple Diseases - Sooty Blotch and Flyspeck (psu.edu)

Sooty Blotch and Flyspeck | New England Tree Fruit Management Guide (netreefruit.org)

Sooty Blotch and Fly Speck of Apple | Ohioline (osu.edu)
2.author: Patricia A New

management instructions: spraying fungicide
removing brambles (like wild raspberry canes)
Removal of the fungus by washing, rubbing, or peeling the fruit
Make sure your apple trees have plenty of air circulation and good drainage.

title: Are these European Hornets? #846773
question: Hello, these large hornet-looking creatures have been flying into my house at night - they seem so huge for European Hornets, so I wanted to make sure that's all they are. I'm sorry he or she is a bit dusty in the picture - I used the vacuum cleaner to catch it because I was scared. Thank you.

answer.response:
Yes, these are a European Hornets, a non-native wasp that has been in the U.S. for over a century and which is commonly encountered in late summer because colonies have become almost as large as they're going to get for the year. Workers hunt for other insects to bring back to the nest, so they can frequent flowering plants and will also visit porch lights at night to pluck off prey like moths attracted to the light. This is one of the only wasps that flies at night as well as during the day, so if you use outdoor lighting, consider turning it off if it's attracting too many of these hornets. Like many bees and wasps, they might accidentally bump into window glass due to the reflection, or bump into window screens, maybe if they miss catching another flying insect they were pursuing.

Despite their intimidating size, these hornets tend not to bother people unless they feel threatened, like someone approaching a nest too closely (especially if there are loud vibrations, such as thumping a tree they're nesting in or using a lawn mower near a nest) or trying to swat or catch an adult out foraging. These wasps might be drawn to certain plants if sap-sucking insects are feeding heavily (they consume droplets of sugar-water produced by those insects) or if they find the bark appealing, since they will chew off a bit of it to use to make the paper-like lining of their nest. Fortunately, the bark-chewing damage on branches of lilac or other shrubs is not serious.

Nests are not re-used from year to year, so once we enter late autumn and winter, frosty nights will end nest activity and kill any workers left.

Miri
answer.author: Mira Talabac

avoid approaching nest too closely
avoid swatting or catching an adult out foraging

We know that is disappointing and looks concerning.

You don't need to pull the plants out.


Christine

title: Velvetleaf? #811600
question:
Hi, I'm attaching pictures to help identify this random plant that popped up in my yard over the past month or so. It looks suspiciously like Velvetleaf.

According to your website, it says that OSU would like to know of report instances of this weed, if indeed it is Velvetleaf. 
Can you advise me on the best way to dispose of this. I won't put it in the recycle. Should I burn it to prevent further seed spread from the landfill?

I live in an established 20+ year old neighborhood in Redmond, OR.  I have never had this plant in my yard before. 
Any advise would be great,
Thank you,
B H

answer.response:
Hi B H:

Yes this is Velvetweed.  It is invasive.  As this is your first occurrence, control may not be as difficult as it could be.

For now, as they seem pretty well developed, hand pull and dispose of in plastic bags that will go to landfill.  You do not want any chance of them ending up in compost.  Burning will not kill the seeds necessarily.  I know it seems wasteful, but hopefully only temporary.

If they return, you can handweed or torch them when small.  You may also use herbicide, if that's acceptable to you.  The main idea is to destroy them before they have a chance to go to seed and spread.

I'm going to attach a couple of bulletins that will go into more detail and answer any other questions you may have.

Velvetleaf General information

General Methods of Weed Management

Herbicide Treatments for Velvetleaf

If you do use herbicides, please follow all safety instructions and wear protective clothing.

Thank you for your question,
answer.author: Cristi Jones

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The plant in the image appears to be velvetleaf (Abutilon theophrasti), which is an invasive species that can become problematic in gardens and natural areas. Velvetleaf is known for its rapid growth and ability to outcompete native plants.

### Management Strategies for Velvetleaf:

1. **Manual Removal**:
   - **Early Detection**: Manual removal of velvetleaf seedlings and small plants is most effective when they are still young and have not yet set seeds. Use gloves to protect your hands from the sticky sap.
   - **Digging**: Carefully dig up the plant roots and dispose of them properly, ensuring you remove all parts of the plant, including any underground stems or rhizomes.
   - **Frequent Monitoring**: Since velvetleaf can re-sprout from fragments left behind, regular monitoring and follow-up digging may be necessary.

2. **Chemical Control**:
   - **Herbicides**: Apply selective herbicides like glyphosate (Roundup) or systemic herbicides such as triclopyr (e.g., Garlon) directly to the leaves or stems of the plant. Follow the instructions on the label carefully, as these chemicals can harm other plants if not used correctly.
   - **Preventive Measures**: Treat the soil around the plants with non-selective herbicides to prevent new plants from sprouting. This method should be used cautiously and only after removing visible plants.

3. **Cultural Practices**:
   - **Mulching**: Regularly mulching the area where the plant was found can help prevent the spread of seeds. Mulch can also suppress the germination of new seeds by blocking light.
   - **Healthy Native Plants**: Encourage the growth of healthy, native plants that can compete with the invasive velvetleaf for resources. Native plants often have deeper root systems that can outcompete the invasive species.

4. **Biological Control**:
   - **Natural Enemies**: Research and consider introducing natural enemies of velvetleaf into your garden. For example, certain insects can feed on the plant and reduce its population.

5. **Community Efforts**:
   - **Neighborhood Cooperation**: If the velvetleaf spreads to neighboring yards, consider organizing a community effort to manage the problem collectively.

### Important Considerations:
- **Environmental Impact**: Be cautious with chemical treatments as they can affect beneficial organisms and local ecosystems.
- **Legal Compliance**: Check local regulations regarding the use of herbicides and the management of invasive species in your area.
- **Sustainability**: Opt

title: poa triv #759882
question: i have poa triv in 60% of my yard.  most of it is in large parches while some is just in spots.  its dormant now obviously.  how do i attack this?  i have read elsewhere that the only way to kill it is round up and start over.  is this true?  more importantly, if its true, does it have to be done in the spring when its active or can it be done in july/aug so i can re-sod in september?  the last thing i want to do is think i've killed it and it comes back in the spring in the new sod.  if there is a treatment plan shy of round up please explain.  have attached pic from one area.

1.response:
Our turf weed specialist has found that the best, long lasting control is to use a non-selective herbicide such as glyphosate to control the Roughstalk Bluegrass.  Thanks for your picture, you should still be able to control it now based on your picture. 
In this video (;list=PLN87bd8W1ymnbFHsul-Wa3uBZPhHTGqAp&index=5), our turf weed specialist demonstrates the glove method in applying herbicide.  This can help reduce the damage to the tall fescue.  You can do patches between now and fall and then aerate and overseed.
Next spring, you would want to be on the lookout for any Roughstalk bluegrass that germinated and treat at that time before it makes too large of a clump.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows a lawn with Poa triv (roughstalk bluegrass) dominating the landscape, as indicated by the background information. The grass appears to be in large patches and some isolated spots, and it is described as being dormant at the time of the photo.

Given these observations, here's a recommended management strategy:

### Immediate Actions:
1. **Evaluate Dormancy**: Since the grass is described as dormant, the immediate priority should be to determine whether there are underlying issues causing dormancy. This could include soil compaction, improper watering, or nutrient deficiencies. If the dormancy is due to environmental factors such as drought, the lawn might recover once conditions improve.

2. **Watering Management**: Assess the current watering schedule. If the lawn is dry, consider increasing the frequency and duration of watering sessions until the grass becomes more active. However, be cautious not to overwater, which can lead to root rot and other issues.

3. **Soil Analysis**: Conduct a soil test to check the pH level, nutrient content, and overall health of the soil. This will help identify if there are any deficiencies that need addressing, such as nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, or other essential nutrients.

### Long-term Strategies:
1. **Fertilization**: Once the soil analysis is complete, apply appropriate fertilizers to address any deficiencies identified. Choose a fertilizer that is balanced and suitable for cool-season grasses like Poa triv.

2. **Aeration**: If the lawn is compacted, aerating the soil can help improve air and water penetration into the roots, promoting healthier growth.

3. **Dethatching**: Remove thatch buildup from the lawn, as thick thatch layers can restrict air and water movement and hinder nutrient absorption. This step is crucial for maintaining healthy grass growth.

4. **Seeding Mix**: Consider overseeding with a mix that includes varieties of turfgrass better adapted to the local climate and conditions. This can help reduce the dominance of Poa triv and potentially improve overall lawn quality.

5. **Mulching**: Apply a layer of organic mulch around established plants to retain moisture, suppress weeds, and improve soil structure.

By addressing the immediate needs and implementing long-term strategies, you can help promote the recovery and improvement of your lawn, making it more resilient and aesthetically pleasing.

title: Residential lawn dying #273179
question:
Hi,
I hope you can help.  My lawn seems to be dying.  It was a small spot and now is growing.
Can you help me? I could send a picture.
Thank you 
Sharon Evans

answer.response:
There could multiple causes of the lawn deterioration.  Typically, at this time of the year, lawns are subject to damage from grubs and  chinch bugs.  Since there are so many possibilities I have included the following link that lists the many possible problems and how to diagnose the cause.   http://plantscience.psu.edu/research/centers/turf/extension/factsheets/diagnosing-problems#Insects

Based on the photos you included I would guess chinch bugs are the problem.  If you have seen small moth like bugs flying out of your grass as you mow it increases the probability that chinch bugs are the problem.

The above link will provide some direction to diagnosing and treating the problem.  Many of these problems can be overcome with overseeing and fertilizing in the fall to establish a better turf base along with preventive measures that are most effective when performed (usually in the Spring or early summer) before the damage is apparent.
answer.author: Richard Bentz

preventive measures in the Spring or early summer

title: Tree Ambrosia Beatles verses Fungus verses other #773406
question: Tree stump recently carved and still attached to ground/roots. I have white growths coming off the base off carving and the roots that are above ground.  The growths easily fall off.

answer.response:
Hello,

What an amazing carving! Well done. 

The white toothpicks are the work of the ambrosia beetle. You can spray the stump next year to prevent further infestation. Spraying is best when done in the flying stage, which is May - June. You can create a trap to help with timing; when you see beetles in the trap, it's time to spray. This article describes the process in detail:

https://content.ces.ncsu.edu/granulate-asian-ambrosia-beetle-1

If you have questions after reading the article, please feel free to reach out. 

Thank you,

Julie

title: Help for my trees  #737769
question: Something is killing my fruit trees. It appears to be stink bugs. They have resided in them for at least four years. The fruit still bares but they all have holes and the branches themselves are black and cracked looking.

answer.response:
Hi there.  Your tree appear to be on the older side and have a lot of lichens, which won't harm the tree but may indicate that the tree is not thriving.   How many hours of sunlight do the trees get?  Are they being shaded by other trees in the area?   Fruit trees generally need at least 8 hours of direct sunlight to thrive. 

It also looks like there are several dead branches on the tree.  It would be of great benefit to the trees health to prune out the dead branches and help let in more light and air. You can find more guidance on pruning here.  It looks like there has been some physical damage to some of the limbs, which has resulted in the cracking.  If there has been no physical damage, then it is possible that it could be suffering from some type of canker disease.  

As for the insect pictured, it appears to be a leaf-footed bug (similar to a stink bug) that does cause the same type of damage as stink bug, with their peircing sucking mouthparts.  They will damage your fruit, but will not kill the tree. This type of insect is hard to control, even with insecticide.  You could hand pick the ones that you see and also look for their egg masses to destroy.

Good luck.
answer.author: Ashley Bachtel-Bodkins

management instructions: prune out dead branches
hand pick the insects
destroy egg masses
qa_information.background info: the trees are at least four years old and still bear fruit

title: What caused this on my lawn? #616243
question: As most of my mature maples are gone I use straw to cover my tulip beds over winter. Went to look at the straw and found this weird ‘crop circle’ impression. No planters, furniture or anything was on this spot to cause the indentation. I did not poke at it to see if it was firm or squishy. To the best of my knowledge there is nothing there to cause this: no rotting tree roots, no pipes or underground utilities. The photo shows my boots to get an idea of size. The straw is around the base of w flagpole. The pole is set in a cement pad. Pole was erected in mid-1960s.

1.response:
Thank you for writing.
This appears to be a patch fungus disorder. https://apps.extension.umn.edu/garden/diagnose/plant/turf/circular.html
This is the right season for it.
Although many sites suggest fertilizer and fungicides, it would be helpful to improve the turf with core aeration. https://extension.umn.edu/lawncare/how-control-thatch-your-lawn
Also, the depth of roots is correlated with the height of the grass.  Deeper roots make for healthier soil (that is more disease resistant),  set your mower to 3.5 inches--as high as it will go.  https://extension.umn.edu/lawns-and-landscapes/lawn-care
You could get a soil test but it is safe to assume that nitrogen does not need fixing.  A soil test would tell you about pH and about the percent of organic matter.  Organic matter could be improved by letting the roots grow deeper  PH is readily fixable. http://soiltest.cfans.umn.edu/
The odds of extraterrestial causes are very low although you could sell tickets anyway.  Best to you.
1.author: Steve Miles

symptom description: crop circle impression in the lawn
management instructions: Improve the turf with core aeration.
Set the mower to 3.5 inches to promote deeper roots and healthier soil.
qa_information.background info: The lawn had straw covering tulip beds over winter, and there are no known underground utilities or rotting tree roots in the area.

The image shows a patch of grass with a noticeable discoloration and dryness, which appears to be concentrated around the edges of what might be a flower bed or garden bed that was covered with straw over winter. Given that the straw was used to protect tulip beds, it's likely that the straw is still present under the grass. Here’s a recommended management strategy:

1. **Remove Straw**: Carefully remove the straw from the area where it is causing the discoloration. Ensure that you do not damage the grass roots while lifting the straw. This can be done using a rake or similar tool.

2. **Watering**: Once the straw is removed, water the affected areas thoroughly to encourage new growth. Watering deeply but less frequently will help establish healthy roots in the grass.

3. **Aeration**: If the grass looks thin or weak, consider aerating the soil. This can be done using a lawn aerator to improve soil structure and promote better root development.

4. **Fertilization**: Apply a balanced fertilizer after the lawn has recovered from the stress of removing the straw and watering. This will provide nutrients essential for the grass to grow strong and healthy.

5. **Mowing**: Once the grass has recovered, mow the area at the appropriate height for your type of grass. Keeping the grass at a proper length can help it recover faster and reduce the risk of diseases.

6. **Monitor**: Keep an eye on the grass for signs of further stress or disease. If the condition persists, consult with a local landscaper or horticulturist for additional advice.

This approach should help address the issue of the grass looking unhealthy due to the straw cover. It is important to handle the straw carefully to avoid damaging the grass and to ensure that the grass has ample time to recover before any additional treatments are applied.

title: White fuzzy growth on cherry laurel #834676
question:
Hi,

What is this white growth on our cherry laurel tree?  Can it be treated?

Thanks!

answer.response:
Hi Andrea,

Your cherry laurel is afflicted with a type of small insect called a scale-- in this case prunicola scale which is a non-native pest with a waxy covering. Some scale (there a many types) have a softer cover which lets beneficial insects that hunt scale to get at them and also allows insecticidal sprays to be effective.  Prunicola scale has an extra cover making it more difficult to manage. Be aware it can take a year or so to get control.   The best timing of insecticides is when the eggs beneath the female scales hatch into "crawlers" which lack the defenses of the adult. 

Woody plants under stress--like drought--may be more susceptible to infestation so you will want to help build up the plant defenses by keeping it hydrated.

In bad infestations, horticultural oil sprays applied with thorough coverage while the crawlers are active is recommended and will need to be repeated with each period of crawler emergence from now into September. It may also require a systemic/oil combination applied according to directions with an eye to temperature

Here is our much more detailed resource material on this particular pest:

https://extension.umd.edu/resource/white-prunicola-scale

https://extension.umd.edu/resource/pesticide-profile-horticultural-oil
answer.author: Sue Christensen

management instructions: keep plant hydrated
apply horticultural oil sprays with thorough coverage while crawlers are active
repeat oil sprays with each period of crawler emergence
consider systemic/oil combination applied according to directions

title: I have tiny green (looks ... #244686
question: I have tiny green (looks like caterpillars) with black strips horizontally down their back climbing all over my porch.

1.response:
The larvae in the photo looks like the euonymus leaf notcher, a pest of euonymus shrubs. See our website for photos and more information. https://www.extension.umd.edu/hgic/invasives/euonymus-leaf-notcher

At this point, the larvae have probably finished feeding and are walking around looking for a place to pupate. You can sweep them up and drop into a bucket of soapy water. If you have euonymus shrubs, look for damage (notching and shredded leaves). Although the shrubs may exhibit severe feeding damage, they typically recover by mid-summer and re-foliate. No control is necessary. In mid-summer and fall, you could monitor the affected shrubs for egg masses on the twigs and prune them out. Keep the shrubs well watered during dry periods.

Next season - Eggs hatch in mid-March into early April. The damage can be recognized as notching along the leaf margins and shredded leaves. Small infestations can be removed by hand or pruned out of the shrub. Bt var.kurstaki can be used soon after the caterpillars have hatched from the eggs. It is only effective on small caterpillars. Bt can be found in farm supply stores or in a garden or nursery center. There are many different manufacturers.

mh

title: Meyer Lemon Tree Leaf Problems #456802
question: Hello. I have a 4 yo meyer lemon tree with leaves that are on the wilting side and light green. On closer examination, the leaves actually have tiny yellow flecs throughout.  At first I thought the leaves were dusty but the flecs are embedded in the leaves themselves.  Any advice you could give would be greatly appreciated.

answer.response:
Thank you for contacting AaE for help.

It looks like damage from a sucking insect like spider mites. If you tap an affected leaf over a sheet of white paper held underneath and see little dots land on the paper, they're spider mites.  They'll probably look like they're moving, too.

Some spider mites form a colony that encases leaves and sometimes entire plants with a fine web.  In dry environments like our homes in winter, they suck the leaves for moisture which results in those dots of dead leaf material you see on the leaves.  Eventually the leaves die. 

Control methods include washing the plant, insecticidal soap, plant oil extract (applied twice 7 to 10 days apart.) You could take the plant outside and carefully spray with water all over and on top and underneath each leaf.  If you use insecticidal soap or plant oil extract, be sure to read and follow all instructions on the label in order to have the best chance for success and for environmental safety.

I hope this information helps.
answer.author: Ellen Campbell

answer.response:
Thank you for the quick response.  I do not see any webs (which is why it threw me off on the culprit) but I did do the paper test and got some black flecks that crawled.  I treated the plant with Neem and will do again in 7 days, hoping it works and the plant turns the corner.   Will let you know in a couple weeks the outcome.

Best regards,
Sharon
answer.author: The Question Asker

title: Blueberries looking a bit rough #812891
question: Was hoping for some thoughts on my blueberry plants. One of them looks fine but two of them have these brown spots. I saw there are a lot of fungus/diseases that cause spots but they don't look like what I've got. Wondering if mine are just underwatered?

1.response:
I can agree with your diagnosis. You are right that there a lot of fungal and bacterial problems on blueberry. But your image does not really show any of them specifically. I see a light brown necrosis mainly between major leaf veins. That can be typical when the roots are unable to keep up with the water demand of the leaves. The stems look fine so it should do well next year.
We do need to be careful about overwatering. Root rot can give you very similar symptoms. Blueberries have a shallow root system and will need less water more often. A lot of water less often is not a good combination. Good luck with your garden.
1.author: Jay Pscheidt

symptom description: light brown necrosis mainly between major leaf veins
management instructions: Water less but more often to accommodate the shallow root system of blueberries.
Be careful not to overwater, as root rot can give similar symptoms.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The image shows blueberry leaves that appear to be affected by leaf blight or another fungal disease, indicated by the brown spots and discoloration on the leaves. Here's a recommended management strategy for dealing with such issues:

### Diagnosis and Confirmation:
1. **Identify the Disease**: Confirm the exact type of disease (e.g., leaf blight) by consulting local agricultural extension services or a plant pathologist. This will guide the appropriate treatments.

### Management Strategies:
2. **Pruning and Removal**:
   - Remove and destroy infected leaves and branches to prevent the spread of the disease. This helps reduce the inoculum in the environment.
   
3. **Fungicide Application**:
   - Apply fungicides as per the recommendations from the diagnostic confirmation. Common fungicides used for blueberry diseases include copper-based sprays, sulfur, and specific fungicides like mancozeb or thiophanate-methyl. Follow the label instructions carefully for application timing and frequency.
   
4. **Water Management**:
   - Ensure proper irrigation practices to avoid waterlogging, which can contribute to fungal growth. Avoid overhead watering and ensure good drainage around the plants.
   
5. **Crop Rotation**:
   - Rotate crops to prevent buildup of pathogens in the soil. Avoid planting blueberries in the same location every year if possible.
   
6. **Soil Health**:
   - Maintain healthy soil through mulching, composting, and regular soil testing to ensure proper nutrient levels and pH balance.
   
7. **Monitoring**:
   - Regularly monitor the plants for signs of new infections and adjust the treatment plan accordingly.

8. **Cultural Practices**:
   - Practice good sanitation and cultural practices such as maintaining adequate air circulation around the plants to reduce humidity and promote healthier growth.

By implementing these strategies, you can help manage the disease effectively and maintain the health of your blueberry plants. Always consult with local agricultural extension services for tailored advice based on your specific conditions and region.

title: Bug Identification #764456
question:
Monroe County Extension submitting question on behalf of resident...
Could you please identify this insect and give suggestions on keeping them far away!
The large one measures about 2 inches

answer.response:
Hello,

Those are wasps known as Cicada Killers.The larger is a female, the smaller one is a male.

These spectacular insects are known scientifically as Sphecius speciosus (Hymenoptera: Sphecidae). They are the largest wasp that occurs in Michigan. They occur in all states east of the Rocky Mountains and prefer to dig their burrows in sandy, bare, well-drained soil exposed to full sunlight. The wasps feed on flower nectar while the immature or larval stages feed cicadas that are provide to them by the female wasp. Like other solitary wasps with no large colony to defend, cicada killers usually ignore people as they go about their business of digging holes and hunting for cicadas. A mound of fine soil surrounds the burrow of each female cicada killer. Since colonies of burrows are common, infested lawns usually contain several mounds that can smother the grass. However, they prefer to nest in areas of sparse vegetation, and rarely infest thick, vigorous turf.

Cicada killers overwinter as larvae in the soil. Pupation occurs in the spring and the adults emerge in mid-June to early July. Emergence continues throughout the summer. Females feed, mate, and dig burrows for several weeks before hunting for cicadas in nearby trees. Excess soil thrown out of the burrow forms a regular, U-shaped mound at the entrance.

The females search tree trunks and lower limbs for cicadas. The wasp stings its prey, turns the victim on its back, straddles it, and drags it or glides with it to the burrow. Each burrow includes several cells where larvae are raised. Each cell is furnished with at least one cicada (sometimes two or three) and a single egg before being sealed off. Female eggs are provisioned with 2 or 3 cicadas while males are only get one. As a result male cicada killers are much smaller than the females. Males establish territories near nesting females and aggressively defend their territory from other intruding males. The eggs hatch in 2-3 days. Depending on the number of cicadas in its cell, the larva feeds for 4 to 10 days until only the cicada's outer shell remains. During the fall, the larva spins a silken case, shrinks, and prepares to overwinter. Only one generation occurs each year.

Despite their large size and impressive stinger, cicada killers do not readily sting and one can stand amongst their burrows and watch them work without fear of being stung as long as one remains considerate and respectful, i.e., don’t try and catch one with their hands. Most people I talk to however seem reluctant to get that close and would rather kill them off. Cultural practices can prevent or eliminate the establishment of cicada killer colonies. Adequate lime and fertilizer applications accompanied by frequent watering to promote a thick growth of turf and can usually eliminate a cicada killer infestation in one or two seasons. For those not willing to tolerate the wasps, treating the nest openings with Sevin (spray or dust) will eliminate the wasps. Be sure to read and follow all instructions and safety precautions found on the label before using any pesticide.

Read more than you will ever care to know about cicada killers at:

http://web.archive.org/web/20141022032916/http://sites.lafayette.edu/hollidac/research/biology-of-cicada-killer-wasps/


Regards,
Howard

The image shows a wasp trapped inside a glass, which appears to have been caught while it was drinking water. Wasps can sometimes be attracted to water sources due to their thirst or to drink water containing nectar from flowers. Here are some general recommendations for managing such an issue:

2. **Containment**: If the wasp is still alive, place it in a container with a lid and release it outdoors where it will not pose a threat. Ensure the container is large enough for the insect to move around comfortably.

3. **Prevent Recurrence**: If the wasp was attracted to water, consider removing any standing water in the area, as this can attract other insects. Regularly check and empty bird baths, pet dishes, and other water containers.

4. **Safe Removal**: If the wasp is dead, dispose of it properly. Avoid handling it directly as it may have stingers that could harm you.

5. **Environmental Management**: Maintain a clean and tidy environment around your home to reduce the attractiveness of your property to insects. Remove food scraps and pet waste promptly, and keep outdoor areas free of clutter.

6. **Professional Help**: If the issue persists, especially if it involves multiple wasps or aggressive species, consider contacting a professional exterminator for assistance.

Remember, the primary goal is to safely remove the insect without causing harm to yourself or others.

title: Cherry Tree vs Deer #804373
question:
This Montmorency cherry tree was 50% damaged by deer. Will it survive or should it be replaced?  How can it be protected from further deer damage? Due to leaf loss, should it be given nutrients and if so, what? The tree is planted in Hillman MI in Montmorency county. 
Thank you for your help.

1.response:
Hello
If bark is stripped off more than 33-50 percent around the trunk, it is best to plant a replacement. 
Do not fertilize a stressed tree. Just keep it watered, especially during dry, hot weather.

Protect all young trees from wildlife damage by excluding them from the plant. Use hardware cloth in a circle around the tree wide enough to encircle the branches and firmly staked down; and while young completely cage it by using chicken wire or hardware cloth across the top of the cage. Or install a deer fence as outlined in the guides below.

Rabbits and voles can also damage trees over winter, so wire mesh  too small for them to squeeze through can be used as a trunk guard, and perforated trunk guards help, too.
Here are some examples-
https://extension.umn.edu/planting-and-growing-guides/white-tailed-deer-damage#fencing-1880561

https://extension.umn.edu/planting-and-growing-guides/protecting-trees-and-shrubs-winter#deer-972413

Here is a guide to growing fruit trees, including fertilizer timing.  https://plantpathology.ca.uky.edu/files/mw_home_fruit_productn_b591.pdf
1.author: Laura Sheffer

management instructions: If bark is stripped off more than 33-50 percent around the trunk, plant a replacement.
Keep the tree watered, especially during dry, hot weather.
Protect the tree from wildlife damage using hardware cloth or chicken wire.
Use a trunk guard to prevent rabbit and vole damage.

qwen2.5-vl-oeq.answer:
The plant in the image appears to be Virginia creeper (Parthenocissus quinquefolia), which is known for its ability to spread through underground runners. The presence of multiple leafy stems and the way they are growing close together suggests it might be forming a dense, ground-hugging mat that could be undesirable if it's not wanted on your property.

Here are some management strategies for controlling Virginia creeper:

1. **Physical Removal**: Dig up the plants manually. Be sure to remove all the roots, as even small pieces can regrow into new plants. This method is labor-intensive but effective for smaller infestations.

2. **Herbicides**: Use selective herbicides designed for broadleaf weeds like Virginia creeper. Apply the herbicide to the foliage when the plant is actively growing. Always follow the label instructions carefully, as some herbicides may harm desirable plants or be harmful to pets and children.

3. **Biological Control**: In some cases, biological controls such as specific insects or fungi can be used to manage Virginia creeper, though these methods are less common and may not be available everywhere.

4. **Preventative Measures**: If you don't want Virginia creeper to spread further, you can cover the soil with a thick layer of mulch or landscape fabric to prevent the runners from reaching the surface and growing new vines.

5. **Cultural Practices**: Regularly mow grass and keep the area free of debris to reduce the likelihood of Virginia creeper taking hold. This practice can help suppress its growth by reducing competition for sunlight and nutrients.

Choose the strategy that best fits your needs and the conditions on your property. It's important to address the issue promptly to prevent the Virginia creeper from spreading and becoming a more difficult problem to control.

title: Identify and rid tiny insects from invading our house! #439927
question:
For the past two months, we have literally been invaded by small flying bugs that we thought were fruit flies.  We have tried everything to get rid of them -- bottles of vinegar and soap; bought houseplant sticky stakes we even bought a bug zapper!  We cleaned all the drains in the house with vinegar and baking soda three times thinking they might be drain flies, but to no avail.  

We have searched our house to find the source, thinking it may have been from a plant that I brought from outside this fall, but can find no trace of the insects from them.

They even show up dead in our refrigerator.  We have wrapped and sealed everything in our refrigerator, including fresh produce, butter, etc.   

I can't prepare meals, no can we eat without them buzzing around us, they appear to be attracted to white light as they are always on my laptop screen and land on white things.  We can't take it any more.  We don't want to call an exterminator to use chemicals, but have looked high and low in our house to try to figure out the source, but to no avail.  Would you please try to identify what these insects are and how we can get rid of them.   We are really desperate!

I was able to collect a lot of these bugs that died in my refrigerator to scan them.  Please see attached.

1.response:
We sent your photos to the entomologist at MD Dept of Agriculture. They were identified as phorid flies, common names -humpbacked or scuttle flies. Most of the species, deposit their eggs in decaying animal or plant material. They live in rotting stuff. Look for rotting food in your refrigerator or outside of refrigerator for old onions, potatoes, etc. Dispose of source. Take drawers out and clean. They may be attracted to the light in the refrigerator. 
Another source may be your sump pump area.  Check for broken septic lines or cracked septic tanks.  Check for plumbing leaks. You may need to consult a plumber.Here is a Penn state's fact sheet for more information ento.psu.edu/extension/factsheets/phorid-flies

mh
1.author: Home and Garden Information Cent University of Maryland Extension

management instructions: dispose of rotting food source
clean refrigerator drawers
check sump pump area for issues
check for broken septic lines or cracked septic tanks
check for plumbing leaks

title: I found this in the garde... #147921
question: I found this in the garden. What kind of caterpillar is this? It looks nasty.

1.response: Your photo is a tobacco or tomato hornworm. Tomato hornworms feed only on solanaceous plants, most often on tomato. However, larvae will also attack eggplant, pepper, and potato. There are many solonaceous weeds that will host this pest. The one in your photo is covered with cocoons of pupating braconid wasps, which are beneficial insects. Larvae that hatch from wasp eggs laid on the hornworm feed on the inside of the hornworm until the wasp is ready to pupate. The hornworm should be left in the garden to conserve the beneficial parasitoids. The wasps will kill the hornworms when they emerge from the cocoons and will seek out other hornworms to parasitize. LW

1.response:
I would need a picture from a different angle  (frontal) to be sure, but I believe it is a trap door spider, Ummidia spp. I agree with your professor that it appears to be in the more primitive group of spiders that includes tarantulas.  However, in North Carolina, we have no tarantulas, but trap door spiders we have.
